fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Richard
fields.trailText: In Hawaii, Oahu (where you land) is very American, expensive and of no real cultural or much scenic interest. We were strongly advised to go to the Big Island and it was brilliant advice. The island is scenically magificent, with huge variety. Go to the place where you can see a volcano pouring molten lava straight into the sea - best done at night!
fields.body:
Milly,

I am a law lecturer at Swansea University so obviously I was interested in the fact that you will be going to Cardiff next year to study law. 10 years ago I spent a year as a lecturer at the National University of Singapore, and later on I can give you some ideas about Singapore and Bali.

For the moment I want to write about Hawaii where we spent 10 days on our way home. When will you be there and for how long?

Oahu, which is where you land and is where Honolulu and Waikiki are, is very American, expensive and of no real cultural or much scenic interest. We were strongly advised to go to the Big Island, the island of Hawaii itself, and it was brilliant advice. The island is scenically magificent, with huge variety, and culturally more interesting than the other islands. Because of its size it is much more laid back.

If you want to go to the Big Island, or have already planned to do so, e-mail be back and I can give you more detailed suggestions. (The best is the place where you can see a volcano pouring molten lava straight into the sea - best done at night!).

In any case, let me know when you will be in Bali and Singapore, though that looks like being some time off.

I don't suppose you want some preliminary reading for next year, do you!

Have fun,

Richard

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Katherine
fields.trailText: The Cook Islands are beautiful; look out for the little man with a banjo at the airport!! Nearly all the accomodation seemed fine and you'll find you have little choice anyway if it's busy - the islanders make sure everyone has somewhere to stay, but it may not be where you want to go, regardless of reservations!
fields.body:
Hi Sam,

First of all - I am sooooo jealous, despite doing a very similar route over the last 14 months.

San Francisco is fantastic - a good hostel is the Green Tortoise (or something like that). Go to China town - food is fantastic - and definitely don't miss a visit to Alcatraz.

The Cook Islands are beautiful; look out for the little man with a banjo at the airport!! Nearly all the accomodation seemed fine and you'll find you have little choice anyway if it's busy - the islanders make sure everyone has somewhere to stay, but it may not be where you want to go, regardless of reservations!

Good luck for the rest of your travels and I hope you have a fantastic time,

Katherine

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Doug Stratton
fields.trailText: Among all the temples strewn throughout Kathmandu, the most wondrous and peaceful that I found was the Golden Temple (Hiranyavarna Mahavihar) in Lalitpur. You will be asked to pay a few rupees for the upkeep of the place, and to entrust your shoes with the little old man at the gate (tip him a few rupees for extra insurance), but it is well worth a stop for an hour or two. And if you're as lucky as I was, you'll be invited to join a wedding party!
fields.body:
Sue,

You won't remember, I expect, but I sent you an email a few days ago recommending the Kathmandu Guest House as a place to stay in Nepal. I was so surprised to find it in print this weekend, that I felt inspired to come back for more!

I'll recommend just one place to visit in Kathmandu though, as I would imagine you already have enough suggestions to fill a year-long visit!

Among all the fantastic temples strewn throughout the city, the most wondrous and peaceful that I found was the Golden Temple (Hiranyavarna Mahavihar) in Lalitpur, an area that's well worth a walk around. You will be asked to pay a few rupees for the upkeep of the place, and to entrust your shoes with the little old man at the gate (tip him a few rupees for extra insurance), but it is well worth a stop for an hour or two. And if you're as lucky as I was, you'll be invited to join a wedding party!

Have a wonderful time, whatever you do. I look forward to reading more of your postings.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Alan
fields.trailText: I don't know whether your route takes you to Varanasi. If it does and if by then you are OK with eating at budget eating places, try the Madhur Milan Cafe near Dasaswamedh Ghat. The food is good and there is usually a guy seated at the front of the cafe cooking. It's a great place to have lunch and watch the busy streetlife carry on in front of you.
fields.body:
Sue,

I don't know whether your route takes you to Varanasi. If it does and if by then you are OK with eating at budget eating places, try the Madhur Milan Cafe near Dasaswamedh Ghat. The food is good and there is usually a guy seated at the front of the cafe cooking. It's a great place to have lunch and watch the busy streetlife carry on in front of you.

The Ghats are amongst the most fascinating places I visited in India. I watched a man splitting logs with great metal wedges at the burning ghat. Just as I was moving on and trying to avoid the streams of muddy water being used to clean a section of the ghat a man in khadi and a purple pullover came past me. In his arms was a small body wrapped in pink. You could see the face through the single layer. Accompanied by an older man (his father?) and another son plus a man from the ghat he made his way along the earth jetty. There he laid the body on the ground where it was then tied to a short plank and placed in a rowboat. The men went out about 50metres into the river and gently tipped the plank off the bow into the river. The boat returned to the jetty and the boatman was paid. The whole process took maybe 20 minutes and was a very dignified and moving episode which took place alongside all the other business as usual activities along the ghat.

You don't need to tear around all the time looking for moving and memorable images from your trip. I found India so different that they were to be found all around me wherever I found myself. (Well, nearly!)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Liz Marx Petrusha
fields.trailText: I hope you will find the time to visit Grand Junction, Colorado, just to the west of the Rockies. In Grand Junction and the surrounding areas, you can ski on the Grand Mesa, hike the Colorado National Monument, a spectacular high desert preserve, explore canyons and see ancient petroglyphs, or visit the Natural History Museum and see many dinosaur bones that have been found on the Colorado Plateau.
fields.body:
Dear Sam,

Glenwood Springs is a beautiful place. You might get a more authentic, and less touristy experience there compared to a larger ski resort town - it depends what you want. I have been there in the summer and found it breathtaking. Aspen is also nice, perhaps more expensive, but less than Vail.

I hope you will find the time to visit Grand Junction, Colorado, just to the west of the Rockies. In Grand Junction and the surrounding areas, you can ski on the Grand Mesa, hike the Colorado National Monument, a spectacular high desert preserve, explore canyons and see ancient petroglyphs, or visit the Natural History Museum and see many dinosaur bones that have been found on the Colorado Plateau.

There is a tour called "The Grand Circle" consisting of at least a dozen national parks and monuments mostly in Colorado, and Utah. (A monument is not necessarily a man-made structure - it can be a parcel of land containing a unique natural landscape set aside for preservation and enjoyment of all).

I am from Wisconsin, USA, however my parents live in Grand Junction, Colorado, and I have travelled and camped extensively in Colorado (west of the Rockies) and Utah.

I hope this information is helpful to you.

Best wishes for happy travels.

webTitle: BBC output goes before external regulator

fields.headline: BBC output goes before external regulator for first time
fields.standfirst: Special report: white paper
fields.trailText:
Tuesday 6.30pm: The BBC's yearly TV and radio output will be subjected to external scrutiny for the first time, writes Jason Deans.
Special report: white paper
Single ITV 'some way off"
Carlton/Granada criticise white paper
What Ofcom will do
fields.body:
The BBC's yearly TV and radio output will be subjected to external scrutiny for the first time.

Under proposals revealed in today's white paper, the corporation will have to submit detailed accounts of how its services have performed to Ofcom, the new regulatory body.

"The BBC board of governors will naturally want to consider observations by Ofcom in drawing up the BBC's annual statement," says the white paper.

ITV and Channel 4 are already subjected to detailed and sometimes painful scrutiny of their output by the Independent Television Commission as part of the well-established annual performance review.

But this will be the first time that the BBC has got to liaise officially with an outside regulatory body.

Today BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland admitted: "We will have to be increasingly explicit and more precise about our objectives for our services".

By and large the white paper leaves the BBC board of governors intact, noting that the corporation has already moved some way by providing detailed annual reports and statement of promises

Sir Christopher said that the corporation would have to become more accountable to the public but declared himself "very content" with the "sensible proposals" for the BBC.

He highlighted the fact that BBC governors will maintain existing responsibilities "for content on all BBC services and retain sole responsibility for delivering the BBC's public service remit".

"We don't think that responsibility can be shared or second-guessed and the white paper agreed."

The BBC also said it had volunteered to introduce tight new rules which would guarantee news and current affairs in primetime.

Sir Christopher said that contrary to reports the rules were not being imposed on the BBC in protest against its decision to switch the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm.

"We felt it was an anomaly. It won't change our behaviour in any way, but it codifies it," he said.

Sir Christopher also welcomed the proposal which gives Ofcom an "ombudsman" role over complaints about the BBC from viewers and listeners.

"We agree that merging the old BSC role into Ofcom as an appeal forum will bring greater clarity for viewers and listeners.

It also emerged today that Ofcom will police the BBC's obligations in subtitling and regional output.

fields.headline: We got it first!
fields.standfirst: Wales is going to pioneer its own baccalaureate. Will England follow, asks  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: 12 December: Wales is going to pioneer its own baccalaureate. Will England follow, asks Peter Kingston.
fields.body:
The day the Liberal Democrats got their feet under the top table at the Welsh Assembly two months ago it didn't grab a lot of newspaper space across the border in England.

There was even less excitement about their terms for agreeing to enter a three-year coalition with the minority Labour administration. But one of these demands deserves scrutiny, for it may one day spark a revolution in the English education system - it may finally shatter the pre-eminence of that fabled gold standard, the A-level.

It will all depend on how the Welsh take to the baccalaureate. One of the Lib Dems' conditions for entering the coalition was that a Welsh Baccalaureate be tried out in schools and colleges.

A Welsh Bac? Is there such a thing?

Why, yes. And what is more, it promises much broader charms than the rather fearsomely academic International Baccalaureate, which a few institutions in England have been trying out.

The Welsh Baccalaureate model which the assembly last week agreed to fund promises equal weight to vocational and to academic subjects. It can be achieved through a predominantly vocational route with lesser academic components, and vice versa.

It is, according to the people who have been developing it for the last seven years or so, accessible to 80% of the 16-19 population, roughly four times the percentage, they say, who could realistically tackle the International Baccalaureate.

The Welsh Bac is the child of the Institute of Welsh Affairs (IWA), a non-aligned policy thinktank. In the early 1990s, alarmed at Wales's flagging prosperity compared to the rest of the UK and Europe - Welsh gross domestic product per head of population comes out about 80% of the UK average - the IWA concluded that a large dollop of the remedy lay in tertiary education.

Its director, John Osmond, says: "We did a lot of work looking at Ireland's experience. One of the key reasons for Ireland's success in the last decade has been investment in education, not least in tertiary education."

In 1993, the IWA published a report - Wales 2010 Creating Our Future - which recommended looking at a baccalaureate approach to post-16 education built on the International Baccalaureate model.

But why baccalaureate? What is wrong with the tried and tested A-levels?

"There is a broad consensus that the subjects studied at A-level are too narrow," says Osmond. "And there's a broad consensus that we need to do something about vocational qualifications. They are not held in high enough esteem."

Fair enough. But haven't those criticisms been addressed by Curriculum 2000, with its expectations that youngsters should do a fourth, even a fifth subject at AS level, and its intention to raise the status of vocational courses?

The IWA doesn't believe that it has, and it cites support from the higher education sector. Its researchers surveyed and visited admissions staff at 20 universities and higher education institutions to explore the acceptability of the Welsh Bac.

According to one of the IWA team, Cerian Black, they encountered concern from admissions tutors that Curriculum 2000 reforms "would not significantly broaden the studies of the majority of students". There were also serious reservations about "a gap between the rhetoric and aspirations of the government and the actual provision of AS, key skills and vocational education being made in schools and colleges".

The government's hopes that students would study five subjects at AS-level, before slimming down to three A2 A-levels in their second years don't appear to have been borne out. In fact, a survey conducted by the University and Colleges Admissions Service concluded in June that 83% of students would do four AS-levels. And that nine out of 10 Welsh colleges and schools would encourage students to take four.

"There is an avoidance culture," says Osmond. "Young people will do the minimum they think necessary to get where they want to go."

This also means, he says, that many will not seize the chance of keeping up with a subject outside their eventual cluster of A-levels but will stay close to home. Scientists are likely to choose another science rather than English literature or a foreign language, for instance.

The Welsh Bac, like the IB, will force students to carry on with subjects they might not see as their strong suits.

A student has to pick a subject from each of six subject groups: 1 English, Welsh; 2 second languages; 3 Wales studies, history, geography, economics, sociology, politics; 4 maths, biology, chemistry, physics, design technology, environmental systems; 5 art, music, theatre studies; 6 any subject from one of the other groups.

Each subject comes at two levels: higher and standard. A student must do three at higher, and three at standard. The academic options are based on existing International Baccalaureate courses.

Six subjects is also the rule for the vocational route, involving a mix of advanced, intermediate or foundation GNVQs and national vocational qualifications (NVQ). The Welsh Bac can't be done entirely vocationally: everybody must do the second language and a subject from group 1.

In addition students must do a "core studies" course covering a broad range: for instance, theory of knowledge, global concerns, RE, PE and IT. And to top it off, there is serious consideration being given to requiring all students to do a 5,000-word essay.

For the next year, at least, the Welsh Bac will be refined and twiddled. Then the intention is that two cohorts of students will do the two-year programme. It looks as if the pilots will be spread across 12 centres around Wales, and be jointly carried out at each by a school-college partnership. Meanwhile tenders will go out for an exam body to get involved.

Labour was keen on the baccalaureate notion before the 1997 election. But this enthusiasm has since apparently cooled. Apart from anything else, a baccalaureate system would not come cheap. Now that Wales is obligingly test-driving, English attention will be keenly focused on the outcome. And if it proves a success, then pressure will surely be felt in government at Westminster to follow.

As one Cambridge science admissions tutor said: "I hope it will succeed and give a positive lead in curriculum development in the rest of the UK."

Bac in England

At Exeter College, they've been doing the International Baccalaureate for nine years. Only a small proportion of students tackle it, though - 65 against 2000 or so doing A-levels - and about three times as many girls as boys, according to Dr Andy Truscott, who teaches biology.

"There's a definite type who are attracted to the IB," he says. "They tend to be outgoing freethinkers. They argue, they express their opinions quite forcibly. They question things. They are very much more dynamic. They are harder to control than the average A level group."

But they are very rewarding to teach, says his colleague Claire Willman, who teaches them maths and coordinates the college's IB programme. She also teaches GNVQ art students the compulsory maths key skill - "application of number".

"Half of them really resent it," she says. "The IB students are totally the other way. They know they've got to take maths and they're very willing to have a go. Even the weakest is going to try to get something out of it."

It looks as if the pilots will be spread across 12 centres around Wales, and be jointly carried out at each by a school-college partnership. Meanwhile tenders will go out for an exam body to get involved. Labour was keen on the baccalaureate notion before the 1997 election. But this enthusiasm has since apparently cooled. Apart from anything else, a baccalaureate system would not come cheap. Now that Wales is obligingly test-driving, English attention will be keenly focused on the outcome. And if it proves a success, then pressure will surely be felt in government at Westminster to follow. As one Cambridge science admissions tutor said: "I hope it will succeed and give a positive lead in curriculum development in the rest of the UK." Bac in England At Exeter College, they've been doing the International Baccalaureate for nine years. Only a small proportion of students tackle it, though - 65 against 2000 or so doing A-levels - and about three times as many girls as boys, according to Dr Andy Truscott, who teaches biology. "There's a definite type who are attracted to the IB," he says. "They tend to be outgoing freethinkers. They argue, they express their opinions quite forcibly. They question things. They are very much more dynamic. They are harder to control than the average A level group." But they are very rewarding to teach, says his colleague Claire Willman, who teaches them maths and coordinates the college's IB programme. She also teaches GNVQ art students the compulsory maths key skill - "application of number". "Half of them really resent it," she says. "The IB students are totally the other way. They know they've got to take maths and they're very willing to have a go. Even the weakest is going to try to get something out of it."

webTitle: In brief: Russell Crowe plugs Gladiator at the Academy

fields.headline: Russell Crowe plugs Gladiator at the Academy
fields.standfirst: Plus: Andy Garcia joins Soderbergh's all-star line-up; Madonna set to tread the boards in London; Perfect Storm screening turns out to be damp squib; Kristin Scott Thomas steps into Ingrid Bergman's shoes
fields.trailText: Plus: Andy Garcia joins Soderbergh's all-star line-up; Madonna set to tread the boards in London; Perfect Storm screening turns out to be damp squib; Kristin Scott Thomas steps into Ingrid Bergman's shoes
fields.body:
 In a fairly blatant attempt to boost Gladiator's Oscar chances, Russell Crowe was the 'surprise' guest at the launch party for the film's DVD release, held at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in Los Angeles. As if that wasn't a big enough hint, the event featured a Q&A session between Crowe and director Ridley Scott in front of a specially invited audience, right next to a 12-foot Oscar statue!

 Andy Garcia has joined the star studded cast of the remake of Ocean's Eleven, according to ananova. Garcia will join Julia Roberts, Brad Pitt, George Clooney and Matt Damon in the Las Vegas heist movie, which originally starred Ratpackers Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin and Sammy Davis Jr. It is not clear exactly which role Garcia will play in Stephen Soderbergh's project but filming is due to start at the beginning of February.

 Madonna looks set to be the latest American star to follow Kathleen Turner, Jessica Lange and Macaulay Culkin onto the West End stage. The soon-to-be-married singer is said to be considering the title role in Piaf, a musical about the diminutive French singer. The producer of the show, Chris Davis, told reporters, "This is a role that has made people's careers but the way the West End operates at the moment is entirely star driven. It is a great piece and I hope Madonna will take it on."

 A special showing of The Perfect Storm in Los Angeles proved something of a washout when just 11 people turned up. Warner Brothers, which had hoped that the special effects spectacular would show off their new digital projection system perfectly, blamed the tiny turnout on the fact that the film is already available on video.

 Kristin Scott Thomas is in final talks to take on a role, previously played by Ingrid Bergman, Merle Oberon and Danielle Darrieux, in the sixth film to be based on the Stephan Zweig novel, Twenty Four Hours of a Woman's Life. Variety reports that Scott Thomas will play an English widow who falls for a dashing young gambler during a stay on the French Riviera. The film's producer Etienne Comar told the magazine, "Kristin Scott Thomas knew the book and wanted the part immediately. It is a very ambitious project which will have tremendous emotional power.''

webTitle: Briton cleared of net murder plot

fields.headline: Briton cleared of net murder plot
fields.standfirst: Special report: internet news
fields.trailText: A Briton who admitted setting up two websites offering £75,000 to kill his American internet penfriend and her husband was acquitted today of trying to arrange her murder.
fields.body:
A Briton who admitted setting up two websites offering £75,000 to kill his American internet penfriend and her husband was acquitted today of trying to arrange her murder.

Paul Clark, 33, was cleared of one count of soliciting the murder of Brandy Arnett, of El Paso, Texas, and two counts of attempting to solicit the murder of Ms Arnett and her husband Rick between May and October last year.

But after deliberating for seven hours, the jury at Winchester crown court found Clark guilty on two charges of making threats to kill Brandy Arnett. He will remain in custody until sentencing on December 21.

The prosecution said Clark, of Portsmouth, set up the sites after discovering Brandy Arnett was married.

"Are you looking to make some easy money?" one of the sites asked. "Then you have come to the right place." It included a picture and an address of Brandy Arnett with a proposition to "terminate" her.

But prosecutors failed to prove that anyone other than Clark or Brandy Arnett could have found the sites, which did not appear on any index pages of websites.

Clark testified that Ms Arnett lied to him about her marital status and her business affairs, and said the two sites were a hoax that was part of a cyber-war between the pair.

Clark said he developed "genuine feelings" for Ms Arnett after the two struck up a friendship by email. He admitted setting up the websites, but said no one could have gained access to them without the exact address. He added that his threats were not serious and, in any case, he did not have the money to pay any contract killer.

But the jury was shown threatening emails Clark had sent to Ms Arnett. One claimed, "There are plenty of gun-crazed headcases out there - someone will do it." Others insisted the threat was no joke.

In her evidence, Ms Arnett said that after Clark had appeared to become infatuated with her, she had sent him a wedding photograph, newspaper cuttings and a copy of her marriage certificate in an effort to persuade him that she was married.

Clark was remanded in custody for sentencing on December 21. A further charge of attempting to pervert the course of justice was left to lie on file.

fields.standfirst: From Steve
fields.trailText: If you can afford the time and cost, try to visit Crater Lake National Park near Klamath Falls in southern Oregon. Spectacular drive to top of extinct volcano caldera filled with water - with a smaller volcanic cone in the middle of the lake - snowcapped even in summer.
fields.body:
Sam,

San Francisco is one of the most attractive cities in the US; Ghiridelli Square is worth a look - a refurbished old bit of SF that somehow survived the 1906 earthquake. Chinatown you should not miss - I found it was safe to stroll through even at night! You will have to seek further advice when there. Outside SF, visit Yosemite National Park; probably the most picturesque preserved wilderness area on earth. Closer to SF is Muir Woods (Redwood grove) and the vineyards and wineries of the Napa and Somona Valleys. Hot springs and spas at Agua Caliente ('hot water' in Spanish). If you can afford the time and cost, try to visit Crater Lake National Park near Klamath Falls in southern Oregon. Spectacular drive to top of extinct volcano caldera filled with water - with a smaller volcanic cone in the middle of the lake - snowcapped even in summer.

webTitle: White paper criticised by ITN shareholders

fields.headline: ITN shareholders criticise white paper
fields.standfirst: Special report: Communications white paper
fields.trailText:
ITN shareholders criticised the white paper for not going far enough in relaxing rules for ownership of the news organisation. By Jessica Hodgson.

Special report: Communications white paper
fields.body:
ITN shareholders have criticised the Culture Secretary, claiming that the communications white paper hasn't gone far enough in relaxing the rules for ownership of the news organisation.

Carlton and Granada are angry that the communications white paper, published this afternoon, says that the government will "consider" relaxing the 20% limit on ownership of the news provider.

They had hoped that the new legislation would pave the way for a Granada/Carlton carve up.

The white paper removes most of the TV industry restrictions which prevent the consolidation of ITV; dropping the rule that prevents a single TV company owning more than 15% of TV audience share and allowing a single company to control both London weekday and weekend franchises.

But Carlton and Granada are unhappy that the restrictive 20% barrier to ITN ownership is still in place.

Plans for an ITN float, already delayed, have been "kicked into the long grass", according to one source.

"It is known that ITN shareholders are angry with the lack of commitment in the white paper," said another.

The source said the real reason Mr Smith ignored pleas by the ITN shareholders for a free-for-all was his continuing scepticism about ITV's commitment to serious news and current affairs.

A Carlton spokesman said: "We think this limit should be removed and we always have done." He added that an ITN flotation "was always only an option, and it remains an option".

A Granada spokesman said: "It's fine for us for now. It would be more worrying if the reference to it wasn't in there at all."

ITN today gave a warm welcome to the communications white paper. It said it was delighted that its position at the heart of broadcasting was being safeguarded.

Stewart Purvis, ITN chief executive, said: "This white paper was certainly worth the wait. It lends enormous weight to the importance of news in the digital marketplace. It strikes exactly the right balance between retaining a nominated-news provider model for ITV in the medium-term, but with the promise of deregulation when the market develops further.

"All in all, a balanced and pragmatic approach to news provision and a great endorsement of ITN's public service role."

He added: "It also represents a substantial shift in government thinking about external scrunity of the BBC. Whilst the devil will always be in the detail of drafting a bill, we believe this white paper is a watershed in the government's willingness to tackle the BBC's regulation."

webTitle: Single ITV dream still some way off

fields.headline: Single ITV dream still some way off
fields.standfirst: Special report: white paper.
fields.trailText:
Tuesday 6pm: Carlton and Granada's dream of a single ITV is still far from reality, writes Dan Milmo
Special report: white paper.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications and Granada Media have welcomed today's announcement that a single ITV is possible, but their dream is still far from reality.

The communications white paper accepted the possibility of "greater consolidation" of ITV, and said that it would scrap the rule which prevents licence holders from having 15% or more of the total audience share.

However, the document added that any consolidation of ITV could fall prey to the Fair Trading Act, which exists to protect the interests of "consumers and market players such as advertisers".

The Competition Commission has stated that a single ITV company is unlikely to be permitted if its share of the TV advertising market is above 50%. ITV's share of the TV advertising currently stands at 60%.

The Department of Trade and Industry said in the summer that a dominant ITV company "could affect advertising spend" by being indispensable to advertisers and raising prices.

The DTI is wary of any consolidation moves that could affect advertising rates for the likes of Channel 4 and Channel 5.

Despite these concerns, the two major players in ITV remained confident that today's developments could pave the way for a single ITV company.

Charles Allen, chairman of Granada Media, said: "The proposed regulatory framework will allow further consolidation of ITV ownership and the emergence of a single ITV company, which can compete more strongly at home and abroad, serving the interests of our viewers and our shareholders."

A Carlton spokesman said that the white paper was good news, because "it takes away the road blocks to a single ITV".

However, analysts believe there is still some way to go before a single ITV can be created.

Daniel Kerven at ABN Amro said: "A single ITV is not a foregone conclusion because it might distort the advertising market. The white paper goes far enough to pave the way for a single ITV, but the other half of the equation is the advertising market."

webTitle: Education French resources: Trial test for Aids vaccine

fields.headline: Témoin
fields.standfirst: Véronique Lenormand is taking part in a scientific experiment to develop a vaccine against Aids
fields.trailText: Véronique Lenormand is taking part in a scientific experiment to develop a vaccine against Aids.
fields.body:
Suite à un appel de l'Agence nationale de recherche contre le sida, mon mari et moi nous sommes portés volontaires pour tester des vaccins préventifs expérimentaux destinés à lutter contre le sida.

Après avoir envoyé une lettre de motivation, nous avons passé une visite médicale et subi un examen sanguin très poussé, puis un entretien avec un psychiatre afin d'évaluer nos motivations.

Le vaccin m'a été injecté en 1994. Le premier semestre, il m'a fallu venir régulièrement à Paris pour effectuer des tests sanguins. En outre, je devais surveiller de très près ma santé: prendre ma température matin et soir et noter toutes les manifestations corporelles (sueur, malaise, fatigue). Les tests s'étalent sur un an environ. Après, il suffit de faire un bilan de santé chaque année. Je n'ai eu aucune complication. D'ailleurs, en 1998, j'ai accepté de faire un nouvel essai, avec un nouveau vaccin.

Ma motivation? Mes enfants! Mon mari et moi sommes bien conscients que le problème du sida va les prendre de plein fouet quand ils seront en âge d'avoir une vie sexuelle active. Notre but: accélérer la recherche médicale pour qu'ils puissent bénéficier d'un vaccin efficace.

Je n'ai jamais eu peur. L'extrême rigueur avec laquelle s'effectue la sélection des volontaires est rassurante. L'ANRS ne prend aucun risque. S'il y a le moindre doute, la personne ne sera pas retenue. De plus, l'ANRS a toujours eu le souci de nous informer des résultats de leurs recherches. Je ne me suis jamais sentie comme un simple cobaye. On fait réellement partie de leur équipe.

Glossaire/Glossary

un bilan de santé a medical check-up

un examen sanguin a blood test

le premier semestre the first half-year

prendre qn. de plein fouet = frapper de plein fouet (coll) to hit someone head-on

prendre la température to take someone's temperature

se porter volontaire to volunteer

avoir le souci de to be anxious to

suite à following

 Véronique Lenormand was talking to Karine Vandenhove.

webTitle: Education: Are female lecturers discriminated against?

fields.headline: Jobs for the boys
fields.standfirst: Why are so many women only on short-term contracts? Lee Elliot Major investigates
fields.trailText: Why are so many women only on short-term contracts? Lee Elliot Major investigates.
fields.body:
Half of women academics are now on short-term temporary contracts, a new study on staff in UK universities has found. And in some universities, such as St Andrews, women are nearly twice as likely as men to hold fixed-term positions, with contracts lasting as little as three months in some cases.

The statistics represent a damning indictment of the gender inequalities still present in universities, at a time when the government is calling on the academic sector to improve its equal opportunities record.

The study, by the Association of University Teachers, exposes a wide variation in the employment policies of universities, with some institutions increasing the proportion of staff on permanent contracts while others seem determined to move the entire academic workforce into casual employment.

AUT researcher David Watson said: "What is striking about the study is that while many universities are acting retrogressively, others are showing that it is not necessary and are reducing their reliance on fixed-term contracts." The AUT thinks the only way of addressing discrimination against female staff is to limit the number of fixed-term contracts in universities, a move satisfying Europe-wide regulations on fixed-term work.

The conclusions of the AUT study chime with calls for radical reforms to the rules governing research grant applications, to be announced later this month after a survey of researchers by the Wellcome Trust and research councils. The Wellcome study concludes that there is no bias against women in grant competitions, but fewer female academics apply for awards than their male counterparts.

Senior academics, who are mostly male, tend to apply for more grants.

Women also report that they are given less encouragement by their institutions to make grant applications. At the same time, female academics are more likely to be on short-term contracts, and therefore ineligible to apply directly for grants.

The fledgling body set up to improve equal opportunity policies in the academic sector suffered a major blow last week when the appointed head announced he would not be taking up the post after all. The director of communications at the Commission for Racial Equality, Phil Barnet, would not give any reasons for the u-turn. The Equality Challenge Unit is seen as the last voluntary effort to improve career and personell management in universities.

The AUT study looked at staff statistics for 1994-95 and 1998-99. Institutions that increased the number of staff on permanent contracts included Salford, Manchester Metropolitan and Leeds Metropolitan universities. Scottish institutions employ many women staff on short-term contracts.

For many women academics, the report only confirms what they have always known. One 31-year-old female researcher at Imperial College, who wished to remain anonymous, has spent two years on six- and three-month contracts. In the course of a seven-year career, she says, she has written many grant applications. But these almost always need to carry the name of a more senior male academic - a principal investigator eligible to apply to a funding agency.

In her view it is difficult for women to secure tenured positions because most senior university staff who make appointments are mainly men.

"I like working in the academic environment," she says. "But I know in the future I will have to work in a pharmaceutical company for security later in life."

A bad deal for women lecturers

Scottish institutions employ many women staff on short-term contracts. For many women academics, the report only confirms what they have always known. In the course of a seven-year career, she says, she has written many grant applications. But these almost always need to carry the name of a more senior male academic - a principal investigator eligible to apply to a funding agency. In her view it is difficult for women to secure tenured positions because most senior university staff who make appointments are mainly men. "I like working in the academic environment," she says. fields.headline: Inquiry will verify A-level standards
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government's qualifications watchdog will today begin an inquiry into the way it polices A-level standards in a potentially hazardous effort to raise public confidence.
fields.body:
The government's qualifications watchdog will today begin an inquiry into the way it polices A-level standards in a potentially hazardous effort to raise public confidence.

David Hargreaves, the new chief executive of the qualifications and curriculum authority, has appointed an international panel to question whether the authority and the exam boards are ensuring that A-levels do not get easier.

"I'm putting my organisation on the line," he said last night. "I can't be sure that the machinery we have got to keep standards maintained over time is the best machinery. The authority should expose itself to examination from outside. I am trying to be as open as I can."

This year 89.1% of results were A-E grades, up 12 percentage points on 1990, and 17.8% were A grades, up six points in a decade.

On the day Mr Hargreaves took up his job Chris Woodhead, the former chief inspector of schools, called for an inquiry into "grade inflation", and rightwing commentators have long argued A-levels have got easier. Mr Hargreaves sees this inquiry, his first major decision, as a way of clarifying the recurring debate.

"I want to reassure everyone, including myself as a newcomer to this role, that we carry out this role reliably and to the best possible standards."

He said he believed it was impossible to establish whether A-levels were easier than 20 years ago, because exam scripts had not been kept and syllabuses had been transformed, but the authority believed that its monitoring, with rolling reviews of all subjects over a five-year period, had maintained standards.

He was prepared to change if the authority was found wanting. "There has to be public confidence in the A-levels system. We have got to be sure whether standards have improved or not. If you can't be sure, it makes it very difficult to decide whether teachers or students are working better or working harder."

The panel will be chaired by Eva Baker, co-director of the US national centre for research on evaluation, standards and student testing, and will include Barry McGaw, the deputy director for education at the organisation for economic cooperation and development, and Sir Stewart Sutherland, vice-chancellor of Edinburgh university.

The panel's brief is to review quality assurance work by the authority and exam bodies, and compare the work with international practice, but it will have the power to roam widely.

It will start work in February and issue a public report by the end of the year.

webTitle: What the new super-regulator will do

fields.headline: What the new super-regulator will do
fields.standfirst: Special report: white paper
fields.trailText:
Tuesday 5.30pm: Claire Cozens explains how Ofcom, the new single regulator created in today's communications white paper, will work.
Special report: white paper
fields.body:
The government is proposing a three-tier structure for new regulatory body Ofcom that would establish three different categories of regulation: general regulation, regulation of public service broadcasters and self-regulation.

The first tier will cover basic rules that apply to all broadcasters. These include the requirement to provide fair, impartial and accurate news; rules on sponsorship and advertising, and other industry-wide requirements for programming such as access for people with disabilities and equal opportunities. It will also introduce new basic requirements for broadcasters on training.

The second tier will ensure that public service broadcasters comply with the government's requirements. These include sticking to quotas for regional programmes and for independent productions and showing enough news and current affairs programming in peak time.

Commercial radio will also be regulated at this level. The second tier will be responsible for ensuring that commercial radio stations licensed to broadcast specific types of output (such as speech or non-pop music) stick to their remit.

The third tier will involve a more general remit to look at the quality of broadcasters' output.

However, the white paper is short on detail. It says that this tier, which will apply to public service broadcasters such as the BBC, "is less easy to quantify without going back into box-ticking".

But it adds that self-regulation will be encouraged at this level.

ITV, Channel 5, Channel 4, and S4C will also be covered by this tier because of their public service obligations in regional, religious and news and other critical programming areas.

"This is not a reduction in the type of extent of their obligations, but a way of giving them more flexibility in how they fulfill them," the paper continues.

Ofcom will look to the public service broadcasters increasingly to regulate themselves on the issue of quality, giving them more flexibility in the way they fulfil their obligations.

Public service broadcasters will be asked to develop statements of programme policy and to put new systems in place to ensure self-regulation is effective. These will have to be introduced before the new legislation reaches the statute book and will be reviewed every year.

But Ofcom will have the power to intervene if the broadcasters fail to police themselves properly.

fields.headline: NHS may miss e-commerce targets
fields.standfirst: The NHS could save millions by ordering supplies and equipment over the internet. But, asks Michael Cross, will the health service part with post, fax and triplicate form-filling?
fields.trailText: The NHS could save millions by ordering supplies and equipment over the internet. But, asks Michael Cross, will the health service part with post, fax and triplicate form-filling?
fields.body:
At any given moment, one billion paper messages are circulating around the NHS.

If that number - an estimate by the NHS Executive - looks suspiciously round it is because no one has ever counted.

We do, however, know two things for certain. First, most of this paper mountain consists of routine forms and invoices needed to order supplies, equipment and staff.

Second, it costs a lot of money. For every pound the NHS spends on pills, bandages and bedpans, 25p goes into the paperwork.

"Research shows that supply chain costs make up 25% of invoice value," says Sean Flanagan, chief executive of Medex Online, a new "e-health" company. He says that electronic messages could cut this cost in half.

Although the dot.com crash has taken most of the shine off electronic commerce in the consumer market, there is no doubt that, when large organisations do their shopping, e-commerce makes sense: car-makers and supermarkets have been ordering, invoicing and paying for their supplies electronically for years.

Healthcare, too, is getting into e-commerce - in the US at least. Research in the US shows that a 10% cut from supply chain costs adds 1% to an organisation's profits.

As most American hospitals operate on profit margins of only 2% or 3%, the US healthcare industry is taking it seriously.

Now it's the NHS's turn. The NHS Purchasing and Supply Agency, set up in April this year to help the NHS do its shopping more efficiently, is about to publish an e-commerce strategy for the health service.

The agency is also developing an e-commerce system, SupplyStream, that will allow trusts and other NHS organisations to order supplies electronically from private firms.

The scheme is part of a government-wide race to get into the e-commerce age. The Department of Health has already published an internal e-business strategy laying out its plans to hook its internal systems up to the NHS's network, NHSnet, as well as the wider internet.

Like other government departments, it is trying to meet the prime minister's deadline for all public services to be delivered electronically by 2005.

Under this timetable, 90% of routine government purchases are to be made electronically by next April.

Barring a miracle (or, more likely, some creative statistical juggling) this target will be missed.

Although the Office of Government Commerce, set up by the Treasury in April this year, says the government could save £1bn from its shopping bill by catching up with the rest of the world, e-business in the public sector is happening only in patches.

One example is a scheme to issue civil servants with government Visa cards, to cut the £300m the government spends a year on low-value, high-volume goods.

So far, however, only 14% of such purchases are handled by the government procurement card, according to its annual report published last week.

Predictably, the biggest use of the government procurement card was in buying stationery. Last year, civil servants used their flexible friends 37,756 times to buy paper clips, pads and other stationery worth £2.7m from supplier Guilbert.

Yet there is still hope. At Medex Online, Flanagan says the NHS' tardiness at getting into e-commerce could become an advantage. "Healthcare in Europe has a much bigger opportunity than the US."

Because the NHS and other European health systems have more primitive IT systems, they have the chance to skip the 1980s generation of custom-built electronic trading systems and leap straight into the internet age. Thanks to new web technologies, hospitals no longer need to replace their old systems.

Medex Online plans to announce its first NHS trust customer in January.

There are still technical and cultural barriers to e-procurement. Graham Newall, chief executive of Earthport, a company specialising in internet payment systems, says SupplyStream has to overcome substantial challenges to help the government reach its targets. Issues of security and usability are high on the list of priorities.

"We believe that the NHS e-procurement system will be a great success if it's easy to use, light on infrastructure, and scalable in order to cope with huge volumes of data and transactions. It also needs to be secure and able to authenticate the user and process real time cash and secure credit card payments."

And there's the human factor. Jill Turner, owner of The Health Store, a small firm which supplies bed aids to the NHS and the public via the web and traditional channels, says personal contact is important to NHS professionals. "I see no evidence that the NHS is interested in ordering online. They seem to prefer post and fax and purchase orders in triplicate."

 Michael Cross is news editor of www.kablenet.com

fields.headline: ITV wins royal battle
fields.trailText: 3.45pm TV overnights: ITV was last night crowned the winner in the battle of the Prince William documentaries, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
ITV was last night crowned the winner in the battle of the Prince William documentaries.

The BBC went head-to-head with Coronation Street at 7.30pm with its film of William's travels, narrated by royal correspondent Jennie Bond, and garnered 4.5m viewers.

However, ITV got 5.1m viewers half an hour later, going up against Eastenders and a jail-bound Dot Cotton.

Both channels were given access to the Prince William footage, shot by an ITN cameraman. The documentaries were part of a carefully orchestrated Buckingham Palace campaign to show Wills as a caring, sharing 21st century royal.

In a double blow to the beeb, Coronation Street racked up a 14.4m-strong audience and 59% viewing share, against 12.5m for Eastenders and a 50% share.

webTitle: Tories left floundering by EU deal

fields.headline: Tories left floundering by EU deal
fields.trailText:
Tony Blair yesterday neutralised Europe as the Conservatives' most effective election weapon when he
           returned from the European Union's Nice summit with a compromise treaty good enough to meet his
           key political objectives.
fields.byline: Michael White and Ian Black in Nice
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday neutralised Europe as the Conservatives' most effective election weapon when he returned from the European Union's Nice summit with a compromise treaty good enough to meet his key political objectives.

Far from paving the way to a European superstate, as his Conservative critics alleged, Mr Blair, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany and the summit's host, President Jacques Chirac of France, have reasserted the inter-governmental model for Europe - leaving the Brussels commission in retreat before the national power of the "big three".

In contrast to Tory charges of a sell-out to EU federalism at Westminster, one disappointed Dutch parliamentarian declared that "the French elephant has given birth to a mouse". A French socialist MP dubbed it "a mediocre, disappointing and insufficient deal".

After an unprecedented four days and nights committed to rescuing the much-delayed EU objectives - greater numbers of EU members following enlargement to the east, matched by greater effectiveness - the prime minister proclaimed the summit 's success to the Commons in terms which avoided the national triumphalism which marred John Major's pre-election negotiations at Maastricht in 1991.

"It is possible to fight Britain's corner, get the best out of Europe for Britain and exercise real authority and influence in Europe. That is as it should be. Britain is a world power. To stand aside from the key alliance - the EU - right on our doorstep is not advancing Britain's interests. It is betraying them," he insisted.

In exchanges that will set the tone for the election expected in early April or May, William Hague accused Mr Blair and his co-negotiator, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, of a sell-out. "Isn't the truth, when you cut through the spin, that this agreement represents major steps towards a European superstate?" the Conservative leader asked.

Mr Cook retaliated that the Tories were moving further and further apart from any of their "sister" parties in Europe, leaving them the only party in Europe effectively wanting to delay enlargement. Euroscepticism would become an electoral albatross around the party's neck, he warned, while a refusal to adopt the Nice treaty would only play into the hands of ultra-nationalists in the former eastern European countries.

The underlying sub-text of Nice saw much of the summit 's energy consumed by battles between the "bigs" and the "smalls" - so much aware that their leverage is being diminished that they staged a Belgium-led revolt which delayed the summit 's conclusions until 4.30am yesterday.

As the summiteers left Nice in the early morning, exhausted and irritated by the unseemly pre-dawn haggling and compromises, they could at least claim that the central goal of preparing for enlargement had been achieved.

"Not everything has been done," acknowledged President Chirac just before the agreement on votes. "But we did make substantial progress."

There were expressions of frustration from the European commission team, dealt a grave blow by the failure to persuade Britain and its allies to remove national vetoes on indirect tax and social security issues - and by the explicit dominance of the big three member states. Romano Prodi, president of the commission, openly lamented the lack of radical reform in the treaty.

"I cannot hide from you a certain regret that we did not manage to go further," he said.

Downing Street said it did not blame France for the bitter and nail-biting denouement, but argued that better planning and discussion would have avoided wasting the first two days. "We cannot do business like this in the future," Mr Blair said.

One of the few leaders to win plaudits was the Belgian prime minister, Guy Verhofstadt, who brokered the final deal that gave more votes to Lithuania and Romania and saved the summit from disaster. "There were some people around the table - but not many - who were working for the common good of Europe and not for me! for me! for me!" he said. "We fought very hard ... and it is still too little."

Germany, another big winner, was delighted, but said more could have been done.

Applicant nations from former communist eastern Europe were delighted at what was supposed to be the prime motive for the new treaty, which must be finalised and signed next year, then ratified by all 15 existing members.

webTitle: Racist words turn off TV viewers

fields.headline: Racist words turn off TV viewers
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Viewers and listeners are increasingly intolerant of racist language in the media following rising concern over racially-motivated crime.
fields.body:
Viewers and listeners are increasingly intolerant of racist language in the media following rising concern over racially-motivated crime.

According to a survey by the industry's principal regulators, published yesterday, racist abuse has shot up in the league table of offensive words.

But the use of strong swearwords still tops viewers' and listeners' concerns.

Although the report, Delete Expletives?, found that concerns about racist language have increased in the past two years, there is still a significant minority who have less of a problem with such language. Strong sex-related swearwords were considered to be most offensive.

In general, the use of swearwords before the 9pm watershed was generally unacceptable.

But swearing was regarded as more acceptable in adult-oriented drama and films, so long as it was felt to be justified by the context. Bad language in advertising was unjustified even if the adverts were screened after 9pm, according to 81% of viewers.

Presenting the results of the survey, Stephen Whittle, director of the broadcasting standards commission, said it showed that parents did not want their children to be exposed to bad language. "Although there is an acceptance that swearing and offensive language is used in daily life and may be appropriate if a programme is aimed at adults, they would prefer their homes to remain an expletive deleted zone for children."

Caroline Thomson, the BBC's director of public policy, said it would take the survey into account when it made "difficult judgments" about the use of strong language. All its programme-makers would be made aware of its contents, she said.

"Although there is an acceptance that swearing and offensive language is used in daily life and may be appropriate if a programme is aimed at adults, they would prefer their homes to remain an expletive deleted zone for children." Caroline Thomson, the BBC's director of public policy, said it would take the survey into account when it made "difficult judgments" about the use of strong language. All its programme-makers would be made aware of its contents, she said.

webTitle: Comment, Paul Foot: The Met is guilty

fields.headline: The Met is guilty
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The story came to Private Eye by a familiar route: two freelance journalists who had written it for the Daily Express, but couldn't get it published. It featured Gurpal Singh Virdi, a Sikh sergeant at Ealing police station, west London. I spoke to Sgt Virdi who seemed genuinely aggrieved.
fields.body:
The story came to Private Eye by a familiar route: two freelance journalists who had written it for the Daily Express, but couldn't get it published. It featured Gurpal Singh Virdi, a Sikh sergeant at Ealing police station, west London. I spoke to Sgt Virdi who seemed genuinely aggrieved.

He told me how he had dealt with a racist attack in his area in March 1998. Five thugs had attacked an Iraqi student. Sgt Virdi found the student bleeding in the street, called an ambulance, and joined in the hunt for the assailants. Three were found by his colleagues. He arrested the other two in a back street. All five were eventually convicted.

Mr Virdi complained to his superiors that the attack had not initially been classified as racist (as it eventually was). Not much later the sergeant and his family went on holiday. On their return, their home was raided and searched by anti-terrorist officers. Mr Virdi was suspended on suspicion of sending racist mail to himself and fellow officers. He was told that the mail, which included the message that black officers were "not wanted", had been sent from his personal computer. Private Eye ran the story - the first of 12 on the subject in two years.

In March last year, Mr Virdi faced a police disciplinary tribunal. Three commanders sat in judgment - Richard Cullen, then head of the police training school, Graham James, later at the directorate of professional standards, and Alan Shave from south-west London. After a four-week hearing, the commanders declared that Mr Virdi was guilty as charged. The details of the police case were then made available to the press.

The story fitted perfectly with the common prejudice that black police are as likely to be racist as white police. SIKH SARGE TRIED TO STIR UP RACIST HATRED chimed the Sun, and on BBC Newsnight, the Met's deputy assistant commissioner, Michael Todd, announced: "Three commanders independently assessed the evidence of over 80 witnesses, and over 50 gave evidence - their decision was beyond all reasonable doubt." After 17 years' impeccable service to the police, Sgt Virdi was sacked, his name smeared in the press and on television, his family humiliated at school and in the neighbourhood.

His only hope was the north London industrial tribunal to which he had taken his case, alleging race discrimination. First, the police tried to get the tribunal to drop the case, arguing that the matter had already been decided - by them. When this claim was rejected, Deputy Assistant Commissioner Todd went on the radio to denounce Virdi for wasting time and money by pressing on.

One night last August an ecstatic Gurpal Virdi rang me with great news. He had been completely vindicated by the tribunal. There was "no evidence", it concluded, that Mr Virdi had sent out the racist mail. Indeed, the racist messages were probably never even in the computer print-outs studied by the police. The tribunal waited for an apology from the police and a settlement. Instead Commander John Grieve, the officer appointed after the Stephen Lawrence affair "to nick racists", announced publicly that Mr Virdi would get no apology from him.

Someone higher up obviously thought again. Last month Deputy Commissioner Ian Blair issued an unqualified apology, and told Mr Virdi he could (if he wants, which seems unlikely), rejoin the force. Mr Virdi's lawyers started negotiations with the police over compensation, but these were called off by Mr Virdi when the contents of his lawyers' first letter were splashed all over the Daily Mail.

Last week, the tribunal met again to discuss a remedy. They awarded Mr Virdi £150,000 damages to compensate for his injured feelings at his discrimination. This is easily a record for such compensation. Anyone who thinks it too large should read the tribunal's detailed findings. They add up to a devastating attack on the police for the way in which they treated Mr Virdi, secretly taped an interview with him, and tried to entrap him in incriminating answers which were not forthcoming for the simple reason that he is an anti-racist, completely innocent of the serious crime alleged against him.

I scanned the media on Saturday hoping at last for some proper public vindication of Gurpal Virdi. I was glad to see decent coverage in the doomed Daily Express, which rejected the story two years ago, and front-page treatment in the Independent. Even the Daily Mail piece suggested that its editors (possibly as a result of an official complaint from Mr Virdi) have recanted.

SEPP THE PEACEKEEPER

It was way past the witching hour when the Fiver - locked in a boozy embrace with Sepp Blatter - finally staggered out of Fifa's glitzy awards ceremony. It had been a good night. A minor border skirmish between Argentina and Brazil had been avoided. The giant wheels of global capitalism were still rolling. And Maradona and Pele had - albeit briefly - been in the same room together (until El Blizzardo walked out). Such an unexpected display of goodwill, the Fiver decided, was down to one man - and one man only - Mr Blatter. And how we showed him our appreciation.

It was Sepp's genius to award both Maradona and Pele the title of Player of the Century, with Maradona winning the internet vote and Pele romping away with the hastily arranged poll of Fifa's Football Family. Sadly, one man was not happy, and that man was Diego Maradona. "I had the vote of the people. Pele won by the book," he blazed, his eyes bulging after a sleepness night. "People who say that only young people voted on the internet, those who didn't see Pele play, forget that children are not orphans. There's always a father who buys the computer and perhaps influences their vote," he continued, his nose sucking up line after line of oxygen.

But in South America, Fifa's decision to name both players as Player of the Century has incredibly united both Brazil and Argentina. "At the last minute, Fifa created a trick to kick Maradona into touch," claimed Jornal do Brasil. While in Argentina, Ole reckoned: "The questionable aspect of this whole story was the way Fifa handled it when it became clear that Maradona would win the internet vote." First he brought Pele and Maradona together. Then Brazil and Argentina. So hats off to Sepp Blatter - and the ticket to Belfast is in the post.

THE FIVER'S INTERACTIVE ADVENT CALENDAR

Dec 12: Click here

SHAME ON THE GAME IN SPAIN (ALRIGHT, BRAZIL)

In a move which will please conspiracy theorists everywhere, the head of the Brazilian Football Confederation (CBF), Ricardo Teixeira, is to be interrogated by the Brazilian senate this week. He will be asked questions about the Federation's finances, their legendary deal with ethical sportswear manufacturers Nike, and why those bright lights appear in the sky every time there's a football match at night.

[This story is interrupted while the Fiver tries on its new claw-set brilliant cut diamond earstuds in the mirror. Mmm, they really are beautiful and provide one with a real feeling of self-worth.]

Teixeira, head of the CBF for the past 11 years, will face questions from a congressional inquiry after widespread public discontent over the state of the national game (something Brazilians take quite seriously apparently). The inquiry has already spoken to Wanderley Luxemburgo, the short-lived national coach, as to why he earned more than $9m from the CBF in the last five years. Luxemburgo, who has been accused by a former lover of smuggling cocaine "like 007" (claims Luxemburgo denies), must have stayed late to do some database programming or something.

So Teixeira can look forward to being quizzed about Ronaldo's appearance in the World Cup final (the inquiry wants to speak to the goofy one himself next year), his relationship with ex-father-in-law and former Fifa chief Joao Havelange, the full extent of Nike's deal with the CBF, and why marketing company Traffic (crazy name) has managed to cream exclusive broadcast rights to Brazilian matches and control over the sale of advertising hoardings in a deal the inquiry has already described as "fantastic for Traffic and terrible for Brazilian football". But that's all. Wonder if we could do the same for Kelvin Koogan

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"The Worthington Cup is something I value. After all, I have a very good goalscoring record in this competition. I think I have scored something like 25 times in 29 games. I think if this was an English test, my marks would be above average!" - Robbie Fowler

INSERT PICTURE OF LIVERPOOL BADGE SPLIT DOWN THE MIDDLE HERE

Now that Chelsea have turned the corner and are stampeding up the table like the world-class team we always knew they were, the position of Official Premiership Crisis Club needs filling. Hmm. How about Liverpool? They've just lost four of their last six league games, their manager's team selection and transfer policy are under fire from certain quarters, and they're useless. Yep, they'll do for now.

"What people say will not affect my policy or my line because I firmly believe that this is long-term management," a defensive Gerard Houllier insisted today as his omission of Emile Heskey for the defeat against Ipswich was brought into question. "Six months ago, everybody was asking why I had bought Heskey because we already had Fowler and Owen at the club. Now they are asking why I put Emile on the bench for one game. You never win!"

Once it had been explained to Houllier that never winning was an integral part of the problem, Gerard swiftly got desperate, claiming that "A lot has been made of Leeds' young squad, but ours is younger", and "I even underwent laser surgery on my eyes so I don't wear glasses watching the team anymore!" Calm down, Gerard! You could always turn things round in Europe what's that? Liverpool are unseeded for tomorrow's Euro-Vase draw and will play either Barcelona, Roma, Porto or Celta Vigo? Oh dear. Crisis! Crisis!

THE RUMOUR MILL

Newcastle have failed in a bid to lure Gianluca Vialli out of retirement. "Luca is very happy and he will come back into football for sure, but not as a player," said his agent Athole Stole. "The door is closed on that - he is not interested in the slightest." The Geordies have now been linked with Roma's Italian international striker Marco Delvecchio.

Aston Villa look closer to signing Benni McCarthy after the South African striker flew out of Vigo this morning. But John Gregory is also reported to be interested in signing River Plate's Colombian striker Juan Pablo Angel.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Leeds midfielder Matthew Jones is poised to join Blackburn Rovers after the two clubs today agreed a fee of £2.75m.

Ronaldo gave a positive drink-driving test in San Sebastian in the early hours of Sunday morning, Spanish police confirmed on Tuesday. "A four-by-four vehicle, with a foreign number plate, was stopped at random by an alcohol control and it was being driven by Ronaldo," a police spokesman revealed.

Newcastle captain Alan Shearer could play against Bradford on Saturday after having a steroid injection in his injured knee. However, if the injection - his third - doesn't work, he will need an operation.

Coventry defender Colin Hendry has moved to Bolton on loan.

Leicester manager Peter Taylor has denied tabloid reports that he is discussing a new contract with the club.

Dundee defender Lee Wilkie may have played his last game for the club after a training-ground altercation with player-manager Ivano Bonetti. "I don't want to say too much but I definitely think I have played my last game for Dundee," said Wilkie.

Alessandro Del Piero will be out for at least a month after injuring his right thigh.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Various shoddy regional sports specials (11.30pm)
Allow the likes of Andy Steggall, Bob Wilson and Roger Tames to put you through an hour of hell.

Football Extra (3.10am)
Suddenly looking at Dave Beckett doesn't seem so painful.

Channel 4: Football Italia (2.05am)
Don Howe will still make blood seep out of your ears, though.

Channel 5: Argentine Football (4.40am)
Possibly postponed if Diego has managed to start another international conflict with Brazil.

Sky Sports 1: Inside Scottish Football (6.30pm, 11pm)
Don't knock it. It's going to be more exciting than the Premiership.

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2am)
What would you give McCaff for Christmas? Email the.boss@theguardian.com with the subject heading "Even if I was going to stick it where the sun don't shine, I'd still wrap it first".

Sky Sports 2: Live Worthington Cup Football - Crystal Palace v Sunderland (7pm, 12.30am SS1)
Don't knock it. It's going to be more exciting than the FA Cup.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7.30pm)
For some reason, the Worthington Cup inspires a 90-minute Irish rant about Manchester United's ineptitude at media relations.

webTitle: Triumphant Endeavour astronauts return to earth

fields.headline: Triumphant Endeavour astronauts return to earth
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Space shuttle Endeavour's five astronauts returned from the international space station and, within minutes, were receiving accolades for pulling off Nasa's most complicated and critical construction mission yet.
fields.body:
Space shuttle Endeavour's five astronauts returned from the international space station and, within minutes, were receiving accolades for pulling off Nasa's most complicated and critical construction mission yet.

"In anybody's ballpark, this mission was really a home run," said shuttle program manager Ron Dittemore. Endeavour's flight ended Monday evening the same way it began: right on time.

The shuttle touched down on the illuminated runway just four minutes after the space station, Alpha, soared overhead with its gleaming, new solar wings. The station was clearly visible as it streaked through the dark sky.

By the time the shuttle landed, the station was just off the Virginia coast, its three residents supposedly asleep.

"Outstanding job. Welcome back," Mission Control told Endeavour commander Brent Jett Jr. once he guided the shuttle to a safe stop.

During their week at the space station, Jett and his crew installed the world's largest and most powerful solar wings. Three spacewalks were required to attach the $600 million wings, hook up all the cables and then tighten the slack right wing.

The astronauts also spent one day inside Alpha, helping commander Bill Shepherd and his two Russian crewmates with computer problems and cargo transfers.

"If you've been following the mission, you know it's been a pretty exciting 11 days for us," Jett said after climbing out of Endeavour.

It was Nasa's third space station mission in as many months, but the most critical by far "because we knew we had to get those solar arrays installed and deployed," Dittemore said.

Thanks to the new electricity-producing solar wings, which stretch 240 feet from tip to tip, Shepherd and cosmonauts Yuri Gidzenko and Sergei Krikalev no longer have to conserve power aboard the space station. They also now have access to the entire three-room complex; one room had been sealed off because there was not enough power to heat it.

Altogether, the solar wings cover half an acre and make Alpha one of the brightest 'stars' in the night sky. Nasa Administrator Daniel Goldin was thrilled to see Alpha fly overhead.

"Fantastic! No binoculars, no telescopes," Goldin said. "It's a symbol of what great accomplishments we've made."

Shepherd and his crew have been aboard the space station for one month and have three more months to go before they return to Earth. Their ride home aboard space shuttle Discovery likely will be delayed a week or two because of damaged thrusters that need to be replaced, Dittemore said.

The next space station visitors will be five astronauts who are supposed to deliver the American-made lab Destiny aboard space shuttle Atlantis in January.

Nasa held off moving Atlantis to the launch pad Monday to inspect electrical connectors for explosive devices used to separate the two solid-fuel boosters from the shuttle during liftoff. One of those devices failed to work during Endeavour's climb to orbit on November 30; a backup charge severed the left booster as planned.

fields.headline: Consumers come first says Smith
fields.standfirst:
Smith talks to MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: communications white paper
fields.trailText:
5pm update: Culture secretary Chris Smith has said viewers and listeners would remain at the heart of all legislation.
Smith talks to MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: communications white paper
fields.body:
Culture secretary Chris Smith has said the communications white paper was written "first and foremost" with consumers in mind with the need to support "dynamic" media and telecoms sector coming "a close second".

Unveiling his blueprint for the future of telecommunications and TV, the minister said viewers and listeners would remain at the heart of all legislation.

Mr Smith stressed the need for strict quality control, saying he wanted to safeguard public service TV including the BBC, Channel 4 and parts of ITV.

"There is a danger that unless we protect public service broadcasting, regional strengths and cultural diversity, that we will end up with cut-price TV and poorer quality," he said.

"What we don't want to see in a multi-channel world is more meaning worse. We want to ensure the framework of protection is retained."

The new regulatory watchdog, Ofcom, will formalise regulation of the internet for the first time.

Mr Smith said it was paramount that parents could confidently allow their children to surf the net safely but admitted it was complicated.

"In new areas like the internet, because of the global nature of the medium, it is more difficult to achieve regulation of this kind.

"Nevertheless, it's important to give parents the tools to protect their children."

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said the government would pave the way for a single ITV company, but he did not envisage it happening for some years yet because of competition rules guarding against one dominant player in the TV advertising market.

Mr Byers said cross-media ownership rules had been reviewed as recently as 1996 but it was time to revisit the subject.

"We do think the time is right to look again," he added.

fields.headline: Relaxation of news provider rules threatens ITN
fields.standfirst: Special report: Communications white paper
fields.trailText:
1.15pm: Rules barring Sky News from providing news to ITV may be scrapped in today's white paper, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Special report: Communications white paper
fields.body:
ITN's contract to provide ITV with its news bulletins could come under serious threat because of changes in the law.

The communications white paper says it will consider scrapping the ownership rules barring Sky News from bidding for the prestigious contract are scrapped.

The government says it is considering relaxing the current law that prevents any single shareholder from having more than a 20% stake in the news company that supplies ITV with its bulletins.

Up to now the rule has frustrated Sky News' attempts to win what has been termed "nominated news provider" status from the Independent Television Commission. This is because Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation owns 37.5% of the satellite company.

Sky News has tried to break ITN's monopoly control on a number of occasions. ITN supplies bulletins for ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5. Last year Sky News came close to winning the renewed Channel 5 contract, but was eventually undercut by ITN.

Although the nominated news provider system is expected to be maintained under the new legislation, it is thought the white paper will make it easier for the government to revoke it, opening it up to competition from commercial networks such as Sky News.

While Sky's chances of winning the flagship contract to provide ITV with its news have always been considered slim, the relaxation of the rules will give fresh impetus to its campaign for change.

New legislation could also spark changes in ownership at ITN itself.

It is currently owned by Carlton, Granada, Reuters, United News & Media and Associated Newspapers but could now be swallowed by one or two media players.
