fields.headline: 'The revolution has just begun'
fields.standfirst:
Culture secretary Chris Smith tells MediaGuardian.co.uk why he thinks the white paper will be a blueprint for the future.
Special report: white paper
Government white paper website
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: Culture secretary Chris Smith tells MediaGuardian.co.uk why he thinks the white paper will be a blueprint for the future.
Special report: white paper
Government white paper website
fields.body:
"The way we communicate with each other has been totally transformed over the last couple of decades. And this communications revolution has only just begun.

"Digital media is bringing hundreds of TV channels in reach of all viewers while TV sets will be used for email, ordering services and goods as well as devising personal viewing schedules.

"Millions of people already have access to the internet through their computers but will increasingly use their televisions, mobile phones and games consoles.

"The government's white paper, A New Future for Communications, sets outs how the UK will make the most of this communications revolution for the British citizen and economy.

"It's a goal that means extending choice for consumers - ensuring the widest possible access to the new opportunities and existing channels while enhancing cultural diversity and improving quality.

"It means making the UK the world's most dynamic and competitive communications market so we continue to create jobs and prosperity but also ensuring it's the safest and most reliable environment to use the new services.

"Achieving these ambitious goals means overhauling a regulatory framework first devised for a handful of TV channels and clear divisions between different forms of communication which have disappeared forever.

"In its place, the white paper sets out a new framework for communications regulation which not only takes account of the developments that we have already seen but those likely in the future.

"It sets out how we will ensure universal access to existing and new services, increase competition and maintain standards.

"The white paper includes measures to:

 Promote access to the internet for all
 Retain public service broadcasting
 Strengthen TV and radio's regional dimension
 Reform ownership rules to reflect increased outlets
 Make more services and channels available to everyone

"The white paper also proposes a new watchdog for the entire communication industry as a single replacement for the many different regulators at the moment.

"Ofcom's role will be to increase consumer choice by promoting competition, to regulate TV and radio and set a framework for standards which will allow flexibility across the industry while protecting the public.

"It's a white paper to ensure we all - individual consumers and the country as a whole - make the most of the benefits from the new digital communicate age."

fields.headline: A strange ringing in the brain
fields.trailText: Tuesday:
fields.body:
Tuesday:

During breakfast, I am surprised to be addressed directly by my wife. "Look at this," she says, pointing to a page in the Telegraph. "That mobile I bought you for your birthday last year, it's top of this league table. Isn't that good?" Yes, I say, but what precisely has it won? She doesn't reply, and only when she moves on to the Mail do I get the chance to check. The Ericsson T28 is top of the mobiles, I read, for radiation emitted.

Wednesday:

Today a gradual change - a strange sense of disorientation and remoteness - is more noticeable, while the short-term memory is appalling. I have ascribed this to the aggregated effects of drink and age, but I'm not so sure. When a professor from Charing Cross hospital, a charming man whom we met once in the summer, rings to ask us to a party, I try to pick his brains. But he says it isn't his field.

Thursday:

Thumpy eyes, taut scalp, sensitised sinews, stiff neck . . . I am struck by the familiar symptoms of some nameless viruses, and midway through walking the dog I am too fatigued to continue. I call the Grove clinic on the mobile. Although things are running smoothly there, and I am kept waiting barely 10 minutes, by the time the receptionist asks me what the problem is, I have forgotten why I rang in the first place.

Friday:

The virus worsens, and I lie beneath a blanket on the sofa, doing what Rebecca calls my "Elizabeth Barrett Browning wan consumptive number". Yet for all the sharpness of her tongue, my wife is astoundingly attentive. She calls 11 times from her office for a bulletin - each time, perplexingly, on my mobile. When it rings for a 12th time shortly after noon, it is my physician, Sarah Jarvis. "Ah, doctor, thanks for calling back," I say, but she replies that I never called in the first place. The doctor chats away for ages before muttering something about wanting to contact someone called Penny but ringing the wrong number - and when I ask if she knows where I might come by a second-hand geiger counter, she hurriedly takes her leave.

Saturday:

A friend who keeps me in touch with cybermedicine emails recom mending an "ask the doctor" feature at AmericasDoctor.com. Although baffled by the home page, I manage to register to be kept up to date with major cancer and cardiac developments. Or so I think. Two hours later, a confirmatory email arrives, thanking me for volunteering and asking me to "ensure you arrive at the University of Wisconsin medical centre promptly by 9.30am on January 27, when the female stress incontinence clinical trial will begin."

Sunday:

Awake feeling dazed and distressed having passed a troubled night. In the dream, my Ericsson T28 goes missing and Rebecca promises to replace it. "Let's go and get the new one now, for your Christmas present," she says. The next I know, we are landing on the Sellafield helipad, where a white-coated Dr Jarvis greets us. "Hurry," she yells over the whirring of blades, "they've only got one Depleted Uranium phone, with WAP and text messaging, left in the shop." Hurriedly, Rebecca pays for the phone. When, within moments of calling the speaking clock, I notice a third eye in the middle of my forehead, I awake.

Monday:

Another troubled night, then a fretful day. Something is plaguing me, and has been for some time, but not until night do I work out what. "Of course, it's that nice professor," I yelp over the Indian takeaway. Rebecca eyes a forkful of Bombay aloo quizzically and asks me to expand. "The professor who asked us to his party . . . don't you think it's odd?" "Why?" "No one ever asks us to a party. Obviously someone's asked him to lure me over so he can examine me. It's a brain tumour, isn't it?" Rebecca snaps a poppadom in two."Remind me," she says, "what exactly he's a professor of?" "I told you before," I snap back, "gynaecology." Finishing her chicken korma, she replaces her cutlery and leaves the room.

fields.headline: The high-flying obsessives
fields.standfirst: What might these three men have in common? Not just brilliance but a form of autism that is only now being recognised in thousands of intelligent people. Karen Gold on the Asperger explosion
fields.trailText: What might these three men have in common? Not just brilliance but a form of autism that is only now being recognised in thousands of intelligent people. Karen Gold on the Asperger explosion.
fields.body:
Remember the child in your class no one ever wanted for their partner? Or that furtive-looking microbiologist in your hall of residence, who never spoke but ended up getting a first? Or your train-spotting ex-boss? You probably dismissed them, more or less sympathetically, as nerds and geeks. But what if the reason they struggled on the social fringes but succeeded academically was because they had the form of autism known as Asperger syndrome?

Asperger syndrome was unheard of 20 years ago. Now it seems to be everywhere. Ludwig Wittgenstein, the philosopher, who designed and made a sewing machine at the age of 10 and was friendless and teased by his fellow students, is thought to have had Asperger. So too is long-haired, green-slippered Albert Einstein, who used to lose his train of thought in the middle of giving a lecture.

Their modern day equivalent, Bill Gates, the Microsoft chief executive and Windows inventor, has been described as having autistic-type traits: lack of eye contact, poor social skills, a monotonous voice, a prodigious memory and a tendency to rock backwards and forwards during business meetings.

Twenty years ago we thought we knew what autistic people were like. They had low IQs and limited language, they behaved bizarrely, and they were put into special schools and residential homes. Autism occurred in about one in 10,000 of the population. Since then, it has been redefined as a spectrum ranging from mild to severe - and with that redefinition has come a massive increase in numbers. Some researchers say one schoolchild in every 70 is now diagnosed with a form of autism, including children with average or higher intelligence and no difficulty learning to speak. These are the ones categorised as having Asperger.

Much of this extraordinary increase is due to teachers and psychologists looking again at children who might have been written off as loners or anti-social, and recognising the typical autistic pattern of social reticence, poor imagination, inability to see into others' minds, emotional blankness, unusual obsessions. But unless something nasty has got into the water, the implication of finding all these extra autistic children is that there have always been large numbers of otherwise ordinary people with this cluster of symptoms, which means that an awful lot of us are walking around with AS and no idea that we have it.

Dr Simon Baron-Cohen, a Cambridge psychologist and autism expert, sees adults making this discovery all the time in his recently established clinic, the first in the country to specialise in late diagnosis of the syndrome. Their GPs have referred them because they fit a set of criteria suggesting that they have had unrecognised AS all their lives.

Some of them are terribly sad, says Baron-Cohen: "We are seeing people in their 20s, 30s and 40s. Many have awful stories to tell about being bullied at school, losing jobs, broken relationships. You see men who have meals and sex with their wives, but they don't have an emotional relationship. Their partners will start saying something that is a clear signal for emotional support, like "I got the results of my tests back from the doctor today" and they will say "Not now, I'm watching the football."

Since the clinic was established, Baron-Cohen has seen more than 50 adults and has a waiting list of another 20. To confirm Asperger, which is always detectable in early childhood, whereas schizophrenia or obsessive-compulsive disorder would appear in the teenage years, patients must, if possible, bring along a parent: "It can be a bit embarrassing, asking an 80-year-old mother if her 40-year-old son used to mix with the other children when he went to playgroup. But quite often you get a really clear picture. They say, 'My child has always been a loner; at school the only people my child talked to were the teachers'. That's a classic."

The majority of clinic attenders are men. (Nine out of ten autistics are male). Half are married or in steady relationships. Their jobs (most are in work) are largely in computing, scientific research, mathematics and engineering. They all have obsessions: "One 35-year-old woman had 2,000 videos and knew the directors of all of them," says Baron-Cohen. "You begin to get a picture of what these people's bedrooms are like."

But one man's obsession is another's life work. Many people with Asperger are high-achievers: one man reads dictionaries and speaks 10 languages; others are at the cutting edge of technology. Not all gain promotion to the level of their qualifications: one draughtsman had won a string of awards for his work, but remained low on the pay scale because he would not allow anyone who worked for him to stop for coffee or conversation.

Some work environments enable people with the syndrome to flourish. Richard Borcherds, professor of maths at Berkeley in California, was 38 and teaching at Cambridge when he won the Fields medal - the equivalent of the maths Nobel prize. He suspected he might have autism after reading an article about it when he was in his 30s and recognised many of its symptoms in himself. Borcherds, who describes himself as "socially inept", knew Baron-Cohen, who assessed him for a study of Asperger high-flyers and diagnosed that he did indeed have AS. Yet his career has certainly not suffered: "I've spent most of my life in universities, where eccentricity is fairly common, which probably made me stand out less. Most maths departments I've been in have at least one person who is clearly weirder than I am."

There are theories that whatever makes the Asperger brain function differently - and the current theory is that the right and left halves of the AS brain have insufficient "central coherence" or pulling-together power to see the overall picture - may also be of benefit in work which requires very precise attention to detail.

People may need to think like this, to a greater or lesser extent, to be the best computer analysts. That does not necessarily mean that all computer analysts have Asperger. But there are weird results from surveys of students and professionals in science and engineering showing that very large numbers - "sometimes more than one in four" - have a close relative with autism. Since autism has a powerful genetic factor, the implication is that the labs are full of people who fit somewhere on the autistic spectrum too.

But if they can live and work with Asperger, why go to the trouble of labelling them? Borcherds believes that for him, diagnosis was fairly pointless: "It might have been useful 20 or 30 years ago; maybe I could have had explicit lessons in social behaviour or something like that. But by now it seems to make little difference."

That is not what the people attending the Cambridge clinic feel, since they or their families - several patients have been sent along by their desperate wives - are by definition seeking some kind of help. Nor is it the view of Clare Sainsbury, daughter of Lord Sainsbury, the Labour peer and science minister, who was 20 and an Oxford philosophy student when she read about Asperger and recognised herself.

She grew up, she says, bullied, depressed, convinced that she was either schizophrenic or an abandoned alien from another planet. She trained herself to perform social smiles in front of a mirror, and got away with parroting back greetings like "hello" and "goodbye" until the awful day when somebody wished her happy birthday.

"Being diagnosed was a huge relief. Finally to have a name for it, to be able to say, 'this is how Clare is and it's not that she's not trying hard enough or being deliberately difficult'. I have been able to stop tortur ing myself, and it has been wonderful for my family because parents often get blamed for their children's behaviour and it must have been very hard for them to defend the way I behaved, even if it didn't conform to other people's ideas of normal."

Viewed from the majority perspective, people who fail to make eye contact are shifty or sinister. Asperger adults are constantly tailed by shop security guards, even though their inflexible mental processes make it unthinkable that they would break the law. Viewed from the perspective of an AS researcher at Yale University, the picture is rather different: "If we are autists, you guys are heterists. The diagnostic features of heterists are making lots of eye contact and overlooking details such as small coins on patterned carpets or car number plates."

Maybe what we need is to value as well as label the differences between the ways our different brains work. Or as Temple Grandin, an American autistic woman whose obsession with cattle pens led her to become the world's expert on humane corralling of cattle cattle, puts it: "What would happen if you eliminated the autism gene from the gene pool? You would have a bunch of people standing around in a cave, chatting and socialising and not getting anything done."

 From the Cambridge Lifespan Asperger Syndrome Service, email sb205@cus.cam.ac.uk

He suspected he might have autism after reading an article about it when he was in his 30s and recognised many of its symptoms in himself. Borcherds, who describes himself as "socially inept", knew Baron-Cohen, who assessed him for a study of Asperger high-flyers and diagnosed that he did indeed have AS. Yet his career has certainly not suffered: "I've spent most of my life in universities, where eccentricity is fairly common, which probably made me stand out less. Most maths departments I've been in have at least one person who is clearly weirder than I am." There are theories that whatever makes the Asperger brain function differently - and the current theory is that the right and left halves of the AS brain have insufficient "central coherence" or pulling-together power to see the overall picture - may also be of benefit in work which requires very precise attention to detail. People may need to think like this, to a greater or lesser extent, to be the best computer analysts. That does not necessarily mean that all computer analysts have Asperger. But there are weird results from surveys of students and professionals in science and engineering showing that very large numbers - "sometimes more than one in four" - have a close relative with autism. Since autism has a powerful genetic factor, the implication is that the labs are full of people who fit somewhere on the autistic spectrum too. But if they can live and work with Asperger, why go to the trouble of labelling them? Borcherds believes that for him, diagnosis was fairly pointless: "It might have been useful 20 or 30 years ago; maybe I could have had explicit lessons in social behaviour or something like that. But by now it seems to make little difference." That is not what the people attending the Cambridge clinic feel, since they or their families - several patients have been sent along by their desperate wives - are by definition seeking some kind of help. Nor is it the view of Clare Sainsbury, daughter of Lord Sainsbury, the Labour peer and science minister, who was 20 and an Oxford philosophy student when she read about Asperger and recognised herself. She grew up, she says, bullied, depressed, convinced that she was either schizophrenic or an abandoned alien from another planet. She trained herself to perform social smiles in front of a mirror, and got away with parroting back greetings like "hello" and "goodbye" until the awful day when somebody wished her happy birthday. "Being diagnosed was a huge relief. Finally to have a name for it, to be able to say, 'this is how Clare is and it's not that she's not trying hard enough or being deliberately difficult'. I have been able to stop tortur ing myself, and it has been wonderful for my family because parents often get blamed for their children's behaviour and it must have been very hard for them to defend the way I behaved, even if it didn't conform to other people's ideas of normal." Viewed from the majority perspective, people who fail to make eye contact are shifty or sinister. Asperger adults are constantly tailed by shop security guards, even though their inflexible mental processes make it unthinkable that they would break the law. Viewed from the perspective of an AS researcher at Yale University, the picture is rather different: "If we are autists, you guys are heterists. The diagnostic features of heterists are making lots of eye contact and overlooking details such as small coins on patterned carpets or car number plates." Maybe what we need is to value as well as label the differences between the ways our different brains work. Or as Temple Grandin, an American autistic woman whose obsession with cattle pens led her to become the world's expert on humane corralling of cattle cattle, puts it: "What would happen if you eliminated the autism gene from the gene pool? You would have a bunch of people standing around in a cave, chatting and socialising and not getting anything done."  From the Cambridge Lifespan Asperger Syndrome Service, email sb205@cus.cam.ac.uk

webTitle: The chaos of Catriona Bass's hospital stay

fields.headline: 'The whole culture of care was crumbling'
fields.standfirst: When Catriona Bass fell off a ladder her troubles were only just beginning. First she lay for 23 hours on a trolley in the corridor, then she waited six days for a back brace. Here she charts the despair and chaos of her hospital stay
fields.trailText: When Catriona Bass fell off a ladder her troubles were only just beginning. Here she charts the despair and chaos of her hospital stay.
fields.body:
What surprised me most about my experience in the John Radcliffe hospital was the anger it inspired in other doctors. "You have to sue," one trauma doctor friend said. "You must write to your member of parliament," a local GP insisted. "You must write to the press." He even thought we needed to adopt something of America's litigious culture to improve the situation. "It's third world!" he said. "Nothing will change unless patients are prepared to complain."

I hadn't expected this from the professionals. For me, as for many people, the virtue of the NHS was an article of faith. I still had an image of valiant doctors and angelic nurses fighting together an ordered campaign against the odds. I cling to this image still. But a week in the orthopaedic/trauma ward of the John Radcliffe makes you painfully aware of the human reality of chronic underfunding. You feel that you are lying somewhere near the bottom of a downward path, where the lines of command and control are breaking down. In your worst moments, it seems that all that survives is the sweet talk of care.

I flew into chaos the moment I arrived by helicopter having fallen from an eight foot ladder on an island in the Thames. Although the paramedics had efficiently radioed ahead to tell the hospital that the helicopter was for logistical reasons rather than resuscitatory, the message had not got through to the trauma team, which had been dragged from other operations to greet me. They vanished in understandable irritation when they saw that I was conscious, instructing the radiographer to x-ray my back.

I saw my spine emerge on a light box attached to the far wall. As I lay there trying to decipher its ominous message, the kindly radiographer kept leaving her job to ask me whether a doctor had seen it yet. Eventually, she pulled the x-rays off the wall and strode out of the room to find someone herself.

The doctor she brought told me that I had fractured a vertebra but I would probably be discharged and advised to take bed rest. In the end, I lay in hospital for six days, waiting for a full torso brace to be fitted and then another five in the Nuffield orthopaedic centre where I had a new brace fitted because the first did not fit. Apparently, the John Radcliffe reverted to making back braces out of unwieldy fibreglass instead of thermo-plastic after the machine for heating the plastic broke and was replaced by one that was too small.

Like others in my ward, I lay for the first 23 hours on a trolley in a corridor in casualty, watching stretchers rolling in. Without a bell and without my friend, who had gone home expecting me to be discharged, I spent an increasingly frantic night trying to get more pain-relief. People were passing but my voice was too small to attract their attention. In their state of overwork, they seemed to adopt a kind of closed look, trying, like waiters in a busy bar, not to catch your eye. I managed to get five people to stop in the space of several hours. After the fifth had said, with swift sympathy like the rest, that he would see what he could do and disappeared, I was desperate. An innocent junior doctor got my explosion: "I've been in pain for hours. I've been told I can have morphine and I can't get anyone to give it to me."

I got my morphine and while I had the nurse's attention, I asked about my hand which was hurting even more than my back. I thought the intravenous line in the back of my hand was causing the pain. The nurse wasn't convinced. She said I had probably hurt it during my fall and showed me the bruises up my arm. But she already had another patient to attend to. I felt I'd had my ration of care. Six weeks later, when the pain was still there, my GP sent me for an x-ray. I had, in fact, broken my hand. Now, three months later, the plaster has been removed and my hand hasn't healed. I will probably have to have an operation.

It is not surprising that such mistakes are made. One nurse I spoke to told me that the John Radcliffe has only a third of staff required. I thought I'd misunderstood her and that she meant that they were understaffed by a third. "No," she said. "We are down by 60%."

The strongest impression I got from my week in the JR was of the destructiveness of chronic underfunding. You felt you were way down a line in which doctors and nurses had been coping with too many people for too long. From the moment of admission you acquired a new persona - you were "a patient": your needs were familiar but impossible to meet adequately, you would therefore be demanding and need placating. What was interesting was how quickly we adopted the role: how quickly the bond between patient and nurse deteriorated into a sense of "them and us". Each time a nurse entered the ward we all sought her attention, not knowing when we were next going to get help.

Indeed, we very quickly sussed the prisoners' dilemma. Everyone rang their bell for me when I was about to vomit, lying flat on my back unable to move and in danger of choking. We all rang our bells when one of us was left painfully stranded on the com mode. After a particularly bad night, during which the 94-year-old woman in the bed next to me had been crying in pain on the bedpan for ages and was then chastised for not having used it, I said to one nurse who had a sense of humour: "Sometimes this feels like a prison."

I kept thinking of something Brian Keenan wrote about his experience as a hostage in Lebanon. According to him, the physical torture was never as bad as the torture of uncertainty. I had found that difficult to believe. But in my ward, the times that people broke down were not when we were in agony but when we were rendered powerless in the face of apparent chance. The woman in the bed next to me was starved all day for an operation and then told, after dinner had passed, that it had been cancelled. She was halfway through breakfast next day when, without warning, the trolley arrived to take her to theatre. They had forgotten to put "Nil by mouth" on the end of her bed. On many occasions, my cup of tea was left beyond my reach. No one had time to help me eat or to work out what I could eat by myself. Eventually, my family brought in food which they fed me and stored in the hospital fridge.

On the fifth day, somebody noticed that I hadn't been given aspirin since my accident despite a danger of blood-clotting. I still had not got my brace. The nurses' reassurances began to seem frighteningly disconnected from reality. Two days running I had been told I would be taken to the plaster room. At lunch-time the nurse would go to find out what was happening. Then the shift would change and I wouldn't hear what she had been able to find and the day would come to an end.

Finally, on the sixth day there was a bus crash outside Oxford and the ward was told to clear 15 beds. I still did not have my brace. The nurses said I'd be more comfortable in the Nuffield - it was a specialist hospital and I'd have a private room because I might be carrying bacteria from JR. I wasn't convinced. Fortunately, as the management was organising my transfer, the consultant appeared and told them that I could not be moved without a brace. That was the necessary spur. Two women arrived from the plaster room, smiling and stressed. As they pushed my bed along it emerged that they had been spending a significant part of the week wheeling patients around the hospital as there weren't enough porters.

It felt like dangerous chaos. Doctors were doing the work of nurses and nurses were doing the portering. For six days I took a precious bed and four people to turn me every few hours because I wasn't fitted with a brace. It was clear that this was no longer a simple question of injection of funds. I had the impression that the hospital had been in this state for so long that the whole culture of care was crumbling, that its efficacy was more often determined by chance, and that it will now take a lot more than money to turn things around.

fields.headline: Clinton tells the peacemakers: 'Keep going'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The US president, Bill Clinton, today urged all sides in Northern Ireland not to give up in the quest for a long-term political settlement to the troubles.
fields.body:
The US president, Bill Clinton, today urged all sides in Northern Ireland not to give up in the quest for a long-term political settlement to the troubles.

He said: "We have to keep going. I do not think reversal is an option."

Mr Clinton went on to indicate that he would be prepared to continue aiding moves towards a permanent peace if requested by whoever won the on-going American Presidential race.

The president Clinton met the Irish Republic's taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, in Dublin in advance of his talks with all sides in Belfast tomorrow, but none of the party leaders expect any major breakdown over the disarmament and policing deadlock threatening the future of the process.

On his third visit to Ireland, Mr Clinton urged those not involved in the process to join and not wreck it - there was too much to be gained. Too much, he said, had already been gained.

The president, commenting after arriving at Dublin's government buildings for discussions with Mr Ahern and other ministers about Northern Ireland issues, said: "I have had a special interest during my tenure in the peace process. The taoiseach (Mr Ahern) and prime minister Tony Blair have worked very hard and there is still a little work to be done. "So I thought maybe if I came back I could help a little bit."

Mr Clinton said he believed the people of Ireland had embraced the peace and were in some ways leading the process.

"And I don't think they want to go back. I think the leadership of the Irish government and the support of the British government have helped, I think the incredible success of the Irish economy has helped.

"I think people can see the benefits of peace and my message to those parties who are not involved in the process is that they ought to join. I reckon there is too much to be gained and too much has already been gained."

The president, quizzed about reports he might become a special peace envoy to Ireland at the end of his term of office next month, replied with a laugh: "I think the new president, whoever it may be, will want to have a new team in place and I will support that - I want to support whatever decisions the new administration takes.

"If I can be a resource I will - if I can ever help the Irish, of course I will. But in terms of my government's representation, that will be entirely up to the new president."

When it was put to him that he really cared about Northern Ireland and the peace process, Mr Clinton answered softly: "Yeah, I do."

He added: "The American people, about 40m of us have some Irish blood and we have also had a unique relationship with Great Britain. They burned the White House, but since then, it's been pretty good.

"We fought two world wars together. The way it used to be was a source of great pain to a lot of Americans. I hope and believe we have changed that over the last eight years.

"So to me it is a question that you have just got to keep going and bringing more and more people in. Because the Irish have proved you can do this.

Mr Ahern said: "the very fact that the president is coming in to help will help people focus on what are still difficulties and to try to narrow down those difficulties and look at the possibilities of what we can do."

Later, Mr Clinton and Mr Ahern enjoyed a reception at Dublin's Guinness Storehouse where Mr Clinton gave a brief address after meeting around 2,000 gathered dignitaries and politicians.

Referring to his role in the Northern Ireland peace process, he said: "I have often wondered how I got involved in all this ...

"Maybe because there are 45 million Irish Americans and I was trying to get a few votes, I don't know. The truth is, it just seemed to be the right thing to do.

"America has suffered with Ireland through the Troubles and even before and we seemed paralysed and prevented from playing a constructive role when I became President.

"I decided to change America's policy in the hope that in the end that not only the Irish, the British too, would be better off."

Recalling the shift in US policy towards Ireland in the first half of the 1990s, Mr Clinton said: "When I started my involvement with the Irish peace process, to put it terribly, half the political experts in my country thought I had lost my mind.

"And (after) some of the all-night sessions I had had ... I thought I had lost my mind."

But he added: "I believe that America has in some tiny way repaid this nation and its people for the massive gifts that your people have given to us over so many years, going back to our beginnings.

"For me one of the things that I will most cherish about the eight years the American people have been good enough to let me serve as president is that I have had a chance to put America on the side of peace and dignity."

The Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams and other top Sinn Fein figures were among scores of politicians to meet Mr linton when he attended a function at the Storehouse.

Mr Adams shook hands warmly with president and embraced his wife Hillary. He said Mr Clinton's "open-handed and encouraging support" could inspire Tony Blair "to get us out of this current dilemma".

And he added: "Before this it [the US government] simply echoed the British line. Whoever wins the election, I cannot see the incoming president abandoning that, going back to the old exclusion."

However, John Bruton, Fine Gael leader and former Irish prime minister, described the visit as a "lost opportunity".

Speaking at the reception, Mr Bruton said: "There would have been moves to break the deadlock (in the peace process) if there had been an intensive process of talks in the two weeks leading up to it."

The Ulster Unionist deputy leader, John Taylor, reacted coolly to the idea of Mr Clinton retaining an on-going role in the peace process, warning there would be "considerable hesitation" among unionists.

"The Democrats are, to a large extent, the captives of the Irish mafia in America - the Kennedy clan, New York, Massachusetts, all that population who are clearly are pro-Irish," he told BBC Radio 4.

fields.headline: BBC escapes regulatory axe
fields.standfirst: Special report: Communications white paper
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: The BBC will get off scot-free when the communications white paper is unveiled this afternoon, writes Jason Deans.
Special report: Communications white paper
fields.body:
The BBC will get off scot-free when the communications white paper is unveiled this afternoon, with both governors and the corporation's independence coming through the regulatory review unscathed.

Quashing speculation that the governors would become accountable to an outside body, Ofcom, for the first time, the white paper is expected to state that the BBC's current role and remit should remain unchanged,

The corporation will, however, be expected to adhere to more stringent public service broadcasting rules than its commercial rivals, sitting at the top of the three-tier system envisaged for regulating all TV services.

Under the new system, regulation will be graduated according to channel. A basic tier of programme regulation governing traditional issues relating to content, including privacy and taste and decenc,y will apply to every channel.

But a more severe code of practice will apply to public services broadcasters - the BBC and Channel 4.

However, in an unexpected move, the governmen will ask the BBC along with commercial broadcasters' public service commitments, to draw up detailed programming policy statements and regulatory arrangements to make the new three-tier system work.

This leaves the BBC board of governors' role as the chief guardian of content across TV and radio untouched.

The BBC is expected to argue that with its programming and operational review for the annual report, and statement of promises to viewers and listeners which is reviewed and updated yearly, it already has effective regulatory mechanisms in place.

The role of the BBC governors as the body responsible for policing the corporation's public service commitments was believed to have been seriously under threat.

fields.bodyText: The BBC will get off scot-free when the communications white paper is unveiled this afternoon, with both governors and the corporation's independence coming through the regulatory review unscathed. Quashing speculation that the governors would become accountable to an outside body, Ofcom, for the first time, the white paper is expected to state that the BBC's current role and remit should remain unchanged, The corporation will, however, be expected to adhere to more stringent public service broadcasting rules than its commercial rivals, sitting at the top of the three-tier system envisaged for regulating all TV services. Under the new system, regulation will be graduated according to channel. A basic tier of programme regulation governing traditional issues relating to content, including privacy and taste and decenc,y will apply to every channel. But a more severe code of practice will apply to public services broadcasters - the BBC and Channel 4. fields.headline: 80,000 new free nursery places pledged
fields.trailText: The government is to create 80,000 new free nursery places next year for three-year-olds, Education and Employment Secretary David Blunkett has announced. The places will be provided in the voluntary, private and local education authority sectors.
fields.body:
The government is to create 80,000 new free nursery places next year for three-year-olds, Education and Employment Secretary David Blunkett has announced. The places will be provided in the voluntary, private and local education authority sectors.

"Nursery education plays a big part in providing children with the pre-literacy and social skills that are essential for their future progress," Mr Blunkett told the Daycare Trust and DfEE's annual conference for early years development and child care partnerships this afternoon.

Mr Blunkett also announced an architecture competition to generate design ideas for new centres under the disadvantaged areas child care initiative. The scheme aims to create 45,000 child care places in around 900 new neighbourhood nurseries in disadvantaged communities.

"These neighbourhood nurseries will offer the best facilities and be designed to the highest possible standards. That's why I'm launching a competition to generate designs for these and other day centres for children," Mr Blunkett said.

"We recognise that families living in our most deprived areas have particular problems with child care. That's why the £203m over the next three years - £46m in 2001-02, £74m in 2002-03, and £83m in 2003-04 - is so important. It will help create over 45,000 childcare places in around 900 new nurseries in the areas that need it most, with further resources also being available to start up and support childminders."

In September, the government pledged a free nursery education place for every three-year-old (whose parents want them to have one) by September 2004. As part of the comprehensive spending review, announced earlier in the year, the government plans to make £986m (£250m in 2001-02; £328m in 2002-03; and £408m in 2003-04) available over the next three years, through direct grant.

The money will be used mainly to fund free early education places for three-year-olds. But it will also support the training and development of nursery teachers and improvements to nursery facilities.

Earlier, Margaret Hodge, minister for employment and equal opportunities, announced funding to help sustain and develop local voluntary pre-school and playgroup projects. Seventeen new projects are to receive funding under a special scheme. The projects cover assistance for groups seeking to expand their services or register for nursery funding, as well as support for administration and financial management.

"We made available £1.75m between 1998 and 2000 to help voluntary pre-schools and playgroups facing financial difficulties," said Mrs Hodge. "More than 1,500 pre-schools have benefited in the first two years of the scheme. I'm pleased to say that after having declined since 1994, the number of playgroup places rose by 5,900 between 1999 and 2000 to 353,100.

While welcoming the announcements, the audience expressed anger at the government's decision last week to allow registered childminders to smoke in front of children and smack them with their parents' consent. Daycare Trust called the decision, which will form part of national child care standards, "an attack on children's rights, their health and safety". Delegates said the government needed to help develop a culture where violence against children was unacceptable. They called for uniform standards, whether in nurseries or in childminders' own homes.

But Mrs Hodge said the government had surveyed parents and found 84% in favour of leaving the issue up to individual parents, in consultation with childminders.

"What we are saying is that the nature of how you discipline a child in what is a different environment in a home than in a child care centre is different," she said. Parents did not want the state to regulate "that intimate relationship" between them and their childminders. The government did not want to create a "nanny state", she said.

webTitle: Social development must focus on individuals

fields.headline: Social development must focus on individuals
fields.standfirst: Only community development programmes focused on individuals can make a real difference, argues Adrian Pancucci of the Peabody Trust
fields.trailText: Comment: Only community development programmes focused on individuals can make a real difference, argues Adrian Pancucci of the Peabody Trust
fields.body:
What do you call someone with no job or no qualifications? No, not the prelude to a bad joke, but a question that a wide range of initiatives are trying to answer. Are they a crippling social burden or the untapped potential that could solve Britain's skill shortage?

Increasing choice and opportunity for people living in deprived communities is a key aspect of current government thinking, yet the effectiveness of conventional education and employment programmes is often limited. Applying a system similar to the ones that failed originally will not address individual needs and goals.

But alternatives do exist. The Peabody Trust and the Prince's Trust are examples of organisations that fund projects that focus on individuals, enabling them to effect positive and lasting change in their own lives and in their communities.

Since 1997, Peabody's Leaders for London programme has used £1.2m from the millennium commission to fund community projects that address issues of education, race and exclusion, health and culture. Another £2.4m from the commission will fund Champions for Change. Staring in January, the programme will target people who have difficulties connecting to conventional learning systems.

Howard Doe, a Peabody project head, said: "People are entitled to a better deal and imaginative solutions are needed if we are to release the reservoir of social capital that exists in this country. Too often people who have underachieved are treated with great arrogance but Peabody's approach is radically different. We help people identify their goals, acquire the direction and confidence they lack and then learn the skills that enable them to realise their ambitions. They then go on to act as beacons in the community and mentors for future participants, showing others in the community that success is an option."

Peabody estimates that 25% to 30% of those who participated in Leaders for London have gone into paid employment and a further 15% into education. Crucially, they have made this move on their own terms, building on the success of delivering their own structured project.

Ginny Lunn, of the Prince's Trust, explains how their approach is similar to Peabody's: "The emphasis of our awards programmes is to help young people develop social responsibility by applying imagination and enthusiasm to help those around them. Projects that lead to personal development and benefit the community at the same time can only reinforce a culture of achievement and aspiration. This is the way to combat neglect and deprivation."

Merlene Wynter is an example of what can be achieved when funding is matched to the individual. Diagnosed with ovarian cancer in 1997, she found that there was little information available to black people about the effects of the intensive chemotherapy treatment she was receiving. By using a £2,000 grant from Leaders for London, she established a support network and newsletter for black women undergoing chemotherapy, a project that also had a massive impact on Merlene herself.

"My project gave me the drive and self-esteem to come out and be active. Cancer sufferers and their relatives are hungry for information but confused by misinformation. Developing a support network has really helped other women come to terms with their illness and it has helped me immensely. It even prepared me for a return to work and I'm now a work preparation officer for Instant Muscle, helping disabled people find jobs. I now have empathy and tact as well as the confidence I need to face new challenges." Merlene's cancer is now in remission.

With a focus on individual needs, funding can go a long way. The UK would then be in danger of another flood - one of talent pouring out of the reservoir it has been held in for too long.

 Adrian Pancucci is a communications consultant working with Peabody Trust and other organisations in the social housing sector.

fields.headline: Vauxhall closes Luton plant
fields.trailText: Motor giant Vauxhall surprised the car industry today by announcing the ending of car production at its Luton plant with the loss of 2,000 jobs - a fifth of its total workforce.
fields.body:
Motor giant Vauxhall surprised the car industry today by announcing the ending of car production at its Luton plant with the loss of 2,000 jobs - a fifth of its total workforce.

The company, owned by General Motors, blamed "rapidly changing" European market conditions and over-capacity for the decision to stop building cars at the Bedfordshire plant. The jobs will go over the next 15 months, with workers offered what the company called a "very reasonable" redundancy package.

Vauxhall made the Vectra at the plant and workers had been assured that that car's replacement would be made at Luton. That work will now be carried out in Germany.

Company chairman Nick Reilly said the decision, taken at the company's European headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, was necessary to retain competitive manufacturing in the UK.

But Luton South MP Margaret Moran told BBC Radio 4's World at One that it was: "A devastating announcement for the local economy, and one which we are going to fight all the way."

Ms Moran said that she had already spoken to the trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers about a possible rescue plan and was confident that the car manufacturing jobs could be kept in the town.

She added: "I think that we will be able to put together a package which will be able to secure most, if not all, of the jobs that we need to in Luton.

"But that doesn't absolve Vauxhall Luton, or GM in particular, of their responsibilities and the assurances which they gave us less than two years ago about the future of the Vauxhall plant." The government itself has pledged a "rapid response".

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union, said: "This is rapidly turning into UK manufacturing's blackest week.

"In the last 24 hours more than 3,500 jobs have been lost in shipbuilding, textiles and car manufacturing. The government must act to prevent the high level of the pound squeezing the life out of Britain's manufacturing heartlands."

Workers too were shocked at the news. Pravin Panchal, 45: "It's going to be a different Christmas for everyone  Everyone's concerned and angry, but what can we do? I feel really unsure about my future."

fields.headline: On the web
fields.standfirst: Shakespeare
fields.trailText: Shakespeare
fields.body:
William Shakespeare

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

It's slightly prosaic and older pupils may find it dull when compared to Surfing with the Bard, but this site has a good collection of links (look under Educational) and archives a substantial amount of Shakespeare criticism.

Surfing with the Bard

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

Excellent and animated site which is particularly useful for students studying Romeo & Juliet and A Midsummer Night's Dream. Teachers can submit or browse lessons, while reluctant pupils have their own section, Shakespeare 101.

Savage Shakespeare

Aimed at: KS4 onwards

A lively discussion board where any Shakespeare-related topics can be discussed freely.

We're making Macbeth

Aimed at: KS2 teachers

Students at Sheffield university helped to teach Macbeth to 10-year-olds at a local primary. Their research report and multimedia journal, which includes audio and video, is reproduced here. Of interest to primary teachers who want to introduce a class to Shakespeare.

Going to the dogs

Aimed at: KS3

Timon of Athens, the Merry Wives of Windsor, Titus Andronicus and As You Like It rendered in cartoon form and starring a cast of dachshunds. According to the artist, "I do these cartoon versions prior to taking my own students to see live theatre. The cartoons give them an idea of the plot so they don't feel lost."

Shakespeare's Globe

Aimed at: teachers

Details of the Globe's education programmes for KS2-5, answers to frequently-asked questions about the theatre and interactive shots of the reconstructed space.

Magnet poetry

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

A simple but effective notion: generate a given number of words at the same frequency as they are used in Shakespeare's plays, then scramble, nudge or pack them and create new sentences. Try it as a warmer activity if your pupils tend to feel uncomfortable with "old- fashioned" language.

Search the works

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

If you can remember a brief phrase but can't recall which play or poem it came from, this search engine will track it down. The drawback is that extracts are not identified, so you will still need to look up the play to find a reference.

Shakespeare.com

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

Informal, commercial site. Good for its queries section, reviews and monthly chronicle of events 400 years ago.

Shakespeare classroom

Aimed at: KS4 onwards

Study questions on various plays and a guide to cinema adaptations from a US postgraduate student. Note that you can also find screen adaptations by searching the comprehensive internet Movie Database

 You can find more Shakespeare sites on Education Unlimited netclass.

 See January 9 issue of educ@guardian for more websites and software.

webTitle: Why Scotland wants its own NHS plan

fields.headline: Why Scotland wants its own NHS plan
fields.trailText: Analysis:There is a strong consensus in Scotland that the country has different health needs from the rest of the UK, and therefore should have its own NHS plan, writes Barbara Millar
fields.body:
Scotland has different health needs and NHS structures from the rest of the UK. This is why doctors, nurses and managers say Scotland deserves its own NHS plan.

There is a strong consensus north of the border that historical, cultural and epidemiological circumstance means that there should be a specifically Scottish solution to Scottish health needs and problems.

"Scotland's health services had a different structure long before devolution," says Dr Lindsay Burley, chief executive with Borders health board.

"There is also quite a significant cultural difference north of the border. For example, we have traditionally been better at recruiting staff, especially doctors, and there isn't nearly so much private practice here."

Dr Charles Swainson, medical director at the Lothian acute trust, says: "Our priorities may be different and we may decide to target our resources in a different way. "The Scottish health plan is about recognising the diversity in the UK. The whole point of devolution was to give more local control over how the resources agreed should be spent.

"We might think it a better long-term health gain to spend money on improving the housing stock than on asthma, or to spend money on improving children's diets or the sexual health of young people rather than on Relenza."

According to Dr Jim Rodger, chair of the Royal College of General Practitioners' Scottish council, Scotland needs its own health plan because the population has traditionally been poorer than England's, leading to a greater reliance on the NHS.

"I believe there is also a stronger feeling for the NHS in Scotland, both by the general public and by health professionals. They are totally committed to the NHS and its principles," he says.

The plan is likely to reflect specific Scottish health needs including high rates of coronary heart disease and lung cancer, as well as issues such as remoteness - Shetland, for instance, is more than 200 miles from the mainland.

Jeremy Taylor, chief executive of Grampian primary care trust, says: "There are much higher levels of morbidity and deprivation in many of these areas. That isn't to say that England doesn't have dreadful problems too. But on a national scale, Scotland can be regarded as having a relatively unhealthy population, compared with the rest of the UK and Europe."

Eight of the 10 most deprived political constituencies in the UK are within Scotland, says James Kennedy, board secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, Scotland. "Types of lifestyle here have to be addressed in the plan."

But while Scotland's NHS plan will be custom-made, few feel it will become radically different from its counterparts in England and Wales, and Northern Ireland.

"I don't think there will be marked differences," says Mr Taylor. "The fundamental principles of the NHS will remain, north and south of the border.

"It is a natural process in medicine, for example, to homogenise. This includes working to guidelines, standards and protocols that are developed nationally and internationally.

"Even if there are different parties in power in Scotland and England, I don't think we will see a radical departure from the basic principles that all political parties espouse."

Dr Swainson adds: "I am keen that we continue to learn from each other as well as celebrate our diversity, although if there are governments of different persuasion we will certainly have to watch things carefully."

Some patients in the border areas use health services in England and vice-versa, says Dr Burley. "If health services were very different this could compromise universality of access and the health areas which sit on the borders would have to face the problems of what to do if there were different sets of rules."

Dr Rodger is not optimistic that there will be much difference at all between the English plan and the Scottish plan, when it is unveiled.

"We had expected that we were going to go our own way in developing health care," he says. "But now we believe we will be dragged back into a UK-wide version."

"I don't think there will be marked differences," says Mr Taylor. "The fundamental principles of the NHS will remain, north and south of the border. "It is a natural process in medicine, for example, to homogenise. This includes working to guidelines, standards and protocols that are developed nationally and internationally. "Even if there are different parties in power in Scotland and England, I don't think we will see a radical departure from the basic principles that all political parties espouse." Dr Swainson adds: "I am keen that we continue to learn from each other as well as celebrate our diversity, although if there are governments of different persuasion we will certainly have to watch things carefully." Some patients in the border areas use health services in England and vice-versa, says Dr Burley. "If health services were very different this could compromise universality of access and the health areas which sit on the borders would have to face the problems of what to do if there were different sets of rules." Dr Rodger is not optimistic that there will be much difference at all between the English plan and the Scottish plan, when it is unveiled. "We had expected that we were going to go our own way in developing health care," he says. "But now we believe we will be dragged back into a UK-wide version."

fields.headline: Catching the runaway train
fields.standfirst:
Amy Vickers examines current internet regulation, the problems involved in legislating for the internet, and what the government can realistically expect to achieve.

Special report: Communications white paper
fields.trailText:
Comment: How will Ofcom go about regulating the internet, asks Amy Vickers.
Special report: Communications white paper
fields.body:
Internet regulation is still very much a grey area and something that is made even cloudier by the global nature of the internet and the pending law deriving from Electronic Commerce Directive from the European Parliament.

The biggest regulatory issue on the internet is that of copyright.

However, with increasing progress being made towards broadcasting TV-like pictures via websites, there is a growing concern that users will gain access to inappropriate programming that is not governed by a watershed.

The need for regulation on the internet can be illustrated by last summer's Big Brother programme, which was broadcast live on the internet.

The producers of the Channel 4 show voluntarily applied television standards, including the 9pm watershed, to govern what video pictures of the reality game show they put out.

The ITC has statutory responsibility to regulate television programmes broadcast over the internet, but not programmes made specifically for the internet.

The ITC has no power, for instance, to stop individuals broadcasting from webcams.

Regulation in this area will be far from straightforward to implement, given the lack of national boundaries for the internet. Any proposals on internet regulation in the white paper will have to take account of European legislation.

The Electronic Commerce Directive, which is currently going through the European Parliament, will provide protection for internet service providers in the event of libel action.

Once the law goes through, ISPs will only be able to be sued for defamation or breach of copyright if they ignore repeated complaints about content.

The Periodical Publishers Association (PPA) wants to see the communications white paper address measures to protect its members' copyright, given that millions of pounds are being lost each year through copyright infringement.

This is what has been achieved so far in internet regulation:

The ITC joined forces with the BSC in October 1999 with a mission to look at ways in which the internet could be regulated by the two bodies.

However, it concluded a few months later that technical solutions to protect consumers existed and might be sufficient.

At the outset there was support for some form of external control from focus groups, but ultimately the consumers polled realised that software can help parental supervision.

Since then, concern has intensified that there is too much contentious material on the internet.

In a recent case a French court stopped Yahoo from selling Nazi memorabilia on its site. Also there are fears that paedophiles lurk in every chat room, following a case in the UK this autumn involving a child abuser posing as a teenager.

However the government proceeds, regulation can no longer be media-specific.

Two years ago the arguments centred on computers versus television. But now the boundaries have been blurred so much so that internet content can be accessed via a PC, TV or even a mobile phone.

The ITC also looked at interactive TV, but concluded that regulation was not workable and the best approach was a light touch and a flexible regulatory approach.

At the time it was said that a new code specifically to cover interactive services was not yet appropriate but could change as the market grows and viewers' use and experience increases.

fields.headline: Egg loses retail marketing director
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: Online bank Egg has lost Tony Anderson, the high-profile marketeer it poached from EasyJet earlier this year. By Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Online bank Egg has lost Tony Anderson, the high-profile marketeer it poached from EasyJet earlier this year.

The move is a blow to Egg, which is under pressure from shareholders to find new revenue streams to subsidise its loss-making online banking operation.

Mr Anderson had been hired from EasyJet to transform Egg's brand from an online bank into a broad-based retailer.

Egg confirmed that Mr Anderson, its retail marketing director, had left last week and that he had not yet been replaced. Mr Anderson declined to comment on his future plans.

It is likely he became frustrated with Egg's changes in business strategy following its disappointing float earlier this year.

Egg's central marketing function has done little advertising for its shopping arm and, at the end of November, admitted it was considering opening high street outlets to boost its brand presence.

With its distinct brand of weird and offbeat advertising, Egg has become one of the best-known brands in the UK, but its heavy £30m ad spend, combined with highly competitive banking rates, helped generate a £115m loss in the nine months to September.

Mr Anderson was originally charged with generating new retail revenues to offset this heavy outlay. In order to make money, Egg has to cross-sell new products to its 1.2m-strong customer base.

Director of brand communications Tony Williams has talked of Egg competing with heavyweight online retail brands Amazon, Tesco and Yahoo.

While at EasyJet, Mr Anderson was responsible for developing the Easy brand from airlines into internet cafes and beyond. He was the right-hand man to owner Stelios Haji-Ioannou.

At Egg he was a victim of the collapse of dot.com stocks which failed to raise Egg the sort of money it expected from its float.

Analysts now believe just 3m people will be banking online by the end of this year, compared with earlier estimates of 5m.

Last month Egg began trialling a service that lets people shop on the net without giving their credit card details with the intention of launching the service next year.

webTitle: Independent watchdog to regulate broadcast ads

fields.headline: Broadcast ads to be regulated by new watchdog
fields.standfirst: Special report: Communications white paper
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: The government has rejected outright attempts by the advertising industry to regulate TV and radio commercials, writes Claire Cozens.

Special report: Communications white paper
fields.body:
The government has rejected outright attempts by the advertising industry to regulate TV and radio commercials.

Under the proposals unveiled in today's communications white paper, the new umbrella watchdog, the Office of Communications, will take principal responsibility for regulating advertising in the broadcast media.

The news will come as a disappointment to the advertising industry, which had been lobbying for a self-regulatory system for broadcast advertising.

However, it will be welcomed by consumer groups who believe advertisers should remain independently regulated.

Under the existing system, the Independent Television Commission is responsible for regulating all television advertising, while the Radio Authority oversees all radio commercials.

But all print and poster advertising is policed under a self-regulatory body, the Advertising Standards Authority, which is industry-funded.

The ASA has been criticised in the past for being a lame organisation.

Earlier this year the Advertising Association, the industry body that represents the UK's advertisers, submitted proposals for broadcast advertising to be controlled on the same regulatory basis as press and posters.

The AA believed the convergence of broadcasting and telecommunications would create a need for more flexibility and speed, which only a self-regulatory system could provide.

The white paper will also set out plans to keep the existing controls on religious advertising and programmes. And the current ban on political advertising on television will also remain in place.

fields.headline: Hamilton case 'too flimsy to answer'
fields.trailText: Neil Hamilton's case for depriving Mohamed Al Fayed of his cash for questions libel victory was "so flimsy" that it did not require factual rebuttal, the court of appeal heard today.
fields.body:
Neil Hamilton's case for depriving Mohamed Al Fayed of his cash for questions libel victory was "so flimsy" that it did not require factual rebuttal, the court of appeal heard today.

Mr Hamilton had sued the Harrods boss over claims made in a January 1997 Channel 4 Dispatches programme that he had corruptly demanded and accepted cash payments, gift vouchers and a free holiday at the Paris Ritz in return for asking parliamentary questions on behalf of Harrods.

Opening his case on behalf of Mr Fayed, Michael Beloff QC said that it was recognised as a fundamental principle of the common law that where a litigant had obtained a judgment in a court, he was entitled not to be deprived of it without "very solid grounds".

Mr Beloff said: "The grounds for depriving Mr Fayed of the jury verdict are not only not solid - they are indeed on their very face so flimsy as not to require factual rebuttal."

He also told Lord Phillips, the master of the rolls, Lord Justice Sedley and Lady Justice Hale that they should reject Mr Hamilton's application to admit fresh evidence about allegedly stolen legal documents and refuse him permission to appeal the jury verdict - without hearing evidence from Mr Fayed himself.

Even if the appeal judges were to find that the trial judge, Mr Justice Morland, and the jury were misled a year ago, the most that 51-year-old Mr Hamilton would be entitled to was a retrial, Mr Beloff said. "It would certainly not be in the public interest for him to obtain a verdict in his favour at this particular juncture."

Earlier, Mr Hamilton and his wife Christine listened as Mr Hamilton's counsel, Anthony Boswood QC, said that Mr Fayed was "like one of those Olympic athletes who has been found to have cheated after receiving his medal".

He added: "He should be deprived of his medal and banned for life."

Mr Boswood said that the verdict should be set aside and judgment entered for Mr Hamilton, who would have to consider whether to pursue damages, given his acceptance that such a judgement would not clear his name.

The costs orders imposed on Mr Hamilton, who faced "imminent bankruptcy", should also be set aside and Mr Fayed ordered to pay his costs, he said.

Dismissing the allegations as a pack of lies, Mr Hamilton faced an estimated £2m costs bill at the case's close, but claims that he would probably not have lost if the judge and jury had known that Mr Fayed was involved in paying £10,000 for legal documents stolen from dustbins outside the chambers of Mr Hamilton's lawyers.

Mr Fayed, who denies the allegations, was guilty of "gross impropriety" sufficient to invalidate the trial, said Mr Boswood.

The court should attach no weight to his bare denial without him undergoing cross-examination, he said.

Mr Boswood said: "This is a case of procedural fraud or collateral fraud or abuse of process of the utmost seriousness involving theft of counsel's prodigiously detailed notes for cross-examination of the very witnesses whose corroborative evidence the judge evidently considered of prime importance to Mr Fayed's case."

The appeal court, he said, could not simply decline to act on the grounds that they were immaterial and that Mr Fayed would have won anyway.

The hearing continues.

fields.headline: The new regime
fields.trailText:
2.15pm: A super-regulatory body, Ofcom, will replace the separate regulatory bodies for radio and television, reports Jason Deans.
Special report: Communications white paper
fields.body:
The Broadcasting Standards Commission, the Radio Authority and the Independent Television Commission will be scrapped, Culture secretary Chris Smith will confirm today.

In their place will be a new super-regulatory body, Ofcom, which will combine "expertise and vision to understand the converging communications landscape".

As anticipated, Ofcom will inherit regulatory activities currently carried out by bodies including the Independent Television Commission, the Broadcasting Standards Commission, Oftel and the Radio Authority.

It will also be given powers to entertain complaints about the BBC, acting as an independent ombudsman for aggrieved viewers and listeners who feel dissastisfied with the BBC's internal complaints system.

This will be the first time an outside body has dealt with complaints about the BBC.

Ofcom will also have beefed up powers to regulate competition in the communications sector.

"As competition becomes more pervasive, we will expect it to rely more on these general powers than on specific sectoral ones," said one source.

The regulator will have additional powers to govern spectrum allocation, a job currently done by the Radiocommunications Agency, an outpost of the Department of Trade and Industry.

The remit of the new regulator will also include:

 The power to ensure that public service broadcasting channels are given due prominence on electronic programme guides.

 Responsibility for maintaining content standards in the electronic media. A new ratings and filtering system designed to help parents protect children will be introduced.

 Responsibility to commission audience research, currently undertaken by the BSC, to ensure the public interest is reflected on our screens

 The power to investigate complaints of unfair treatment or unwarranted privacy.

 Powers, similar to those held by Oftel, to intervene when the industry does not meet its obligations to consumers.

webTitle: Back in Belfast: Clinton revisits the peace process

fields.headline: Back in Belfast: Clinton revisits the peace process
fields.standfirst:
Home truths expected from president who may seek to retain peacemaker role when he leaves White House, writes Derek Brown
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Home truths expected from president who may seek to retain peacemaker role when he leaves White House, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton is sure of a warm welcome in Ireland today, though he has no quick-fix solution for the faltering peace process.

Instead, the US president is likely to offer some uncomfortable home truths about the urgent need for compromise. He has already talked of the need to purge "the lingering demons of the past" - a perceptive phrase to apply to a land obsessed with ancient grievances.

Intriguingly, a White House aide has spoken of a future role for Clinton in the peace process after he steps down from the presidency next month. Certainly he has already demonstrated his commitment to a lasting peace, throwing his formidable weight behind the Good Friday agreement.

Now that agreement is again under intense strain. The unionists are frustrated and angry about the failure of the IRA to disarm. The republicans are furious about being excluded from the all-Ireland ministerial council and about the dilution, as they see it, of police reforms.

There is a new word for the impasse: sequencing - or, more correctly, the lack of it. The theory apparently is that a move by one side will allow the other side to respond, and lead to a sequential chain of compromise.

The problem is of course that neither side is prepared to take the first vital step. That is where Clinton comes in. If he can use his personal and presidential prestige to nudge the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, and the Sinn Fein leader, Gerry Adams, to the starting line, there may yet follow some sequencing.

British and Irish officials are understandably playing down any suggestion of a breakthrough. That, they say, is not what the Clinton visit is about. But both governments also have a crucial responsibility for restoring momentum to the peace process.

The British government in particular has some tough decisions to take on security. Republican anger over the toned-down reforms of the Royal Ulster Constabulary is genuine, and it is shared by the more pragmatic nationalists of the Social Democratic and Labour Party.

The problem is that a more radical shake-up of the RUC would infuriate Trimble's Ulster Unionists and risk them losing more support to Ian Paisley's anti-Good Friday agreement Democratic Unionists.

Sinn Fein, meanwhile, has found another security issue to complain about. It claims that the British government has reneged on its pledge to "demilitarise" border areas of Northern Ireland, especially South Armagh which is rabidly republican.

The army top brass are said to be outraged by the idea of a unilateral pullback which, given the deep-rooted hostility to the unreformed RUC in the area, would effectively hand it to the undisputed control of the IRA.

Interestingly, Clinton has chosen to make a keynote speech tonight in Dundalk, south of the border and adjacent to South Armagh. He will likely implore the IRA to make a palpable move towards disarmament and warn anti-peace breakaway factions that they will face the wrath of America if they try to pursue a military campaign.

Dundalk is widely seen as the main power base of the small but dangerous Real IRA and Continuity IRA groups, both pledged to continue the armed struggle for a united Ireland.

Tonight, the US president will progress to Belfast, where there will doubtless be some plain speaking with first minister Trimble about the need to face down the Ulster Unionist hardliners and act boldly to preserve the Good Friday deal.

A great deal of the visit, however, will be out of doors, as the president indulges his passion for flesh-pressing walkabouts and "informal" town meetings. That is no bad thing, for it will remind people on both sides of the border just how much they owe to the American leader.

More, it could concentrate their minds on how little time he has got to contribute, as president, to the fragile peace. For there is little doubt that the next US president, whoever it turns out to be, will have less time and less inclination to pursue that cause.

webTitle: Relaxation of cross-media ownership rules fails to materialise

fields.headline: No relaxation of cross-media ownership rules
fields.standfirst: Special report: Communications white paper
fields.trailText:
2pm: A long-awaited relaxation of cross-media ownership rules has failed to materialise. By Dan Milmo.

Special report: Communications white paper
fields.body:
The long-awaited relaxation of cross-media ownership rules has failed to materialise in today's communications white paper.

Instead, the Department for Trade and Industry will "invite comments" on reforming the guidelines, which include a ban on newspaper owners with a market share of 20% or more from holding an ITV, Channel 5 or radio franchise.

Industry observers hoped the paper would introduce the principle of "share of voice", allowing companies to straddle all forms of media.

This would have allowed the combination of broadcast audience and advertising share and newspaper circulation figures into a single points system.

However, it appears that the government has been caught between big media players who wanted more flexible rules, and the smaller companies who wanted protection from predators.

The uncertainty has filtered through to proposed changes in newspaper and radio guidelines, which were the focus of stiff lobbying from interested parties.

The DTI said it will "consider a lighter approach for newspaper mergers", after current guidelines effectively scuppered the Daily Mail and Daily Telegraph's chances of buying the Express newspaper group.

Both newspapers would have been referred to competition watchdogs, hampering the chances of a quick deal.

Commercial radio broadcasters will also be left frustrated, as the document delivered vague promises on changes to ownership guidelines.

fields.bodyText: The long-awaited relaxation of cross-media ownership rules has failed to materialise in today's communications white paper. Instead, the Department for Trade and Industry will "invite comments" on reforming the guidelines, which include a ban on newspaper owners with a market share of 20% or more from holding an ITV, Channel 5 or radio franchise. Industry observers hoped the paper would introduce the principle of "share of voice", allowing companies to straddle all forms of media. This would have allowed the combination of broadcast audience and advertising share and newspaper circulation figures into a single points system. However, it appears that the government has been caught between big media players who wanted more flexible rules, and the smaller companies who wanted protection from predators. The uncertainty has filtered through to proposed changes in newspaper and radio guidelines, which were the focus of stiff lobbying from interested parties.
