webTitle: UK to take US-style approach to regeneration

fields.headline: UK to take US-style approach to regeneration
fields.standfirst: Business improvement district schemes have transformed urban wastelands in the US and Canada. They are the inspiration behind five projects aiming to make their areas safer, cleaner and more prosperous places, which launch in London next year.  David Harding examines the plans
fields.trailText: Business improvement district schemes have transformed urban wastelands in the US and Canada. They are the inspiration behind five projects aiming to make their areas safer, cleaner and more prosperous places, which launch in London next year. David Harding examines the plans
fields.body:
Most ideas from the US eventually end up on this side of the Atlantic. And, next April, a regeneration scheme similar to ones which have radically transformed run-down areas in major cities across the US and Canada will take its first tentative steps here.

On April 1, five local improvement partnerships in London will receive almost £5m of government funding between them. Their aim is to make parts of Paddington, Holborn, the South Bank and Lambeth safer, cleaner and more prosperous places to work and live. Between them, they will also seek to re-train local unemployed and begin community-based programmes to help the homeless and those with drug addictions. If successful, such schemes could spread nationwide.

Patricia Brown, chief executive of the central London partnership - the organisation overseeing the establishment of the schemes - said the aim of the partnerships is to give "a little tender loving care for each area". One of these, the Holborn business partnership, seems to take more than its fair share of inspiration from the ultra-successful business improvement district schemes (Bids) in the US.

Crucially, the Holborn scheme will be led by business. Although money and ideas will come from the public sector, the private sector provides the main impetus.

The board has a majority of members drawn from the corporate world. The chairman, Geoffrey Lander, is a partner from the legal firm Nabarro Nathanson. "It's regeneration but the difference is that it is corporate led," said Mr Lander.

With other Holborn-based companies, such as Warner Bros and Cable and Wireless, it aims to raise "millions" of private sector pounds to pour into the area, "through the big corporates putting their hands in their pockets", explained Mr Lander.

The companies unashamedly admit they are acting out of self-interest. "We are not trying to say we are altruistic," added Mr Lander. They want to make the area safer for employees and more attractive for clients and investment. The wider benefit, so the argument goes, is that if an area is safer, cleaner and more prosperous, everyone benefits, not just business.

Such a point of view may seem alien to UK tastes, and reminiscent of "trickle-down" economics, but it has certainly proved successful in the US.

There, Bids have transformed urban wastelands. Their most obvious success has been in New Yorkcity where they have helped in the fight against "grime and crime" to beautify previously declining areas such as Grand Central Station and Times Square.

They first emerged in the late 1970s. Now the city has more than 130 Bids, and the US has more than 1,000 Bids in total as other cities such as San Francisco and Philadelphia spotted their potential.

Where they were first established it was at businesses' frustration with federal and local government to reverse the decline in American cities. They work through businesses in a given area coming together and forming a district plan. If that plan is approved by a majority of companies then they agree to impose a tax on themselves, which goes into regenerating their area. This area can cover one street, a block or a city centre. This tax will then be spent on projects such as hiring private security, cleaning up graffiti or clearing up gum from the pavements.

"Business improvement districts in New York city effectively provided much-needed resources to spruce up local neighbourhoods when the city's fiscal and management capability was under strain," said Rosemary Scanlon, former deputy state comptroller for New York city.

"Collectively, Bids have led the renewal of New York city, there's no doubt about that," said Tony Travers, of the London School of Economics' Greater London group.

And they are not limited to the business districts. There is a Bid in Manhattan's run-down Lower East Side and in Harlem (the 125th Street Bid). Bryant Park, just off Fifth Avenue has been transformed, with the help of $10m of private sector money, from a disused six-acre stretch of land that averaged 10 rapes and 150 robberies a year into a park that hosts fashion shows and open-air cinema and attracts 10,000 visitors daily.

Their success has long prompted envious glances from the UK.

Patrick Jenkin, the former Tory environment secretary, now Lord Jenkin of Roding, failed in an attempt to push through a private members' business improvement districts bill in 1998. Last year the Commons environment, transport and regions committee urged ministers to use Bids.

Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott has been to see Dan Biederman, the man seen as New York's Mr Bid, to see if they could work over here.

Another scheme, British business parks, begun in Walsall in 1992, has now stretched beyond the West Midlands. Again, this uses voluntary payments from the corporate sector to improve security and cleanliness on industrial estates.

Now the government's urban white paper, published in November, has promised to look into the possibility of establishing Bids in the UK.

Yet, ministers remain hesitant. Although they have allowed for a limited supplementary rate to be raised through local taxes, they are still reluctant to give over wholesale mandatory tax powers to businesses for local regeneration.

Bids have also attracted some criticism. One fear is that they gentrify areas to such a degree that vibrant areas become sterile. This is a criticism levelled at New York's Times Square. Also, there is the worry that far from solving problems, Bids are merely displacing them, pushing issues such as homelessness into adjacent neighbourhoods.

And many of them arose from a complete lack of faith in the public sector in the US. Here, to exclude councils from regeneration would hardly prove consistent with the government's partnership mantra.

But despite government indecision, the shadow of Bids remains on British regeneration policies. Next April could prove vital in breaking that indecision.

fields.headline: Career advice for Clinton
fields.standfirst:
As the outgoing US president considers a future as a peace envoy, foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall offers some further suggestions

Special report: US election
fields.trailText: As the outgoing US president considers a future as a peace envoy, foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall offers some further suggestions
fields.body:
As Bill Clinton arrives in Ireland for one last foreign trip as US president, questions are being raised about life after the White House.

American taxpayers have been picking up the bill for Bill since 1982. That's when William Jefferson Clinton became governor of Arkansas. He has been on the public payroll ever since.

Now that the political gravy train is nearing its terminus, how will Bill keep himself in the manner to which he has become accustomed? What will he do?

At age 54, it's a bit late to start a new career. Bill originally trained as a lawyer (which certainly helped when the Monica scandal blew). He could try the law again - he's certainly had plenty of experience telling porkies. Why not get paid for doing it on other people's behalf?

He could become a house-husband, making sure the barbecue is fired up when Hillary comes home from a hard day on Capitol Hill. But the image of Bill in a frilly apron, toasting fork in hand, doesn't quite convince. He'd be sure to get bored and start propositioning the cleaning lady.

The William J Clinton School of Jogging is another possibility. The idea would be to make people who are embarrassed about their appearance and ashamed to expose their bodies in public feel better about themselves.

After all, who could look worse than podgy Bill, the western world's top tubby, shambling down Washington's Mall in a naff baseball cap?

Another possible future career could come in publishing. There are lucrative kiss 'n' tell memoirs to be written. There are lectures to be given. And given his various capers over the years, there have to be limitless possibilities in adult magazines and video markets.

As long as he keeps his kit on. That famous, Paula Jones- alleged physical peculiarity or "distinguishing characteristic" affecting his wedding tackle must remain a mystery forever. Please.

But surely, two terms as US president must qualify a chap for something in the professional line.

Some say he may become a sort of permanent US envoy to Ireland - a guardian of the peace process. People who suggest such things clearly don't like the Irish very much.

Bill in Londonderry, Belfast and Dublin had rarity value: one visit every three years was about right. But imagine being on the receiving end of the Clinton charm every day! You've got to pity Hillary.

"Hiya, guys! How y'all doin'? What's with this decommissioning shit, Gerry? I mean, hey Dave, you gotta keep peace alive, man. Well, hello there Peter M. You can join my military any day of the week, know what I mean!"

Speculation has been proliferating in New York that Bill could run for mayor. Current incumbent Rudy Giuliani says that if that happens, he'll have seen it all. Giuliani is retiring due to health problems. But with Clinton looming, folks in the Big Apple may insist he stays, dead or alive.

Saddam Hussein has not been asked for his suggestions as to Clinton's future role. But unofficial Iraqi sources suggest Bill would make a very fine human shield next time the US decides to bomb Iraq's weapons installations.

This idea probably appeals to both Al Gore and George W Bush, not to mention the US air force.

Slobodan Milosevic, the freedom-loving former Yugoslav president, has definite plans for Bill. He had him indicted for international war crimes in Kosovo and Serbia and wants him put on trial along with Tony Blair, Jacques Chirac and Robin Cook.

This idea probably appeals to everybody.

But all of these suggestions ignore the obvious. Bill has always been a very religious man. He goes to church most Sundays. He speechifies like a Bible-basher. He has always used politics as a pulpit.

After eight years in Washington, he knows all about hell and purgatory. And he has almost unrivalled experience of seeking forgiveness for sins.

Think about it. Everybody knows John Paul is on his last legs. There's a vacancy coming up in Rome. Converting to Catholicism is no problem - hey, we're all ecumenical now. And what an inspirational figure Bill would be - a potent, post-impeachment symbol of redemption and resurrection.

Yup, that's it. Bill for Pope. Gotta be.

webTitle: Many families still struggle to find affordable childcare

fields.headline: Many families still struggle to find affordable childcare
fields.standfirst: There is a long way to go before we can confidently say that a childcare revolution has begun, says Stephen Burke, director of the Daycare Trust
fields.trailText: Over the last three years, the child care gap has closed significantly - in just three years, it has reduced from one place for every nine children under the age of eight to one place for every 6.9 children.
fields.body:
Over the last three years, the child care gap has closed significantly - in just three years, it has reduced from one place for every nine children under the age of eight to one place for every 6.9 children.

The child care tax credit is now helping three times as many families on lower incomes pay for child care. The pace of development and change is arguably faster than in any other area of social policy.

But we are only at the beginning. The childcare revolution is still invisible to most parents in the country. Every day parents call our helpline searching for financial help or simply saying that no child care is available where they live.

Child care is the crucial missing link in our communities. The child care revolution we talk about can be compared to the 1880s when schools became available to all or the 1950s when health care became available to all. We must ensure that child care is built into the infrastructure of this country like many of our European neighbours.

Last week, Daycare Trust with the support of the Commission for Racial Equality published a new report on the child care needs of black and minority ethnic children. It shows the big gap still facing many families.

Parents who work shifts find it almost impossible to find registered child care. Children with special needs still have very few child care services. Student parents often struggle to find affordable care at or near their college.

Places for children under three are in short supply even if you can afford high fees. And many families living in some of our most disadvantaged communities can't access services at all.

The numbers of children going into local authority care are rising rapidly and many are entering the care system at a younger age. Quality child care services for all must be part of the solution to give children a better start in life and to support families.

That's why we have all got to think big. Daycare Trust is launching a five-point Thinking Big plan, which sets out a realistic agenda that can be achieved by the year 2010:

A sustainable child care place for every child who needs one, whether you live in the town or the country. More help paying for child care by promoting and reviewing the child care tax credit. A fully trained, properly rewarded workforce to deliver quality services.

Making sure child care is at the top of the agenda of all those we do and could work with - in local authorities, regeneration, housing, employers, Sure Start, NHS trusts and others.

Daycare Trust has warmly welcomed the Government's disadvantaged areas child care initiative and its plan for 900 new neighbourhood nurseries.
We have also welcomed the new national arrangements under Ofsted for regulating and inspecting child care. We welcome the prospect of consistent standards across the country to help parents choose child care that will benefit their children.

But we are appalled that the Government has decided to press ahead with its plans to allow childminders to smack children and smoke in their presence. Caring and smacking don't go together.

Parents need to know that child care is quality child care, where their children will learn, thrive and play safely. Most fundamentally, this is an attack on children's rights, their health and their safety.

Child care is the key to the future. Let's set our sights high. Let's work flat out for quality services that unlock the potential of all our children, for quality services that support parents to work and boost family income, and for quality services in every neighbourhood that build a fairer society where everyone has a better chance in life.

webTitle: SRH calls in advisers for strategic review

fields.headline: SRH strategic review could lead to sale
fields.standfirst:
Dec 8: SRH advises shareholders to hold fire
Dec 8: Scottish Media Group sparks radio acquisition spree
fields.trailText:
10.30am: Scottish Radio Holdings has appointed advisers for a strategic review that could lead to its sale, writes Dan Milmo.

Dec 8: SRH advises shareholders to hold fire

Dec 8: Scottish Media Group sparks radio acquisition spree
fields.body:
Scottish Radio Holdings, owner of Radio Clyde and Radio Forth, has appointed advisers for a strategic review of the company, which could lead to the sale of the coveted broadcaster.

SRH confirmed its place at the forefront of consolidation in UK radio by hiring investment bank Goldman Sachs to look at the company's options in the light of the government's communications white paper, out at 3.30pm today.

If the paper recommends the relaxation of radio station ownership rules then Scottish rival Scottish Media Group, which bought a 14.9% stake in Scottish Radio Holdings last week, could pounce on the whole company.

A Scottish Radio statement confirmed that the "implications" of the white paper will feature in the strategic review.

In the event of a sale, SRH would want the highest price possible. Sources at the company say it is unlikely to "roll over" if SMG comes in with further offers.

Smaller radio companies are set to become prey to the likes of Emap, Capital Radio and GWR, which have the financial firepower to reduce the current 12 major radio companies to just three.

webTitle: Ofcom to take charge of internet content standards

fields.headline: Ofcom to tackle internet content standards
fields.standfirst: Special report: Communications white paper
fields.trailText:
12.30pm: The new unified regulatory body, Ofcom, is to take on responsibility for electronic media content standards, writes Amy Vickers.
Special report: Communications white paper
fields.body:
The new unified regulatory body, Ofcom, is to take on responsibility for electronic media content standards and develop codes where appropriate to support policies on internet content.

The white paper pays lip-service to new delivery mechanisms and says the way in which broadcasting is regulated and delivered will have to change to reflect these new operating conditions.

The most important message being put out from Ofcom about the internet is that it aims to achieve universal access to the internet by 2005.

Ofcom will also extend its role in tackling illegal material on the web and promote ratings and filtering systems to help internet users control what content they and their children are exposed to.

The bottom line, though, is that self-regulation is going to be the only way forward for the internet.

fields.headline: Single ITV gets go-ahead

fields.trailText:
12.45pm: The government will pave the way for a single ITV today, sweeping aside a 45-year-old system of regional television, write Lisa O'Carroll and Dan Milmo.
Special report: Communications white paper
fields.body:
The government will dramatically pave the way for a single ITV company today, sweeping aside the last vestiges of a 45-year-old system of regional television.

The communications white paper, to be published later today, will scrap the current rule that bars any one ITV company controlling more than a 15% share of the total TV audience.

It will also do away with the law that bars any one company owning the two London franchises.

This will open the way for Carlton to own both its London weekday franchise and the LWT weekend licence, currently owned by Granada.

And it would now be possible for both Carlton and Granada to consolidate their existing franchises into one single powerful ITV company operating in England.

The white paper will also confirm the demise of TV watchdogs and regulators in the commercial sector.

The Broadcasting Standards Commission and Independent Television Commission will both be scrapped and subsumed under a new umbrella regulator called Ofcom.

Critics will say the demise of ITV as a network of 15 individual TV stations will be a blow for plurality and diversity.

However, the government will try to reassure viewers' interests by putting consumer interests at the heart of Ofcom.

It hopes to see legislation on the statute books by 2003.

The government is also considering scrapping the rules barring any one company owning more than 20% of ITN.

The proposals on the single ITV company have not won the wholehearted approval of the City.

One analyst said: "It is certainly not what people are looking for in terms of opening the way for a single ITV. We were looking for something more specific on share of audience."

webTitle: Regulatory structure before the white paper

fields.headline: The old regime
fields.standfirst: How the UK media industry has been regulated up until now
fields.trailText: 1pm: How the UK media industry has been regulated up until now.
fields.body:
BBC BOARD OF GOVERNORS

Who heads it
Chaired by Sir Christopher Bland. The former LWT chairman has held the post since April 1996. How many employees?
The BBC has 12 governors, including the chairman. They are appointed by the Queen on recommendation from government ministers on a part-time, non-executive basis. What is its current remit?
It is responsible for ensuring the BBC is accountable to Parliament, licence payers and audiences. Governors hold BBC management to account for their performance against agreed strategy and objectives, including compliance with the BBC Charter. The governors also appoint the BBC director general and other senior managers. They meet monthly. How long have the BBC governors been in existence?
Since January 1 1927, when the British Broadcasting Company became the British Broadcasting Corporation.

INDEPENDENT TELEVISION COMMISSION

Who heads it?
Chief executive Patricia Hodgson heads the ITC's full-time staff. The former BBC director of public policy joined the commercial TV sector regulator at the start of September. Sir Robin Biggam is chairman.
How many employees?
There are 200 full-time staff, but around 20 posts are expected to go as part of restructuring in anticipation of white paper. The commission itself has 11 members, including Mr Biggam, who are appointed by the secretary of state for Culture, Media and Sport.
What is its remit?
It is responsible for licensing and regulating the programming and advertising on UK commercial TV services, including ITV, Channel 4, Channel 5 and cable and satellite channels. The commission itself meets monthly . The regulator's permanent staff monitors UK commercial TV output, processes viewer complaints and handles day-to-day relations with broadcasters.
How long has the ITC been going?
The ITC took over regulating commercial TV from the Independent Broadcasting Authority on January 1 1993.

ADVERTISING STANDARDS AUTHORITY

What is its remit?
The ASA is the regulatory body for all non-broadcast ads that appear in the UK. Its duty is to ensure that they are "legal, decent, honest and truthful". It is independent of both the government and the advertising industry, and its work is funded by a levy on advertising and direct mail expenditure. However, it is widely seen as toothless, making decisions long after controvserial poster campaigns have gone.
Who heads it up?
The ASA is chaired by Lord Rodgers of Quarry Bank. The director general is Christopher Graham, a former BBC executive.
How many employees?
70
How long has it been around?
The ASA was set up in 1962.

BROADCASTING STANDARDS COMMISSION

Who heads it?
The resignation of Lord Holme in October following a sex scandal has left it without a head.
How many staff?
It employs 30 staff. In addition there are 13 commissioners who make judgements on complaints and strategy.
Its remit
The BSC writes codes of guidance on standards of taste and decency, impartiality and privacy covering the whole broadcasting landscape, taking in satellite, cable and terrestrial television and radio. It has some statutory powers to force broadcasters to apologise when they get it seriously wrong, particularly when it comes to invasion of privacy.
When was it established?
The Broadcasting Standards Commission was formed from the merger of the Broadcasting Complaints Commission and the statutory body, the Broadcasting Standards Council, in 1998.

OFTEL

Who heads it?
David Edmonds, director general of communications.
How many employees?
197.
Its remit
Oftel is the watchdog for the UK telecoms industry, ensuring that customers get the best deals in terms of quality, choice and value for money. The best way to do this has been through ensuring a healthy level of competition between telecoms companies, leading to recent clashes with BT over opening up telephone exchanges for high-tech broadband internet services.
When was it founded?
1984

RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS AGENCY

Who heads it?
David Hendon, chief executive.
How many employees?
550.
Its remit
The Radiocommunications Agency manages radio frequencies in the UK, operating within the Department of Trade and Industry. It ensures that there is enough space on the airwaves for commercial radio, mobile phones and wireless broadband services. It also negotiates with European counterparts to arrange harmonisation of frequencies.
When was it founded?
1990.

webTitle: Academic staff study shows increase in short term contracts

fields.headline: Academic staff study shows increase in short term contracts
fields.trailText: AUT researcher, David Watson, reveals glaring disparities between the employment practises of universities and colleges.
fields.body:
Previous research carried out by the Association of University Teachers has revealed that casual employment in the academic sector has grown rapidly in recent years with, for example, three out of four new academic appointments now made on a fixed-term basis.

This report looks at trends in casual employment in more depth by comparing Higher Education Statistics Agency data for 1998-99 with that for 1994-95. The analysis considers trends for individual universities and colleges.

The main findings are:

The proportion of research staff on fixed-term contracts marginally increased between 1994-95 and 1998-99, despite the introduction in 1996 of the Concordat, which aimed to improve the careers of contract research staff.

Between 1994-95 and 1998-99 the proportion of academic staff on fixed-term contracts increased from 39% to 42%, and the proportion on permanent contracts dropped by more than 4%.

However, 31% of institutions increased the proportion of academic staff on permanent contracts between 1994-95 and 1998-99, and 51% of institutions increased the proportion of new academic appointments made on a permanent basis.

The proportion of women academics on fixed-term contracts increased from 48% in 1994-95 to 50% in 1998-99. The proportion of male academics on fixed-term contracts meanwhile increased from 34% to 38 % over the same period.

The conclusion is that what is needed is not better ways of managing fixed-term staff, but a reduction in the extent of fixed-term employment, i.e. limits on the use of fixed-term contracts. This would be one route to a reduction in the level of discrimination against women academic and related staff. The variation in the trends for different institutions presented here shows, paradoxically, that things in fact can be improved. Implementing the European Fixed-term Work Directive in the UK is one means of addressing this issue.

Trends in casual employment: all academic staff

In 1998-99 there were 130,534 academic staff in UK academic institutions. Of these, 111,924 (85.7%) were full-time, and 18,610 were part-time.

HESA defines four categories for the terms of employment of academic staff: permanent, fixed term, and 'other' (including hourly paid and/or casual staff).

The statistics show that the majority of academic staff are still employed on permanent contracts. But the proportion on fixed-term contracts has increased over the past four years from 38.5% to 42.2 %, and the proportion on permanent contracts has dropped by more than 4%.

We can look in detail at institutional practice by examining trends in the proportion of fixed-term and permanent academic staff since 1994-95. This gives us an estimate of the proportions of institutions that have reduced or increased reliance on fixed-term contracts.

Just over a quarter of universities and colleges employed 50% or more of academic staff on fixed-term contracts in 1998-99. However, over a third of institutions decreased the proportion of staff on fixed-term contracts between 1994-95 and 1998-99. Salford University for example has increased its total academic staffing from 591 in 1994-95 to 737 in 1998-99, and has reduced the number of staff on fixed-term contracts by 23%.

We can better appreciate change in levels of casualisation by concentrating on change in the proportion of permanent staff. In 1994-95, the proportion of academic staff on permanent contracts was 59.3%. In 1998-99, the figure was 55.1%. However, 31 % of institutions increased the proportion of academic staff on permanent contracts. St.Mary's College (with about 150 academic staff) witnessed a 27.6 % increase in the proportion of permanent staff.

Institutions, on the other hand, which have reduced the number of permanent academic staff by the highest percentage include a number of specialist arts institutions, but there are also much larger, generalist institutions such as Goldsmiths College and the Sunderland University in this category.

Since nearly all research staff are employed on fixed-term contracts, these changes may reflect changes in an institution's research activity, rather than a general shift in employment practice. In order to look at the prevailing practice in institutions, we must consider the proportion of new academic appointments that were permanent in the academic years 1994-95 and 1998-99.

The overall proportion of permanent new appointments was almost the same in 1998-99 as it was in 1994-95: 22.2% and 21.9% respectively. However, 51% of Institutions increased the proportion of permanent academic appointments.

Institutional mergers and the acquisition of existing permanent staff may play a factor here, but there are grounds for assuming that a significant proportion of institutions are gradually changing employment practices, even though the overall figures are disappointing.

Trends in casual employment by employment function

HESA defines three categories for the functions of academic staff: teaching only, research only, and teaching and research. Of academic staff in 1998-99, 11,884 (9.1%) were teaching only, 38,971 (29.9%) were research only, and 79,679 (61.0%) were teaching and research.

The figures show that the extent of casualisation varies among types of academic staff, with virtually all research only staff on fixed term contracts, and fewer than one in five teaching and research academics on fixed term contracts. It is also clear that the level of casualisation has increased for all three groups.

Trends in casual employment by gender

Men are more likely than women to have secure employment. For all women academic staff in 1998-99, 46.8% were on permanent contracts, and 49.7% were on fixed term contracts. For male academics, 59.5% were permanent, and 38.2% were fixed term.

The degree of difference between men and women academics was 13.9% in 1994-95 and 11.5% in 1998-99. This slight narrowing of the gender gap results from the increase in the proportion of male fixed-term academics, rather than a decrease in the proportion of female fixed-term academics.

Conclusions

The level of casualisation of research staff in the UK has increased since 1995-96, despite the signing by employers in 1996 of the Concordat on Contract Research Staff Career Management, which resolved to improve the careers of contract research staff. The level of casualisation of academics in general, and women academics in particular, has increased. However, a number of institutions are reducing reliance on fixed-term contracts and have begun to change employment practices.

The association believes that casualisation undermines career progression, creates great insecurity, erodes academic freedom, contributes to the levels of stress experienced by academic and related staff, and causes recruitment and retention problems. Further, casual employment erodes quality in higher education and undermines the ability of its staff to contribute fully to society.

The imminent implementation of the European Fixed-term Work Directive may compel the more backward institutions to change. We believe that they should follow the lead of the more farsighted institutions and immediately aim to transfer onto a permanent basis not less than 75% of staff currently on fixed-term contracts, or employed on a casual part-time basis, and limit permanently the future use of such contracts.

The full report can be found on the AUT website

webTitle: Homelessness is a big issue in Argentina too

fields.headline: Homelessness is a big issue in Argentina too
fields.standfirst: A decade after John Bird took to the streets of London with the first Big Issues, Latin America is waking up to the idea of combining media, business and social projects. Chris Moss reports
fields.trailText: A decade after John Bird took to the streets of London with the first Big Issues, Latin America is waking up to the idea of combining media, business and social projects. Chris Moss reports
fields.body:
"It hurts me too when I see people living on the streets," explains Kato, who is homeless and a vendor of the street paper Hecho en Buenos Aires. "I want to tell them come on, go out there and sell it, but it's hard to make someone who is homeless understand that he or she can escape this situation using a magazine."

Six months ago, Hecho en Buenos Aires (Made in Buenos Aires) hit the streets of the Argentine capital. It was not the first homeless paper in Argentina - there are church-backed programmes and several projects for street kids - but it was the first to adopt the Big Issue model of upbeat journalism, including copy and advice from the London magazine, combined with John Bird's motto of "a hand up, not a hand out".

Patricia Merkin, an Argentine translator who leads the Hecho team, was attracted by the content, image and infrastructure of the UK company. "There's nothing like the Big Issue on the newspaper stands, nothing that even looks like it," she said. "The church has always been involved in social assistance and the standard model is of 'winners' helping 'losers'."

Nor, she believes, is there any awareness of schemes in which the disadvantaged are protagonists: "We have to explain to politicians and the general public that this is a social business, not another charity."

After ten years under a Menem government bent on establishing a stable currency at any price, weakening the unions and selling off inefficient public services, Argentine society struggles with an overvalued peso and IMF-imposed austerity plans.

The parallels with London in the 1990s, when the first, humble-looking Big Issues hit the street are obvious.

Buenos Aires, always a city with European airs, has seen the evolution of a yuppie class employed by the multinationals who bought up the services, while the poorer classes have watched their lifestyles and incomes deteriorate.

The homeless, at the very bottom of the social ladder, have grown in number and have less chance of finding employment than ever before. "It may look like Europe," said Ms Merkin, "but out on the streets it might as well be Africa."

There is scant statistical information on homelessness in Buenos Aires - official figures put the number at around 1500 people living on the streets of the capital but there are literally millions of people who are "vulnerably accommodated" in slums, run-down hotels and squats. With unemployment at 16% in densely-populated Greater Buenos Aires (but double that in some suburbs), many thousands are in arrears for months of rent and the few homeless shelters that exist are underfunded, grim-looking dormitories full to bursting.

Many Argentines have no idea why people end up on the streets and have vague notions about the identity of the homeless. "When someone is homeless in Argentina," explained Jorge Martinelli, the Hecho volunteer who works most closely with vendors, "he or she has probably lost all connection with the family and here it is the family which is the dominant social model. On top of this, homeless people usually have drink or drug problems, owe numerous debts and chances are they are hundreds of kilometres from their home in the provinces."

With small amounts of funding from the British Council, Big Issue sponsor Levi's and from the city government's social work department, Hecho can just about afford to print 5,000 copies a month and with vendors taking 90% of the one peso cover price. Its writers and helpers must, for now, work unpaid.

Dole is non-existent, begging and peddling are rife, the streets are cluttered with underemployed people giving out promotional flyers and free media (Metro has just arrived here) and the daily task of selling the magazine is as chaotic as the urban context it springs from.

There is, though, room for optimism, argues Ms Merkin. "The growing importance of the marketplace means Hecho fits into the economic model. The Ministry for Social Development took an interest in the project from day one, but has been slow to respond with funds. President de la Rua must realize that his government needs to invest in social business and must also encourage major companies to help us. For we are, ultimately, the safety net that this kind of society needs."

Already working closely with a Brazilian project along the same lines, Hecho has received enquiries from Ecuador and Colombia, as the homeless media business idea spreads way beyond Big Issue-branded operations in Australia and South Africa. The latter, in particular, is of interest to those working in developing countries and Ms Merkin and team hope to strengthen their links with the Big Issue through membership of the INSP (international network of street papers).

Kato, meanwhile, remains positive. "The first issue told us to 'Get a job!'" - an allusion to the first cover headline, which quoted the Tebbit-like response of many well-off Argentines to those who live on the streets - "Now I work all day, and you forget even to stop for a drink of water because the adrenalin keeps you going."

Already working closely with a Brazilian project along the same lines, Hecho has received enquiries from Ecuador and Colombia, as the homeless media business idea spreads way beyond Big Issue-branded operations in Australia and South Africa. webTitle: Chinese stowaways 'had only hours to live'

fields.headline: Chinese stowaways 'had only hours to live'
fields.trailText: Twelve illegal immigrants from China were found in a semi-conscious state after sealing themselves into a container to foil carbon dioxide detectors during transit to the US.
fields.body:
Twelve illegal immigrants from China were found in a semi-conscious state after sealing themselves into a container to foil carbon dioxide detectors during transit to the US.

Police at Hong Kong's Kwai Chung terminal found that tarpaulin and packing tape had been used to create an airtight seal at the container's entrance. They said that if the stowaways had not been detected on Sunday some of them would have died.

"When we opened up the container the illegal immigrants were all in a semi-conscious state," Chief Superintendent Tsang Wai-hung said.

They are thought to have entered the container only hours before and had made makeshift preparations for the trip to Long Beach, California, which usually takes 11 days.

A few small airholes cut into the container floor were plugged with removable wood blocks and a bare minimum of food and water was stacked around them.

The Organised Crime and Triad Bureau made 14 other arrests in follow-up raids, claiming to have cracked an international gang of smugglers, including its ringleader.

But the find suggests that the "snakehead" people-smuggling gangs are flourishing, and that there is no shortage of mainland Chinese prepared to risk the journey to a new country.

All 12 immigrants seized on Sunday are believed to have come from the province of Fujian, traditionally the main source of Chinese migration. It was the home of the 58 immigrants who suffocated to death in the Dutch container found at Dover docks in June.

In October, 26 illegal immigrants from Fuzhou, Fujian, were found alive in a Kwai Chung container heading for Long Beach. The snakeheads had charged them £34,500 each, a court was told.

fields.headline: Chinese journalists flex some muscle
fields.standfirst: China's previously diffident journalists are starting to come to life although it falls well short of a direct challenge to government, writes John Gittings
fields.trailText: China's previously diffident journalists are starting to come to life although it falls well short of a direct challenge to government, writesJohn Gittings.
fields.body:
China's normally docile journalists' association issued an unusual statement last month in defence of press freedom after two Beijing reporters were manhandled while trying to carry out an investigation.

It was not quite as fearless a move by the association as it sounded. The two reporters had not been door-stepping President Jiang Zemin or trying to interview a dissident or a member of the Falun Gong.

They had rushed to a hospital where pop singer Mao Ning was being guarded by personal minders anxious to protect his reputation after a stabbing incident. The affair which turned out to involve a jealous lover, or perhaps two, has become a media sensation.

Yet the fascination of the Chinese popular press with such scandal stories is only one example of an increasingly active journalism which also covers more elevated ground.

More journalists than ever before are learning the art of "clipping the edge of the table" - a metaphor from table tennis which corresponds to the concept of sailing close to the wind.

In the highest profile case so far, a Chinese business magazine that alleged serious irregularities on the Shanghai Stock Exchange stood its ground after being criticised for sensationalism.

The monthly Caijing (Business and Finance Review) claimed that China's ten mutual-fund companies were manipulating the market to boost their own fund values. Its report described meetings in a Shanghai bath-house - a venue chosen so that no one could record the conversation secretly - where fund managers agreed to "churn" the market by buying and selling one another's stocks.

Although the funds are technically independent, they are part of a financial establishment dominated by government interests which does not look kindly on any disturbance. The managers took out advertisements in other newspapers to denounce Caijing and call for an apology, but the journal stood by its story. Official regulators have now agreed to crack down on stock-market fraud.

Caijing was previously regarded as a house magazine for the industry but its defiance shows how government restrictions can be thwarted by determined journalism - and the increasing role of market forces.

"It's too passive if you just say we have no press freedom and so we can do nothing," editor Hu Shuli told the English-language China International Business. "We believe there is a lot of space to do an independent job if you work hard enough."

The magazine's exposé in its October issue created a surge in demand, with circulation said to rise in November from 50,000 to 120,000.

China International Business, which is sponsored by the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation (Moftec), has published its own approving editorial.

"These publications have largely been cut free of the state budgets that formerly bankrolled the Chinese media," it said. "They have responded in the only way possible - by listening to what readers want, and giving it to them. This is an exciting time to be in the media."

Human rights observers abroad, and jailed democracy or Falun Gong activists at home will have no difficulty in pointing out the obvious limitations of today's exciting time. Chinese journalists too are candid in private about the number of subjects which remain off limits. They see themselves as pushing the limits of what is permissible rather than issuing an open challenge.

It is also true that the contents of hundreds of provincial and local daily newspapers are as turgid as ever, though some are facing a modest challenge by new evening papers with a more popular touch.

The pace-setting standard for investigative journalism has been set by newspapers such as the Beijing Youth Daily and the Southern Weekend which, although regionally based, are sold on street corners in main cities throughout the country.

Beijing Youth Daily first broke the mould in 1994 with a story about a poor student who was forced by high education fees to abandon college and go back to his village in the countryside.

More newspapers are now pursuing a similar agenda. In a recent example, the English-language Shanghai Star focused on the plight of freelance rubbish collectors who are being deprived of their lean earnings by new city restrictions.

Southern Weekend regularly focuses on cases of official corruption and misuse of power, and on a wide range of environmental themes. It is particularly strong in highlighting the plight of peasant communities who are hit with higher taxation and lower prices for their crops.

"There is nowhere to tell the truth", wrote Li Changping, a rural official in Hubei province, in a letter published by the newspaper earlier this year. "Senior officials prefer hearing positive news about agriculture and scold lower staff for a negative report."

Publication of his letter, originally addressed to China's state council, seems to have achieved ambiguous results. Some reforms were begun in his county, but Mr Li himself has now resigned.

Telling the truth is not an easy business anywhere in China, and the results will continue to be mixed. But this should only increase our admiration for the Chinese journalists who are struggling to break the old mould.

fields.headline: Scottish health - a statistical snapshot
fields.trailText: Scottish health - a statistical snapshot. By Kirsty Regan
fields.body:
Health spending
The Scottish health budget in 2001-02 will be £5.8 bn. Of this, the government has committed £15m to four initiatives called health demonstration projects with the aim of developing good practice in its priority areas - child/maternal health, sexual health, cancer and coronary heart disease. An additional £1m annually has been earmarked for the establishment of an Institute of Public Health for Scotland, based in Glasgow.

Comparative health spending
According to the Scottish Parliament's research service, spending per head on health in Scotland in 1999-2000 was about one-fifth more than the UK average. The figures show that, according to Westminster projections, the amount actually spent on health in Scotland will increase from £1,059 per head in 2000-01 to £1,150 in 2001-02.

Staff shortages
In common with the rest of the UK, Scotland suffers shortages of doctors. Scotland has been without an operational heart transplant unit since the departure of transplant surgeon Surendra Naik in May. NHS trust bosses are attempting to recruit two consultants with the aim of re-opening the unit at Glasgow Royal Infirmary in the spring of 2001. In April 1999 there were more than 1,200 full-time equivalent vacancies for nurses in the NHS in Scotland. Some 450 of these were unfilled for three months or more.

Heart disease, cancer and strokes
Heart disease is responsible for 40% of all deaths in Scotland. Despite a 50% drop in the death rate since 1980 (656 per 100,000 down to 332 per 100,000) Scotland remains top of international league tables for the "big three" killers: heart disease, cancer and strokes. Heart disease has now replaced cancer as the UK's biggest threat to women's health and here too the north/south differential remains. The premature death rate (before age 75) is 70% higher for women in Scotland than in East Anglia.

Drug use
The number of injecting drug users in Scotland has risen by 50% in the last six years to around 30,000. The knock-on impact on health services is considerable, with the number of new patients attending drug misuse services rising more than 300% from 2,980 in 1992-93 to 9,500 in 1998-99. A recent survey by greater Glasgow health board estimates that there are more than 15,000 drug addicts in the city - of whom 90% inject heroin. In the city centre alone, 43% of adults are believe to have some kind of drug problem.

Diet and nutrition
The legacy of the traditional Scots' fatty diet is revealed in latest statistics showing 75% of men and 62% of women over the age of 45 are overweight or obese. The Scottish health survey reveals that less than half of adult Scots eat cooked green vegetables five times a week.

Smoking
One-third of all adults in Scotland are regular cigarette smokers - more than in either England or Wales (33% in Scotland compared to 29% in Great Britain). Smoking rates among professional workers have halved over the past 20 years, but smoking is now concentrated among low-income groups. Roughly half of the men and women in the lowest income quarter in Scotland (49%) smoke, a figure which has hardly changed since the 1970s.

Teenage pregnancy
More than 9,000 teenagers become pregnant each year in Scotland and half of those pregnancies end in termination. The government's target is to reduce the pregnancy rate among 13-15 year olds by 20% by the year 2010. Teenage pregnancy rates in Scotland average 41 per 1,000 girls, while the average rate for teenage abortions was 34 for every 1,000 girls. Dundee tops Scotland's teenage conception rates with nearly 80 out of every 1,000 girls aged between 15 and 17. This is marginally less than the London borough of Southwark, which heads the statistical table for England and Wales with a pregnancy rate of 85 girls for every 1,000 - twice the national average.

fields.headline: Tough choices for Hackney
fields.trailText: Analysis: Hackney council's catalogue of woes includes a deficit of up to £40m, a strike and collapsing services. And it could get worse before it gets better, writes Simon Parker
fields.body:
The London borough of Hackney is facing some stark choices as it struggles to rescue its terminally unbalanced books. The council could end up £40m in the red by the end of March, and has approved a series of cuts designed to shave as much as possible off the deficit.

This programme, designed to turn the council around, yesterday resulted in the three largest town hall unions - the GMB, the Transport and General Workers union and Unison - voting for strike action, beginning with a one-day walkout on December 20. They are protesting against cuts that will see around 250 posts scrapped with minimum redundancy payments, as well as the borough's plans to renegotiate staff terms and conditions.

The move comes against a background of collapsing services. The Audit Commission says Hackney has a backlog 17,000 housing benefit claims, and tenants face eviction as a consequence.

The council's refuse collection and street cleaning services are not meeting basic standards, despite being among the most expensive in the country. At one point rubbish collection stopped, leaving black bags piling up in the streets.

And Ofsted last month slammed the borough's education service for being "deeply depressing".

There is little doubt that cuts in Hackney's budget are desperately needed. But neither is there much doubt that workers are being made to suffer for the sins of their employers. Frontline social care and refuse collection staff are, in fact, among the few groups that have not yet been blamed for Hackney's failure.

Politicians instead say the fault lies with former chief executive Tony Elliston, and his Transforming Hackney programme. This, they say, devolved budgets to council managers without sufficient controls on their spending.

Politicians, of course, had to rubber stamp Mr Elliston's proposals. Some now claim they only did so because they were lied to about the plans. Mr Elliston, in turn, says the attempt to blame him for the borough's problems more than 18 months after he left "reeks of desperation and dishonesty".

Some blame the borough's troubles on Thatcherism and its emasculation of local government, others on a lack of left-wing nerve from Hackney's political leadership. The truth is that Hackney's recent problems simply result from a double whammy of poor political and managerial leadership.

The council became hung in 1996, leading to a paralysing period of political splits, turmoil and in-fighting. The Labour and Conservative groups are working together at present, but insiders say the loose coalition, founded early this year, is not a strong one. The Liberal Democrats, originally part of the joint-working agreement, dropped out within weeks. The Conservatives are said to be unsure about the arrangement, but are held in place by their imposing leader Eric Ollerenshaw.

An Audit Commission report on the borough last month also highlighted the lack of strong management at Hackney. While managing director Max Caller seems almost universally respected, the report says: "The council does not have a strong team of top managers to play a key role in leading it out of trouble." With the help of ministers and local government's self-policing body, the Improvement and Development Agency, Hackney has appointed a number of interim managers. It has also, however, lost important staff members such as former education director Liz Reid, a department of education favourite who has since attacked the council's education service.

Both the government and the Audit Commission believe they can solve Hackney's problems, but their plans will do little to cheer the striking workers. The commission has urged the borough to look at outsourcing more services. Ministers, however, say they want to see "mixed solutions" to the problems in Hackney's housing benefit, refuse collection and financial management services. Unless terms and conditions are maintained, however, staff are not likely to view a public/private partnership body any more favourably than full-scale privatisation.

It is not yet clear what effect the strike action will have on the council. The unions claim they can shut Hackney down on their first one-day strike. The council says less than half its non-teaching workforce is unionised, and claims that, while the strike ballot produced an overwhelming vote in favour, a low turnout means there is little real support for the action. "It's not as though the council will be brought to its knees", said a Labour group spokesman.

Councillors are under massive pressure to cut their budgets, and do not want to be seen to be cutting back on services. A reduction in the wages bill, no matter how unfair to staff, may be inevitable, and this will leave workers with their own stark choice: Take redundancy on poor terms, or try to force improvements and risk going down with their sinking employer.

fields.headline: Folly of lessons in citizenship
fields.standfirst: Citizenship classes are an ill-advised measure that only place an additional burden on teachers rather than provide a better education for children, argues Dea Birkett.
fields.trailText: Comment: Citizenship classes are an ill-advised measure that only place an additional burden on teachers rather than provide a better education for children, argues Dea Birkett.
fields.body:
We're all model citizens now. Or rather we'll all be on the way to being so by tomorrow, when the home secretary, Jack Straw, and the education secretary, David Blunkett, launch Active Citizenship.

This 200-page booklet is designed to prepare teachers and students for the introduction of citizenship as a compulsory component of the national curriculum for 11- to 16-year-olds from September 2002, giving pointers as to how the subject might be taught.

The notion of citizenship is nebulous. What exactly does it mean? When I asked Community Service Volunteers, one of the four "citizenship organisations" behind the American-inspired handbook, I was told it was about "active, participatory learning. How students can participate in an active way." I was assured that the handbook dealt with "very real stuff" and that I would find concrete examples that would be useful to teachers.

But flicking through Active Citizenship, any concrete examples that do emerge bear a close resemblance to the type of activities in which management consultants indulge on training weekends away in the Welsh hills. "Self-empowerment through reflection", keeping a journal and writing a "mission statement" are the suggested lessons. Predictably, there is a great deal of role-playing. One of the most practical tasks is 105 "key citizenship words for use with weekly spelling lists", including community, concerns, sharing and, of course, citizenship.

The project is awash with false sentiment. Each chapter contains a scattering of quotes rather like a Patience Strong calendar. "Working together works" is one motto, followed by "Anything one person can imagine, other people can make real," and "If you can dream it, you can do it," attributed to none other than Walt Disney. It's as if the pedagogical experience is being reduced to the ditty inside a greeting card.

But the real difficulty with such a touchy-feely approach to teaching is how reductive it is of very complex ideas and very messy young, emerging minds and emotions. The student guide section encourages "an exploration of yourself". An avowed aim is "schooling the emotions". But can emotions be schooled? And if so, which emotions and when? Love, anger and fear are not easily explicable one-dimensional things, but complex and often self-contradictory. Ironically, oversimplistic emotions are often signs that a child has a special educational need, rather than that he or she is particularly well educated.

The underlying, if unstated, thesis behind such an approach must be that there are correct emotions to have at certain times and in certain situations. But you can't get your emotions right or wrong like you can your Tudor kings and queens. They just don't work like that. Emotions are sometimes utterly inappropriate, yet rightly so. A child whose sibling dies, for example, may well feel more anger than grief. Even adults get their feelings in a twist. A woman who is desperate to have a child may, on getting pregnant, feel distraught. But although inappropriate, none of these emotions are wrong. They just reveal how complex human reactions are in any situation.

"Self-esteem" is one of the core attributes that citizenship classes will aim to develop in children. But even if you feel good about yourself, it doesn't necessarily follow that you will do good to others. Surely a child can be very pleased with themselves indeed yet display no empathy whatsoever for anyone else. Self-esteem is no less complex an emotion - with no fewer facets - than any other.

Active Citizenship is not prescriptive, and much of what it says is common sense. But perhaps the most worrying aspect of this emphasis on separating out citizenship as a subject in itself is the presumption that children are currently taught something utterly different and devoid of much of the citizenship lobby's laudable aims. Surely well-taught history English and science are about citizenship. A recent series of history lessons at my local primary school looked at the life of Martin Luther King. Seven-year-olds learned King's "I have a dream" speech and acted out the story of African-American seamstress Rosa Parks, who was arrested after refusing to give up her bus seat for a white person in segregated Alabama in 1955. If that isn't a lesson in citizenship, without following the advice of any Active Citizenship handbook, then I don't know what is.

There are many things we can learn from the country that brought us confessional chat shows, but emotional maturity is surely not one of them. Nor is participatory citizenship: only half of American citizens cast a vote in their presidential election.

And perhaps therein is a lesson for Blunkett. Teaching citizenship does not necessarily guarantee that those taught will begin to participate more fully in the democratic process. As in America, it might have the opposite effect to that intended. It might make those newly educated in citizenship realise that there is little point in voting at all. And, as a result, the secretary of state for education may find himself without a mandate to introduce yet more ill-advised measures that only place an additional burden on teachers rather than provide a better education for children.

webTitle: Express considers weekly supplement in OK! style

fields.headline: Express considers weekly supplement in OK! style
fields.standfirst: Express shake-out: news round-up
fields.trailText:
9am:Richard Desmond is considering launching a weekly OK!-style supplement with the Express, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Express shake-out: news round-up
fields.body:
Richard Desmond is considering launching a weekly magazine supplement bringing OK!-style celebrity news to the Express.

Reports that a supplement called OK! Express would be published this week - on either Thursday or Friday - were denied both by the Express's new editorial director, Paul Ashfor,d and by OK! editor Martin Townsend.

But both confirmed that the new Express owners were looking for synergies between the newspaper and OK!, now both owned by Mr Desmond's Northern & Shell.

Mr Ashford told MediaGuardian.co.uk: "We want to add pages to the Express in different ways. In due course we will be wanting either to do a supplement in the newspaper or adding to the pagination in some other way."

Adding that "the form it takes is up to Rosie", he said: "You shouldn't assume that just because we're doing celebrity news first, that that's the way we're going to run the paper."

Insiders at the Express say there has been speculation for some time that the new owners would want to create synergies between OK! and the Express.

They say the supplement would be run by showbusiness editor Shekar Bhatia and Robert Jobson, royal correspondent and head of the showbusiness and media departments.

In a separate development today, the Express unveiled its "brilliant new columnist", Carol Sarler, who has been poached from the People.

Her arrival is the first new blood since Mr Desmond took over and sparked an exodus of writers including columnists Peter Hitchens and Mary Kenny.

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: WHO WAS PLAYER OF THE CENTURY?
fields.body:
WHO WAS PLAYER OF THE CENTURY?

Maradona and Pele: worthy dual winners of the Fifa player of the century award? Not according to some of our readers. "Pele is so nice that he gets boring. His diplomacy also makes him two-faced," reckons Brian Reid. "I have heard him say Bobby Charlton was the best player he ever saw. I also heard him say the same thing about George Best, Bobby Moore and Johan Cruyff. Not only that, but he's said a similar thing to lots of different people," he continues. Bet he hasn't said it about Maradona though.

Speaking of the pot-bellied one, Ed Hoskins isn't that enamoured with the Argentine's claims either. "Maradona's still-shocking breach of sportsmanship in claiming the Hand of God goal means he isn't the player of the century by a long stretch," Ed opines. "Someone should remind him he's a cheat. The true tragedy is that he could have achieved so much, but I still think Pele was the more complete player. The internet results just reflect recent memory."

CONTINENTAL FOOTBALL

Elsewhere, several of you have written in to praise our continental football round-ups. "Absolutely love the Spanish Liga weekly round-up - but would it be possible to mention what Steve McManaman is up to each week?" asks Rod Kohler. "I don't need his life history, just something about whether he was in the team for the match and how he played. Likewise, something on Robbie Keane in Italy would be good too." Consider it done, Rod.

Meanwhile, Sid Lowe's stories about crazy, card-happy Spanish referees have got John McGrath reminiscing. "I was always of the opinion that referees in Spain were media victims who took far too much of the blame for the chaos at some matches," he says. "However, this changed last year when I turned up at Guadix versus One Horse Town Rovers (I really can't remember the name) in their equivalent of the Conference and the ref gave a superbly inept display.

"After disallowing a perfectly legitimate goal for the home side, he managed to send off one of the home players. The away team had a free kick on the halfway line and as the Guadix player was walking towards his own box, and as the ref had his back turned, the away player intentionally booted the ball into the back of the poor sod who had just been booked.

"Cue cries from the away dugout just next to where the kick had been taken, a bemused look on the part of the Guadix player, and a swift red card from the ref who deemed this as obstructing the free kick. I was left to laugh my head off (the locals were not amused), and the ref needed a police escort and an umbrella to shelter him from all the spit raining down on him as he left the field."

Brian Wynne also "loved" yesterday's Serie A round-up - although he takes issue with the "wispy snow on the Alps" line. "As always, you seem to sum up the Italian scene pretty accurately," he says. "However, no wispy snow on the Alps this morning; at least not on the peaks I can see from my office window!" But a half-an-hour later he writes back, explaining: "Now that the early morning mist has cleared: maybe it is wispy snow after all! My betting is on icy snow, and definitely not (yet) for skiing on."

AN ERROR IN THE GUARDIAN. NO, REALLY

"I enjoy reading the match reports written by your knowledgeable football journalists," writes Tom Rogerson, setting us up perfectly for his sucker punch. "One problem however, in the recent Everton-Sunderland game I don't recall Kevin Phillips running into his own box, rounding his own keeper before shooting against the post," he continues, quoting our report:

'First Niall Quinn controlled well with his chest and Phillips timed his dash on to the through-pass to perfection, skipped round Thomas Sorensen but shot against the post from a comfortable angle.'

"This could suggest an inherent problem differentiating between other things like arses and elbows," he adds, before closing off by wishing us a "Merry Christmas and H'way the lads." And a Merry Christmas to you too, Tom.

webTitle: Comment: Gore, Bush and the Middle East

fields.headline: Who supports what
fields.standfirst:
One thing distinguishes Bush and Gore - their approach to Israel and the Middle East crisis, writes Geoffrey Wheatcroft

Special report: Israel and the Middle East

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: One thing distinguishes Bush and Gore - their approach to Israel and the Middle East crisis, writes Geoffrey Wheatcroft.
fields.body:
Does it matter who won? Since election day neither George W Bush nor Al Gore has covered himself with glory, and "Bore and Gush" leave a lingering impression that there's little to choose between them anyway. But there is one vital area of real difference which has been almost unmentioned, and that is the Middle East. Its importance is highlighted by Ehud Barak's resignation, which has precipitated a new crisis and an Israeli election in the new year.

By European standards, the distinction between Republicans and Democrats often does seem slight, even on what are meant to be "wedge" domestic issues. Bush is opposed to abortion, but then Gore is none too keen on it. Bush gloats over the people he is going to put to death (convicted of capital offences or not as the case might be), but Gore also supports the death penalty. On many foreign policy questions they are also closer than election rhetoric suggests. Bush preaches "strategic humility" and wants American soldiers to "stop escorting kiddies to school" in the Balkans, but it's clear that some degree of American withdrawal is coming under whichever party.

But on the Middle East, the divide between the two is actually greater than election rhetoric suggests. If Gore wins, he will be the most totally committed partisan of Israel ever to be president. He has been nurtured and hand-reared for the role for 35 years. At Harvard, he was taught by Martin Peretz, a rich academic who later bought the New Republic, and has made that weekly paper a byword for uncritical or even fanatical support for Israel right or wrong. After decades spent grooming his protege for the White House, "the Palestinian-hating Peretz", as his foe, the Jewish radical Michael Lerner, calls him, sees the prize snatched away. Peretz's rage now permeates the pages of his magazine.

Then turn to the other side. To talk of policy differences "between Bush and Gore" misses the point. Writing about the two candidates over this past month, Maureen Dowd of the New York Times shrewdly saw something: Gore wants to win the presidency much more than the Democrats do, and the Republicans want to win much more than Bush does. That sums up the two men more broadly. Gore is a workaholic and a wonk, Bush is a indolent booby who devotes as little as possible of such intellectual energy as he may possess to the political task in hand.

His underlying foreign policy isn't so much Ernest Bevin's - to buy a ticket and go anywhere I damn well please - as George V's - abroad is bloody and foreigners are hell. This is, after all, a man who, far from buying tickets, has never visited Europe and whose world view isn't so much isolationist as parochial. Bush couldn't find Hebron on a map, let alone explain the historical origins of the conflict in the Holy Land. And so, whereas Gore's attitude to the Middle East stems from that acutely personal partisanship in which he has been inculcated, Bush's will in reality stem from his cabal of advisers.

A fascinating cabal it is. His enforcer in Florida has been none other than James Baker, who was secretary of state in Bush the elder's administration. It was at that time, when the Middle East was being discussed at a government meeting, and Jewish-Americans influence was mentioned, that Baker is supposed to have said, "Fuck the Jews. They don't vote for us anyway." Whether or not he did utter the pithy phrase (not surprisingly, he didn't confirm it publicly), the words were blazoned as a headline in one Israeli newspaper and Baker is execrated to this day in Israel and by its American supporters.

Although every presidential candidate has to intone the platitudes about "Israel-our-truest-friend-in-the-Mideast", Republican administrations have been much less susceptible to Israeli pressure than the Democrats. That was true of Eisenhower at the time of Suez, of Reagan selling Awac surveillance aircraft to Saudi Arabia in 1981 despite ferocious Israeli opposition and of Bush the elder 10 years later. Summing up his frustration at Israeli intransigence - and lobbying - in faintly risible but heartfelt words, he said that he was "one lonely little guy down here" who was "up against some powerful political" groups.

There are good objective reasons for Republican detachment from Israel. It's quite true that the Jews don't vote for them anyway. And Israel doesn't have any oil fields. The likely Bush administration drips oil from every orifice, and has many good Arab friends, if not in Gaza, then in the Gulf.

It has been President Clinton's last great wish to secure a "legacy", something by which posterity might remember his presidency without sniggering. That was why he tried so desperately to secure a "final settlement" for the Middle East last summer, a fatuous aspiration even before the latest recrudescence of bloodshed.

There isn't going to be a settlement before the new occupant takes over the White House, or before the Israeli elections. Then, if 2001 sees continuing violence, with another Bush as president and - who knows? - either Binyamin Netanyahu or Ariel Sharon in power in Israel, it could be an interesting year.

fields.headline: Courtroom election drama grips America
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Ninety concentrated minutes of gritty legal argument, spiced with high constitutional theory, held much of America spellbound yesterday as lawyers for George W Bush and Al Gore battled for the hearts and minds of the nine members of the US supreme court in the decisive showdown of the presidential election dispute.
fields.body:
Ninety concentrated minutes of gritty legal argument, spiced with high constitutional theory, held much of America spellbound yesterday as lawyers for George W Bush and Al Gore battled for the hearts and minds of the nine members of the US supreme court in the decisive showdown of the presidential election dispute.

As the court grappled head-on for the first time in its history with a case in which it may decide who becomes the nation's president, the justices peppered the rival candidates' lawyers with questions which were instantly seized upon for clues about the way the court was moving.

When the time-limited oral arguments were over, chief justice William Rehnquist and his eight colleagues withdrew to discuss their ruling. There was no immediate indication of when they would announce their verdict, though today is the deadline for Florida to nominate its 25 members of the electoral college. The college is legally bound to meet in all 50 states next Monday, December 18, to choose between Mr Bush and Mr Gore.

At issue for the court was Mr Bush's complaint that the Florida supreme court had overstepped its authority, threatening "irreparable harm" to his rights, when it ordered a complete count of previously excluded "undervotes" in the November 7 election. fields.headline: Don't let the hypocrites decide
fields.trailText: Analysis: The government should not be railroaded into tightening restrictions on Viagra, writes Patrick Butler
fields.body:
Yesterday's announcement that ministers are to review the regulations covering the NHS availability of impotence drugs such as Viagra gives it several options as to whether and how it wants to make such drugs an election issue.

The public consultation on whether the current Viagra prescribing restrictions should be relaxed or tightened announced yesterday (six months later than planned) is due to end in February.

This gives ministers the flexibility to dodge the issue to avoid charges of rationing or recklessness (claiming it needs time to consider the results of the consultation), effectively burying the argument until after a May general election.

Or it could exploit the issue to its electoral advantage. There are two options open to it, both of which will be justified by a good proportion of the likely responses to the consultation.

The first is to make the drugs freely available to all men with a clinical need for impotence treatment. This would please the professions and patient groups (and the drugs companies) and provide a politically timely symbol of NHS largesse.

The second is to tighten the restrictions on Viagra-type drugs or ban them altogether, thus appealing to the Tory right and its media tribunes, who argue the NHS should have no truck with such "lifestyle" drugs, regardless of clinical appropriateness.

Which way will Labour go? The puritanical wing of old Labour is more or less at one with the new Puritans of new Labour in believing Viagra is essentially a frivolous accessory unfit to stand alongside 'real' treatments for cancer and heart disease.

Tightening the restrictions even further will hardly dent its popularity in the Labour heartlands, and would in theory only increase its appeal in middle England, which might approve of such "hard choices" for both moral and economic reasons.

The original 1999 consultation on impotence drugs recorded a high proportion - about 75 per cent - of responses apparently in favour of restrictions, with a further 10% believing it should be banned altogether.

But in making a political calculation, Labour would be unwise to trust such responses. The expenditure figures for Viagra and its like were around £8m higher than expected in the year to July 2000, despite tight restrictions on its use.

This suggests that the public displays of piety and outrage mask a real public demand for the drug (presumably, even among the pious and their friends and families), and - importantly - a serious belief among GPs that it is clinically effective.

Of course the argument about "lifestyle" drugs is often bogus. Few MPs who resent Viagra would seek a ban on the cardiac drugs shelled out by the NHS in truck loads to combat the effects of high fat, low exercise "lifestyles". It reminds us that there are few things more guaranteed to provoke hypocrisy among the British than its twin obsessions: sex and the NHS.

The government should refer the Viagra question to the national institute of clinical effectiveness. Let the experts, not the hypocrites, decide.
