webTitle: In brief: Strikebreaker Tiger pays his dues

fields.headline: Strikebreaker Tiger pays his dues
fields.standfirst: Plus: De Niro moves into Docklands penthouse; Garage star Robbie Craig spotted by Coppola; Famke Janssen squeezes Michael Douglas in before T3; Wahlberg ready to remake Charade; Linda Fiorentino and Alec Baldwin team up for wartime thriller
fields.trailText: Plus: De Niro moves into Docklands penthouse; Garage star Robbie Craig spotted by Coppola; Famke Janssen squeezes Michael Douglas in before T3; Wahlberg ready to remake Charade; Linda Fiorentino and Alec Baldwin team up for wartime thriller
fields.body:
 Golf champion Tiger Woods (pictured), who, like Liz Hurley, was accused of working during an actors' strike, appeared yesterday before the Screen Actors Guild trial board. Woods was fined $100,000 (£68,700), but he will only have to pay half of that amount as long as he does not cross a picket line during a five-year probationary period. Said Woods: "The decision to shoot a commercial during the SAG strike was a difficult one. I was facing the impossible task of trying to live up to my obligations to my sponsors while at the same time honouring my commitment to other SAG members. Now more than ever I understand how serious SAG's situation was, and I apologise for any pain I may have caused. I value my Screen Actors Guild membership and I hope this result will further strengthen the value of my membership." Liz Hurley has yet to go before the board.

 The Independent reports that Robert de Niro is to move into a £3.25m London penthouse which was previously owned by world boxing champion Lennox Lewis. The actor's new home is in the Docklands, where he can enjoy views over the Thames alongside his own private landscaped gardens. De Niro is coming to Britain next year to begin producing Nick Hornby's About A Boy, starring Hugh Grant.

 Rumour has it that British garage star Robbie Craig has landed a role in Francis Ford Coppola's next movie - despite having no acting experience. The singer will star opposite Charlie Sheen in Pig Six, which begins shooting next spring. Coppola apparently spotted Craig in the video for Woman Trouble, his recent hit with The Artful Dodger. Says Craig: "After seeing the video they realised I could act, and from there cast me in it! Crazy, eh! Singing has always been my first love, but who would miss a chance to take up an offer like this?" Apparently Coppola also hopes that Craig's mate Robbie Williams will make a cameo appearance, as well as record the music.

 Famke Janssen has announced her next film, and no, it's not Terminator 3 (see our earlier story). The X-Men star will play Michael Douglas' wife in the action-thriller Don't Say a Word, from Kiss the Girls director Gary Fleder.

 Mark Wahlberg has committed to star in Jonathan Demme's The Truth About Charlie, a remake of Stanley Donen's 1963 thriller Charade. Thandie Newton will co-star with Wahlberg in the roles originally played by Audrey Hepburn and Cary Grant.

 Alec Baldwin and Linda Fiorentino have been cast as Major Durant and Lt Nash, respectively, in Spoils, a thriller set during the second world war.

fields.headline: Lord Archer pleads not guilty
fields.trailText: Former deputy chairman of the Conservative party Lord Archer denied at the Old Bailey today that he had asked a friend to lie for him during a libel case.
fields.body:
Former deputy chairman of the Conservative party Lord Archer denied at the Old Bailey today that he had asked a friend to lie for him during a libel case.

The millionaire author and playwright was making his first appearance at the court for a preliminary hearing. The date of his trial was fixed for May 14 next year.

Lord Archer stood in dock in the number one court and pleaded not guilty to five charges - two of perjury, two of perverting the course of justice and one of using a false instrument, relating to diaries used in his libel trial against the Daily Star in 1987.

Lord Archer, 60, appeared with his former friend, television producer Ted Francis, 67, who faces a single charge of perverting the course of justice. He denied the charge.

It is alleged that Lord Archer, accused under the name of Jeffrey Howard Archer, asked Mr Francis to lie for him in order to provide a false alibi for the high-profile libel case.

Bespectacled Lord Archer, dressed in a dark navy suit, blue shirt and dark tie stood motionless, staring directly ahead as he was arraigned. He replied not guilty to each charge as it was put to him by the court clerk. He had arrived at the court in a chauffeur-driven green BMW and left immediately after the hearing without comment. His wife Mary was not with him.

The recorder of London, Judge Michael Hyam, told both men that they were granted bail, but if they failed to attend their trial without reasonable cause they faced a fine or imprisonment.

The charges they pleaded not guilty to today were as follows:

Lord Archer:

 That, on a day between the December 22 1986 and April 7 1987, in relation to an action commenced by Lord Archer against Express Newspapers Plc and Lloyd Turner, who had said that Lord Archer had sexual intercourse with prostitute Monica Coughlan on September 10 1986, he procured Edward John Francis to provide his solicitors with a version of events in relation to the evening of September 9 1986 which he knew to be false.

 Perverting the course of justice between March 26 1986 and July 7 1987, in relation to diaries relating to September 1986, in that he failed to reveal the existence of his main office diary and provided Angela Peppiatt with a blank diary which he instructed her with details to write in the diary. The new diary was then handed to his solicitors for use in the court case.

 Using a false instrument under the Forgery and Counterfeiting Act: That between March 26 1986 and July 7 1987, Lord Archer used the A4 diary with the intention of inducing the newspaper and its editor to accept it as genuine.

 Perjury: On June 23 1987, he made a statement under oath for use in judicial proceedings that the diary and a list of appointments were the only documents of that type which had been in his possession.

 Perjury: On the July 8 1987 as a sworn witness in judicial proceedings at the high court, made a false statement that the diary was in existence before October 26 1986.

Mr Francis faces one charge as follows:

 Perverting the course of justice that between December 22 1986 and March 27 1987 when he agreed to provide and later provided solicitors acting for Lord Archer, a version of events on September 9 1986, which he knew to be false.

The trial is expected to last two to three weeks, but possibly running into a fourth.

webTitle: Voluntary sector takes the lead in tackling young bullies

fields.headline: Voluntary sector takes the lead in tackling young bullies
fields.standfirst: While the government debates its anti-bullying strategy in the wake of schoolboy Damilola Taylor's murder, volunteer groups are working hands-on to find innovative solutions
fields.trailText: While the government debates its anti-bullying strategy in the wake of schoolboy Damilola Taylor's murder, volunteer groups are working hands-on to find innovative solutions. Liza Ramrayka reports
fields.body:
The murder of London schoolboy Damilola Taylor has re-ignited debate over current strategies for tackling youth bullying. The issue will be in the spotlight again this week, when education secretary David Blunkett is due to address a conference run by the charity Family Service Units on non-punitive approaches to bullying.

But while the government decides whether to beef up its 'no blame' approach to bullying, voluntary organisations have been quick to take a lead in finding innovative solutions to the age-old problem.

In south London, Action Southwark is a volunteer programme for 16-24 year olds living in the borough, which includes the north Peckham estate where Damilola was murdered. The programme was set up four years ago by Community Service Volunteers (CSV) as a pilot project. It now delivers the Millennium Volunteers scheme, the government initiative to encourage youth volunteering.

CSV volunteers have also recently worked with Camberwell-based Greenhouse Trust, a charity that works with youngsters who have been bullied or who have bullied at school. Volunteers organise role playing activities and listening sessions to help participants let off steam and increase their confidence. In another CSV project, at Walton High School in Stafford, staff and pupils have supervised peer support and listening services as part of citizenship, health and anti-bullying campaigns.

"CSV has been active in setting up volunteers to support anti-bullying campaigns for two reasons: to get people to think about bullying for themselves and to look at peer mentoring schemes," said Sian Austen, co-ordinator of Action Southwark. "Volunteers can act as mentors for the bullied and the bullies or can be used as a sounding board when young people do not want to approach their teachers or parents."

Although schools have since September 1999 been obliged to tackle bullying, racism and harassment, charities and other agencies working with children claim more could be done to encourage anti-bullying strategies.

Latest research by MORI shows that during the past 12 months more than a third of secondary school students were bullied. For many of the victims, the ordeal will result in truancy and underachievement.

Charity Young Voice, which regularly polls young people on a variety of issues to inform educationalists and policymakers, next month publishes its latest survey of young people's experiences and attitudes to bullying. Findings show that 37% of teenage boys have experienced physical abuse from bullies, while physical bullying of girls has increased from 17% to 22% over the past four years.

Young Voice executive director Adrienne Katz believes agencies need to work together to achieve a situation where children are protected both inside and outside the school gates. "Every child has the right to safety and parents have the right to believe their child is safe," she said. "This will not happen without a multi-agency, community-wide approach.'

Durham county council has employed a service-wide approach to bullying since last year, covering social services, the police, libraries and leisure facilities as well as schools. Its "statement of principle" encourages input into anti-bullying policies from voluntary organisations, parent groups and young people.

Marianne Taylor, area senior educational psychologist responsible for the council's anti-bullying service, believes this joined-up approach to tackling the problem is the way forward. "It means different agencies are working towards the same goal and can support one another," she said.

webTitle: Excite agrees to settle in Estee Lauder lawsuit

fields.headline: Excite agrees to settle in Estee Lauder lawsuit
fields.trailText: 11.15am: A lawsuit filed by cosmetics giant Estee Lauder against search engine Excite over internet ads has been settled, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A long-running battle between Estee Lauder and Excite over internet advertising has been settled.

The row began in January 1999 when the cosmetics giant filed a lawsuit against the internet search engine, accusing it of selling rights to words including "Estee Lauder" and "Origins", an Estee Lauder brand name, to rival cosmetics firms.

Estee Lauder alleged that Excite sold its trademarked names to the online retailer Fragrance Counter.

Internet search engines have long been selling rights to key words to advertisers who want their banner ads to appear when those words are entered by an internet user.

Under the terms of the settlement, Estee Lauder has regained the rights to words that appear in its brand names. Its own ads will now pop up when users enter those words.

webTitle: Bidding war for horse-racing TV rights drags on

fields.headline: Stewards' inquiry called into horseracing deal
fields.standfirst: Nov 21: TV race deal delayed again
fields.trailText:
11.15am: The bidding war for the TV rights for UK horse-racing looks set to drag on into the new year, writes Jason Deans.

Nov 21: TV race deal delayed again
fields.body:
The protracted bidding war for the TV rights for UK horseracing looks set to drag on into the new year, after the Racecourse Association announced an inquiry into aspects of the bidding process.

The investigation follows allegations that one racecourse owner approached one or both of the two bidders - Carlton Communications and the Go Racing consortium - about entering into a consultancy agreement in return for support of one or other of the TV bids.

Angus Crichton-Miller, RCA chairman, said it was now "extremely unlikely" that a deal could be struck with Go Racing before Christmas.

"The media rights deal is of great importance and it is planned to be for 10 years. It is therefore vital that the bidding process is seen to be without taint," he said.

fields.headline: Anatomy of desire
fields.standfirst: The most complained-about advertisement of the year for Opium perfume features a naked Sophie Dahl. So what's so shocking, asks  Libby Brooks - and what does our response say about how we view sexual pleasure?
fields.trailText: The most complained-about advertisement of the year for Opium perfume features a naked Sophie Dahl. So what's so shocking, asks Libby Brooks - and what does our response say about how we view sexual pleasure?
fields.body:
She could be porcelain. Supine, naked but for a pearl choker and bracelet, this image of the English model Sophie Dahl appears on billboards and in magazines across the country advertising the Yves Saint Laurent fragrance, Opium.

Her head is thrown back, exposing her lovely throat. She cups one breast. Her emerald-shaded eyes are closed, but her legs are open, feet arching into opulent gold stilettoes. The pose is strikingly erotic. It has power - to excite and, it would seem, to offend.

Since the advert first appeared last month, the Advertising Standards Authority has received more than 200 complaints about it, significantly more than any other advertisment this year. From a Welsh assembly member in Cardiff to road safety officers in Yorkshire, debate is raging over the suitability of the poster, taken by the celebrity photographer Stephen Meisel, for public sites. And in France, the campaigning feminist group Chiennes de Garde (Guard Bitches) has condemned the advert as "porn chic".

The viewing public is inured to the use of flesh to attract attention. As a nation, we are used to breasts. So what is it about this particular photograph that causes such offence? What is this image about: ecstasy or exploitation, pleasure or danger, the watcher or the watched? In essence, it begs one question: what does she want? To be fucked? By you? By herself? The reason the photograph of Dahl illicits such a powerful reaction is that it strikes at the centre of the complex, uncomfortable relationship between gender and desire.

What is desire, in all its sticky, sexy forms? It is a memory, and a vision. It is engulfing, and unselfconscious. It is also about self-determination, about taking responsiblity for, and responding to, one's sexual impulses. But taking the initiative is a trade-off for many women: bursting the unbearable bubble of sexual tension, taking control on a more practical front where pregnancy or safety are concerned, but seldom wholeheartedly embracing sexual appetite. And it requires more than a flipping of the binary vision of male and female as doer and done-to to change this.

Female sexuality, like the female body, is generally construed as passive. Compare Dahl's hungrily parted legs with the Barbie doll blankness of Claudia Schiffer, presently gracing 30ft-high banners across London, advertising the clothing store Hennes. Schiffer is the embodiment of female sexual passivity. In her pretty pastel bra and knickers she is slutty, but not too slutty, eager to please, easy to satisfy - and as challenging as a blow-up doll.

The image of Dahl is threatening because she looks as if she knows what she wants and, for all the progressive talk of bedroom liberation, that continues to alarm us. Popular culture now offers the superficially subversive notion of woman as sexual aggressor. But in the private sphere, we still teach girls a romantic narrative of which sex forms one element, while teaching their male peers about a discreet act that underpins masculinity.

So how much of this passivity is constructed by social imperatives, and how much is an unconscious response to them? Jacques Lacan, the French psychoanalyst, once said that women want to be wanted, not to be loved. In the sexual realm, this could be taken to mean that women are so uneasy about desiring directly, whether through shame or ignorance, that they can only experience it in a mediated form.

Essentially, wanting to be wanted stems from a desire for power that has been transformed and ultimately hidden. Despite the advances of feminism, female power continues to be experienced as dangerous or exotic, and not something that can be directly expressed.

So we find our power in the image we project rather than in our own actions. Appearance - whether that is looking good or acting sweet - trumps what we actually want for ourselves; reliance on other people to provide our own feelings of worth traduces emotional authenticity.

If women have so little confidence in their desires, then it is not surprising that they tend to present themselves as less sexual beings compared to men. Most national surveys show that women want sex less often than men, experience orgasm less often and find greater satisfaction in emotional intimacy than genital sex.

The pop psychologists would have it that women are cuddle-obsessed, finding it impossible to separate sex from love. The evolutionary psychologists tell us that the higher male sex drive has an ancient Darwinian rationale. But do men and women experience desire differently?

"Women are said to have lower sex drives than men," writes Natalie Angier, the Pulitzer prize-winning science correspondent, "yet they are universally punished if they display evidence to the contrary - if they disobey their 'natural' inclination towards a stifled libido."

"Women supposedly have a lower sex drive than men do, yet it is not low enough. No, there is still just enough of a lingering female infidelity impulse . . . to justify infibulation and purdah . . . How can we know what is 'natural' for us when we are treated as unnatural for wanting our lust, our freedom?"

Women may be more aware of their sexuality than ever before, but they continue to offer it an ambivalent embrace. How does that aped, or genuine, sexual confidence play out in the masque of flirtation? Although our sexual conversations are highly nuanced these days, negotiating the path from bar to bed can often feel like a war of attrition. Although chastity and sexual passivity are no longer openly feted, both men and women retain a lingering suspicion of promiscuous women. Especially among the younger generation, where girls' power is located in their ability to say no, and their weakness in the inability to do so effectively.

Desire is also about greed - literally. Women are bad at admitting to hunger, constructed as we are as givers, not seekers, of pleasure. And if, as Naomi Wolf suggested in the Beauty Myth, dieting is the essence of contemporary femininity, are we starving ourselves of lust? Studies have consistently shown that with dietary deprivation, sexual interest dissipates, and fertility plummets. Meanwhile, self-consciousness is the enemy of desire. Erotic abandonment and fretting over the flatness of your tummy are mutually exclusive.

Finally, women's desire has always been mediated through a male prism. From the pornography women share with their partners, to the way we are sold cars, the erotic landscape is overwhelmingly male. Our culture is suffused with the homogenous imagery that has come to represent What Turns Men On (though the reality of male desire doesn't necessarily conform).

Although discussion of women's pleasure has lately entered the mainstream, it remains minimal and reductive: the saucy scandals of tabloid nymphets, advertisers who link ice cream and seduction, or the censoring of parodic "laddish" behaviour.

Female sexuality remains a dark continent. Largely, women remain in a state of anxious comparison: wanting to be, envying and - yes, sometimes - desiring the male's object of desire. But I don't feel like that when I look at that photograph of Sophie Dahl. Personally, I think it's a beautiful, sexy image of a woman caught in a moment of pleasure. For all its high art allusions and anti-realist photographic tricks, it reminds me of what sex could actually look like, or what it can look like in fantasy.

It is genuinely erotic in a way that all those other images that pretend to read our sexuality never succeed in being. It reminds us, in a society where our public representations of sex have become increasingly static, that desire is a vivid, transformative force. But perhaps it is so shocking to some people because of this very public exposure of a private interlude: the time when we were last, best touched.

fields.headline: Ian Kershaw: My inspiration
fields.standfirst: Ian Kershaw is professor of modern history at the University of Sheffield. The second volume of his biography, Hitler 1936-45: Nemesis, has been nominated for the Whitbread Prize
fields.trailText: Historian and author of Hitler 1936-45: Nemesis describes his early influences
fields.body:
"I was born in 1943 in Oldham and spent the first two years of my life with my mother, as my father was based in Abingdon where he was director of the RAF band by night and a fitter repairing Lancaster bombers by day. I always wondered how the planes remained airborne as he was lousy at DIY.

"My dad was a devout Catholic so I was sent to St Joseph's, the local Catholic primary. It had no scholastic pretensions and neither did I, initially. I never thought of myself as academically able, but I suppose I must have had some ability as I was one of only five children selected to take the 11+. Two of us even passed, which I think must have made it an annus mirabilis for the school.

"I went on to Count Hill grammar school. The church forbade me from attending the morning assembly, and so, along with the three other Catholics at the 700-strong school, I felt marked out and different. I had just settled down when I was transferred to St Bede's, the Catholic grammar school in Manchester, after my father complained to the Bishop of Salford, so I had another difficult period of readjustment.

"St Bede's had a very good, classical reputation. "When I reached the sixth form, I had no trouble selecting Latin and French as my first two A-levels, and I only chose history as it seemed like the least painful option. It proved to be an inspired choice as we had a wonderful teacher, Father Burke. He was brilliant because when teaching the Reformation he gave such a loaded Catholic interpretation that I was forced into the reference library in order to challenge him. The two essays I remember writing for him are the ones that got the worst marks. Perhaps starting an essay entitled 'write a defence of Mary Tudor' with the words 'There is no defence ...' was asking for trouble.

"The school wanted me to take a scholarship for Cambridge, but I didn't want to leave the area. I applied for a place at Manchester University instead but they never replied, so I accepted an offer from Liverpool, which did. As it turned out, Liverpool was stacked with a galaxy of top medieval historians, so I could hardly have done better."

 Ian Kershaw is professor of modern history at the University of Sheffield. The second volume of his biography, Hitler 1936-45: Nemesis, has been nominated for the Whitbread Prize.

webTitle: Our love of a good loser

fields.headline: Our love of a good loser
fields.standfirst: Oliver James explains why we prefer losing
fields.trailText: Oliver James explains why we prefer losing
fields.body:
We enjoyed Eddie The Eagle crashing his way to failure on the ski slopes, we treasure Dunkirk, we guffaw at Norway's annual "nul points" in the Eurovision Song Contest. The very concept of The Weakest Link amuses because, to us, losing is immense fun.

Our reactions to winning are less positive. Partly this is because its comic potential is so much less. Beyond a wry "until next time", it is useless. But it is also because we are a "glass half-empty" culture, and winning is about glasses being full. You have to be mildly depressed to fit in here: self-disparaging, never the show-off and always unthreatening. This is sometimes attributed to the rapid loss of empire - but it goes far deeper than that.

It is found in all classes. Although Eton's motto is "Floreat Etona", it could equally be "Life is to be enjoyed, not endured" - and this is largely achieved by piss-taking. No one there gets away with taking themself seriously, however grand or wealthy their origins; self-mockery is the only recognised coinage.

The same is true from Liverpool to Newcastle to Glasgow. In films like Four Weddings and a Funeral, Gregory's Girl or Withnail and I, or in almost any sitcom or soap, the best-loved characters are brilliant at taking the piss out of themselves.

This sensibility also underlies the use to which we put our countless sporting fiascos. Those of us old enough to remember the footballing catastrophes of the 1970s lapped up Baddiel and Skinner's "30 years of hurt". And we gasped with admiration at Kevin Keegan's admission that the job of national coach was beyond him.

By contrast, almost everyone who is not a Manchester United supporter loathes their pride in their achievements. Exactly the same hostility applies when it comes to soap stars. Give us Nigel Pargiter any day over pushy Brian Aldridge in the Archers.

You can keep that money-grabbing show-off Ian Beale in EastEnders if the wit and modesty of Pauline Fowler are on offer. Stuff the loud-mouthed grandiosities of Mike Baldwin in Coronation Street if Bet Lynch is around to serve a sherbert or two.

It is no coincidence that in all these cases, the show-offs are also successful entrepreneurs upon whom the scriptwriters have rained misfortune. They are being punished for showing signs of having American attitudes to winning.

Likewise, the American concept of the loser is not one that fits comfortably with us. I recall what I believe was the first time "loser" was used as a term of abuse on EastEnders, in 1986. Ian Beale spat it at his cousin for not making more money. But even today, and despite all Thatcher's grisly efforts to persuade us otherwise, the word has not really been accepted by us. We remain committed to the idea that it is the playing that matters, not the winning or losing.

What is more, we are dead right. The heart of a fulfilled adult life is the playfulness to be seen in small children. Their unconfined joy in pretence, not their sometimes greedy, selfish grandiosity, is the model for our humour, our aliveness and our attitude to games. We still realise that it is only a game.

webTitle: Men in Black 2 deal keeps stars out of the red

fields.headline: Men in Black 2 deal keeps stars out of the red
fields.trailText: Will Smith and Tommy Lee Jones to receive record breaking share of the box office takings for the Men in Black sequel
fields.body:
In 1997, the original Men in Black earned more than $500m (£344m) worldwide, making it one of the decade's most successful movies. Sony must be counting on its long-mooted sequel having similar box office appeal: its stars have been given one of the most lucrative profit-sharing deals ever.

Inside.com reports that Will Smith and Tommy Lee Jones have been offered an unprecedented 50% of all profits on the sequel, up to the $200m (£137.4m) mark. Given that the film's budget looks set to be in the $100-140m (£67-96m) range, the studio must be banking on seriously big takings for the sequel, and recouping its heavy initial investment from foreign box office, video and DVD sales and other ancillary markets.

The closest that a studio has previously come to signing over such a huge chunk of a film's gross earnings was Universal's groundbreaking deal with Jim Carrey and director Ron Howard for How the Grinch Stole Christmas. The studio agreed that 34% of the film's profits would be split between Carrey, Howard, producer Brian Grazer and the estate of the late Dr Seuss. All four must be doing nicely out of that deal now, as The Grinch is currently enjoying its fourth week atop the US box office and is on course to become the most successful film of the year.

But The MiB2 pact trumps The Grinch, by giving Smith 20% and Jones 12.5% of the profits. In addition, director Barry Sonnenfeld will receive 10%, while 5% will go to producers Walter Parkes and Laurie MacDonald, and Steven Spielberg, who as executive producer of the original title made $100m (£67m).

Will Smith must have rued the day when he agreed to the (relatively) paltry sum of $5m (£3.43m), with no cut of ancillaries, for his role in the first MiB. Inside.com reports that, this time round, the actor drove a particularly hard bargain, demanding to be given a stake in all profits made from promotional tie-ins.

fields.standfirst: German families hold their main celebration a day earlier than us on Christmas Eve. So,  Nicole Prestle asks, what else is different?
fields.trailText: German families hold their main celebration a day earlier than us on Christmas Eve. So, Nicole Prestle asks, what else is different?
fields.body:
Mit Weihnachten ist das so eine Sache. Dass [daß] das Christkind am Heiligen Abend in allen Wohnzimmern liebevoll den Baum schmückt, glauben heute nicht einmal mehr alle Kinder. Und dass [daß] es an den Häusern derer, die nicht immer brav waren, vorbeigeht, auch diesen Bären kann man kaum mehr jemandem aufbinden. Das golden glitzernde Geheimnis der Adventszeit hat eben viel von seinem Mythos verloren.

Trotzdem gibt es noch immer Traditionen, an denen viele Familien festhalten: Kinder schreiben Wunschlisten ans Christkind", obwohl sie wissen - später sind es nicht die weiß gekleideten Himmelsboten, sondern Mama und Papa, die im adventlichen Einkaufsrummel ins Schwitzen geraten. Für die musikalische Einlage unter dem Christbaum proben viele schon Wochen vorher. Und wenn am Heiligen Abend alle Geschenke ausgepackt sind, geht die ganze Familie gemeinsam zur Kirche.

Weihnachten ist vor allem in Familien mit Kindern so geblieben, wie es auch vor vielen Jahren war. Ob sie selbst das Christfest traditionell feiern oder lieber auf Geschenke und Brauchtum verzichten, wollten wir von Jugendlichen wissen.

Gemeinsam den Weihnachtsbaum schmücken, weihnachtliche Lieder singen, Plätzchen backen. Was haltet ihr [Ihr] von solchen Weihnachtstraditionen?

Franziska (11): Ich finde das toll. Bei uns schmücke immer ich eine Hälfte des Weihnachtsbaumes, den Rest meine kleine Schwester. Das nervt aber manchmal, weil die Sachen, die sie auf den Baum hängt, nie zusammenpassen. Plätzchen bäckt bei uns die Oma, weil meine Mama in der Arbeit ist und keine Zeit hat.

Alexander (16): Bei uns wird unter dem Weihnachtsbaum gesungen - jedes Jahr wieder. Ich mache da nicht mit, weil ich nicht singen kann. Ich halte das alles auch nicht für so wichtig, da ich nicht an Gott glaube. Deshalb bin ich auch ganz froh, dass [daß] unsere Familie an Weihnachten nicht geschlossen zur Kirche geht.

Tobias (17): Ich spiele an Weihnachten Keyboard. Für solche Traditionen ist man meiner Meinung nach nie zu alt. Keyboard spielen macht Spaß und die Weihnachtslieder sind außerdem nicht so schwierig.

Welcher Brauch gefällt euch [Euch] noch immer am Besten?

Maria (15): Für mich sind das die Geschenke, das muss [muß] ich offen zugeben. Auch wenn man für die anderen Kleinigkeiten kaufen muss [muß], man kriegt es doch fünffach zurück.

Dominique (17): Am liebsten mag ich es, wenn wir am 24. Dezember alle zusammen essen. Es gibt immer einen richtigen Schmaus, für den man sich lange Zeit lässt [läßt]. An normalen Tagen ist so etwas bei uns selten, weil jeder unterwegs ist und man zu verschiedenen Zeiten isst [ißt].

Linda (19): Ich backe sehr gerne Plätzchen mit meiner Mutter. Ich muss [muß] sie zwar jedes Jahr wieder dazu überreden, aber sie macht dann doch immer mit. Und gemeinsam den Baum zu schmücken, auch das finde ich eine tolle Sache.

Auf welche Tradition könntet ihr [Ihr] dagegen verzichten?

Nadine (10): Wir gehen vor der Bescherung immer in die Kirche. Darauf könnte ich gut verzichten. Meinen Eltern habe ich das aber noch nie gesagt. Ein paar Jahre lang werde ich noch mitgehen. Wenn ich dann älter bin, l asse ich es sein .

Maria: Für das Singen unter dem Weihnachtsbaum bin ich selbst zu alt. Das habe ich irgendwann mit zwölf Jahren aufgehört. Meine Schwester singt aber noch und das finde ich auch ok, so lange [solange] ich selbst nicht mitmachen muss [muß].

Ist an Weihnachten auch mal Disco angesagt, oder bleibt es ein Familienfest?

Alexander: Ein einziges Mal bin ich - nachdem die Geschenke ausgepackt waren - in die Disco gegangen, ja. Das hat aber tierisch Zoff gegeben mit meinen Eltern. Ich würde es deshalb nicht mehr machen.

Dominique: Weihnachten ist und bleibt ein Familienfest. Ich würde da nie abends weggehen. Einmal im Jahr kann man auf jeden Fall einen ganzen Tag mit seinen Eltern und Großeltern verbringen. Sonst ist sowieso immer alles so hektisch.

Tobias: Meine Eltern würden mich an einem solchen Tag gar nie weglassen. Und ich möchte das auch nicht. Außerdem hätte sowieso keiner meiner Kumpels Zeit, weil auch sie alle bei ihren Familien sind.

Wie möchtet ihr [Ihr] einmal mit eurer [Eurer] eigenen Familie Weihnachten feiern?

Maria: Eigentlich ganz genau so, wie wir es jetzt machen. Mit Geschenken, mit Baum, mit Singen. So hat man es uns beigebracht und so ist es auch schön. Manche Traditionen muss [muß] man einfach bewahren.

fields.trailText: Aston Villa's search for a striker continues. Last weekend, John Gregory flew to Buenos Aires to make a £10m bid for Colombian international Juan Fablo Angel, reports the Mirror's Harry Harris. Angel certainly looks worth the money - he has scored 30 goals in just over 40 matches for River Plate - and, as Harris notes, "is keeping Hamilton Ricard out of the Colombian team".
fields.body:
Aston Villa's search for a striker continues. Last weekend, John Gregory flew to Buenos Aires to make a £10m bid for Colombian international Juan Fablo Angel, reports the Mirror's Harry Harris. Angel certainly looks worth the money - he has scored 30 goals in just over 40 matches for River Plate - and, as Harris notes, "is keeping Hamilton Ricard out of the Colombian team".

And Aston Villa's "hit list" doesn't end there. According to the Mirror, a club representative watched £11m-rated Espanyol striker Raul Tamudo play against Barcelona.

Newcastle have made an audacious bid to sign Gianluca Vialli as a stand-in striker, reports the Star. However, Vialli's agent Athole Still has explained that the former Chelsea manager has no plans to resume playing. "Luca's very happy and he'll come back into football for sure - but not as a player," Still insisted. "The door is closed on that - he's not interested in the slightest."

Newcastle have also failed to sign John Hartson on loan, reports the Sun. The paper claims that Bobby Robson will now turn his attention to Rangers' striker Rod Wallace. Meanwhile, Hartson is reported to be interested in a move to Celtic.

Raimond Van Der Gouw is angling for a move to the United States. He said: "There has been interest in me from the States and I would love to live in Florida. My agent pulled off something special to get me to such a great club as United but I'm open to another adventure."

fields.headline: Christmas spirit
fields.trailText: What is Christmas? Who is Father Christmas and where does he come from? And what of gifts, decorations, food and, less often, the story of the birth of Jesus? Any or all of these make up these Christmas-book themes
fields.body:
What is Christmas? Who is Father Christmas and where does he come from? And what of gifts, decorations, food and, less often, the story of the birth of Jesus? Any or all of these make up these Christmas-book themes.

How the Grinch Stole Christmas, by Dr Seuss (Collins, £12.99/£4.99, 6+ yrs)
In his inimitable rhyming couplets, Dr Seuss tells how the Grinch steals Christmas from the Christmas-loving Whos of Whoville. A brilliantly inventive story of how on old curmudgeon's heart is turned when he realises Christmas is about more than gifts and wrapping. This cuts to the core of what Christmas should be.

Happy Christmas, Maisy, by Lucy Cousins (Walker, £9.99, 2+ yrs)

In this simple pull-the-tab book, you can help Maisy to shop and wrap presents for her friends, decorate a tree, empty her stocking and greet her visitors in a cheerful, mousy version of Christmas.

Dream Snow, by Eric Carle, (Hamish Hamilton, £14.99, 2+ yrs)

Father Christmas is styled as a benign old farmer who, after a hard day's work, falls asleep dreaming of snow. As the pages turn, clever opaque acetates shroud the farmer and the animals in thick, white blankets. On waking, he discovers it was no dream: snow has fallen and now he must quickly set about his task of delivering the gifts. This simple story grounds Father Christmas firmly in reality and then adds a touch of magic. The push- button tune at the end sparkles, too.

Zelda and Ivy One Christmas, by Laura McGee Kvasnosky (Walker, £9.99, 4+ yrs)

Naked materialism is tempered with some warm-hearted sentiment around thinking of others in three interlinked stories. Zelda and Ivy choose their ideal Christmas presents dream Christmas dreams and show genuine warmth towards a friend, as well as collecting up their own Christmas goodies. These foxy sisters have a convincing, affectionate relationship, making this a Christmas story of nice domestic detail.

How the Reindeer Got Their Antlers, by Geraldine McCaughrean and illustrated by Heather Holland (Orchard, £9.99, 3+ yrs)

This is an original add-on to the mythology about why reindeer pull Father Christmas's sledge, highlighting their role in the Christmas story. The practical yet magical explanation is uncovered in a beautifully written, warmly illustrated fantasy.

My First Christmas Story (Nicola Smee, Orchard, £3.99, 3+ yrs)

A cosy, family drama with a contemporary feel. A very floaty angel tells a slightly hippy, barefoot Mary she has been chosen by God to be the mother of his son. Everything goes well from then on with a sunburst birth and three undistinguished-looking wise men.

Jesus, by Brian Wildsmith (Oxford University Press, £10.99, 4+ yrs)

This brightly illustrated book covers more of Jesus's life than just his birth, conveying the Bible story with great dignity and impact. The angels are pleasingly unethereal; the three wise men delightfully magisterial.

2000 Nestlé Smarties winners

Gold

(5 yrs and under) Bob Graham: Max (Walker);
(6-8) Jacqueline Wilson: Lizzie Zipmouth (Corgi);
(9-11) William Nicholson: The Wind Singer (Mammoth).

Silver
(5 and under) Satoshi Kitamura: Me and My Cat (Andersen);
(6-8) Tony Mitton: The Red and White Spotted Handkerchief (Scholastic);
(9-11) Beverley Naidoo: The Other Side of Truth (Puffin).

Bronze
(5 and under)
John Burningham: Husherbye (Cape);
(6-8) Lauren Child: Beware of the Storybook Wolves (Hodder);
(9-11) Kevin Crossley-Holland: The Seeing Stone (Orion).

Kid's Club Network Special Award: Jacqueline Wilson for Lizzie Zipmouth.

webTitle: Kevin Smith's write stuff at the Academy

fields.headline: Kevin Smith's write stuff at the Academy
fields.trailText: Maverick director Kevin Smith raises some eyebrows with his frank admissions about his career in independent films during a lecture to the Academy Foundation
fields.body:
If you invite Kevin Smith to deliver a lecture, you presumably realise that you're in line for an unorthodox evening. The writer and director was asked by the Academy Foundation to deliver this year's Marvin Borowsky Lecture on Screenwriting, which was endowed by the late screenwriter/writing professor's wife so that people could: "Hear an accomplished screenwriter review the challenges, the frustrations and, undoubtedly, the joys of the work."

Past speakers have included Nora Ephron, Waldo Salt, Robert Towne, Billy Wilder and Ron Bass. Independent director Smith's credits include Clerks, Mallrats and last year's Dogma, which starred Ben Affleck, Matt Damon and Alan Rickman.

Industry website Inside.com reports that Smith told his audience: "I think this is the first time fisting has ever been discussed at the Academy," referring to a scene from Chasing Amy.

Standing at a podium between two giant Oscar statues, the director noted, "I figure this is the closest I'll ever get to one of these - especially after tonight."

Smith spent the entire evening fielding questions about his career, his films and his experiences in Hollywood from the audience of several hundred people.

He also offered advice to would-be screenwriters, but with the caveat: "You don't want to take notes from me - I made Mallrats."

"Just write what you want and finish what you start," Smith told the audience. "Of course, what I just said is the worst advice I could possibly give you if you want to make any money in this business."

Reminiscing about his community college experience, Smith told the audience: "I took a lot of criminology and criminal justice classes because I figured they would lead toward my ultimate goal of being Batman."

The director, who is currently working on the road movie, Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back, mused on the internet: "I'm still not convinced that the net isn't just the same five of us talking to each other over and over again." (This despite - or perhaps because of - his production company's extremely popular site View Askew.)

Finally, he defended last year's controversial film, Dogma. "I don't care what anybody says, Dogma was my valentine to God."

webTitle: Rivaro ready to pass Oxford examination

fields.headline: Rivaro ready to pass Oxford examination
fields.standfirst: The Six Nations player makes his University debut today
fields.trailText: The Six Nations player makes his University debut today
fields.body:
From the Azzurri to the Light Blues. In bygone days the University match could be the making of an international player. The 119th Oxford-Cambridge game at Twickenham today, though, completes a year in which Marco Rivaro has gone from being a threequarter in Italy's Six Nations side back to amateur rugby as a student, breathlessly cramming training sessions between lectures.

In Cambridge, the city of bicycles, Rivaro's little white Lancia has become a familiar sight transporting him from his college, Hughes Hall, to the rugby ground at Grange Road. The 27-year-old, who has begun a two-year degree course in social and political science, is expected to give Cambridge an extra gear today as they seek to avenge last season's 16-13 defeat by Oxford.

He is not the only international on view. Oxford's pack features the United States prop Ray Lehner, who has won 39 caps for the Eagles, and the Australian flanker Brett Robinson, who has led the ACT Brumbies in the Super 12 competition. This pair make Oxford marginal favourites in a game that is always as tight as many of the spectators in this traditional bunfight for City gents.

Lehner and his fellow prop, the Welshman Hayden Jeffreys, are both over 18 stone. But a "game-breaker" is often needed to rise above the mayhem and Rivaro, who today, unusually, plays on the left wing, could be just that.

The past 16 months in the Italian's life have been an extraordinary roller coaster. After winning a first-class honours degree in law from Genoa university he came to London in August 1999 to study for a post-graduate diploma at Westminster university. The part-time rugby player picked up Yellow Pages and phoned the clubs in the capital, asking for trials. "The secretary at Saracens didn't even want to put me through but eventually Harlequins and London Irish offered me part-time contracts."

Rivaro chose to join London Irish, and the new Italy coach, the former All Black Brad Johnstone, watched him perform in Irish's televised game against Newcastle. "It really has been an amazing year. On January 1 I received a call from the Italian federation and Brad Johnstone called me into this huge training squad of 90 players in Tuscany. I was then picked for the Six Nations squad."

His meteoric rise continued when he came on the field early in the second half of Italy's historic first Six Nations win over Scotland in Rome, his three huge hits on the hapless Scots helping ensure the 34-20 victory and cementing his place in the side for the games against Wales and Ireland.

"I love rugby," he says, "and the experience of winning against Scotland was unforgettable, but I didn't like it too much when rugby became a full-time job. By the end of the season I was exhausted and wasn't enjoying playing any more. When I was playing at London Irish it was very, very intense. Every time you came off the field at the end of the game, all you felt like having was an aspirin. But here at Cambridge, while the quality of rugby is very high and there is a group of talented young players, you can enjoy life too.

"Here the coach Tony Rodgers is sympathetic to your needs to find time to study. Sometimes we train at 7am before lectures or in the evenings because the club recognises that you have to attend classes."

Rodgers, the Cambridge coach for whom this is the 21st University match, has a laid-back style but it does not disguise the fact that Cambridge are intense in their preparations for this match. He is not the only international on view. Oxford's pack features the United States prop Ray Lehner, who has won 39 caps for the Eagles, and the Australian flanker Brett Robinson, who has led the ACT Brumbies in the Super 12 competition. This pair make Oxford marginal favourites in a game that is always as tight as many of the spectators in this traditional bunfight for City gents. Lehner and his fellow prop, the Welshman Hayden Jeffreys, are both over 18 stone. fields.headline: Please - call off the dogs
fields.standfirst:
Continuing our week-long job-swapping experiment, the Guardian's architecture critic Jonathan Glancey reviews 102 Dalmatians while, our film critic Peter Bradshaw takes his seat for English National Opera
'Where are all the close-ups?': Peter Bradshaw at the ENO
fields.trailText: Continuing our week-long job-swapping experiment, the Guardian's architecture critic Jonathan Glancey reviews 102 Dalmatians.
fields.body:
Cor blimey, Jimmy, half a mo - look you, up the canny apples and pears, like, bah gum. I'm terribly sorry. Aren't there just too many faux regional accents in that first barking sentence? Well, when the wonderful world of Disney sets a film in London, what can you expect but a chim-chiminee of stock British characterisations with scenery to match: Big Ben, Tower Bridge and immaculate red Routemaster buses.

I know that 102 Dalmatians, the Kevin Lima-directed sequel to Disney's 101 Dalmatians, is meant to be a fairy tale. Yet I couldn't help feeling - sitting through this 94-minute dog, people and parrot caper - that this movie alone could put down every vain attempt by New Labour to make its whizzo, privatised, Wap-phone New Britain a US cartoon-style reality. For this, me ol' chinas, is how Uncle Sam, Mickey Mouse and global corporations based in Seattle or wherever must see little old England today: as up-to-date as Hector's House or the adventures of Rin-Tin-Tin.

Both Dodie Smith's book 101 Dalmatians and the magical Disney cartoon it spawned in 1961 were set in London, too. In 102 Dalmatians, London is a city without a single high-rise building; where the chimes of Big Ben boom deafeningly (in reality they can barely be heard above the traffic); in which lovable cockney families (every one white) spend Sundays watching Punch and Judy shows (I ask you!); where the trains at foggy Green Park station are controlled by Victorian semaphore signals from a clapboard signal box. In Uncle Walt's London, it's either raining cats and dogs, pea-souped out or snowing. The working class is deferential and the train to Paris, from St Pancras rather than Waterloo, is a steam-hauled chocolate-and-cream Pullman.

Yes, but it's only a story. Don't take it so literally. Try and be an echt film critic. You see, I've got the vocabulary. Still, they didn't need to change the locomotive at the head of the Paris-bound, dalmatian-filled, Orient Express halfway to Dover from Flying Scotsman to BR Class 5 number 73082, did they? Stop whingeing like a child over train-spottery details, and concentrate on the spotty dogs, camera angles and screenplay. Get a grip, as they say on set. Enter the seasonal spirit. This is a film for the kiddies, not for some la-la-long-haired aesthete who writes in this paper mostly about architecture, cities and design. Wolves, too, mind you. Yes, but you're watching dalmatians. Stick to the point. But dalmatians are famously bad with children and since the 101 Dalmatians was released a couple of years back, dog pounds in LA have been dogged with Dalmatians. I've warned you. Start being a proper film critic now, or no walkies.

Here we go, then... Glenn Close as Cruella De Vil dressed in a wacky wardrobe of mad fur creations, designed by Anthony Powell, is a suitably diabolic pantomine witch, but the rest of the cast - animals aside - aren't very funny. Two thirds of the way through, I scribbled "Goes on a bit", but felt rather guilty for doing so. Perhaps children will love 102 Dalmatians, although I'm not too sure. Along with every other child I know, I loved the cartoon version, and 102 didn't seem a patch on it.

Also, there were no children at the Odeon Leicester Square preview, just a pack of seen-it-all critics who would surely prefer to be reviewing some obscure out-of-focus Romanian masterpiece about a young woman tractor driver who falls in love with a reclusive existential poet who... or maybe Lassie Come Home.

A thing of spots and patches, 102 Dalmatians does have some delicious moments. The denouement is gloriously messy: when the dogs, triumphing over the evil designs of Cruella De Vil and her camp couturier Jean Pierre Le Pelt ( jambonned into life a little too effortlessly by Gérard Depardieu) operate a Brobdingnagian baking machine that turns the dognapping villainess into a giant cake. A child's delight.

Cruella steals the show, whether piloting her Panther De Ville limousine manically through Paris streets (Paris equals the Eiffel Tower, baguettes, poodles and Renault 4 taxis - Renault 4s? ) or staggering deliriously across Westminster Bridge and seeing the Houses of Parliament, Portcullis House and New Scotland Yard covered in spotted dalmatian fur. How she howls through her mansion, part Addams family house, part Sir John Soane's Museum (one for the architectural buffs). How she barks at a wavering Jean Pierre Le Pelt: "Faint heart never won a fur lady." This line made me laugh, for the first time, an hour or so into the film. I began to write it down and then faced one of the difficulties of being a film critic: I couldn't see what my Biro was up to, and when I brought my notebook up to my eyes, I couldn't see the screen. How very different, I couldn't help thinking, from visiting a new building or part of a city I've not seen before and making my notes as I please in a cafe.

The script of 102 Dalmatians, by the way, abounds in puns - most of them as funny as a dog sicking up over the new Axminster. How do they get away with this stuff? The dogs themselves and special effects are fun to watch, but then comes the mandatory love interest bit, which children hate and which made me want to get out my unfinished copy of Medicine and Magnificence: British Hospital and Asylum Architecture, 1660-1815, by Christine Stevenson, which I just happened to have in my bag. But it was too dark to read.

In the affair on-screen, a silly chap with a Welsh accent (Ioan Gruffudd) plays man-as-misunderstood-yet-lovable-puppy who saves unloved dogs from beastly owners. He wears shorts for most of the film. Enough said. He falls for a Princess Diana lookalike (Alice Evans) who is a kind-hearted but efficient Anglo-American blonde probation officer, a nannyish breed that appears to put puppy boys' lives firmly on leads. I felt like scratching frantically on the Odeon doors at this point to go walkies.

Anyway, they go on a first date to an Italian restaurant shipped in from the Central School of Catering by the look of the decor, and eat spaghetti with meatballs. Meanwhile, their dogs and the parrot who thinks he's a Rottweiler and blathers on in an annoying mockney accent (Whoops, it's the voice of Eric Idle - say no more) stay at home to gawp at Disney's The Lady and the Tramp on video.

They watch the scene in which Lady and Tramp eat spaghetti with meatballs in the backyard of an Italian restaurant. So, people are dogs, too - geddit? Or dogs are people. Whichever, the trouble here is that the love scene between spaniel and mongrel in the enchanting cartoon is infinitely more touching than that between the goody-two-paws Welsh boy and Anglo-American Princess Diana lookalike in 102 Dalmatians. The dogs are good, though...

Back outside the cinema, the real London comes thankfully back into focus, this mongrel city of second-rate skyscrapers, of Starbucks and McDonald's, where the buses are dented, the people are every colour under the rainclouds and no one says: "Cor blimey, guv, half a mo', up the old apples and pears."

Back to the day job with a bang, but with thoughts not so much of the film I've tried my best to review, but of the many more than 102 dogs, dalmatians or otherwise, that will be bought as Christmas presents - then dumped at pounds for what could be the rest of their spotty and all too real lives.

 In the big shuffle tomorrow: TV critic Gareth McLean goes to the opera and dance critic Judith Mackrell visits a gallery.

webTitle: Peter Bradshaw reviews the English National Opera

fields.headline: Where are all the close-ups?
fields.standfirst:
Our film critic Peter Bradshaw takes his seat for English National Opera
'Call off the dogs': Jonathan Glancey reviews 102 Dalmatians
fields.trailText: Our film critic Peter Bradshaw takes his seat for English National Opera.
fields.body:
For the centenary of Verdi's death in January 2001, Phyllida Lloyd has brought English National Opera the first fully staged production of the Requiem. This fiercely spartan production looked very strong when it came to evoking the human fear and trembling in the face of death, but demonstrated a less certain realisation of the hope of life eternal, which seemed to manifest itself in a bunch of gambolling children.

The Chorus are initially presented in serried, seated ranks, as if attending their own funeral, or perhaps a legal proceeding at which their own crimes are at issue. Stefanos Lazaridis's design has the performance space bounded by three whitewashed walls at the back and sides, which reminded me of the notorious leaflets about whitewashing your windows to "ward off" the heat flash of a nuclear blast. Certainly the grim faces of the Chorus seemed somehow ambiguous, as if absorbing some of God's anger, and defiantly returning it.

But simply sitting there, in however striking a tableau, is obviously not an option for 90 minutes. So there is movement. The Chorus cower behind their chairs; they clutch each other, like a therapy group in hell; they rush to the back; they rush to the front; they rush to the middle. In one faintly Beckettian moment, they all put on blindfolds as if awaiting the divine firing squad.

These are happy inventions, but I was less comfortable with the children, dressed brightly in contrast to the black-clad adults. There is an unhappy moment when the adults have to run about in panicky circles in infant school music-and-movement mode. But the overall effect is sturdy and sure-footed.

It was beautifully sung, though I am not qualified to make further judgment, and there is something cinematic about Verdi's grandiloquence, and arguably something cinematic inherent in taking a choral piece and animating it so that it becomes in a sense its own soundtrack.

As a big setpiece, Lloyd has a seven-ages-of-man sequence with a naked, pregnant woman coming on, followed by a baby, a child, and so on up to an old lady. That, combined with the coincidence of the date of the Verdi centenary, reminded me of the end of Kubrick's 2001, with successive visions of an ageing human self.

The experience is actually a culture shock in different ways for the cinema critic. The way people move looks very earth-bound, compared with the hyper-real agility conferred by film on people in the most normal of situations. On screen, no one hesitates or missteps- at least not without some elaborately flagged reason. But on stage, there are a thousand infinitesimal uncertainties.

The experience of watching opera renders superfluous the cinema critic's expertise in assessing the composition of a "shot". Often force of habit had me complaining for a fraction of a second: surely this set-up is wrong? A is sitting behind B and I can't see his facial expression. Can't we cut to a close-up of A's face, then to A's view of the back of B's head? Actually, another strange learned reflex for the critic comes into play in just looking, head-on, at the proscenium arch for an hour and a half. I kept thinking of it as the longest static wide shot imaginable. And, used to the manner of arthouse masters like Theo Angelopoulos, who seems to have only about a couple of dozens edits in each movie, the critic can hardly avoid thinking: "Hmm, how interestingly severe - holding this shot for 90 minutes."

Another culture shock for this cinema critic is that here I was forced to look at faces in a way subtly discouraged by the cinema. On screen, an important speaker is shown in close-up with crashing music if they are saying something important. Then they disappear from shot. In this production, with the entire company on stage throughout, you can look at any face you like, for as long as you like, where they are normally visible, without the coercion of the camera. In some ways, it is a more human, more democratic experience than the cinema.

webTitle: Voluntary sector has a lot to teach government

fields.headline: Voluntary sector has a lot to teach government
fields.standfirst: If the government is to succeed in establishing an effective strategy for disadvantaged youth, it needs to learn from agencies like Centerpoint, writes chief executive Victor Adebowale
fields.trailText: If the government is to succeed in establishing an effective strategy for disadvantaged youth, it needs to learn from agencies like Centerpoint, writes chief executive Victor Adebowale.
fields.body:
Over the past month, a plethora of announcements about the New Deal, beggars, drugs, rough sleepers and curfews for young offenders, have given the distinct impression that the government is worried about young people in our communities. The latest attempt to try to pull this area of social policy together comes in the form of the newly established children and young people's unit.

And in the middle of all this, casting a long shadow, has been the death of Damilola Taylor. While our hearts go out to Damilola's family and local community, his death has justifiably provoked a response, and in some ways confirmed the feeling that "something must be done".

But can we come up with an all-embracing strategy for young people which curbs anti-social behaviour, yet provides opportunities for children like Damilola? One which gives the most disadvantaged children a chance, while respecting the needs of young people as individuals? I firmly believe that we can, but in order to succeed the government needs to learn from agencies like ourselves, and to understand how the variety of complex problems faced by young people today fit together.

Those who work with young people every day know that if they are excluded, from school or from other opportunities, at an early age, they tend to remain excluded.

Too often the consequences of this exclusion are severely damaged young people, lacking basic building blocks in their lives - a home, family, friends, their health and basic skills such as literacy - that enable them to take advantage of the opportunities offered. They end up sleeping rough or begging; involved in crime or addicted to drugs; mentally unstable or permanently or endemically excluded. And far too often, this exclusion applies disproportionately to black and ethnic minority young people.

These young people, without the infrastructure and support provided by a stable social environment, are missing out on the government's solutions. The New Deal may have created opportunities for young people, but it hasn't yet reached this most disadvantaged group. webTitle: Welsh councils to have more control over funds

fields.headline: Welsh councils to have more control over funds
fields.trailText: Welsh councils are to gain more discretion over how they spend their budgets, the country's assembly announced today. By Simon Parker
fields.body:
Welsh councils are to gain more discretion over how they spend their budgets, the country's assembly announced today.

The Welsh Assembly currently "monitors" councils to ensure budget increases for services such as education and social care are spent on the areas intended, limiting the freedom authorities have to redirect the funding according to local priorities.

Ministers will now instead secure central goals through a system of policy agreements between the assembly and councils.

These will set targets for areas including education and the environment. Councils that sign up to the agreements and meet the targets could gain extra funding - the assembly has put aside a £10m performance incentive grant for the next financial year, and £30m for 2003-04.

Welsh Local Government Association leader Sir Harry Jones said: "The association has argued for several years that councils should be free to decide how best to deploy resources locally to meet the needs of their communities. Ring-fencing removed that discretion and was damaging for services outside education and social services."

Local government and communities minister Edwina Hart announced the move alongside next year's financial settlement for Welsh local government.

Councils will receive over £2.7bn to pay for frontline services, with £80m of that in specific grants. Overall, the settlement represents an 8% increase in revenue support. General capital funding, which councils can spend as they see fit, will rise 6% to £269m.

Ms Hart said the money should allow authorities to keep council tax increases to an average 3% in the coming financial year. "This settlement provides for councils to increase their spending on key services well ahead of inflation without any authority needing to set double-figure percentage council tax increases."

webTitle: Big Brother's Anna to host BBC Choice show

fields.headline: Big Brother's Anna to host travel show on BBC Choice
fields.standfirst: Dec 11: E4 signs up Big Brother's Melanie
fields.trailText:
8.15am: The lesbian former nun from Big Brother is to present a travel show for BBC Choice called Anna's Women, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Dec 11: E4 signs up Big Brother's Melanie
fields.body:
The lesbian former nun who was pipped to the post in Big Brother by scouser Craig Phillips has revealed that she is to host a travel show for BBC Choice called Anna's Women.

Anna Nolan's deal with the BBC digital channel comes as former Big Brother rival Melanie Hill nabs a presenting gig on a new reality TV show for Channel 4 digital entertainment channel E4.

Ms Nolan, who won the hearts and minds of viewers with her cool approach to the traumatic weekly voting and backbiting among contestants, has had several offers of TV work, but says she has been waiting for the right opportunity.

Ms Nolan told MediaGuardian.co.uk that she would be "travelling around the world and talking to interesting and bizarre women" in the six-part series.

The interviewees, which will include a Thai prostitute and a New York aristocrat, will all be "real women" according to Ms Nolan.

The high-profile series will be a boost to BBC Choice, which is being rebranded as BBC3, a youth channel that will compete with Sky One and the soon-to-launch Channel 4 digital channel E4.

Stuart Murphy, head of BBC Choice, said that the programme was an "interesting commission" for the channel.

He said: "Anna keeps a lot back in the Big Brother house, and I'm delighted that viewers will be able to learn a lot more about her in this exciting series."

The announcement follows the news that Melanie Hill, who notched up two romantic encounters with housemates while the series was on air, will front a reality show on E4.

fields.headline: Hollywood films a Kursk lookalike
fields.trailText: Hollywood film-makers are hoping that the world's fascination with the grisly fate of the Kursk will continue as they prepare to make a disaster movie about the sinking of a Russian nuclear submarine.
fields.body:
Hollywood film-makers are hoping that the world's fascination with the grisly fate of the Kursk will continue as they prepare to make a disaster movie about the sinking of a Russian nuclear submarine.

Harrison Ford and Liam Neeson were in Moscow last week to research their leading roles in the film, but out of concern for the feelings of the relatives of 118 men who died in the Kursk in August, the film-makers have chosen to dramatise a 1961 incident which shocked the Soviet Union.

In July that year the submarine K-19 - known affectionately as Hiroshima because of its history of radiation leaks - was left stranded in the middle of the Atlantic after an accident, cut off from all contact with the shore.

A small group of heroic submariners exposed themselves to potentially fatal levels of radiation in an attempt to repair the vessel.

Several died later from radiation poisoning.

Another Soviet submarine mounted a dramatic mission to save the crew.

The 1961 incident contains much of the horror and tension of the more recent disaster, with the added bonus - from the scriptwriters' point of view - that there are survivors who have been persuaded to help with the project.

The film has been given the working title, K-19: Making Widows, according to a report in Komsomolskaya Pravda.

Survivor agreed to cooperate only on the condition that the film's directors focused purely on the accident itself and the bravery of the Russian sailors rather than their private lives.

Neeson and Ford spent several hours last week talking to veteran submariners and survivors of past accidents in an attempt to understand the sense of fear that grips a crew when catastrophe strikes.

They also went to St Petersburg to explore a retired Russian submarine and received instructions on the workings of the vessel.

At the Sailors and Submariners Club, the K-19's captain, Vladimir Vaganov, played in the film by Neeson, gave them a detailed description of life on board.

A genuine Russian submarine - sold off as a tourist attraction in 1992 - has been obtained by the project's producers, and will be taken to Florida to be prepared for filming.

webTitle: Beeb.com unveils Top of the Pops competition

fields.headline: Beeb.com unveils Top of the Pops competition
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Beeb.com is to make a teenager's dream come true by offering the chance to appear on Top of the Pops, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Beeb.com is to make a teenager's dream come true by offering someone the chance to win a once-in-a-lifetime appearance on Top of the Pops.

The contest, which runs until January 2, will be eagerly fought out after more than 15,000 entries were recorded on just the first day.

To promote the competition, beeb.com is running an estimated £50,000 ad campaign in the national press and across leading websites.

Wannabes can enter via Top of the Pops' website at beeb.com [beeb.com/totp] simply by voting for their favourite ToTP Christmas performances.

Visitors to the site will also be treated to sneak previews of this year's Christmas ToTP line-up - including Madonna, U2, and Robbie Williams.

The overall winner will spend the day at ToTP's Elstree Studios on January 18 with three friends, before performing the track of their choice in front of a live studio audience.

fields.headline: Fayed 'paid for stolen papers'
fields.trailText: Mohamed Al Fayed paid £10,000 in "crisp readies" for documents relating to his libel battle with Neil Hamilton which were stolen from a lawyer's rubbish bin, it was claimed at the appeal court yesterday.
fields.body:
Mohamed Al Fayed paid £10,000 in "crisp readies" for documents relating to his libel battle with Neil Hamilton which were stolen from a lawyer's rubbish bin, it was claimed at the appeal court yesterday.

Lawyers for Mr Hamilton claimed the alleged theft invalidated last year's high-profile trial which ended with a jury declaring the former Conservative minister corrupt.

On the first day of Mr Hamilton's attempt to set aside the verdict, Anthony Boswood QC said the documents which had been stolen could have been used to help Mr Fayed's case.

Mr Boswood said the new "facts" cast "grave and very possibly fatal" doubt on the fairness of the five-week trial. "It's hard to imagine a more serious abuse of process than to obtain and pay for confidential and privileged material belonging to the other side's legal team. It completely undermines any confidence in the trial."

Mr Hamilton has been fighting for six years to clear his name, since the Guardian first reported the "cash-for-questions" controversy in 1994.

Mr Hamilton went on to sue Mr Fayed over claims he made in a Dispatches documentary broadcast on Channel 4 in 1997 that the former MP had demanded and received thousands of pounds in cash, Harrods gift vouchers and hospitality at the Ritz hotel in Paris in return for parliamentary services. Mr Fayed pleaded justification - that the allegations were true - and the jury found in his favour.

Yesterday Mr Boswood, who at this stage is seeking permission to bring a full appeal, told three judges that the verdict brought about "personal ruin" for Mr Hamilton. He faced a legal bill of £2m, but this year won a stay on paying £500,000 towards the sum after it emerged that police were investigating the allegations that Mr Fayed had paid for stolen documents. Mr Fayed has denied the allegations. Last weekend police said they had found no case to answer.

Mr Boswood insisted, however, that there was "cogent and compelling evidence" that highly confidential privileged documents had been taken from rubbish outside the chambers of Mr Hamilton's counsel Desmond Browne and passed on to Mr Fayed's camp in return for a "handsome cash reward and the promise of more".

He said the documents were obtained by Benjamin Pell, who is said to make a living rifling rubbish of the rich, famous and lawyers, and passing documents on to interested parties, including journalists.

Mr Boswood said the documents were handed to a freelance journalist, Mark Hollingsworth, who had frequently worked for Mr Fayed and had been engaged by his head of security, John Macnamara, shortly before the libel trial.

Mr Hollingsworth took the documents, which filled five brown envelopes, to Mr Macnamara who accepted them "gratefully", Mr Boswood said. Mr Hollingsworth was paid £10,000 in cash with the promise of a further £10,000.

Counsel for Mr Hamilton said it was "inconceivable" that Mr Fayed had not known what was happening, though it was apparently kept secret from his legal team.

Mr Boswood also claimed that Mr Pell had claimed that a Guardian journalist, David Leigh, had advised him to get the documents for Mr Fayed. Mr Hamilton's side could not say precisely what material had been obtained, nor what use had been made of it. But it was believed to include drafts of cross-examination notes and witness statements.

Mr Boswood said it should be presumed that Mr Fayed did make use of the material. He argued that if the trial judge, Mr Justice Morland, had been told of the evidence, he would in all probability have discharged the jury, investigated the matter, and then struck out Mr Fayed's case.

Even if the trial had continued, Mr Fayed's credibility would have been "truly destroyed at the very outset". He added: "It goes to demonstrate flagrant abuse of process and conduct which should have debarred Mr Fayed from defending the case at all."

Mr Boswood disputed an argument that Mr Hamilton would inevitably have lost the action because the outcome did not turn on anything said by Mr Fayed but on an allegation that Mr Hamilton had corruptly demanded a payment from Mobil Oil.

Mr Hamilton had claimed he had a legitimate consultancy with Mobil Oil in 1989. It later emerged that he had done little more for the company than table an amendment to that year's finance bill, for which he later demanded payment. Under parliamentary rules, taking cash solely for parliamentary action is corrupt. But Mr Boswood said it was nonsense to suggest that the Mobil allegation was overwhelming.

The hearing continues.

webTitle: Regeneration aims do not add up

fields.headline: Regeneration aims do not add up
fields.standfirst: The government wants to improve the lot of both urban and rural dwellers, but the countryside is always going to get the best part of the deal
fields.trailText: Analysis: The government wants to improve the lot of both urban and rural dwellers, but, says Tony Travers, the countryside is always going to get the best part of the deal
fields.body:
Despite the fanfare when the urban white paper was launched, there was nothing for the cities in the Queen's speech. Could that be because, read back-to-back with last week's rural white paper, the two contradict each other? Between them, the government intends to make it less likely that people will quit metropolitan centres and more likely that those who live in rural areas will be happy. The two objectives do not add up.

Here is the problem. For many years people have flooded away from older, larger towns and cities towards the safe beauty of the countryside. Once transport and telecommunications made it possible to enjoy the benefits of the city while living in the countryside, it is small wonder that millions fled the (often imagined) horrors of Manchester, Liverpool and the rest.

The table shows how satisfied people are with their local area. It demonstrates the problem faced by the government: over three-quarters of people living in rural areas are "very satisfied", compared with just 35% in urban locations. The less urban an area is the more popular it will be. Only 3% of people in the most rural areas are in any way dissatisfied with their area compared with 14-16% in urban areas.

The government said it wanted spending and tax breaks to increase the attractiveness of Britain's tatty cities. If more people could be persuaded to stay in them, developers would have less incentive to despoil what remains of England's green and pleasant land. John Prescott's department put together a respectable range of measures to make cities more financially and visually acceptable to their inhabitants.

Now look at the rural white paper. This certainly painted a less bleak picture of the countryside than its urban counterpart did about the cities. Nevertheless, the rural document highlighted problems such as falling farm incomes, declining village services, development pressures and isolation. New initiatives, funding programmes and local government changes are proposed. For example, there will be more money for rural policing, extra resources for affordable housing in the countryside, dramatic improvements in rural bus services and more powers for parish councils.

No one would oppose the proposed improvements to countryside services. For the poor, the non-car-owning and victims of crime in rural parts of the country there will always be a need for better public provision. The difficulty is that while problems in rural areas tend to centre on the poverty and difficulties of a minority of individuals, the white paper's solutions will have the effect of making the countryside as a whole even more attractive than it already is.

Urban areas would, without public intervention, have major advantages over rural ones. The provision of new technology, for example, is already far more widespread in the cities than elsewhere. Other things being equal, the benefits of agglomeration (as economists are fond of calling them) point to significant advantages for large towns and cities. Yet governments of all parties feel the need to bring such urban advantages to the most rural of areas. Universal telephone and postal services are provided by way of cross-subsidies from towns and cities.

The rural white paper makes clear how the government intervenes to bring the technological advantages of urban concentration to rural areas: "the market alone will not deliver affordable high-speed connections to all rural areas. We will therefore work through the development agencies to develop effective strategies for the roll-out of higher bandwidth (new cable and/or wireless links) services in rural areas, taking full advantage of public sector investment".

Though the urban paper makes similar commit ments, in effect, people living in the countryside - likely to be better off anyway - are to be publicly subsidised to bring the advantages of urban life to their doorsteps. It is small wonder that people who can afford it flock away from the grime and poor services of (particularly) the older, northern cities. By moving to rural areas, they enjoy less stressed schools and hospitals, cleaner air and a chance of living somewhere with which they are really satisfied. Better still, governments of all parties will guarantee that universal service provision is subsidised so all the relative advantages of the cities are on tap.

This is not to argue that people - particularly the vulnerable and children - who live in the countryside should be deprived of modern facilities and opportunities. But it is important to understand that society's kindly Fabian desire to ensure that no one, even in the most remote areas, should be denied a fuller set of public and private services than could be provided without subsidy is removing our cities' main advantage.

So the government's urban and rural white papers will, between them, provide both urban and country areas with marginal new advantages. However, by giving the countryside new and better public services, there must be the risk that even more people will want to go and live there. It is easier to put on new bus services in country lanes than to remove dereliction and deprivation from inner-city housing estates. The paradox is that stopping the urban exodus would probably require less government action to make rural areas attractive.

 Tony Travers is director of the Greater London group at the London School of Economics
