Other things being equal, the benefits of agglomeration (as economists are fond of calling them) point to significant advantages for large towns and cities. Yet governments of all parties feel the need to bring such urban advantages to the most rural of areas. Universal telephone and postal services are provided by way of cross-subsidies from towns and cities. The rural white paper makes clear how the government intervenes to bring the technological advantages of urban concentration to rural areas: "the market alone will not deliver affordable high-speed connections to all rural areas. We will therefore work through the development agencies to develop effective strategies for the roll-out of higher bandwidth (new cable and/or wireless links) services in rural areas, taking full advantage of public sector investment". Though the urban paper makes similar commit ments, in effect, people living in the countryside - likely to be better off anyway - are to be publicly subsidised to bring the advantages of urban life to their doorsteps. It is small wonder that people who can afford it flock away from the grime and poor services of (particularly) the older, northern cities. By moving to rural areas, they enjoy less stressed schools and hospitals, cleaner air and a chance of living somewhere with which they are really satisfied. Better still, governments of all parties will guarantee that universal service provision is subsidised so all the relative advantages of the cities are on tap. This is not to argue that people - particularly the vulnerable and children - who live in the countryside should be deprived of modern facilities and opportunities. But it is important to understand that society's kindly Fabian desire to ensure that no one, even in the most remote areas, should be denied a fuller set of public and private services than could be provided without subsidy is removing our cities' main advantage. So the government's urban and rural white papers will, between them, provide both urban and country areas with marginal new advantages. However, by giving the countryside new and better public services, there must be the risk that even more people will want to go and live there. It is easier to put on new bus services in country lanes than to remove dereliction and deprivation from inner-city housing estates. The paradox is that stopping the urban exodus would probably require less government action to make rural areas attractive.  Tony Travers is director of the Greater London group at the London School of Economics

webTitle: Tories hit at 'big lie' over the number of nurses

fields.headline: Tories hit at 'big lie' over the number of nurses
fields.trailText: Conservative and Labour health spokesmen accused each other yesterday of lying about the number of nurses needed to implement the NHS plan.
fields.body:
Conservative and Labour health spokesmen accused each other yesterday of lying about the number of nurses needed to implement the NHS plan.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, said Tony Blair's promise in July to recruit 20,000 more nurses by 2004 had been exposed as a complete fabrication.

He seized on a workforce analysis by the Royal College of Nursing suggesting that the 20,000 would include part-timers. If the government had presented its figures as full time equivalents, the proposed increase in staffing would have been between a quarter and a third smaller - easier to achieve, but less likely to be sufficient.

"Labour have constantly given the impression that the 20,000 will be working full time. Now the government has been forced to back-track into admitting they are nothing of the sort," Dr Fox said.

"Labour have lied in previous NHS announcements, with triple accounting about funding and double counting of doctors. Now they have been caught out on nurse recruitment. It is difficult to see how anything the government says on health can now be trusted.

"There is an increasing gap between the NHS that ministers talk about and the real NHS which nurses work in and patients are treated by," he said.

The first response from the Department of Health was to deny that the extra nurses were presented as full-timers. "We have made repeatedly clear to media and the nursing profession that our 20,000 target is a headcount figure. As whole-time equivalents usually make up around 65%-75% of a headcount figure, that equates to about 12-15,000 whole time equivalents."

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, capped this by accusing Dr Fox of inventing "the big lie" to undermine the NHS plan and prejudice the public against state provision for health.

The RCN report said the NHS would need to fill 110,000 vacancies by 2004. If retirements and other staff losses continued at their current rates the service would need to find 90,000 replacements before embarking on recruitment of the extra 20,000 promised by the prime minister.

With 53,000 new nurses expected to qualify over the next four years, the government would have to find 57,000 more by recruiting overseas or tempting back some of the 70,000 registered nurses who have left the profession.

The warning came a week before ministers publish recommendations from the nurses' pay review body.

webTitle: Action Time makes 'US election' game show

fields.headline: Action Time makes 'US election' game show
fields.trailText: 8.15am: TV producer Action Time has come up with a big money, interactive game show format inspired by the US election. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
TV producer Action Time has come up with a big money, interactive game show format inspired by the stalemate in the US presidential election.

In the Florida Trap contestants will be forced into knife-edge decisions over a potential £1m prize fund.

Just as in the US election, contestants can win the quiz show but ultimately lose the prize money because they have lost the public vote.

Stephen Leahy, Action Time managing director, said: "You can do everything possible to out-play and outwit your opponents and still end up a loser. Just when you think you've won, the votes are recounted."

In a show in which participants compete with each other to answer quiz questions and complete brain teasers, they also have to face a viewers' vote on their behaviour.

The Florida Trap mixes the big cash prize element of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? - offering a total cash prizes worth £1m - with the competition and public participation featured in reality game shows such as Big Brother.

Ten contestants start out with £5,000 stake money each and can win money off their rivals by answering general knowledge questions in a studio-based quiz. But they can also team up to solve more complex puzzles requiring lateral thinking.

At the end of each 60-minute show, contestants can make a plea to the audience, before £100,000 is distributed among the participants according to the percentage of votes each receives in a viewer poll.

Then the contestant with the least money - when their balance and the cash received from the viewer vote is added together - is eliminated.

Over the course of the series, £1m in prize money will be at stake, and Mr Leahy said he reckoned the eventual winner could walk away with £300-400,000.

"The dilemma for contestants is that they must try and knock-out their opponents in the quiz, by winning their stake money and sending them into negative equity," he added.

"But this behaviour may not endear the quiz winners to viewers when it comes to the vote."

Mr Leahy added that The Florida Trap would have a strong online element, with people being able to vote via the net, as well as by phone, and discuss different contestants' character and chances of winning on chatrooms.

He is talking to a number of UK broadcasters about the format and will also be pitching it to several US networks at the Natpe programming market next month.

The Florida Trap has already been optioned by broadcasters in Israel, Greece and Italy.

Action Time has worldwide rights to the new format, with talent agency CAA's Michael Comachao handling the US negotiations.

The indie, which is owned by Carlton Communications, is also producing upcoming Channel 5 psycho game show The Mole and distributing another, Survivor, around the world.

webTitle: Checks failure could allow 'bogus' GPs to treat patients

fields.headline: Checks failure could allow 'bogus' GPs to treat patients
fields.trailText: Few GP practices carry out even the most basic of checks on locums they employ, allowing incompetent or bogus doctors potentially to pick up temporary work where they could damage patients, acccording to the Consumers' Association.
fields.body:
Few GP practices carry out even the most basic of checks on locums they employ, allowing incompetent or bogus doctors potentially to pick up temporary work where they could damage patients, acccording to the Consumers' Association.

Research by the association reinforces the concerns spelled out recently by the audit commission and which the government has promised to address. The association interviewed locums and the surgeries that take them on.

They found that vetting was poor, too much rested of word of mouth, recruitment agencies could not be relied on to make necessary checks, and locums themselves were unhappy with the situation.

A survey in Health Which?, published by the association, found that 13% of the locums questioned were asked for their references the last time they worked in a new GP surgery. Only 4% were asked for proof of their identity and less than a third were asked to provide a copy of their CV.

Even though it is illegal for surgeries to employ locums who do not have the right GP qualifications, only 37% of locums were asked for proof of GP training. Fifty eight per cent were asked about medical defence insurance and a similar number for proof of GMC registration without which no doctor can practise.

webTitle: New rules aimed at closing pay gap

fields.headline: New rules aimed at closing pay gap
fields.trailText: The government yesterday promised to reinvigorate the 30 year old equal pay laws by placing the burden of proof on employers in sex discrimination cases.
fields.body:
The government yesterday promised to reinvigorate the 30 year old equal pay laws by placing the burden of proof on employers in sex discrimination cases.

A duty is to be placed on tribunals to hear almost all equal pay claims. At present a tribunal can dismiss a claim without examining the merits of the case if an employer can show there is no reasonable grounds for it being heard.

The employment minister, Tessa Jowell, said yesterday that reform of the Sex Discrimination Act would be a key step to improve the status of women. She also promised to widen the act's scope to cover indirect discrimination.

Changes to the act are required by EU directives.

The CBI immediately attacked the changes saying they contradicted separate moves by the Department of Industry to reduce the burdens of employment tribunals. The reforms were praised by the equal opportunites commission.

Streamlining of the tribunal system will include questionnaires to help women obtain key information from their employer at the start of a hearing, and a reduction in the number of experts giving evidence. In future only an indepndent expert appointed by a tribunal will give evidence and be cross examined.

Ms Jowell also promised to scrap a loophole allowing tribunals to dismiss cases before they are even heard. In future a tribunal would either have to consider the claim itself or appoint an independent expert to consider it.

Research published by the Department of Employment yesterday showed that the gender pay gap has halved from 37% to 18% since the Equal Pay Act was introduced in 1970.

But Ms Jowell said in recent years the best help for women in lower paid jobs such as catering had not been the Equal Pay Act, but the introduction of the minimum wage.

She estimated there was "a lifetime earnings gap" of £241,000 for a "middle skilled" childless woman.

For a mother with two children there was an additional £140,000 gap.

John Cridland, deputy director general of the CBI, said: "The proposal to remove the no reasonable grounds defence will worry business because it may make it more difficult to dismiss weak claims. It is a move in the opposite direction to recent tribunal reforms, which aim to free employers from defending no hope cases."

webTitle: One in seven viewers quits Panorama

fields.headline: One in seven viewers quits Panorama
fields.trailText: Viewing figures for BBC1's flagship current affairs programme, Panorama, have plunged since it was moved to Sunday night, a senior corporation manager admitted last night. By Rebecca Allison.
fields.body:
Viewing figures for BBC1's flagship current affairs programme Panorama have plunged since it was moved to Sunday night, a senior corporation manager admitted last night.

Tony Hall, the BBC's head of current affairs, said figures for the long-running series have fallen by 14% since its move into a slot branded a "graveyard" by critics. The move to 10.15pm on Sunday, made in October against the wishes of Panorama journalists and production staff, was made in the ratings war raging between BBC1 and ITV.

In an interview Mr Hall said: "Yes, the ratings are down, but the Sunday night slot is not a graveyard slot. I started off worried about it, but let's see what happens. It's 14% down, but we're still hooking into an awful lot of people," he said.

Mr Hall said the programme was still breaking high profile stories: "There's a smell in the air, a belief that current affairs is a dying genre. I absolutely reject that. Look at Panorama. Since the summer we've had the Omagh programme, an in vestigation into Nike and a tough investigation into paedophiles," he said.

The move was forced by the decision of Greg Dyke, the director general, to transfer the main evening news bulletin from 9pm, stealing a march on ITV, whose 10pm bulletin three nights a week starts in January. BBC governors had prevented Mr Dyke from moving Panorama to BBC2.

It is understood that staff remain furious at the move. John Ware, Panorama's reporter on the Omagh bombing, was one of the first senior journalists to go public with their concerns. "The fact that it will go out on BBC1 is a fig leaf to cover the fact that it will no longer air in prime time," he said.

Meanwhile as part of Mr Dyke's shakeup, many of the BBC's specialist reporters are being asked to focus on radio or television, rather than across the two media. The reorganisation is intended to address a number of concerns: Radio 4's news programmes, in particular, have felt neglected in recent years as investment and resources have poured into television news.

In an interview Mr Hall said: "Yes, the ratings are down, but the Sunday night slot is not a graveyard slot. I started off worried about it, but let's see what happens. It's 14% down, but we're still hooking into an awful lot of people," he said. Mr Hall said the programme was still breaking high profile stories: "There's a smell in the air, a belief that current affairs is a dying genre. I absolutely reject that. Look at Panorama. Since the summer we've had the Omagh programme, an in vestigation into Nike and a tough investigation into paedophiles," he said. The move was forced by the decision of Greg Dyke, the director general, to transfer the main evening news bulletin from 9pm, stealing a march on ITV, whose 10pm bulletin three nights a week starts in January. BBC governors had prevented Mr Dyke from moving Panorama to BBC2. It is understood that staff remain furious at the move. "The fact that it will go out on BBC1 is a fig leaf to cover the fact that it will no longer air in prime time," he said. Meanwhile as part of Mr Dyke's shakeup, many of the BBC's specialist reporters are being asked to focus on radio or television, rather than across the two media. The reorganisation is intended to address a number of concerns: Radio 4's news programmes, in particular, have felt neglected in recent years as investment and resources have poured into television news.

webTitle: A face for radio, BBC tells reporters

fields.headline: A face for radio, BBC tells reporters
fields.trailText: The lure of television has proved a powerful motivator for dozens of BBC correspondents, but some of them are being told today that their faces just do not fit any more.
fields.body:
The lure of television has proved a powerful motivator for dozens of BBC correspondents, but some of them are being told today that their faces just do not fit any more.

As part of a reorganisation, many of the BBC's specialist reporters are being asked to focus on radio or television - and some have been left with the impression that their craggy features simply were not welcome on the small screen.

The 30 or so specialists who work in the corporation's social affairs unit - which includes education, health and media reporters - are being briefed today on their new roles. A number were told of their future yesterday; one described it as "a bloodbath".

They have worked across both radio and television as part of the "bi-media" strategy begun by the former director general, John Birt, but that is now being dismantled under his successor, Greg Dyke.

Among those who have been assigned to radio is the highly regarded home affairs correspondent, Jon Silverman, who has made his name with trenchant reports on former war criminals living in Britain. His colleague Jane Peel will concentrate on television.

Rosie Millard, the arts correspondent who was landed in hot water recently over comments she made about Tory party policy, is to concentrate on the early television programmes such as Breakfast and the One O'Clock News, with her more sober-minded colleague Torin Douglas focusing on radio. Nick Higham will cover the 6pm and 10pm television bulletins.

The reorganisation is intended to address a number of concerns: Radio 4's news programmes, in particular, have felt neglected in recent years as investment and resources have been poured into television news.

Vin Ray, the executive editor at BBC newsgathering, said that radio reporters should not regard their role as inferior. "Radio is incredibly important to the BBC. We have to service radio as well as we have to serve television."

fields.headline: Count me in
fields.standfirst: A shop, restaurant or cinema cannot legally refuse entry to a disabled person. But a school can.  Dea Birkett  examines the implications of a new bill which looks set to open the school gates to all
fields.trailText: A shop, restaurant or cinema cannot legally refuse entry to a disabled person. But a school can. Dea Birkett examines the implications of a new bill which looks set to open the school gates to all.
fields.body:
When Lauren Roberts and her mother Julie went along to the local secondary school they were shocked by the poor welcome. "I always wanted Lauren to go there," says Julie, "but then we met this really negative attitude. They gave only excuses. Like, how will she get into school? How will she do the entrance test?

"I told them someone could read it to her, or photocopy it blown up very big. The teacher said they hadn't got the facilities for that. Another teacher came over and said: 'How will she play netball?'" Lauren pipes in, "What was really annoying was the school's motto, 'Makers of the past. Makers of the present. Makers of the future'. I'm a maker of the future!"

Lauren, now 14, is severely visually impaired. Until the age of 11, she travelled to a specialist school for the blind. But Lauren and her mother wanted her to attend a local mainstream secondary school.

Since October last year, a cinema, restaurant, shop or leisure centre cannot reasonably refuse their services to Lauren, but a school can. Currently there is little to prevent a school excluding a child on the grounds that they couldn't cater for their disability. Educational establishments were specifically excluded from part 3 of the Disability Discrimination Act.

But the new SEN (special educational needs) and disability rights in education bill, published last week, is designed to redress this exemption. For the first time, schools will be obliged to plan for the inclusion of all children. The presumption is that children with statements of special educational needs will be educated in mainstream. At last the excuses Lauren faced will no longer count as valid reasons to keep her from being educated with her peers.

The bill has been warmly welcomed by the disability lobby, teachers unions, the voluntary sector, and families with children with disabilities. But there's concern that some children may still face unnecessary hurdles. A controversial caveat in the bill states that a child with SEN shall be educated within mainstream provision unless it prejudices "the provision of efficient education for other children". It will be a continual point of debate. It could be challenged at the bill's committee stage early next year.

This caveat has been described as a cop-out clause, as nimbyism in the classroom. It's fine in principle to include all children - a laudable aim - but in practice when a child with a disability applies to go to a particular school, perhaps your school, only then do the objections arise from the local education authority, the teachers and other families.

Lauren is now happily in the third year of her mainstream secondary school, Waverley, in south-east London. "With Waverley it was different," says Julie Roberts. "They had such a positive attitude from the start."

Inclusion can be a long, slow process. Initially, Lauren attended only two days a week, building slowly up to full-time. The physical environment was unfamiliar to her; dinner and break times were spent sitting in the specialist learning centre, where she ate her packed lunch. Now she has school dinners and is in the playground with her friends. She has a support assistant and teaching support, in case she needs something copied down off the board or the content of a video to be described. The school provides very wide-lined paper for her to write on.

She proudly shows me her work, with projects on plant cells and soil erosion in Nepal. Pages from textbooks are photocopied on to large A3 sheets so she can read them close-up. She is allowed to keep all her work in one big ring folder with dividers, so she doesn't have to differentiate between subject books. "The only class I don't join in is metalwork, because of the machinery," says Lauren. "I do try sport, but in football I can't see the ball. Netball is better."

Disability is not a single condition, but covers a wide spectrum of needs. Stuart Hayter is head of an inner London primary school that prides itself on being inclusive. Alfred Salter is a newly built, fully accessible school, resourced for the hearing impaired, with 31 children with statements of educational needs on a school register of around 400. Hayter has been seconded by the local education authority to persuade other schools in the borough to become resourced for specific disabilities.

"The ones you can never persuade schools to take on are children with emotional and behavioural difficulties," he says. "They don't want to be a magnet for difficult children. To be fair, it's something even we would think twice about." But Hayter believes that the inclusion of even the most disruptive children is possible. "The whole staff has to be motivated to make it work. Staff should be trained to de-personalise themselves from any incident, and be able to deal with it." He adds, "You need a lot of training."

However good the intention of the new bill, the burden of inclusion inevitably falls on those with little knowledge of special needs. Seventy per cent of teachers will teach a child with autism; only 5% have had autism-specific training. "TheDisability Discrimination Act had training that went with it for people who ran businesses," says Lindsay Brewis, Scope's education adviser.

"This new bill has no staff training that goes along with it. There's nothing to help schools in how they might implement it, so schools are trying as they go along, and make mistakes. It's these mistakes that get the publicity. They create a wariness of taking children with disabilities."

Lauren's form tutor says it was a "matter of chance" that expertise was available. By coincidence, someone from Lauren's former school started working at Waverley, and could give them advice. Of course, training costs money, and there is as yet no financial package to accompany the new bill.

But money has been made available to make schools more accessible. Government funding for the Schools Access Initiative has been doubled to £220m over the next three years. But Lindsay Brewis still worries where this money is going to be spent.

"The Schools Access Initiative budget is often used for new schools, which would have to be accessible anyway, rather than making what already exists accessible," she says. "And there's often a very narrow view of what accessibility means. It's not just ramps and handrails. It's the acoustic environment, communications aids, assistive technology, or a cooling-off suite for EBD [emotional and behavioural difficulties] where children could go and thrash about a bit."

A little investment can go a long way towards inclusion. Wide-lined paper made all the difference to Lauren. Classroom teacher Sarah Beckwith, who admits she has "never had any training in SEN, just talked to past teachers", has an 11-year-old girl with cerebral palsy in her year 5 class at Lawley primary school in Telford.

"This year she's been given a computer with programmes that use phrases, so she doesn't have to key in every letter," says Beckwith. "Before, she was getting frustrated because she knew more than she was able to write down. She can join in the group work more, and others can use the computer for shared work. Now she's showing her capabilities."

With the emphasis on league tables, the concern of schools is often that children with special needs will adversely affect their results. "You've got mixed messages from government," says Stuart Hayter. "Standards, standards, standards - yet inclusion. They should put results into context far more. When you present league tables or other performance indicators, you can say there are 31 statemented children, but you can't say the nature of their difficulties. A bright child with physical disability is not the same as a child with severe learning difficulties. The simple numbers don't explain the impact. But sometimes people worry too much about Sats results. You have to be a bit more broad-shouldered."

Jan Nicolas, chief executive of Parents for Inclusion, argues that inclusion can increase your league table status. "By including a wider range of children whose potential to date may not have been recognised, the overall achievement of the school may benefit," she says. A National Autistic Society report, Inclusion. Is it Working?, found that the more able children were more likely to be excluded - 29% compared to 21%. More able children are less likely to receive the support they need, as their disability is not so obvious. And because they don't receive the support, including them can be more difficult.

To some families, there appears to be an impossible burden on children with special needs. John King's 10-year-old son Thomas, who has cerebral palsy, is in the final year of mainstream primary school. He applied to mainstream secondary, but the local education authority has raised objections; in a recent amended statement they said Thomas "can distract others", a potential reason for exclusion under the "prejudicial to other children" caveat. "He's pushed over a pencil pot a couple of times!" says King. "As soon as you have a child with SEN they take things any other child would do and turn it into a problem."

Lindsay Brewis sees the caveat as putting the onus on children with SEN to behave better than the general population. "The caveat is there for all children already. Any child that prejudices the development and learning of the rest of the school can be excluded or not admitted. Do we need to have it restated for children with SEN? It has been used to exclude those who are just difficult to accommodate, rather than those who are genuinely prejudicial to the education of other children."

Many schools have found that including those with SEN enhances the school life of the other children, rather than prejudicing it. Anne Parrish's eight-year-old, who is not disabled, goes to Alfred Salter Primary School. Anne had not come across children with disabilities until her daughter went to the school nursery. "I think it's really good that disabled children join a school from the very start. Then the other kids just see them as part of the class. If they come later on, or at secondary school, you and they wonder 'What's that?' They realise early on what a child with a disability can do. You shouldn't judge a book by it's cover."

"It's made them more understanding," says Lauren's form tutor. "I'm not saying they're angels - because they're not. But there's more of a community spirit about. It's developed a caring side of their nature that we don't always get to see."

John King has gathered together letters from the children in Thomas's class, supporting his son's application for a mainstream secondary place. "I'm in Thomas's class and it is, to me, the luckiest class in the school," wrote one girl. "He needs extra help in some things, but that doesn't mean he's different. He wants to go to your school because he likes it. I'd like to be in the same class as him if you let him in. He always joins in our games, comes to assembly. So please let him in."

webTitle: Murdoch faces foxy opponent in $2bn network row

fields.headline: Murdoch faces foxy opponent in $2bn network row
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch, the head of NewsCorp, is attempting to prevent his partner in the Fox Family children's network from demanding up to $2bn in cash for his stake, reports Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch, the head of News Corporation, is being forced to use his considerable negotiating skills to prevent his partner in the Fox Family children's network from demanding up to $2bn in cash for his stake.

Haim Saban, chief executive of the network and owner of 49.5% of Fox Family, is preparing to exercise a put option on the five-year-old venture. Under the terms of the deal, Mr Saban can ask Mr Murdoch to give a "fair market value" for his stake on December 31.

A report in the Wall Street Journal yesterday suggested that Mr Saban wanted about $2bn for the stake in the network, which has struggled to win market share in the past three years.

However, Mr Murdoch is unwilling to pay cash and is looking at options including the use of shares. Analysts also believe the two men will differ markedly over valuation of the business. Failure to come to an agreement could result in sale of the Fox Family network by the two companies.

In a statement yesterday, Mr Saban said he "valued" his relationship with News Corp and was discussing the future of the network with Mr Murdoch and other executives.

A month ago Mr Saban denied any interest in selling but yesterday's statement said: "Mr Saban will decide shortly whether to exercise the right to require News Corp to buy its interest in Fox Family for a fair market value in cash."

Mr Saban, who is thought to have hired Morgan Stanley to advise him on the issue, is understood to feel the contract gives him the upper hand in the negotiations because it forces Mr Murdoch to pay him something for the business.

The put option comes at a difficult time for Mr Murdoch. He is keen to purchase a US satellite broadcaster, such as Hughes Electronics' DirecTV, owned by General Motors. His ability to raise the cash needed could be hampered by Mr Saban's demands.

Chris Dixon, analyst at UBS Warburg, said the Fox negotiation should not have much impact on the Hughes deal because the latter involves Mr Murdoch's satellite assets.

Mr Murdoch has long been more amenable to complicated share swaps than straight cash deals.

A spokesman for News Corp declined to comment yesterday.

fields.headline: NatMags ties knot with wedding mags publisher
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Publisher NatMags has acquired a controlling stake in specialist publisher AIM Publications, writes Jessica Hodgson
fields.body:
The National Magazine Company has acquired a controlling stake in specialist publisher AIM Publications, which publishes You & Your Wedding, London Wedding and Bride and Groom.

AIM will be absorbed into NatMags and retain its managing director, James Buchanan, but will be renamed NatMag Specialist Media.

The company will stay at its current location in Beak Street, but may move into the NatMags office on Broadwick Street if the company expands.

This is the second acquisition by NatMags in the past six months. In August, the company acquired the UK arm of German media group Gruner + Jahr, which publishes magazines including Prima, Best and Your Home.

webTitle: Consumers win powers at giant media watchdog

fields.headline: Consumers win powers at giant media watchdog
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Net news
fields.trailText: A powerful consumers' panel is to be placed at the centre of a proposed giant single media regulator covering television, radio, advertising, the internet, telephones and the press.
fields.body:
A powerful consumers' panel is to be placed at the centre of a proposed giant single media regulator covering television, radio, advertising, the internet, telephones and the press.

The new regulator, dubbed Ofcom, will be outlined in today's communications white paper as the government's main response to the blurring of boundaries between media technologies.

The independently appointed consumers' panel will have powers to commission research, canvass public opinion and publish advice to the regulator, as well as its views on issues of taste, programme content and quality.

It will also advise Ofcom on its regulatory powers, including decisions on media ownership rules. The panel could for instance argue against Rupert Murdoch being allowed to extend his media empire into terrestial television.

The government accepts that economic regulation decisions directly affect consumer concerns such as price, choice, and programme content.

Some ministers privately hope the panel may also act as a powerful popular restraint on media magnates, allowing government to step back from the front line of the battle to control media quality.

A government source said the move would put consumers "at the heart of regulation".

He added: "This is a world where some of the most powerful companies in the world operate and lobby bloody hard."

The source added that the consumers' panel could also consult through citizens' juries and the internet.

fields.headline: Neighbourhood TV 'coup' brings network closer
fields.trailText: A network of free-to-air local television stations, featuring news, sport and entertainment, is being planned to sit alongside the present five terrestial channels.
fields.body:
A network of free-to-air local television stations, featuring news, sport and entertainment, is being planned to sit alongside the present five terrestial channels.

The stations, with catchment areas of 20,000 to 600,000 people, are to be started over the next two years by VFG, a little-known film and TV production business quoted on the alternative investment market.

The company yesterday announced that for £7.4m it has secured 36 licences across the country in a series of small acquisitions.

So-called restricted service licences have been issued in several tranches by the independent television commission since 1997 to allocate spare analogue spectrum, but the majority have been dormant. Most of the stations that did launch were beset by financial or technical difficulties.

David Stamp, VFG's chief executive, said that aggregating the licences would provide a better chance of success.

"The market for local advertising is worth around £4bn but local television has pretty much been ignored by the larger media groups. VFG is a small AIM company which has managed to pull off a real coup," he said.

The channels will cover editorial ground previously the preserve of the local press, from fétes to pensioners marking their century. "If someone in your street or neighbourhood reaches 100 then I think that is a very valid local story," said Mr Stamp.

The group is aiming to raise £50m through a second round of financing and claims to have been in discussions with a number of trade investors.

Yattendon Investment Trust, the local newspaper group which owns titles in Hertfordshire and Essex, has put in just under £2m and will cross-promote stations in its areas.

Despite low budgets, Mr Stamp insisted the emphasis would be on quality programming. There would be similar quality thresholds placed on advertisers. One aim is to set up a national advertising sales operation.

If successful the company will restore credibility to licences which have barely registered on the national consciousness. Chris Smith, the culture secretary, welcomed the company's commitment to getting services running.

VFG has formed a new company, Local Broadcasting Group, to manage the stations which it expects will employ 750 people once the the existing licences are on air. LBG will be run by David Lowen, a former director of Yorkshire Television.

The 36 licences reach 4m people in several clusters in Scotland, south-east England, East Anglia and the south-west. VFG aims to acquire other licences as they become available.

After the deals announced yesterday, VFG will control 55% of the local TV licences currently on offer.

The stations will all be locally branded and can be received by tuning in a spare channel on any TV set.

The largest acquisition was of Herts TV - holder of 22 licences - for £1m cash plus 3m shares in LBG. The others were City Television (seven licences), Glasgow's Own Television Channel, On Ayr Television and the licences for Edinburgh and Aberdeen from Channel 6.

VFG shares inched 2.5p higher to 35.5p.

webTitle: Big Brother pair get own shows

fields.headline: Big Brother pair get own shows
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Two of the most memorable characters to emerge from Channel 4's summer sensation, Big Brother, are to launch rival television careers on competing channels.
fields.body:
Two of the most memorable characters to emerge from Channel 4's summer sensation, Big Brother, are to launch rival television careers on competing channels.

Anna Nolan, the lesbian former nun, is to front a Whicker's World-type travel show for the BBC, while Melanie Hill, whose on-screen kiss with Andy was one of Big Brother's steamier moments, is to present a game show for Channel 4's entertainment station, E4, to be launched next month.

Ms Nolan's quest will be to "examine femininity across the globe". She meets a prostitute in Thailand and an aristocrat in New York for the six-part series, Anna's Women, on BBC Choice.

Signing her is part of a strategy to reposition Choice as an entertainment network, in preparation for its relaunch next year as BBC3, subject to approval by the culture secretary, Chris Smith. Sources say the series is being made for £150,000 per half-hour.

E4 announced yesterday that Melanie Hill will present Chained, in which six people are manacled together 24 hours a day. One contestant is nominated the "picker", and each day gets rid of another until an "ideal date" remains.

Ms Hill will find out how the contestants feel about each other, who the picker will unchain next, and how the freed contestants feel about their experience. The contestants will survive on a prize fund of £5,000. The picker is allowed to keep whatever is left at the end of the week.

webTitle: LineOne hires celebs for new-look website

fields.headline: LineOne hires celebs for new-look website
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Internet firm LineOne has signed up celebrities including Joan Collins and George Best in a bid to attract new users, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Internet firm LineOne has opted for the celebrity route in a bid to attract new users and boost its image while its backers negotiate a trade sale.

The portal has signed up a number of media personalities to write exclusively for the new-look site, which it has already started billing as the "portal with personality".

The move marks a change of direction for the ISP that has decided that its core focus should be the 30 to 45-year-old audience.

Joan Collins will contribute a regular column giving lifestyle advice; Ruby Wax is to write about de-stressing; George Best gives his views on football, while Craig Charles writes about games and entertainment for the website.

Explaining how she first got involved in the internet, name-dropper Joan Collins, said: "It was Shirley MacLaine who first switched me on to the net. Suddenly it seemed to me this was now the best way to communicate. There is now no barrier between my public and me."

The high-profile additions to the website coincide with a number of new features, including personalised user home pages, an online organiser - My Calendar - that updates itself and sends text message reminders and a system that helps you manage incoming calls while you're surfing called LineOne Call Manager.

The new-look, new-focus LineOne is to be bolstered by a £20m marketing campaign kicking off in the new year, which will run across all media.

LineOne, which is expected to be sold before the new year, claims to have around 1.4m registered members with 1m unique users visiting its portal every month.

webTitle: Bad Girls in trouble in Australia

fields.headline: Bad Girls in trouble down under
fields.trailText: 8.15am: ITV's Bad Girls has run into trouble down under after a chain of adult clubs complained the prison drama was giving its topless dancers a bad name. By Patrick Barkham.
fields.body:
Bad Girls, the award-winning ITV series, has run into trouble down under after a chain of Australian adult clubs of the same name complained that the prison drama was giving its topless dancers a bad name.

The owners of the Bad Girls trademark in Australia are to lodge a complaint with a Queensland state court and seek damages from the Seven Network, the channel which imported the drama from the UK.

"The key aspect of their business is that they rely upon attractive... desirable women," said Robert Hynes, legal spokesperson for Cross Promotions, Cross Calenders and The Drink Nightclub, which run several nightclubs in Queensland featuring naked, dancing "Bad Girls".

"The difficulty with the programme that's being aired by Channel Seven under the same name is that it relates to women who have committed offences, are in prison, [and] are certainly of a very different type to what the stereotyped Bad Girl is for my clients," Mr Hynes told Sydney's Daily Telegraph.

Bad Girls formed part of the Seven Network's high-profile campaign to hold on to the vast audiences it gained during the Olympics.

But the drama was not a massive ratings-winner for the channel, which has been comprehensively beaten by Kerry Packer's Channel Nine in the post-Games ratings battle.

Australia, of course, invented the women-get-up-to-mischief-in-prison genre, with the cult soap opera Prisoner Cell Block H.

fields.headline: FSA ducks Equitable blame
fields.trailText: Howard Davies, chairman of the financial services authority, yesterday defended its handling of the crisis that has engulfed Equitable Life but dashed some policyholders' hopes by saying it was "too early" to talk about a full-scale inquiry.
fields.body:
Howard Davies, chairman of the financial services authority, yesterday defended its handling of the crisis that has engulfed Equitable Life but dashed some policyholders' hopes by saying it was "too early" to talk about a full-scale inquiry.

He said the City watchdog would reflect on what lessons could be learned, and that its new approach to regulating financial services companies meant "this kind of thing would be handled in a different kind of way in the future".

Mr Davies was speaking three days after the company closed to new business and warned existing policyholders they could expect lower investment returns after it failed to attract a buyer.

These moves, plus its decision to impose a 10% penalty on any with-profits pension customer wanting to switch from the company, left many of Equitable's 650,000 policyholders worried and confused.

The company said yesterday it had received thousands of calls to its helpline but it was too early to say how many people intended to move their money. It will write to policyholders in the next few days .

Equitable put itself up for sale after losing a legal battle involving guarantees given to some policyholders. Some commentators have said the FSA should have taken action earlier and criticised the decision to allow Equitable Life to continue selling policies until late last week, even after reports that the potential bill faced by the insurer to meet the guarantees might be much higher than originally thought.

Mr Davies said: "I believe that since we took over responsibility for this, which was only in January 1999, we have acted appropriately. I think what we have done has been a reasonable attempt to find a way out of what has been a very difficult situation.

"We took the view that policyholders' interests were best served by allowing the firm to seek a sale."

Equitable could face more legal action, from policyholders angry about its refusal to extend annuity guarantees to policyholders' partners, usually widows. Leon Kaye, a solicitor acting for some policyholders, said court action was "very much possible".


Callers left with many questions, few answers


Roderick Clyne, an Equitable Life policyholder for 12 years and a Guardian journalist, relates how he fared when he phoned Equitable's helpline for worried customers:

"I have an old-style retirement annuity contract with Equitable, left over from my years of self-employment and working on non-pensionable contracts. I have another fund built up at Equitable as a result of additional voluntary contributions I make to the Guardian's pensions scheme.

"I have been increasingly worried since the court cases started going against Equitable but did not start panicking until this weekend, when I started having visions of my carefully hoarded funds becoming worthless following a classic run on the bank. Seeking reassurance, I logged on to the company's website, to be greeted with the ominous words 'Equitable online client service is currently unavailable'.

"The first two calls to the company advice line resulted in silence - not even a ringing tone - but at the third attempt I was answered within seconds. I found that one of my two policies was covered by the annuity guarantee.

"I asked whether I could pretend to retire early, thus avoiding the harsh penalties for transferring the fund to another provider. 'We'll have to phone you back on that one,' I was told. I am still waiting."

webTitle: Prisons chief urges sale of inner city jails

fields.headline: Prisons chief urges sale of inner city jails
fields.standfirst:
Victorian buildings in prime locations may be offered to developers so cash can be reinvested in the system
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: Victorian prisons, some of which have put in more than 150 years of penal servitude, could be sold on the open market to raise funds to improve conditions inside the rest of the system.
fields.body:
Victorian prisons, some of which have put in more than 150 years of penal servitude, could be sold on the open market to raise funds to improve conditions inside the rest of the system.

Martin Narey, the director general of the prison service, revealed his plan in response to criticism from the chief inspector of prisons about conditions in the 37 jails in England and Wales.

The most likely candidates are those in prime inner London suburban sites such as Wandsworth, Pentonville and Brixton, which would attract developers interested in providing loft-style yuppie apartments. But Victorian prisons such as Leeds, Reading and Winchester, some of which have also been in continuous use since the 1840s, could also prove attractive to developers.

Mr Narey said the bill for maintenance and repairs stood at £800m and he could not promise that the Treasury would provide the needed injection of funds.

"One of the biggest differences of culture and attitude is between prisons that are old and new. It is not a matter of public or private," said the director general.

"One of the things I would like to do over the next few years is to replace some of the Victorian prisons and to sell them and use the resources, some of which should be significant because of their location, to build prisons which are fit and decent to house prisoners in the year 2000."

Mr Narey said the backlog of repair work was now so large that "if it were somebody's house I would think they would move out completely. I do not think we can expect to carry on with prisons built 130 years ago for the next 50 years".

The idea would be to match the prisons sales programme with a programme of new prisons, probably funded through the private finance initiative. The use of greenfield sites might be limited by the need to locate the new prisons near existing courts.

A non-executive director of the prisons board has already been asked to draw up a list of prisons which would raise a reasonable price.

Many Victorian prisons were built on a radial design developed by the utilitarian philosopher Jeremy Bentham, and by a Major Webb. Their design, whereby the wings sprout from a central hub like spokes from a wheel, first appeared at Pentonville prison in north London and has been copied around the world.

One problem facing potential developers is that parts of the prisons which are the most likely candidates are listed buildings. Some 27 of the 37 Victorian prisons in England and Wales are partly or fully listed. At Wandsworth prison, south London, the gatehouse, and governor's and doctor's houses are all listed but some developers may be able to make a feature out of them.

Last night the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, said that he would support such a sales programme. "I would obviously welcome anything that is done to improve the facilities inside prison."

He added: "The old Victorian local prisons were not designed to do what the prison service aims to do. I don't believe the sites lend themselves to providing modern conditions. It is entirely logical to move the prisoners to 21st century conditions."

Sir David's report published yesterday said that many remand prisoners were held in worse conditions than those who had already been convicted.

He noted that the majority of prisoners on remand - many of whom did not receive a custodial sentence - were not allowed to wear their own clothes and were confined to their cells for most of the day because they were ineligible for work or education.

Making crime pay

Estate agents yesterday enthusiastically greeted the idea of a sell-off of Victorian jails, with an especially strong demand predicted for those in property hotspots in the inner London suburbs.

Richard Haynes, a partner in Knight Frank, said that the market was strong enough to overcome the stigma attached to prisons.

"I think it is a realistic proposition. It has worked with barracks. There has been the Peninsula barracks scheme at Winchester and Caterham barracks has been converted into a nice residential scheme.

"If they work on the basis that these prisons are passed the end of their useful life then they might as well cash in on the assets they have got."

The fact that many Victorian prisons have parts that are listed could prove an obstacle but the prospect of a development which features the cell where Oscar Wilde was held or the jail where the Kray brothers were behind bars might appeal to a more macabre clientele.

But one feature of Victorian prison life will not be available - the last working set of gallows was removed from Wandsworth in 1995.

Estate agents are convinced it would prove a money raiser. "Intensive inner [London] suburb sites like Wandsworth, Brixton, and Pentonville could easily fetch £500,000 or £750,000 per acre," said Tim Sketchley, a partner in Healey and Baker.

webTitle: Engel: Hunt the enemies of freedom

fields.headline: Hunt the enemies of freedom
fields.standfirst: Let people chase foxes and smoke dope, though probably not at once
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel: Many of those keenest on a hunting ban are most enthusiastic about lifting the restriction on cannabis. I think everyone should keep their traps shut about the pleasures of others which they do not understand.
fields.body:
Living in the country, we get a card through our letterbox every so often: the local hunt will be meeting on such-and-such a date, it says. "If the hounds pass your way, we hope they will be welcome." There is a phone number to call.

The subtext of this message is as follows: "We are going through the motions of asking permission to hunt over your property. And, yes, you have the right to stop us. But we can't imagine that the kind of muesli-eating wretch who would do such a thing is living round here in the first place." We have never rung up, and thus far the hounds have never come our way. Someone else has, though. This time last year our broody hen hatched three fluffy yellow ducklings (it's an effective form of avian surrogacy). No mother of triplets was as preeningly proud and maternal as she was. They were a lovely sight.

It was on the 10th morning that I found the four of them, or what remained: two severed heads, and a pile of feathers. The fox had destroyed my blockade with the casual arrogance of the hunt sending a postcard. He came back for afters too, picking off several more chickens and our best layer of duck eggs. Our once-proud collection of poultry now consists of four wet hens, who have not laid an egg between them in months, one lame duck (recently renamed Clinton) and one lubricious drake, whose sexual voracity and adventurousness cannot possibly be satiated by his one official mate. (He might also be called Clinton.)

So in the matter of fox-hunting I am a militant agnostic. I do not ride to hounds, only partly because the last time I got on a horse I froze in terror when it broke into a trot. But the fox is no friend of mine. By not making that phone call, I suppose I give my implied consent to hunting, an offence punishable - under the most extreme of the government proposals published last week - by a fine of £5,000 or else.

I find both sides of the argument vacuous. The pros make absurd claims about the economic and cultural importance of hunting in the countryside, and are incoherent about whether they are controlling a pest or protecting a vulnerable species. The antis are wholly remote from the persistently cruel reality of nature: foxes murder poultry; hounds murder foxes; cats murder songbirds; the British allegedly love animals but will eat millions of factory-farmed Christmas turkeys without asking any questions at all.

I am also baffled by the government's position. I'm sure Tony Blair cares not a stuff whether hunting is banned. But he seems to perceive political advantage in keeping the issue alive until the election. In theory, the Commons can take on the Lords; an almost united Labour party can take on the divided Tories; the anti- hunting majority can overwhelm the minority. Closer to May, it might not seem that way. As happened early in the Blair government, the hunting issue will get bundled in with all manner of rural discontents, with Labour painted as a party of urban ignoramuses; this will play very badly in many of the seats won in 1997.

There is another aspect. It was raised in a letter to the Times last Thursday signed by Sir John Mortimer, General Sir Peter de la Billière, Jeremy Irons, Ivan Massow and Roger Scruton. The tactic was stupid: letters like this need to be signed by one person or 50; five just looks pathetic. But the argument was valid: "A fundamental question of civil liberty is at issue ... to criminalise an activity which has the support of so many law-abiding people would constitute a radical and undesirable break with the liberal tradition of law-making in this country." This is true. So far as I can discover, sports like cock fighting that so engaged the 18th century were suppressed in the 19th only when religious revivalism created a significant consensus in favour of change. There is no consensus on hunting.

Curiously, many of those keenest on a ban are most enthusiastic about lifting the restriction on cannabis. I think everyone should keep their traps shut about the pleasures of others which they do not understand. The Attlee government lost its huge majority in 1950 largely because it was perceived as bossy and interfering: find-out-what-everyone-is-doing-and-stop-them-from-doing-it. It's a piece of history of which Blair should be more aware.

The modern Conservative party has no credibility on personal liberty; after all, it tried to stop people attending football matches without identity cards. But, if it had an ounce of sense, it would strangle Ms Widdecombe and establish itself as the party of genuine freedom. Let people hunt if they insist; and let them smoke dope too (but not both at the same time on the public highway). Better still, this could be a Labour battle cry.

matthewengel@ndirect.co.uk

webTitle: Sketch: Tory leader treads on his wicket

fields.headline: Owzat!
fields.standfirst:
Tory leader treads on his wicket

Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Tory leader treads on his wicket
fields.body:
The prime minister, reporting on the Nice summit, began with what sounded like swaggering arrogance. "After five gruelling days," he said, "the victory was secured!" Tories began to boo and jeer in a comfortable sort of way. Thank goodness, you could see them thinking, he's going over the top. He's going to make it easy for us.

Mr Blair paused, smiled, and continued: "And so I feel sure that the House will want to send our congratulations to the England cricket team."

Given that almost the entire parliamentary Conservative party was lined up against him like the terracotta army of Xian, it was a splendidly insouciant display. Some years ago I went on an official flight with the then foreign secretary. After dinner I requested a cognac as a digestif, and the motherly WRAF steward brought me a bottle of Remy Martin, explaining, "I'll leave this with you, it'll save me running up and down the aisle all night."

Clearly someone had served the prime minister with a bottle of five-star adrenalin and left it on the next seat with ice, lemon and tonic. For a man who must have had almost no sleep since Thursday, it was an astonishingly poised, confident and destructive performance.

Mr Hague smiled in his placid way, as he invariably does, so you feel he ought to shave what's left of his hair, put on saffron robes, and hop along Oxford Street with a tambourine, but he must have known he had failed at a critical moment, a moment his party will long remember. This was almost certainly the last EU summit before the election; having flopped flat on his face now, he may not get another chance.

He outlined a fairly predictable list of objections to the treaty, quoted Richard Perle, a German newspaper, and similarly unconvincing rightwing sources, then declared that the Tories would not ratify the treaty. Labour MPs chortled merrily, either because they were taken with the absurdity of renegotiating the treaty, or else at the impossibility of a Tory election victory.

Mr Blair got up to reply. The adrenalin was clearly pulsing through his veins. I wouldn't want to be standing in the neighbouring stall when he next visits a urinal; the porcelain would probably start smoking.

"Well," he said diffidently, "I think I preferred it with the jokes." Britain had its own protection on the important matters affected by the end of the veto, he said. "With respect to the other matters there's the appointment of the deputy secretary-general of the council," (Labour laughter) "pension arrangements for the registrar of the court," (more Labour laughter) "and the improvement of the rules of procedure of the court of auditors!" (A wave of almost lunatic Labour laughter.)

The Tories had rejected the idea of a referendum on the euro, Mr Blair said. "But when it comes to deciding the pension arrangements of European court officials, we would all be trooping off to the polling station!"

"More, more!" shouted Labour MPs, as they flopped around on the benches like jellyfish being jabbed by an electric cattle prod.

"He has said that he would block the treaty. Let me explain the full, rounded idiocy of the Tory position," which he did rather effectively, pointing out that not even a single European Conservative party supported the British Tory view.

Mr Hague kept smiling. Iain Duncan-Smith pretended to be outraged, thrusting his finger at the prime minister. Francis Maude looked deeply unhappy, but Michael Portillo stared blankly ahead. Inside, I suspect, he was very pleased indeed. But perhaps I'm being unfair.

fields.headline: Quiet plodders beat dot.com dashers
fields.standfirst:
Old-economy firms profit from benefits offered by new technology

Net news
fields.trailText: The real e-business revolution is taking place among traditional British companies which are using digital technology to cut costs and boost profits, according to new research.
fields.body:
The real e-business revolution is taking place among traditional British companies which are using digital technology to cut costs and boost profits, according to new research.

While "pure-play" dot.coms have grabbed headlines over the past year, long-established firms have been working quietly to build businesses online, a study by accountants KPMG and researchers at Henley Management College says.

"The real e-business revolution is taking place quietly but effectively within the UK's 'traditional' companies," said Dominic Swords, an economist at the college. "Fuelled by experience, organisations' knowledge and conservative but reliable finance, change is taking place in the way so-called 'old technology' companies do business."

That trend confirms predictions by several new-economy economists, such as Sushil Wadhwani, a Bank of England policymaker.

The Henley team studied 43 blue chip companies and found those that had moved slowly but surely towards implementing new IT systems, experimenting with a variety of approaches, were reaping the benefits.

Corporate intranets to communicate with staff and internet-driven improvements to the supply chain were the most frequently cited benefits.

Asda told researchers it set up an intranet linking its 241 supermarkets and 100,000 employees with Asda House, its headquarters in Leeds. A committee was set up to ensure that information circulated on paper was not duplicated on the intranet and to avoid information overload.

The system has been upgraded to be compatible with that of Wal-Mart, the US retail group that bought Asda last year.

Asda has two separate intranets. One is for management and is used for the circulation of information to store managers. The other is the "colleague intranet" on which information ranges from descriptions of individual products to the company phone book.

Tesco.com, the supermarket chain's internet-driven home delivery service, is now generating revenues of £5m a week.

Tom Britten, a spokesman for Tesco.com, says the key to success has been the decision to fulfil orders direct from shops rather than the warehouses some rivals use.

Improvements have been evolutionary: at first "pickers" would wander round the store collecting ordered goods then take them to the checkout to be scanned. Now they carry handheld scanners, cutting collection time significantly.

Bourne Leisure Holdings, owner of Rank Holidays and Butlins, has tried to build a strong presence online for each of its brands. Most simply allow customers to order brochures but Butlins' site enables users to book. The sites are also represented on 50 specialist holiday portals.

The company has generated £5m in sales from the web, having targeted £500,000 worth in its first year. Bourne Leisure says it is likely to stick with its "softly, softly" approach.

webTitle: Hugo Young: Everyone was a winner at the battle of Nice

fields.headline: Everyone was a winner at the battle of Nice
fields.standfirst:
For once, it wasn't a contest between Britain and the rest

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: For once, it wasn't a contest between Britain and the rest
fields.body:
Modern politics is labyrinthine, wherever you are. There are no simple options. Watching the Nice summit, you're tempted to think there must be. Tony Blair said we couldn't go on doing business like this.

Yet nothing is simple in Washington either. Winner-take-all politics is supposed to produce clear winners, a choice of one or the other. But the US, we learn, has no process for dealing with a dead-even split in the electorate. The EU, by exact and equal contrast, is not designed to produce a neat divide. One system speaks to simplicity, the other to complexity, yet each can produce its own version of sweaty deadlock.

The lesson is especially sharp for the British. Steeped for centuries in winner-take-all juices, the British find it hard to absorb confessions of compromise from their leaders. They like the clarity of black and white. That's the way all EU summits are reported, both by the politicians and by the media. National victory and/or defeat seems to be the only basis on which most Brits can understand events. So that's the way Mr Blair and Mr Cook presented Nice.

They talked of victory partly because the tabloid agenda demands tabloid responses - though Mr Cook went a little far when he claimed that Britain had "more votes" than ever before, as if this was some marvellous competitive triumph instead of the natural result of general uprating. But they also talked victory because it is, in their terms, true. Even the Sun was prepared to say so. On defence, contrary to Saturday's malign reporting in several papers, the rapid reaction force meets Anglo-American needs. More broadly, the veto agenda set out beforehand was well satisfied. For once, this wasn't a summit contest ranging Britain versus the rest.

On the other hand, it wasn't black and white. For the future of Europe, Nice sent out mixed signals. It was indeed a compromise, partly integrationist and partly the opposite. The short-term requirements of governments produced results that cut both ways for the EU, and may have permanent effects.

On one side of the checklist, for example, sits tax reform. The exemption of all tax change from qualified majority voting (QMV) will have dire consequences as well as good ones. Not only direct tax rates but every tax initiative for other purposes will need unanimity. By insisting on this, Britain excluded, perhaps indefinitely, the possibility of eco-taxes under the EU's aegis: a crude veto that destroys any claim this country has to environmental sensitivity. Disintegrationism flourishes, even in a field where uniformity would make sense.

The other side of the reckoning, though, foreshadows shifts the other way, towards more integration. Changes in national weights of vote show that. Germany made a heroic sacrifice, unimaginable from France or Britain, in not insisting on the highest weight, to reflect its 20m extra population. But the total vote of the six founder members of the community will be 117, up from 48% to 51%. They usually agree. With Spain, Austria and Portugal alongside, they will push their line.

The Brit-Scandinavian bloc, by contrast, is weaker. Though the three largest countries will have blocking power, this historico-regional dividing line matters more in the real world than smalls versus bigs, the issue that brought Nice closest to breakdown.

The integrationist thrust, in other words, has not expired. Out of the murk of trade-offs and compromise, the twin impulses of enlargement and integration emerge as complementary. The very rigour of the Nice negotiation, because it concluded with a treaty, shows a process that still has momentum.

It is not clean, and it's far from easy. Its imperfections can be instantly listed. The leaders emerged exhausted after an exercise in coalitionism that is alien to the Anglo-American political tradition. But it was neither the fiasco nor the disaster which that tradition deemed proper to report before the end was reached. Those words will soon look more appropriate to the election result legitimised by the US supreme court.

Reporting to the Commons yesterday, Mr Blair plunged deeper into the language of Europeanism than he has before. After chalking up his national victories, he started to offer lessons in the bigger picture. They were about enlargement, about making the EU work better, about the naked self-interest in extending some aspects of QMV. He even dared to say he'd tried to get QMV brought in faster for certain trade issues.

Presenting himself as the acme of common sense, he carried the pro-Europe argument to the enemy on the other side with more relish than I've ever seen, discovering new wells of ridicule to expose the Conservative line on Europe for what it is: petty, narrow, anachronistic, contradictory, dishonest and protected by the impenitent ignorance that derives from blazing doctrinal anger.

Another stage of the journey into continental complexity now begins. Mr Blair did not ask for a new intergovernmental conference to be fixed, with a 2004 deadline. He didn't want it before the first wave of new members are admitted. Originally the British also opposed the framing of a charter of rights, let alone its implementation into law.

On both points, Mr Blair quietly acquiesced before Nice. It's almost certain that the charter, now registered as a declaration in the treaty, will be pushed towards more formal status at the next IGC, which is one reason why Britain wanted to slow-time both developments.

The temptation will be to enter the 2004 process in wholly defensive mode. That would be the usual British way. It was how Margaret Thatcher and John Major viewed every IGC they failed to prevent, and also, to begin with, how the Blair government regarded aspects of what loomed at Nice.

The Foreign Office is leery of these developments. It knows how dangerous it is to start unpicking and simplifying treaties, which is set out as one of the 2004 tasks: a sensible thing to be doing, in response to the ever-deepening incomprehensibility of everything to do with the EU, but a tricky one all the same.

Mr Blair may be less defensive. With an election victory under his belt, he should be. There were signs at and after Nice that he might be. He has, after all, won quite a lot already, especially in influencing the economic trajectory of the EU. He has also won some big arguments, notably over the British budget contribution, and defence. The euro presents his biggest decision before 2004. If he ducks it, his influence will soon wane.

But an IGC, led by Germany, to establish the borderlines between the EU and national governments in this federation of nation states is an opportunity not a threat. It presents formidable complexities, in the continental style. But we are not living in the American system. Fortunately, some might say. Winner-take-all, as applied to the EU, produces what Hague insists on: loser-take-nothing.

It's almost certain that the charter, now registered as a declaration in the treaty, will be pushed towards more formal status at the next IGC, which is one reason why Britain wanted to slow-time both developments. The temptation will be to enter the 2004 process in wholly defensive mode. That would be the usual British way. It was how Margaret Thatcher and John Major viewed every IGC they failed to prevent, and also, to begin with, how the Blair government regarded aspects of what loomed at Nice. The Foreign Office is leery of these developments. It knows how dangerous it is to start unpicking and simplifying treaties, which is set out as one of the 2004 tasks: a sensible thing to be doing, in response to the ever-deepening incomprehensibility of everything to do with the EU, but a tricky one all the same. Mr Blair may be less defensive. With an election victory under his belt, he should be. There were signs at and after Nice that he might be. He has, after all, won quite a lot already, especially in influencing the economic trajectory of the EU. He has also won some big arguments, notably over the British budget contribution, and defence. The euro presents his biggest decision before 2004. If he ducks it, his influence will soon wane. But an IGC, led by Germany, to establish the borderlines between the EU and national governments in this federation of nation states is an opportunity not a threat. It presents formidable complexities, in the continental style. But we are not living in the American system. Fortunately, some might say. Winner-take-all, as applied to the EU, produces what Hague insists on: loser-take-nothing. hugo.young@compuserve.com

webTitle: England triumph as the sun goes down on Pakistan

fields.headline: England triumph as the sun goes down on Pakistan
fields.standfirst: Full Scorecard
fields.trailText: In the gathering gloom of a Karachi evening, England's cricketers saw off all manner of adversity yesterday to beat Pakistan in the third and final Test and win the series 1-0, their first victory in Pakistan for 39 years.
fields.body:
In the gathering gloom of a Karachi evening, England's cricketers saw off all manner of adversity yesterday to beat Pakistan in the third and final Test and win the series 1-0, their first victory in Pakistan for 39 years.

It was 5.54pm, half an hour after sunset, when Surrey's Graham Thorpe hit the final runs in what had been a dramatic run chase against the clock. He finished unbeaten on 64 as England reached 176 for four to win by six wickets and set up Pepsi-spraying balcony celebrations before their journey home last night.

Defeat was felt particularly keenly in Karachi, hitherto the citadel of Pakistan cricket. In 33 previous Tests, they had never lost at the ground.

England have now beaten Zimbabwe, West Indies and Pakistan in successive series, their best sequence in a calendar year since 1978 and a measure of the progress that has been made under Nasser Hussain's captaincy and the shrewd, understated tuition of their Zimbabwean coach, Duncan Fletcher.

In a further sign that the game is enjoying a renaissance, it was also announced yesterday that England had secured a new contract with their current sponsor, Vodafone, that could be worth £12m.

"We showed a lot of spirit to come back and win," said Hussain, who batted alongside Thorpe to finish unbeaten on six. "I wouldn't pick any performance - it was just a pleasure to play in that side. You can name so many people, all of whom performed in the whole series. We have stuck together."

Ultimately, the poor light hampered both sides, with Pakistan's fielders seemingly unable to pick out the ball as England closed on their target.

Hussain praised the umpires, Steve Bucknor and Mohammad Nazir Junior, for allowing play to continue beyond what they thought was reasonable. "It would have been a tragedy if this game had not been finished off properly."

fields.headline: BOC defends chief's £1.5m pay
fields.trailText: BOC, the industrial gases company, yesterday defended paying remuneration of £1.5m to its chief executive Tony Isaac, up from £675,000 in 1999.
fields.body:
BOC, the industrial gases company, yesterday defended paying remuneration of £1.5m to its chief executive Tony Isaac, up from £675,000 in 1999.

BOC said the payment was just reward for him sticking with the group for 10 months of uncertainty created by a planned takeover.

The group had intended to merge with Air Liquide and Air Products before the deal was scuppered by US regulatory authorities in May. The proposed takeover led to the departure of the previous chief executive Danny Rosenkranz who received £1.8m the previous year.

According to the report and accounts for 2000, Mr Isaac's remuneration included a £931,000 bonus. Part of this was a payment of £250,000 "for his commitment and performance during the period of the offer". He is to receive an additional £500,000 in the financial year 2002. The figures do not include £104,000 paid into his pension and any awards of options, or gains on options exercised.

The group admitted it was flouting normal corporate governance codes by putting in place a new mid-term share plan. It also altered the performance criteria of its long-term incentive plan following the collapse of the merger. Instead of having to beat the FTSE 100 index, which the firm argues no longer contains comparable stocks, the company's earnings per share must beat the retail price index plus 3%.

The company said that only options granted to directors in 1995 fitted this criterion by the end of this financial year.
