webTitle: Test for ban on questioning of rape accusers tested

fields.headline: Test for ban on questioning of rape accusers tested
fields.trailText: A new law which bars defence lawyers from questioning women who accuse men of rape about their sexual history is to be challenged as a breach of human rights, in a move which could put rape trials throughout England and Wales on hold.
fields.body:
A new law which bars defence lawyers from questioning women who accuse men of rape about their sexual history is to be challenged as a breach of human rights, in a move which could put rape trials throughout England and Wales on hold.

Lawyers for a 26-year-old student asylum seeker charged with raping a 25-year-old arts teacher are to challenge a ruling by an Old Bailey judge banning cross-examination of his accuser about their alleged sexual relationship.

The case is the first to raise the argument that the ban on questioning a woman about her past sexual behaviour, in an attempt to show she consented to sex, breaches the man's right to a fair trial under article 6 of the European con vention on human rights. The convention became part of UK law in October when the Human Rights Act came into force.

The student denies raping the teacher, who claims he attacked her on a Thames towpath on June 14. He insists they had been having a sexual relationship and that she consented to sex in the bushes.

Judge Simon Goldstein gave leave to appeal "with enthusiasm" last Wednesday after ruling that he was constrained by "rape shield" provisions in the Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act, which had come into force two days earlier.

He added: "The sooner this is looked at the better. This problem is likely to arise in many, many cases before crown courts." Judges, lawyers, accused men and alleged victims "have to know where they stand".

The crown prosecution ser vice said it was asking for the case to be fast-tracked at the court of appeal. "This is an important point of law," said a spokeswoman. "We propose to fast-track it so it will be heard early."

"We hope we will have an early judgment because obviously it has implications for other cases as well." The trial was due to begin last Tuesday, the day after the rape shield law came into force after a long campaign by women's groups, which argued that questions about women's sexual past were irrelevant.

But the student's counsel, Emma Lowry, argued that it was impossible for him to have a fair trial because she could not quiz the woman about earlier sexual encounters with her client and he would be gagged from mentioning them in his own evidence.

Judge Goldstein said any accused had the right "for every possible issue to be put fairly and squarely before a jury" and crown courts everywhere would be left wrestling with the same dilemma. He said: "The sexual activity of a prostitute or someone as chaste as a nun will never be known because it cannot be explored."

The law deliberately removed the judge's discretion because judges so frequently allowed questioning about past sexual behaviour, despite laws designed to discourage it.

The new law is modelled on a similar law in Canada, which was challenged this year as breaching a right to a fair trial. The supreme court of Canada upheld the ban on questioning about sexual history.

The court of appeal would have to take that judgment into account in deciding whether the British act violates the right to a fair trial.

fields.headline: At this price?  HP Bulmer
fields.trailText: Herefordshire cidermaker HP Bulmer yesterday became the latest drinks company to bemoan "the summer that never happened", as bad weather held back sales of Strongbow, Scrumpy Jack and Woodpecker.
fields.body:
Herefordshire cidermaker HP Bulmer yesterday became the latest drinks company to bemoan "the summer that never happened", as bad weather held back sales of Strongbow, Scrumpy Jack and Woodpecker.

The company disappointed the market with a 2.1% fall in half-year profits to £16.5m and indicated that life remains tough. Chief executive Mike Hughes reckons that "the marginal pint", which drinkers sneak while on their way home, has fallen victim to the rail crisis. Fuel blockades and flooding have not helped, hitting cider's rural heartlands.

Bulmer's shares slipped 23.5p to 474p, continuing a slow decline from this summer's peak of 535p. The setback is disappointing for Mr Hughes' team, who were just beginning to attract significant interest the City.

Mr Hughes arrived two years ago, shortly after the cider industry was decimated by the sudden popularity of alcopops. He has been battling to overcome the perception that cider is a drink in long-term decline.

For Mr Hughes, Strongbow and Woodpecker are less ciders than "long alcoholic drinks" - lumping them together with trendier high-volume lagers.

The company has been trying to build the credibility of Strongbow by using Big Breakfast star Johnny Vaughan in its advertising. The approach is paying off - sales of the brand edged up 8%, against a decline of 1% for Scrumpy Jack and a 3% fall for Woodpecker.

These figures are commendable, considering the market for "long" drinks was down by 5% overall. Recent ruses such as Sidekick - a vodka shot which clips to the side of a bottle - should continue to attract the youth market.

Bulmer has been trying to expand overseas but success has been patchy with decent returns from the US and Europe but problems in Australia and South Africa.

At 474p, the shares trade on a moderate rating of roughly 12 times expected earnings. However, this is unlikely to be a vintage year for cider. Sell.

Andrew Clark

webTitle: Comment: Passengers kept in the dark about Tube perils

fields.headline: Passengers kept in the dark about Tube perils
fields.standfirst: Transport chiefs say breakdown records are not 'for public debate' but regulators may force disclosure.
fields.trailText: Transport chiefs say breakdown records are not 'for public debate' but regulators may force disclosure.
fields.body:
London Underground is becoming less safe and more secretive as it moves falteringly towards the private/ public partnership that John Prescott intends unleashing on the travelling public before the next election.

Although under scrutiny from the health and safety executive, LU refuses to discuss breakdown figures or give details of performance which it is legally obliged to provide. It hides behind the excuse that the recent woeful record of breakdowns on the Central and Jubilee lines is not a matter "for public debate". It claims performance records "contain commercially sensitive information".

With reluctance, it admits that trains have been performing badly. That is an understatement. Official LU figures show that, while Central and Jubilee line trains should run for at least 25,000km (15,500 miles) before failing, in October last year they were able to achieve only about 4,500 km before breakdown occurred.

When asked for more recent information, LU refused, saying it did not "intend to enter a public debate". It did say it experienced teething difficulties with the opening of the Jubilee line extension last year, since largely resolved.

Tell that to its passengers who daily make more than 2.6m journeys on the Tube, nearly as many as the entire national rail network. Demand has reached record levels and continues to grow as people in the capital try to escape congestion in the streets above.

The increasing fragility of an overcrowded system and the health and safety executive's growing exasperation with LU have exposed examples of management failure.

Some 2,000 people were trapped for two hours in the rush hour on two Central line trains recently, stuck behind another which had broken down at Liverpool Street station. It had blown a fuse and a replacement was not immediately available. Staff tried unsuccessfully to shunt the crippled train out of the station. The fire brigade was not summoned quickly, and the angry, frustrated and frightened passengers were eventually escorted out along the tunnel.

Under LU's undertaking, following the King's Cross fire 11 years ago, they should have been evacuated within half an hour.

The HSE is unhappy that LU was slow to get the passengers out. It, too, has found problems getting accurate information from management and says there is a "serious" risk that it will have to prosecute LU. Hardly a day goes by without incidents on the Tube, from signalling failures to escalator breakdowns and train cancellations. They have become so common, and the public so inured to them, that the media have reduced coverage of the scandal.

But safety, as the Paddington rail crash has demonstrated, is an issue. That is heightened on the Tube by the HSE's insistence that it will not accept any plans for public/private partnership unless it is "completely happy" with the safety case. This may be a belated move to protect itself from criticism of the railways inspectorate's failure to act in events leading up to the Paddington crash.

The HSE also plans to produce a report on the government's plan to part-privatise the system, which could sound the death-knell for the project.

Billions of pounds of new investment is required to reverse the Tube's rundown state and make it an efficient system. For Ken Livingstone, London's mayor, that is essential. The capital's streets are clogged by road works and cable laying, carried out haphazardly. The impact on public transport above the ground has been alarming.

Much of Mr Livingstone's electoral success is down to a promise that he would solve London's transport problems, with the introduction of congestion charging at the heart of his strategy.

However, that project has been beset by objections to the level of charges and demands from "essential workers" for exemption. That makes a safe, reliable Tube system all the more important if London is to keep moving.

Keith Harper is the Guardian's transport editor

fields.headline: George Wimpey takes a dive
fields.trailText: Property developer George Wimpey yesterday had one of its biggest falls of the year as shares went down 7.9% from 12.5p to 145.5p after it issued a profits warning.
fields.body:
Property developer George Wimpey yesterday had one of its biggest falls of the year as shares went down 7.9% from 12.5p to 145.5p after it issued a profits warning.

The company said first half profits for 2001 would probably be lower than this year's first half due to planning delays.

Dealers clearly considered this information more important than the company forecast that this year's results would be in line with expectations. It is also significant that Wimpey is merging two subsidiaries to save up to £15m a year.

Elsewhere telecoms, media and technology shares rebounded, buoyed by Friday's 6% surge in the tech-heavy Nasdaq index. There were tentative signs of the traditional year-end rally, according to analysts, with the FTSE 100 index rising 82 points to 6370.3, a two-week closing high. Among the heavyweight technology stocks, Vodafone was up 9p to 273.75p, after reports of its agreement to buy a 15% stake in Japan Telecom.

Marconi rose 69p to 856p on news of a joint venture with LG Electronics.

Bookham, Baltimore, Arm and Sage all benefited from the technology revival.

Expect news shortly that Sage chairman Michael Jackson will take the same role at Planit, up 0.5p to 112.5p.

The company, a maker of design software for the furniture industry, is also believed to be close to signing a deal with a major media website for its online design product.

Sage rose 16.5p to 416p, while Bookham Technology, the loss-making fibre optic and chip manufacturer, rose 108p to 1461p and Baltimore, the computer security software developer, added 43p to 460.5p.

SurfControl, which last week announced it had achieved in three months what the market expected from it in four, saw its shares rally 132.5p to £12.05 as investors, many institutional, ploughed in at a bargain price.

Clarity Commerce Solutions, which supplies software and point of sales equipment to restaurant and pub groups, was steady at 135.5p after unveiling its first results since it joined AIM in July. Turnover reached £1.4m, with losses of £502,000.

New contracts include a major pizza chain. It is also linking up with IBM.

Telewest was weak among the telecoms, falling 1p to 113.25p after reports over the weekend that it was to concentrate on its own network, turning away from government plans to free up British Telecom's local telephone network.

Carlton Communications saw its shares rise 38p to 618.5p after Thomson Multimedia agreed to buy its film technology and duplication business.

The banking sector was strong, with shares in Abbey National climbing 52.5p to £11.44 on renewed speculation that Lloyds TSB was finally ready to launch a hostile bid.

Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch food manufacturer fell 14.75p to 520p after Deutsche Bank downgraded its recommendation from "market perform" to "under perform".

Shire Pharmaceutical Group saw its shares fall 194p or 15.79% to £10.32, after it said it would pay $4bn(£2.75bn) in stock for Canada's Biochem Pharma, the developer of AIDS and hepatitis treatments.

Glaxo Wellcome also fell, down 20p to £18.36.

Shares in Eagle Eye Telematics, the vehicle tracking, security and fleet communications company, rose 5.5p to 86.5p on the back of a major deal with Dutch based security transportation company Brinks Nederland.

And there was a glittering AIM debut for European Diamonds which saw its shares end at 135p, almost double the starting price of 70p.

The London-based company led by geologist Roy Spencer also completed a £3.4m placement yesterday to finance its exploration drive in Finland.

Some investors clearly expect a shining future for Finland beyond mobile phone manufacturing.

fields.headline: Financier accused of insider dealing
fields.trailText: City financier Johnny Townsend encouraged a friend to buy 1m shares in a food company after being told confidentially it was taking over a rival for £50m, a court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
City financier Johnny Townsend encouraged a friend to buy 1m shares in a food company after being told confidentially it was taking over a rival for £50m, a court was told yesterday.

Alan Suckling QC, prosecuting, said Mr Townsend, the former vice-chairman of stockbroker Hoare Govett, persuaded Salah Shohet to make the £500,000 deal the day after senior executives at WT Foods privately revealed plans to buy the Noon group.

And he even told three "astonished" colleagues what he was planning to do as they returned from the secret meeting at a country hotel in Hertfordshire, Blackfriars crown court was told.

Mr Suckling said Mr Townsend's actions amounted to "flagrant insider dealing" which happened during the closed period in May 1998 before WT reported its full-year results.

He said Mr Townsend had suggested asking his friend to buy shares "to support the share price" but gave the impression he was "teasing" after being told it was illegal.

"They thought the idea had been dropped but unfortunately he wasn't joking and the next day he persuaded his friend to buy a million shares," said Mr Suckling. "He didn't tell him of the plan to buy the group or the results but insisted the shares were a good investment and expected him to make a good deal of money from buying the shares."

However, the buy order made by Mr Shohet, through Swiss-based investment company Etablissement Finital, was eventually cancelled after being referred to the broker's compliance department.

Mark Ashurst, previously a corporate finance adviser at Hoare Govett, was one of those who met WT's chief executive Keith Stott and finance director Roderick Garland at the Down Hall country house hotel.

He told the court the Hoare Govett team were "excited" by the acquisition which was so secretive that WT and Noon were only referred to as "wolf" and "panther" respectively.

Mr Ashurst claimed Mr Townsend had "led the discussion" about the level of fees which could be earned and suggested they be "incentivised" if the shares could be issued at a high premium.

The court was told Mr Townsend denied passing on inside information when questioned by the department of trade and industry and branded accusations against him "a disgrace".

Mr Townsend, 58, of Eaton Square, south-west London, has pleaded not guilty to one charge of insider dealing.

He spoke only to confirm his name during the hearing.

The case continues.

webTitle: Standard Life sales up but banking arm hurt

fields.headline: Standard Life sales up but banking arm hurt
fields.trailText: Standard Life yesterday reported new annual business up 25% to £5.1bn but said that severe price competition in the mortgage market had resulted in worse than anticipated losses at its banking subsidiary.
fields.body:
Standard Life yesterday reported new annual business up 25% to £5.1bn but said that severe price competition in the mortgage market had resulted in worse than anticipated losses at its banking subsidiary.

Endowment sales have plummeted by 60% amid industry wide concern about some policies. Standard Life, the largest endowment provider in UK, saw sales drop to £21m from £53m.

The figures are the first since the Edinburgh-based mutual successfully fought off a bid by carpetbaggers to turn it into a listed company and pay out windfalls.

Yesterday group managing director Scott Bell re-affirmed Standard Life's opposition to demutualising. He said that the measures introduced last February, including a three-year ban on windfalls for new members, will remain in force for the foreseeable future.

International business, led by strong increases in Canada and Ireland, rose by 33% to £1.6bn while UK new business was up 21% to £3.6bn.

New annual premiums, the bread-and-butter of pension companies, fell slightly to £360m from £363m during 1999.

Bell added that total sales in 2001 were likely to be up by a further 20-25%, boosted in part by policyholders quitting Equitable Life.

"Most of our sales come from independent financial advisers and their share of the market is likely to rise next year because of the exit of Equitable Life."

fields.headline: British Biotech 'turning round'
fields.trailText: Embattled drug development company British Biotech yesterday insisted its recovery was "gaining momentum," despite a sharp increase in half-year losses and continued weakness in its share price.
fields.body:
Embattled drug development company British Biotech yesterday insisted its recovery was "gaining momentum," despite a sharp increase in half-year losses and continued weakness in its share price.

The firm, which was brought to its knees by disclosures from a whistleblower two years ago, pledged it would look carefully at mergers and acquisitions once key trials of its marimastat cancer treatment are completed.

British Biotech blamed the costs of a series of development tie-ups this year for an 18% increase in its interim loss to £13.4m. Finance director Tony Weir said: "We've delivered what we've said we would do and the general feeling out there is that the business is turning round."

But the company, which has been criticised for persevering with marimastat after five successive sets of negative clinical results, yesterday saw its shares slip a further 0.25p to 21.5p.

British Biotech has agreed nine different collaborations with big drugs companies over the past year. The most recent was with Europe's biggest biotech firm, Geneva-based Serono, to develop treatments for inflammatory diseases such as arthritis and multiple sclerosis.

Mr Weir admitted that the company was still labouring in the shadow of marimastat and its follow-up drug BB-3644, which few analysts expect to work. Final data from clinical trials is due in the first quarter. Mr Weir said: "A resolution of that frees us up to look at a lot more issues."

webTitle: Clinton's Ireland visit to boost peace process

fields.headline: Clinton ready to become guardian of peace process
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton is prepared to take on a new role as the "guardian" of the Northern Ireland peace process - one of the outstanding foreign policy successes of his presidency - when he leaves office next month.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton is prepared to take on a new role as the "guardian" of the Northern Ireland peace process - one of the outstanding foreign policy successes of his presidency - when he leaves office next month.

On the eve of his final visit to the province as president, senior aides made clear yesterday that Mr Clinton would dearly like to emulate Jimmy Carter who turned himself into a successful peace envoy.

Mr Clinton arrives in Belfast tonight amid hopes that his visit will help to overcome the deadlock in the peace process. There is no sign of an imminent deal between the Ulster Unionists and Sinn Fein, but the British and Irish governments hope that the president will help to persuade all sides to give ground.

With political leaders predicting that negotiations will continue into the new year, the White House made clear yesterday that the president was happy to continue his role as honest broker after he relinquished power. PJ Crowley, his foreign policy adviser, said: "President Clinton values the help he has been able to render and it wouldn't surprise me if he is willing to remain active after he leaves office, if that is something the parties wanted to consider."

Downing Street indicated that Tony Blair, who will accompany the president, would be delighted if Mr Clinton continued to maintain his interest. "I am sure the prime minister will be interested to know how one of the most formidable and talented politicians of his generation is going to make a contribution," his spokesman said.

Mr Clinton is seen as the ideal candidate to act as a guardian of the peace process because he is widely respected by all the pro-agreement parties. The former US senator George Mitchell, who was equally respected during his chairmanship of the Good Friday agreement, is now a peace envoy to the Middle East.

The government was keen to stress last night that it was too early to say that Mr Clinton would step into Mr Mitchell's shoes. "We have to see what happens in the next few weeks," a spokesman said.

It is guarded because ministers are determined to broker an agreement between the UUP and Sinn Fein before the president leaves office on January 20. There is also a fear that formally designating Mr Clinton as the guardian of the process would admit that it was bound to lurch from crisis to crisis. But an informal role is a strong possibility.

The outgoing president will today meet the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, in Dublin. He will travel to the dissident republican stronghold of Dundalk, Co Louth, tonight, before flying to Belfast for talks tomorrow with Tony Blair, the UUP leader, David Trimble and the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams.

Mr Trimble, who has barred Sinn Fein from a cross-border ministerial council, wants the president to persuade the IRA to re-open its negotiations with the disarmament body. Repub licans are calling on Mr Clinton to ask Britain to honour promises it made on police reform and scaling down security measures, particularly in heavily fortified South Armagh.

London, Dublin and Washington have been trying to find a formula to win round all sides. But insiders admit there is no real expectation of a major breakthrough during the Clinton trip.

Sinn Fein and Ulster Unionist sources said they were not in contact. Both admitted that no one was expecting anything dramatic this week. Others noted, however, that Mr Clinton could lift the political atmosphere in a way that should not be underestimated. "He can remind people of the great distance they have already travelled, the responsibility on their shoulders and what a shame it would be to squander all that in the final few hundred yards," a diplomatic source said. "There is a possible package, if everyone revisits the deal that was made in May and looks at how they can fulfil their commitments."

fields.headline: Free the church
fields.standfirst:
Severing its bond with the state can only benefit everyone

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Severing its bond with the state can only benefit everyone
fields.body:
If I thought for a moment that the Church of England would be more effective in the struggle for justice and peace, would be a better witness to the humanity of Christ and would walk more humbly with God's poor if its links with the state were cut, I would campaign more vigorously for its disestablishment.

That does not alter the fact that the patchwork of customs and ancient statutes that tie the church to the apron strings of palace and parliament do nothing for the nation, limit the church's freedom to represent Christ to the people and, on a lighter note, have simply become faintly ridiculous and therefore cherished. A very English affair of state.

What is this so called establishment? No single legal instrument, no church-state treaty, no signed concordat. It cannot be annulled at a stroke. Sweden's Lutherans tidily and painlessly cut the umbilical church/state nexus. That's not the English way. But the status quo should no longer be left to wither on the vine. Some deliberate pruning is overdue.

Here are some of the main components of this unholy patchwork: the Pope gave Henry VIII the title defender of the faith, the Roman Catholic faith. Henry kept the title, told the Pope to get lost and nationalised the church. Every sovereign has kept it since. It's on our coins. Prince Charles, rightly, hates the idea. He would sensibly like to see the crown as defender of religious liberty: defender of faith, not the faith. Henry and Elizabeth had no time for such human rights.

Elizabeth I, the Protestant queen, accepted an even less acceptable title: supreme governor of the church, a title loved by Europe's Protestant princes: summus episcopus, a ruler above the bishops, in fact the Pope's role. And the princes really did rule. Today that title is a misleading fiction. Theologically, the only supreme governor of the church is Jesus Christ. Administratively, the Church of England is governed by a balance of forces between the archbishops' council and the general synod. The Queen doesn't feature.

Yet parliament does. A totally secular parliament can veto the church's legislation and occasionally does. A church that is unable to make its own decisions, foolish as they may be, is unworthy of the name. Spiritually this is nonsensical.

Worse still, the church cannot freely appoint its own leaders. The prime minister has the last word: remnants of Henry's power, though the church now is right at the margins. Downing Street can refuse to accept the church's choice. Tony Blair has done it. And he just happens to be an Anglican - with strong Roman Catholic connections.

The Act of Settlement (which cries out to be repealed) does not stop the heir to the throne having a mistress or marrying a Buddhist, but a Roman Catholic, never. All this is to frustrate the political power of the papacy; a strange anachronism, unless you march with a rolled umbrella in Belfast. The suggestion that the repeal of this anti-Roman relic would have a catastrophic domino effect is nonsense. Any decent lawyer could cope with this problem and its constitutional derivatives, the damaging supreme governor title included.

It should be no part of a reformed upper house that a fixed number of Anglican bishops, simply by virtue of their office, should sit in it. To reduce the places from 24 to 16 is not the answer. To have at least that number of the nation's spiritual leaders with appropriate gifts from all religious communities would make very good sense. Lord Soper, a Methodist, Lord MacLeod, a Scottish Presbyterian and Lord Jakobovits, a Jew, are excellent precedents. That the clergy of the Church of England, along with lunatics and peers, should be debarred from sitting in the Commons is a fate from which they do not deserve to be spared.

What other privileges are left to the Church of England? It is allowed to keep what's left of the church's medieval lands, or that wealth turned into stocks and shares. Other churches have no such bounty, but then, they don't have ancient cathedrals and thousands of medieval churches to maintain. What remains of the church commissioners' millions is small compensation for maintaining a major part of the nation's cultural heritage. That can stay, but the end of establishment will put paid to the damaging myth that the taxpayer finances the Church of England.

The defenders of the status quo argue that only a state church can serve all the people. That is another fiction, and an unintended insult to other religious communities. Arguably the Salvation Army does a little better and even the small band of Quakers have a social outreach out of all proportion to their numbers. A change in legal status will do nothing to stop cathedrals and parish churches offering all that they do now. The clergy would not notice the difference and no one would make them take down the royal coat of arms in this land of sacred tradition.

The traditionalist scaremongers say that to end the church-state link would be to turn the Church of England into a sect. Is the Holy Roman Church, probably by a small margin the best attended in England, a sect? Anyway, Christianity started as a small Jewish sect which eventually did well enough to sweep the Roman Empire. Holy Trinity Brompton, not to be confused with the Pope's Oratory next door, has comparable ambitions.

No establishment, no "Christian nation"? Ann Widdecombe rightly calls that a fig leaf. The western nation where most people still go to church, the US, strictly separates religion from politics. Christian nations? Take your choice.

Sadly, this is a time for slaughtering the cows that threaten us. The Church of England, which ought to be a threat to the golden calf of the free market, badly needs to sacrifice the sacred cow of an establishment which no farmer or city dweller, subject or citizen, will miss.

Paul Oestreicher is a canon emeritus at Coventry cathedral

webTitle: Flyers with blood clots sue airlines

fields.headline: Flyers with blood clots sue airlines
fields.trailText: Dozens of Australians who suffered potentially fatal blood clots after flying long distances in cramped conditions are preparing to sue leading airlines, including British Airways, for failing to warn them about the so-called "economy class syndrome".
fields.body:
Dozens of Australians who suffered potentially fatal blood clots after flying long distances in cramped conditions are preparing to sue leading airlines, including British Airways, for failing to warn them about the so-called "economy class syndrome".

In the first attempt to seek damages for passengers who suffered deep vein thrombosis (DVT) after long-haul flights, Slater and Gordon, a Melbourne-based law firm, said it would issue writs against at least five airlines.

Paul Henderson, a member of the firm, said he had received calls from more than 100 people who had suffered blood clots after flying from Australia to London, Canada the US and other distinations.

Two months ago Emma Christoffersen, 28, from Wales, died after developing a fatal clot on a 20-hour Qantas economy-class flight from Australia and losing consciousness in the Heathrow arrivals lounge.

Mr Henderson alleged there were 60 deaths a year at Heathrow airport from blood clots. He said: "The big issue is the failure to warn of the risk, and failure to advise of steps that might be taken to reduce the risk, as well as the failure to advise and warn of early onset of symptoms.

"There's no doubt that if the airline warns of the risk appropriately and takes some fairly simple measures to reduce the risk, then they will not be sued. And that's the very disappointing thing. They knew of this risk for some time and they appear to have put their head in the sand."

Mr Henderson confirmed that he would represent passengers aged from their early 20s to mid-60s who had flown on Qantas, British Airways, Air France, Air New Zealand and Emirates, but warned that others could also be targeted.

A spokesperson for Qantas admitted yesterday that it had not previously warned passengers of the risks widely linked to staying immobile for long periods of time on flights, "but we've certainly encouraged people to perform a series of exercises while seated".

Qantas said that inflight videos warning of blood clots and advising preventative in-seat exercises would be introduced at the start of every section of a long-haul journey by the end of January. Its December in-flight magazine is its first to specifically warn about the potential dangers.

The compensation claims, estimated to be each worth up to £22,500, will not necessarily encourage similar actions in Britain because Australian laws make it easier to mount a class action.

A House of Lords report criticised airlines last month for "woefully neglecting" passengers' health and called for warnings on long-haul tickets. But it accepted there was not yet any conclusive proof of the link between DVT and flying, and also said the condition should not be called "economy class syndrome" as immobility, not lack of space, appeared to be the key trigger.

It said that one in 1,000 people will develop the condition each year. Pregnant women and women on hormone replacement treatment or the pill, smokers, and those with heart disease are most at risk.

Qantas said that inflight videos warning of blood clots and advising preventative in-seat exercises would be introduced at the start of every section of a long-haul journey by the end of January. Its December in-flight magazine is its first to specifically warn about the potential dangers. The compensation claims, estimated to be each worth up to £22,500, will not necessarily encourage similar actions in Britain because Australian laws make it easier to mount a class action. A House of Lords report criticised airlines last month for "woefully neglecting" passengers' health and called for warnings on long-haul tickets. But it accepted there was not yet any conclusive proof of the link between DVT and flying, and also said the condition should not be called "economy class syndrome" as immobility, not lack of space, appeared to be the key trigger. It said that one in 1,000 people will develop the condition each year. Pregnant women and women on hormone replacement treatment or the pill, smokers, and those with heart disease are most at risk.

webTitle: Mitchell begins Middle East violence inquiry

fields.headline: Mitchell begins violence inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Former US senator meets Israeli leader at start of investigation into 10 weeks of killing

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: George Mitchell, the former US senator who brokered Northern Ireland's Good Friday agreement, made his first foray into the Middle East conflict yesterday when he opened an investigation into the 10 weeks of bloodshed between Israel and the Palestinians.
fields.body:
George Mitchell, the former US senator who brokered Northern Ireland's Good Friday agreement, made his first foray into the Middle East conflict yesterday when he opened an investigation into the 10 weeks of bloodshed between Israel and the Palestinians.

Mr Mitchell, who heads a five-member fact-finding mission, met the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, for three hours before going to Gaza last night to meet the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat. The team is to travel to Egypt and Jordan.

But their mission was eclipsed by the domestic political turmoil of the first machinations in Israel's election campaign. Mr Barak lashed out at his most formidable opponent, the rightwing former prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu, who declared his candidacy on Sunday.

Mr Netanyahu remains a virtual candidate for now. Because he is not an MP, he is barred from standing in the February election, unless he can prevail on parliament to either disband or amend the electoral law.

Meanwhile, Israel Radio reported that German efforts to win the release of three Israeli soldiers kidnapped by Hizbullah guerrillas in October were making progress. Officials said that a deal to swap the soldiers for 19 Lebanese prisoners in Israeli jails could be reached in as little as 10 days.

Mr Mitchell said: "We have no illusions about the difficult nature of the task ahead. Our hope is that the work will be helpful to the parties in reducing the level of violence which has claimed so many lives and to help ensure an early return to the negotiating table."

The perils of the mission were painfully evident yester day when Israeli soldiers sprayed 19 bullets into a Palestinian man in Nablus. Local people said he had been cut down in cold blood when he stepped outside his shop; the Israeli army said he was a known Islamist militant who had opened fire on one of its posts.

The two versions underscores the huge difficulties in establishing the facts of the last 10 weeks, in which 261 Palestinians, 38 Jews and Israeli soldiers, and 13 Arab citizens of Israel have been killed.

The Palestinians accuse Israeli soldiers of using excessive force, and firing on unarmed civilians. Nearly a quarter of the dead were under 18. The army is adamant that its troops fire only in self-defence, or to protect Israeli civilians.

The truth has become even harder to establish in recent weeks, as the insurrection in the West Bank and Gaza which began with teenagers throwing stones has developed into an increasingly savage low-intensity conflict.

Israeli tanks and combat helicopters have bombarded Palestinian cities in reprisal for militia gunfire, Israeli hit squads have assassinated militants from Mr Arafat's Fatah organisation, and Palestinian gunmen in cars have ambushed cars driven by Jewish settlers.

The investigation into the causes of the violence emerged early on as one of the most contentious issues between Israel and the Palestinians.

The Palestinians lobbied hard for a full-scale international investigation, hoping to haul Israel before a war crimes tribunal. Having been condemned by the UN security council and human rights organisations for excessive force, that was Israel's greatest fear.

Even after agreeing to the mission in mid-October, the Israeli government strenuously resisted Mr Mitchell's visit this week, urging the team to wait until the violence had ended.

In the end, Israel folded. But the mission has only the most modest ambitions. A creature of the Washington administration rather than an inde pendent body, it will rely almost entirely on written reports, spending only three days on field work before submitting its report to the US president in March.

With Israel's fears allayed, Mr Mitchell's initial meeting with Mr Barak passed off smoothly.

"We have nothing to hide, or be ashamed of," said Gadi Baltiansky, a prime ministerial spokesman.

webTitle: Inexperience led soldiers to kill, says MoD

fields.headline: Inexperience led soldiers to kill, says MoD
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence has told the mother of an unarmed Catholic teenager shot in Belfast that the two soldiers who killed her son have been allowed to stay in the army because of their youth and inexperience at the time of the incident.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence has told the mother of an unarmed Catholic teenager shot in Belfast that the two soldiers who killed her son have been allowed to stay in the army because of their youth and inexperience at the time of the incident.

Scots Guardsmen James Fisher and Mark Wright were convicted five years ago of murder for shooting Peter McBride in the back in north Belfast in 1992. Last month, the MoD decided they should be allowed to stay in the army, even though it admitted they had lied at their trial.

The decision was widely condemned, not least by Northern Ireland's independent assessor for military complaints. It was taken by the army board, whose members included John Spellar, minister for the armed forces. The board referred to "exceptional circumstances" surrounding the case.

Last month, Lewis Moonie, the junior defence minister, told the Labour MP Kevin McNamara that the board's report was a "confidential matter for the employer, the army, and the employees."

However, the ministry has sent a detailed report to Jean McBride, Peter's mother, giving its reasons for an "unprecedented" decision. The board's classified report has been passed to the Guardian by the Pat Finucane Centre, a Derry-based civil rights group. "Both Guardsmen were young and relatively inexperienced when the incident took place on 4 September 1992", it says.

Guardsman Fisher was born in 1968 and Guardsman Wright in 1973, says the report. "This was their first tour of duty in Northern Ireland and they and only been there for four months".

It describes the "general security situation" at the time as "tense and particularly so in the New Lodge area where the unit had suffered recent casualties including a fatality".

The soldiers had been briefed to expect "that those associated with terrorist groups would be likely to be carrying personal weapons".

The report adds: "Furthermore, the threat of coffee-jar bombs at the time of the offences was very real: soldiers had been maimed and, on occasion, killed by this weapon. The coffee-jar bomb was a device which was very easy to conceal until the moment of throwing".

The board says there was no evidence of "individual or collective premeditation to commit a criminal offence"; that the army "could not prepare an individual for every eventuality"; that the guardsmen had expressed "regret" for Peter McBride's death, and that neither guardsman had any previous criminal record.

The board says the two soldiers had been "utterly loyal" to the army and their present commanding officer had spoken "very highly" of them, not least regarding the part they had played in operations in Macedonia and Kosovo in 1999.

For these reasons, the board says, the two soldiers should be allowed to remain in the army despite the trial judge's finding that they knew Mr McBride posed no threat, were not "in any panic situation", and "deliberately chose to put forward a version which they both knew to be untrue".

The Belfast high court last week gave Mrs McBride leave to appeal against the board's decision.

The Guardian last week revealed that soldiers from the Scots Guards had sent a Christmas card to the Pat Finucane Centre. An army spokesman described it as "either tactless or malicious and ... deeply to be regretted".

fields.headline: Santa gives Jesus the sack
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The story of Jesus appears to have been rejected by kids in favour of Santa, with only 8% of children now associating Christmas with religion.
fields.body:
The story of Jesus appears to have been rejected by kids in favour of Santa, with only 8% of children now associating Christmas with religion.

The story of the nativity was soundly beaten by the present-bearing charms of Santa, with 67% of children saying they associated the holiday period with presents.

A survey by media buying agency MediaCom TMB asked 1,200 eight-to-16-year-olds to nominate one or more of five options as the thing they most associated with Christmas. Presents topped the poll, followed by family and school holidays. Religion only just beat TV, which racked up 7% of the vote.

There was some slightly better news for traditionalists with 40% of children commenting that Christmas was a time for the family. However the Rev Jonathan Jennings, a spokesman for the Church of England, said that the picture was much more positive than the survey suggested. "Our experience through school curriculum and community groups is that most children are aware of the nativity story and the importance of that to the Christian faith," he said.

"The fact that a film like The Grinch with its important underlying counter-commercial message is so successful indicates that children are more sophisticated than this survey suggests."

MediaCom TMB monitored the attitudes of children to help it plan advertising campaigns for clients such as Volkswagen and Nokia. Questions were posed via email to allow it to keep an eye on what's in and what's out in the fickle world of the playground.

Top present requests, according to MediaCom's Cool Kids panel this Christmas, were likely to include Discmen, CD recorders and stereos and PlayStation 2 for boys. Girls were more likely to ask for a new mobile phone, with many wanting to upgrade to newer models.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Solitude | Judy Garland - I'm Always Chasing Rainbows
fields.body:
John Schlapoberskey used to pull himself up by his prison bars just to catch a glimpse of the sunset over Pretoria's roof tops. After solitary confinement and torture in South Africa's main "hanging prison" he now uses his psychotherapeutic training to counsel other torture victims. In Solitude (11.0am, Radio 4) he tells Peter France about his experiences. The programme includes the unbearably poignant singing of African prisoners just before their execution.

Newly discovered tapes reveal the sad early life of Frances Ethel Gumm, killed by excess sleeping pills at 47. She was, of course, Judy Garland (pictured), and the parental abuse of her early years turned her into one of the 20th century's saddest public figures. From the age of 10 her mother pumped her alternately with stimulants and soporifics. Her father's homosexual indiscretions often required the family rapidly to skip town. The two-part series Judy Garland - I'm Always Chasing Rainbows (9.0pm, Radio 2) relives the agonies.

fields.headline: Single spice
fields.trailText: The best line in The Players Club film about Spice Girl Mel B (tonight, 9pm, BBC2) comes from Melanie Brown's mother, Andrea. She describes how she met her daughter's husband-to-be, Jimmy Gulzar, and was unimpressed.
fields.body:
The best line in The Players Club film about Spice Girl Mel B (tonight, 9pm, BBC2) comes from Melanie Brown's mother, Andrea. She describes how she met her daughter's husband-to-be, Jimmy Gulzar, and was unimpressed.

"I says 'Jim, I think that you're marrying Melanie for her money and I think you're gay'," she recalls. But to mouthy Mel, parental disapproval of Jimmy, allied with the collective doubts of the other Spice Girls, was like a dare. It made her even more determined to marry Gulzar, with predictable tabloid-teasing consequences.

Judging by this TV portrait, they should have called her Noisy Spice instead of Scary Spice. Whether she's at home in Leeds with her family, potty-training baby Phoenix, or riding round in the back of her limo between visits to her divorce lawyer, Ms B simply can't shut up. Lob any subject at her - her childhood showbiz ambitions, the boob job she insists she hasn't had, or her spectacular country house in Marlow, Bucks - and she rants mild- mannered interviewer Trevor Nelson to a standstill. Even when she goes for a pee she has to have somebody to talk to... or at. Her lovely home has a lavatory with two loos in it, because, according to Mel, "girls always go to the loo together".

You'll have seen worse celebrity portraits than this - that shocking piece of drivel about Geri Halliwell and her international "good works", for instance - but no Spice Girl would ever allow TV cameras across her doorstep unless she had some product to plug. In this case, the interviewee has two dollops of money- spinning Yuletide candyfloss on sale, the Spice Girls album and her own solo effort, the lukewarm Hot. The film boosts Mel's image of "feisty northern lass", but makes it impossible to believe she has experienced a moment of serious thought in her life.

fields.headline: A bridge too far
fields.trailText: What The Romans Did For Us | Coronation Street | Neanderthal
fields.body:
Quite the most entertaining thing I know about Adam Hart-Davis is that, in 1959, his father wrote to Humphrey Lyttelton's father, "Adam says his boys' maid has got her own television set and he wonders whether the Welfare State hasn't gone a bit too far." We are, of course, talking Old Etonians here.

The next best thing was his spirited attempt in What The Romans Did For Us (BBC2) to cross a river on 150 balloons. The Romans had their share of mad inventors. One wrote to the emperor with several ingenious wheezes. Why not strap scythes to your chariot wheels? Why not power paddleboats with large oxen? And why not cross rivers on inflated goats? The emperor, though probably mad, was not mad enough to try any of these. Unlike Hart-Davis, who seems to bubble with natural carbonation. Failing to find 150 inflated goats readily to hand but sunnily confident of success ("I've done the sums!"), he improvised with a bridge of bright, sausage-shaped balloons. The bridge bounced, it swayed, it flung him into an impromptu dance ("It's a very bizarre feeling. Aargh!") It behaved in all respects like the Millennium Bridge, though it was, of course, a great deal cheaper.

Watching people crossing rivers is a reliable source of entertainment on TV. I remember John Betjeman's wife Penelope, game girl, crossing a Himalayan torrent by clinging on to an inflated ox, and Ray Mears, the survival expert, demonstrating how to cross a river on a rucksack. (A passing pleasure cruiser, seeing him clinging to his luggage, paused to ask if he was all right. His response was, I thought, abrupt.)

In pursuit of inflatable goatskins, we encountered David and Valerie Marshall, who blow up Nigerian goatskins to make traditional bagpipes. If you wonder why Nigerian goatskins, they eat a lot of goats out there. If you wonder how the Marshalls ended up in this implausible job, so do I.

Meanwhile in Coronation Street (Granada), Natalie has broken the long-dreaded news. "In a few weeks time the Rovers will become the Boozy Newt!" Fred inflated like a bagpipe and gave much the same wail of pain. "Belgian beer and sun-dried chewbacca bread! When they call time on t'Rovers, they call time on an 'ole generation." The Rovers has been threatened with a name change before. Ten years ago Newton and Ridley planned to turn it into a theme pub called Yankees until Bet and Alec, the licensees, manned the barricades and defied them. Pub names are something to be puzzled over and treasured. The Case Is Altered, The King Of Poland, The Goat And Compasses, The Sun In Splendour, The Old Blue Last and The Litten Tree. All of them with a tap root deep in history and branches lost in mysterious mist. Why is the old last blue and what is a litten tree? In fact customers call pubs what they want to call them. Only my mother called our pub the Mill Hill Hotel, giving each unaccustomed aitch a firm tap on the head like a boiled egg. Everyone else called it t'New Pub. The Rovers Return, now there's a strange name, is having one of its traditional dust-ups, from which a new landlady will rise like a knickerbocker glory. I am taking bets. Evens Liz McDonald. 5-2 Linda Baldwin. 200-1 Emily Bishop.

The Neanderthals, who slowly sank in the West last night, seemed unexpectedly gentle and diffident people. Give or take a touch of infanticide. Their instinctive reaction, confronted with a new variety of man with a smart Mohican haircut, fur trousers and blue eye shadow was to run away. The Cro-Magnons, who apparently played the tom-tom during sexual intercourse, could pass without comment for a rock group. What evidence Neanderthal (Channel 4) offered was gained, like Silent Witness, from forensic pathology. Pollen in a Neanderthal grave in Israel may suggest funeral flowers. Or may not. The skeleton found in Portugal of a four-year-old child with Neanderthal and Cro-Magnon characteristics may imply interbreeding. Or, of course, not. Trinkets buried with the child definitely indicate grief and tenderness. If this child was hybrid, it lived 3,000 years after Neanderthals were believed to have died out. That Neanderthals may still be among us is as seductive an idea as that dinosaurs mutated into birds.

webTitle: The remaking of Queer As Folk for US screens

fields.headline: Only in America
fields.standfirst: Americans are a conservative lot. Especially when it comes to explicit gay sex on TV. So when Queer As Folk was remade for US screens, Jacques Peretti was expecting to see something rather tame. He couldn't have been more wrong
fields.trailText: Americans are a conservative lot. Especially when it comes to explicit gay sex on TV. So when Queer As Folk was remade for US screens, Jacques Peretti was expecting to see something rather tame. He couldn't have been more wrong.
fields.body:
Eyes meet across a sea of steaming torsos. Proud owners of baby-oiled pecs turn heliotropically towards one another, like flowers in a wood, eyeing one another's bulging pouches.

It's the ketamine-fuelled, sweat-soaked club scene from Channel Four's hit soap opera, Queer As Folk - which last week transferred to American TV, produced by Showtime with new actors in a new city, but the same basic instinct.

The first thing to say about the US version of Queer As Folk is how shocking it is. How shocking that so many of the sexually explicit scenes from the British original have remained relatively intact. This is all the more surprising when one considers how strict US TV laws are about showing anything raunchier than a man blowing his nose into a handkerchief.

Much has been made of how sanitised the US version is in comparison with Russell T Davies's original. Cleaning up the sex in the same way the US version of Ab Fab excised America's number one fear (greater, even, than homosexuality): smoking.

US Queer As Folk opens with the obligatory yoo-hoo-darling club scene, moving seamlessly to fellatio in the backroom. "Having your dick sucked off is sooo boring", one of the characters yawns, inadvertently making an adroit comment about the whole programme.

Sexier than one had imagined American advertisers allowing, US Queer As Folk is nevertheless dull. It's as slick and humourless as a soft porn video, and as boring as watching Newsnight without Jeremy Paxman.

I asked James Collard, the former editor-in-chief of Out, America's biggest gay magazine, why the US adaptation has erased any trace of humour from the original. "New York now is like England 25 years ago. Crack a joke and you're accused of betraying the entire gay community. Whilst we tend to have a laugh about ourselves, they have a serious and very defensive gay culture".

While Russell T Davies's original drama came from an unapologetic, almost Loaded sensibility towards gay life, the US version looks smug, bland and as realistic as a spread in Maxim. In comparison with Britain, the gay establishment in America is extraordinarily conservative. A stereotypical gay man is less likely to be cavorting on a podium, snorting Sextasy, than walking the dogs with his boyfriend, discussing share prices and wearing Ralph Lauren shirts.

Unlike Britain, the gay community forms a cohesive political lobby with formidable economic clout. It's no surprise that a huge, conservative company like Microsoft is happy to target gay men as model Microsoft consumers because, in a very real sense, American gay men are the straightest people on earth.

So how did Showtime manage to transfer Queer As Folk at all, even in a bowdlerised form? How did networks shift from their position a couple of years ago - running scared of Ellen outing herself - to showing copious amounts of penetrative gay sex?

The path for Queer As Folk was paved by the surprise mainstream success of two late-night shows. The Sopranos proved that ratings and gratuitous use of the word "fuck" are not mutually exclusive. Sex In The City - which looks tame on British TV - caused a storm as the most sexually provocative programme ever shown on US TV. Both proved to advertisers that it was better to be associated with something cool, urban and niche than dull, middle-American and reactionary.

Sex In The City appeared to take a risk by appealing narrowly to young, single women. Yet the show was a ratings success. Queer As Folk, ironically, is aimed at the same audience. Young, urban women who are not intimidated by two men having sex but actually, erherm, turned on. The same secretarial pool, in other words, salivating over the homoerotic builder during their Diet Coke break.

British fans of Queer As Folk will undoubtedly feel the US version is pathetically watered-down - all soft focus humping behind sand-blasted, loft-apartment glass - but its achievement in the US TV marketplace is considerable.

In many ways, it's far more radical in its context than the British version, commissioned by a channel perpetually hungry for controversy, and prepared to promote an otherwise marginal programme on every billboard in the land.

America - one mustn't forget - is a deeply frightening country. One in which a programme like Queer As Folk co-exists with a show like Jenny Jones, on which a man was introduced to a secret admirer... who turned out to be gay. After humiliation before a baying audience of lard-arsed white trash inbreds, the man's response was to stab his admirer with a six-inch knife. Queer As Folk may be watered down, but they have their reasons.

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with... Nasty Nick
fields.trailText: Getting personal with... Nasty Nick
fields.body:
Full Name: Nicholas Bateman

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why?

Yes, to get a good table at a restaurant.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why?

Yes, to a girl.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?

Kind-hearted, strong and emotional.

What was the last illegal thing you did?

Went through a red light.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?

Gave £10 to a tramp.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?

Claudia Winkelmann.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?

JM.

Has a critic ever made you cry?

No.

What would you advertise without a fee?

Cancers relating to men.

What would you never advertise?

Nothing.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning?

Thinking I should have won Big Brother.

What takes you to a "happy place"?

Aircraft.

Nick Bateman presents Trust Me this week on Channel 4.

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: The Otway Range
fields.trailText: The Otway Range
fields.body:
The hills of the Otway Range climb steeply up behind the rocky, shipwreck coast of the State of Victoria. A secluded gully called Mait's Rest (the spot where Maitland Bryan, the area's first Forestry Officer, used to rest his horse) is one of the few remaining pockets of native rainforest. The steep, rugged terrain and the thickness of vegetation preserved the Otway area from European settlement until the middle of the 19th century, when Europeans cleared parts for farming.

When gold was found at Ballarat and Bendigo, commercial logging began, to support the mining industry and the growth of Melbourne. In 1870 a tramway was built to transport timber. Through the 1880s sawmills proliferated; there were no controls. Now, there are state controls, but many think them inadequate. A felling programme which will affect the headwaters of the most spectacular of the Otway's many waterfalls (it falls 130 metres down through virgin forest) is currently pitting the bushwalking, tourism and conservation interests against the timber industry.

Our walk through Mait's Rest when, in the fine rain and cool breeze, the leaves glistened and trembled, took us deep into a still, mysterious enclosed space, with mosses, lichens, luxuriant giant ferns, vines and fungi, down below the lofty canopy that shades them all. Some ancient gum-trees (the kind called mountain ash) tower into the sky, mutilated survivors of fire and felling, their tops sheered off so that far below, on the soft forest floor, great mossy logs are slowly rotting, making their contribution to the forest's slow life-cycle.

webTitle: The stifling effect of the new academy

fields.headline: Fool Britannia
fields.standfirst: Post-modern, post-conceptual, post-ironic? That means not new, not clever, not funny. Mark Wallinger on the stifling effect of the new academy
fields.trailText: Post-modern, post-conceptual, post-ironic? That means not new, not clever, not funny. Mark Wallinger on the stifling effect of the new academy
fields.body:
Charles Saatchi's gallery was the model for Freeze, the show curated by Damien Hirst in London in 1988, and the warehouse and vacant-building shows that followed. These ex-industrial spaces were much too big for the exhibitions, and artworks became stunts - a small explosion here, a revolving bow tie there. The spirit of PT Barnum infected the exhibitions, a sensibility that would persist into the 1990s. Empty buildings - or, strictly speaking, emptied buildings - were sought for a proliferation of artist-run shows. Buildings emptied of history, and, by dint of the artworks, removed from the context of urban blight and redevelopment.

What was missing was the audience. In hot-wiring straight to the moneyed and the influential, the need for a discerning public was successfully avoided. The effacement of a building as a productive space made of that loss a paradoxical kind of value. Art objects were invigorated by their capacity to empty out history; a no-space in no-time where nothing can fail to signify.

For a number of reasons, art had given up the ghost under the weight of theory. The breakdown of distinctions between high and popular culture led to all manner of cultural produce and effluent being sifted and read as text. We were top heavy with theorists (not to mention curators), who needed scant visual stimulus to write the work into the flat ergo of post-modernist irony: in short, what we had was nominalism. Artworks merely had to ring the appropriate bell to set the Pavlovian critics slavering for interpretation.

The artists themselves are curiously mute about their practice, perhaps because there is little to say about works that specialise in stating the bleeding obvious. Art is a commodity in the marketplace, women have a raw deal, children's sexuality is spooky, we are all going to die, etc. Context is all: what is lamentable on Jerry Springer is presentable in the gallery. The authority of the gallery created a magical hiatus where pandering to the audience's appetite for sensation and vulgarity is seen in the guise of importance. However, nothing worthwhile can live long within inverted commas. The lazily adopted tag, "Duchampian", that attaches to much current work is misleading. Far from being subversive, this work is subservient to the institutions validating power. But this "radical" charade is of mutual benefit to the artists and galleries: the first step to success is to get yourself curated.

Artistic practice is the most critical practice. Art works should engage, articulate, problematise, open new ways of seeing, place the viewer in jeopardy of their received opinions, move the artists to the limits of what they know or believe, excite, incite, entertain, annoy, get under the skin, and when you've done with them, nag at your mind to go take another look.

Instead, today we have nominal triggers for regurgitating arguments better rehearsed elsewhere, which are neither illuminated nor in any sense present within the work: art that, in deconstructive logic, is a footnote to the text that justifies its existence. At many art colleges, art history has been replaced as a mandatory part of fine-art courses by critical theory. An academy, an orthodoxy, a training scheme for artists has been created and, as in Mannerist paintings, gestures have lost their connectedness with meaning in the same way that sentiment comes apart from emotion.

Postmodernism, with its refutation of meta-narratives and ideology, has unfortunately served as a handy argument in favour of ignorance as an end-of-history stance. Andy Warhol, having already squeegeed history flat, left his successors nowhere to go, other than A to B (Anal to Banal). This, nevertheless was the path chosen by the students of the Freeze generation. Freeze was the show in which student work broke through. Its greatest quality was its removal of expectations of depth and meaning, to be replaced by the society of the dilettante. In a world that begins and ends at one's fingertips, with an ineffectual past and a baseless future, all things are ever present and equivalent. Within this Fool's Paradise, if you look like an artist, live like an artist and behave like an artist, then you are indeed an artist.

NB: some advice on deconstructing current critical terminology: simply replace "not" for "post", so that post-modern, post-conceptual and post-ironic become not new, not clever and not funny.

This is an edited extract from Art for All, co-edited by Mark Wallinger and Mary Warnock, published next week at £18 by Peer (020 7739 8080 or piertrust@btinternet.com)

webTitle: Short outlines measures to reduce world poverty

fields.headline: Short outlines measures to reduce world poverty
fields.standfirst:
White paper aims to include poor in benefits of 'globalisation'

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Clare Short, the international development secretary, yesterday pledged the government to harnessing the "forces of globalisation" to cut world poverty and accused anti-capitalist protesters of risking a return to a 30s-style slump.
fields.body:
Clare Short, the international development secretary, yesterday pledged the government to harnessing the "forces of globalisation" to cut world poverty and accused anti-capitalist protesters of risking a return to a 30s-style slump.

Publishing her long-awaited white paper on globalisation, Ms Short announced a crackdown on money laundering, more cash to fight polio, and a new facility to help Africa attract investment, and promised to work hard to tear down trade barriers.

Globalisation allows financial and investment markets to operate internationally, but requires a substantial degree of deregulation.

"Globalisation brings with it opportunities and risks. If the poorest people and countries can be included in the global economy on more beneficial terms, it could lead to a rapid reduction in global poverty but if we go on as we are the poor will become more marginalised," Ms Short said.

Accusing anti-capitalists of having a negative agenda, Ms Short said that dismantling international organisations such as the International Monetary Fund, World Bank and World Trade Organisation would unleash a tide of protectionism.

The government's white paper was published a year after the collapse of trade liberalisation talks in Seattle where violent protests marked the beginning of a backlash against globalisation.

Protests have followed at meetings in Washington, Prague and last weekend's EU summit in Nice.

The white paper, Eliminating World Poverty: making globalisation work for the poor, contained seven announcements - an extra £35m to eradicate polio from the world in five years; an extra £15m to help African countries trade more effectively; a new facility to attract private money to improve the continent's infrastructure; a draft bill to tighten laws on money laundering; a commission on intellectual property rights to protect the interests of developing countries; increased support for environmental initiatives; and an end to the practice of tying aid to the purchase of goods and services from British companies.

The shadow international development secretary, Gary Streeter, claimed that the white paper offered a "lukewarm vision of a timid Britain in a world of challenge".

He said: "It is long on rhetoric and short on specifics. There are no detailed proposals on how Clare Short plans to reform multilateral organisations such as the UN and the EU, which continue to under-perform.

The Liberal Democrat inter national development spokeswoman, Jenny Tonge, said: "The only way these well-intentioned words can be put into action is if the white paper receives whole-hearted support and action from all government departments.

"The government has not made the progress we would have liked with the first white paper - what has the DTI done about the arms control bill to control arms brokers, essential for the prevention of conflict which is such a barrier to development in the world's poorest countries?

"The government has not brought about domestic legislation to enforce the OECD anti-bribery convention to prohibit the bribery of foreign officials overseas - essential if we are to try to overcome corruption."

fields.headline: Charles to meet 'slap case' head
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Prince of Wales has told Marjorie Evans, the headteacher cleared of slapping a pupil, that he sympathises with her plight and would like a face to face meeting.
fields.body:
The Prince of Wales has told Marjorie Evans, the headteacher cleared of slapping a pupil, that he sympathises with her plight and would like a face to face meeting.

In an unusual intervention, the prince's private secretary, Stephen Lamport, wrote to Mrs Evans, who has not yet returned to work at St Mary's junior school in Caldicot, Gwent, after being suspended on allegations that she struck a 10-year-old boy.

"The prince has asked me to write to you on a very personal basis to say how much he has felt for you over the very difficult circumstances you have faced in recent months," Mr Lamport wrote.

"His royal highness would very much welcome the opportunity at some point to meet you to talk about your experiences. I wonder therefore if you might be able to ring me at some point to look at the possibilities of how we might arrange a very private meeting with his royal highness."

The prince takes a keen interest in education but it is rare for his concern for someone who so recently faced prosecution to be made public. St James's Palace said the letter, sent on November 20, was private, and the prince's office would not comment further.

Mrs Evans's union, the National Union of Teachers, said she was angry the letter had been leaked to the media. Gethin Lewis, secretary of NUT Wales, confirmed the letter was genuine and added: "She was obviously delighted with the letter and very pleased to receive his support and has already made her own arrangements with regard to meeting him."

The union has complained about recent leaks surrounding Mrs Evans's case, which was being considered again by governors at the school last night. She is on paid leave but after further allegations that she slapped pupils and shouted at them, still faces the threat of disciplinary charges.

Documents compiled by council officials detailing 15 separate allegations against her appeared in local newspapers in Wales last week.

Mrs Evans was suspended in September 1999. In July she was found guilty of assault, but she was cleared by the court of appeal in September. She remained suspended while police investigated more claims, but the crown prosecution service said in October it would not be taking action against her.

The union wants a panel of one governor, one member of the local education authority, and one independent person to review the new charges facing Mrs Evans.

Gethin Lewis, secretary of NUT Wales, confirmed the letter was genuine and added: "She was obviously delighted with the letter and very pleased to receive his support and has already made her own arrangements with regard to meeting him." The union has complained about recent leaks surrounding Mrs Evans's case, which was being considered again by governors at the school last night. She is on paid leave but after further allegations that she slapped pupils and shouted at them, still faces the threat of disciplinary charges. Documents compiled by council officials detailing 15 separate allegations against her appeared in local newspapers in Wales last week. Mrs Evans was suspended in September 1999. In July she was found guilty of assault, but she was cleared by the court of appeal in September. She remained suspended while police investigated more claims, but the crown prosecution service said in October it would not be taking action against her. The union wants a panel of one governor, one member of the local education authority, and one independent person to review the new charges facing Mrs Evans.

fields.headline: No: 1780 Spice Girls
fields.trailText: Hey, sad loser! Who are you calling a sad loser?
fields.body:
Hey, sad loser! Who are you calling a sad loser?

Oops, forgive me. For a moment I got you confused with the delectable Victoria Beckham. Goodness, what has poor old Mrs Megabucks done to arouse such ire? I thought her single was rather decent. And don't forget she's married to Mr Megabucks, the Manchester United footballer David Beckham, who's just released an autobiography and video in time for Christmas.

But it's not me calling her a sad loser, it's the 480,000 readers of Smash Hits. They voted her second saddest loser of the year in their annual poll. Well, at least she wasn't first, which went to Liam Gallagher of the once-great Oasis. And besides, when you're as famous and talented as Posh, you have to expect the odd bit of jealousy here and there.

I suppose that would explain why the Spice Girls came first in the worst group, worst album, worst single and worst video categories, not to mention Mel C storming ahead of the Steps lads to scoop most tragic hair cut. Consistent, if nothing else - and don't forget second worst-dressed. How cruel, coming just weeks after their new album, Forever, spectacularly failed to live up to the hype, dropping out of the top 10 after just one week and selling one-third of that of their Irish arch-rivals, Westlife. The mighty colossus that was once girl power seems to be on the wane, maybe because they took three years off after the last album to pursue solo careers, revealing themselves in the process as ruthless businesswomen who cared more about Gucci than female empowerment.

I say, that's a bit harsh. And les Girls have always had a way of bouncing back from adversity, so it might be too early to be announcing their downfall. I refer you to Mel C's recent "jokey" comment to Frank Skinner on his ITV chat show about having already left the group. Can it be long before the others follow?

Don't say: "Geri, come back!"

Do say: "Don't take any notice, Sporty, I like your haircut."

fields.headline: Web lines
fields.trailText: Internet shopping may be revolutionising Christmas shopping, but a trip to the online malls shows that traditional habits die hard. Keen to help those in need of inspiration, many websites have sorted their goods by gender.
fields.body:
Internet shopping may be revolutionising Christmas shopping, but a trip to the online malls shows that traditional habits die hard. Keen to help those in need of inspiration, many websites have sorted their goods by gender.

Not for women the latest handheld personal organiser, though. Search for "gifts for her" and you will find a stimulating range of practical pressies, from hair-styling tools to teddies (both the underwear and stuffed animal versions). Back to writing lists for Santa then.

While new-media hype tells us that everyone is shopping online, new research shows that people are logging on for reasons closer to their hearts. A survey by the Pew Internet and American Life Project found that US users spend more time surfing for health advice than for online shops, sports news or stock quotes. It said 55% of Americans had used the net within the last month to find information about diseases and treatment, compared to 47% for shopping.

It can't have escaped your notice that those annoying mobile phone conversations on the train home have been replaced by the frantic tapping that signifies text messaging. British users of mobile phone short message services (SMS) are sending 700m messages a month, according to the research group IDC. The phenomenon is most popular with the under-24s who send an average of 10 messages a day, while one in five 13 to 16-year-olds only use their mobile phones for texting. A survey by the mobile phone software company m@gic4 found that 50% of mobile users had been chatted up via SMS and one in five women had used it to dump a partner. Another reason why it's GD2TLK.
