webTitle: Battle over bypasses may hinge on Hastings

fields.headline: Battle over bypasses may hinge on Hastings
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Environment groups and transport campaigners are ready to challenge government plans to spend up to £1bn next year on roadworks and new bypasses which they say could increase traffic with no economic benefit.
fields.body:
Environment groups and transport campaigners are ready to challenge government plans to spend up to £1bn next year on roadworks and new bypasses which they say could increase traffic with no economic benefit.

The Department of Transport is expected in the next week to announce detailed plans for 77 bypass schemes put forward by councils, many in politically marginal areas.

The Council for the Protection of Rural England, Friends of the Earth, Transport 2000 and other groups say some schemes are being rushed through without thorough assessment of their economic, social or environmental impact and without proper consultation with communities. They further accuse the government of wasting taxpayers' money.

This week a CPRE survey suggested that 32 schemes had not been properly assessed and many more were being promoted by government on the basis that they would help economic development despite evidence to the contrary.

The groups, which led the protracted battles against road building in the 1990s and backed dozens of protests including those at Newbury, Twyford Down and Batheaston, said there was growing dismay among members that the government was ignoring its own advice that road building was not the best way to tackle congestion and economic regeneration and often fuelled traffic growth and pollution. They did not, however, expect big demonstrations yet.

"The battle lines are being drawn. Road building is definitely back on the agenda. We do not think that the lessons of the 1990s have been learned," said a CPRE spokesman yesterday.

"The consensus used to be that we could not build ourselves out of the problems with new roads but this is no longer recognised by government."

Many schemes were potentially destructive, with some passing through areas of outstanding natural beauty and protected scientific sites.

"Middle England will be very sceptical", said Stephen Joseph of Transport 2000. "The government thinks the public wants new roads. They are going to upset a lot of people who remember the stupidity of road building in the mid-1990s and know that road building increases rather than reduces traffic."

Transport campaigners intend to "draw a line in the sand" over the possible road around Hastings.

This would damage two sites of special scientific interest and pass through a designated wildlife site.

A government-financed study published this week on building the road, against the option of public transport and other alternatives, was inconclusive, but it warned that road building could further depress the town's economy. The business community is strongly backing the bypass.

The Hastings study is the first of 27 on the impact of big schemes. "It will be a test case," said Mr Joseph. "If the government agrees to road building here, it will be courting disaster. It is a key marginal seat. It would certainly conflict with the government's own transport plan."

But a Guardian survey of some road building by the Conservatives showed that bypasses and roadworks did not necessarily bring economic regeneration or solve traffic congestion. The consensus of communities affected was that they might in the short term reduce traffic at peak times in towns and villages, but many increased dramatically development pressures on greenfield sites.

Paul Hamblin of the CPRE said: "Surveys show that public support is high for measures to tackle traffic growth, provide alternatives to the car and better maintain roads and railways."

In the next two years more than £2bn is expected to be spent on more than 200 road schemes. They include widening motorways and dozens of smaller bypasses.

Roadworks prove a mixed blessing

Newbury

The £74m bypass was the longest running roads dispute of the 1990s, destroying several protected sites and costing up to £50m to guard. It was opened in 1998 and has taken the large lorries out of the town centre and reduced off-peak traffic. But traffic is said to be just as congested at peak times, and the level of bypass traffic is believed to be higher than expected.

Burley in Wharfedale

No sooner had the concrete set on the A65 dual carriageway around the small dales village than developers began to build on the land between the road and the village which has now almost doubled in size. The road has taken through traffic away, but the character of the village has radically changed and older residents say it is now much more of a commuter dormitory village for Leeds.

Brighton and Hove bypass

The £80m Brighton bypass was mostly completed by the early 1990s. It is claimed that it has not increased east-west traffic and has led to slight reductions in city centre traffic.

Travel around Brighton is now easier for people with cars, but aside from great environmental damage, there is intense pressure for out of town developments in the area of outstanding natural beauty.

A55

The A55 north Wales coast road from near Chester to Anglesey reduced the need to upgrade the A5 route through Snowdonia but it has increased traffic by 400% on the coastal route and led to more commuting between north Wales and Cheshire and Merseyside.

Twyford Down

The M3 cutting through the downs led to the first big road protest. It has had a negligible effect on Winchester traffic.

Batheaston-Swainswick bypass

The £60m Batheaston-Swainswick bypass which was finished in the mid-1990s was intended to bypass the world heritage site of Bath and was the focus of fierce protests. It has relieved traffic in the villages of Batheaston and Swainswick, but has not greatly relieved traffic in Bath.

Oswestry

The Oswestry (A5) bypass has made several villages more tranquil but has generated traffic and greenfield housing development.

fields.headline: Town and country
fields.standfirst: The government wants to improve the lot of both urban and rural dwellers, but the countryside is always going to get the best part of the deal
fields.trailText: The government wants to improve the lot of both urban and rural dwellers, but the countryside is always going to get the best part of the deal.
fields.body:
Despite the fanfare when the urban white paper was launched, there was nothing for the cities in the Queen's speech. Could that be because, read back-to-back with last week's rural white paper, the two contradict each other? Between them, the government intends to make it less likely that people will quit metropolitan centres and more likely that those who live in rural areas will be happy. The two objective do not add up.

Here is the problem. For many years people have flooded away from older, larger towns and cities towards the safe beauty of the countryside. Once transport and telecommunications made it possible to enjoy the benefits of the city while living in the countryside, it is small wonder that millions fled the (often imagined) horrors of Manchester, Liverpool and the rest.

The table shows how satisfied people are with their local area. It demonstrates the problem faced by the government: over three-quarters of people living in rural areas are "very satisfied", compared with just 35% in urban locations. The less urban an area is the more popular it will be. Only 3% of people in the most rural areas are in any way dissatisfied with their area compared with 14-16% in urban areas.

The government said it wanted spending and tax breaks to increase the attractiveness of Britain's tatty cities. If more people could be persuaded to stay in them, developers would have less incentive to despoil what remains of England's green and pleasant land. John Prescott's department put together a respectable range of measures to make cities more financially and visually acceptable to their inhabitants.

Now look at the rural white paper. This certainly painted a less bleak picture of the countryside than its urban counterpart did about the cities. Nevertheless, the rural document highlighted problems such as falling farm incomes, declining village services, development pressures and isolation. New initiatives, funding programmes and local government changes are proposed. For example, there will be more money for rural policing, extra resources for affordable housing in the countryside, dramatic improvements in rural bus services and more powers for parish councils.

No one would oppose the proposed improvements to countryside services. For the poor, the non-car-owning and victims of crime in rural parts of the country there will always be a need for better public provision. The difficulty is that while problems in rural areas tend to centre on the poverty and difficulties of a minority of individuals, the white paper's solutions will have the effect of making the countryside as a whole even more attractive than it already is.

Urban areas would, without public intervention, have major advantages over rural ones. The provision of new technology, for example, is already far more widespread in the cities than elsewhere. Other things being equal, the benefits of agglomeration (as economists are fond of calling them) point to significant advantages for large towns and cities. Yet governments of all parties feel the need to bring such urban advantages to the most rural of areas. Universal telephone and postal services are provided by way of cross-subsidies from towns and cities.

The rural white paper makes clear how the government intervenes to bring the technological advantages of urban concentration to rural areas: "the market alone will not deliver affordable high-speed connections to all rural areas. We will therefore work through the development agencies to develop effective strategies for the roll-out of higher bandwidth (new cable and/or wireless links) services in rural areas, taking full advantage of public sector investment".

Though the urban paper makes similar commit ments, in effect, people living in the countryside - likely to be better off anyway - are to be publicly subsidised to bring the advantages of urban life to their doorsteps. It is small wonder that people who can afford it flock away from the grime and poor services of (particularly) the older, northern cities. By moving to rural areas, they enjoy less stressed schools and hospitals, cleaner air and a chance of living somewhere with which they are really satisfied. Better still, governments of all parties will guarantee that universal service provision is subsidised so all the relative advantages of the cities are on tap.

This is not to argue that people - particularly the vulnerable and children - who live in the countryside should be deprived of modern facilities and opportunities. But it is important to understand that society's kindly Fabian desire to ensure that no one, even in the most remote areas, should be denied a fuller set of public and private services than could be provided without subsidy is removing our cities' main advantage.

So the government's urban and rural white papers will, between them, provide both urban and country areas with marginal new advantages. However, by giving the countryside new and better public services, there must be the risk that even more people will want to go and live there. It is easier to put on new bus services in country lanes than to remove dereliction and deprivation from inner-city housing estates. The paradox is that stopping the urban exodus would probably require less government action to make rural areas attractive.

Tony Travers is director of the Greater London group at the London School of Economics

webTitle: Animal terrorists blamed for binliner bomb blast

fields.headline: Animal terrorists blamed for binliner bomb blast
fields.trailText: Animal rights militants are believed responsible for a bomb that exploded in Nottingham yesterday. No one was injured.
fields.body:
Animal rights militants are believed responsible for a bomb that exploded in Nottingham yesterday. No one was injured.

The bomb had been placed next to a van belonging to an electrician, believed to have done work for a firm connected with animal testing.

He was about to get in the vehicle parked outside his house to go to work when he spotted a black binliner bag. Inside, he found a device with canisters and wires.

He went back to his home to phone the emergency services. Within seconds, the bomb had detonated.

The explosion, around 7am, scattered shrapnel and shattered windows in nearby houses in the Colwick district of the city.

Police refused to identify the man for fear of further attacks. He is believed to be an electrician whose firm had carried out work at a company in Loughborough, Leicestershire, connected with tests on animals.

Inspector John Woodward of Nottinghamshire police said: "When he got to the driver's door, he saw a black binliner. He looked inside and saw canisters and wires." A Nottinghamshire police spokesman said detectives believed the device was made by animal militants. "We're keeping an open mind, but the nature of the bomb is of a similar type to those used by these groups," he said.

The area was sealed off as there were reports a second device had been planted. But a search by bomb squad officers found nothing.

The explosion was heard hundreds of yards away. Neighbour Tracey Rai said that everything in the house shook. "I leapt out of bed and ran outside in my pyjamas," she said. "I just can't believe what happened."

The area was still sealed off yesterday afternoon for forensic examination.

webTitle: Letters: Tragedy in the car park

fields.headline: Tragedy in the car park
fields.trailText: Reading about the sad plight of depressed Davina Rappai (Why did this woman starve to death in a car park?, December 9), I cannot help feeling angry that police are once again blamed for something that is surely her family's responsibility.
fields.body:
Reading about the sad plight of depressed Davina Rappai (Why did this woman starve to death in a car park?, December 9), I cannot help feeling angry that police are once again blamed for something that is surely her family's responsibility.

Had the police interfered they would probably have been blamed for harassment.
Marina Grut
London

 I was deeply upset by Davina, she was obviously very disturbed, and I take great offence at being described as a "bloke" who just "cut the grass around the car". I tried to communicate with her every time I went to the car park; only once did I get her to even open the window a crack to accept the number of a women's refuge.

I feel that I did all I reasonably could, her presence and my misgivings were reported early to the police. It was the authorities' failure to get her under medical supervision that led to the tragedy of her death. fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In an article headed The need to modernise our country, page 23, December 6, we referred to the Queen as "the world's richest woman". She is not.
fields.body:
In an article headed The need to modernise our country, page 23, December 6, we referred to the Queen as "the world's richest woman". She is not.

In the Sunday Times Rich List 2000, published March 19, this year, the Queen was listed 106th among the rich of Britain, let alone the world (down from 87th the previous year). Other women appear above her in the list. The question of the Queen's wealth was the subject of a complaint to the Press Complaints Commission from the Queen's press secretary in 1995/96 after the Queen had been placed first, with an estimated wealth of £2.2bn, in a feature called The Rich 500 compiled by the magazine Business Age. The previous year she had been 72nd in the magazine's list.

The Palace argued that the analysis was inaccurate and misleading. The PCC, with some qualifications, upheld the complaint and published its adjudication in its report No 34 (April/May/June 1996).

 Contrary to what we said in a column, page 5, G2, December 6, "Chris Smith's department" does not own Trafalgar Square. Responsibility for the Square (and its pigeons) has recently been transferred to the Greater London Assembly.

 Culzean Castle, Maybole, is in Ayrshire and not Perthshire as we wrongly stated on page 7, Travel, December 9.

 From page 3, Media, yesterday: "...even after a fine tooth-comb examination [they] were exonerated". That would be fine-tooth comb. Collins Millennium, go over with a fine-tooth(ed) comb, to examine very thoroughly.

 From the television column on page 4, Saturday Review, December 9: "There were big parties, we were told, which looked like Fellini sets, with dwarves covered in liver and men dressed as French maids." Covered in livery, that would be.

 The lower-case christmas in our note about the Top 10 cookbooks, page 11, Saturday Review, December 9, was just a slip. Christmas still has an initial capital, even in the Guardian.

webTitle: Women with breast implants face health anxiety

fields.headline: 'Safe' breast implant is banned
fields.trailText: More than 4,000 women who chose to have their breasts enlarged with what were marketed as natural and safe varieties of implant face anxiety and uncertainty following a decision by the Department of Health yesterday to withdraw them from sale.
fields.body:
More than 4,000 women who chose to have their breasts enlarged with what were marketed as natural and safe varieties of implant face anxiety and uncertainty following a decision by the Department of Health yesterday to withdraw them from sale.

Two types of hydrogel implant, which were vigorously promoted in women's magazines by cosmetic surgery clinics following the silicone scare in the United States, have been banned from sale in Britain as a precautionary measure. They are the poly implant prosthesis, manufactured in France, and NovaGold, from Germany.

The government insists nobody has been harmed or is likely to be damaged, but the announcement will cause more distress among women with breast implants, some of whom have had the operation to restore their shape following a mastectomy.

Last year 5,000 women with soya bean oil-filled implants were advised to have them removed for fear that fluid leaking into the tissues of the breast could cause cancer or birth defects.

Yesterday's action against hydrogel implants is a result of the review that the government's medical devices agency (MDA) undertook following the soya bean oil disaster, when it became clear that the safety data on the implants had been inadequate.

Implants do not have to be tested in human beings. They are authorised for sale within the EU by a regulatory agency in one of the member states.

The MDA, which is responsible for implants within the UK, said it was not satisfied with the safety data produced by the hydrogel implant manufacturers.

Pat Troop, deputy chief medical officer, said: "It must be stressed that no definite health risk has been identified. At present there is no information to indicate there is any risk to women with these implants, or their children.

"The recall is purely a precautionary measure, until the manufacturers have addressed MDA's concerns regarding their biological safety assessments."

The MDA said it was pressing European authorities to put breast implants into a higher risk category than at present, so that manufacturers would have to conduct clinical trials in people. David Jefferys, chief executive of the MDA, said the European commission had agreed to a review of the European directives that govern medical devices.

David Sharpe, of the British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons, said hydrogel and soya bean oil implants had been heavily promoted by the cosmetic surgery clinics. "In the rush to get them to market they hadn't really done enough work on the filler. They promoted them as safe enough to eat. So they may be, but you wouldn't put fish and chips under your skin."

The theory behind both types was that a natural substance would do the body no harm if it leaked. Tests later showed that soya bean oil could degrade in the body's tissues and potentially become toxic.

Andrew Hay, managing director of Clover Leaf Products, which distributes the PIP implants in Britain, said he was concerned that the withdrawal would cause women distress. "I'm still a bit mystified," he said. "You're looking at a product that has sold 150,000 worldwide and has a 10-year history, and effectively they're saying it's guilty until proven innocent."

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: PCs jailed for 'beating' resign
fields.body:
PCs jailed for 'beating' resign

Two Bedfordshire police officers resigned yesterday after being jailed for six weeks for a "punishment beating". Steve Watson, 33, and Barry Vardon, 34, had been on remand awaiting an appeal at Luton crown court against their original three month prison sentences for common assault.

Madonna tried for Althorp date

Madonna wrote to Earl Spencer for permission to marry British film director Guy Ritchie at Althorp House, where Diana, Princess of Wales is buried. A spokesman for Althorp said they could not provide the facilities wanted by Madonna who is to marry in Scotland next week.

Ballet blow for 'Billy Elliot'

The ballet hopes of a real-life Billy Elliot took a blow yesterday when the high court ruled that he was not entitled to a discretionary education grant to keep him at a private dance school. Birmingham city council was not under a duty to provide "a Utopian system" to educate Jacob Youngson, 13, "to his maximum potential".

Allergy risk in cosmetics

Ingredients in cosmetics known to cause allergic reactions in some people are not included on labels, Health Which? claims. It also suggests that the way other ingredients are listed can often be confusing.

Christmas card from police

Northamptonshire police yesterday sent Christmas cards asking people who are wanted on warrants to hand themselves in. Inspector Ian Kelly, of Corby police, said: "We wanted to give people a chance to wipe the slate clean."

Go-ahead for Islamic centre

The high court rejected a challenge against a decision to allow an Islamic centre to be built on land owned by Magdalen college. Protesters said the Oxford Centre for Islamic Studies, with a 75ft dome and 108ft tower, would swallow up a green field site near the River Cherwell.

Probation for killing wife
A man who stabbed his wife 16 times with a kitchen knife after going beserk when she spoke about separation was put on probation for three years yesterday on condition he received psychiatric treatment. Brian Trethewey, 51, of St Austell, Cornwall, had pleaded guilty at Truro crown court to the manslaughter of Carol Trethewey, 51, on the grounds of diminished responsibility.

BBC apology to disabled athlete
The BBC yesterday apologised to the disabled athlete Tanni Grey-Thompson after she was unable to collect her third prize in the sports personality of the year award because there was no ramp to get her wheelchair on to the stage. Grey-Thompson won four gold medals in the Sydney Paralympics.

Smile wiped off raider's face
An armed robber dubbed the Laughing Cavalier was yesterday jailed for eight years at Stafford crown court after admitting four raids at banks and building societies. Paul Roberts, 46, a debt-ridden television repair man, from Kingstanding, Birmingham, gave himself up after police issued video footage of him smiling during one of the raids.

Pubs want Scots rule
Whitbread is preparing to ask the Scottish parliament to grant 71 London pubs the status of a sovereign Scottish mini-state to allow drinkers to enjoy the same rights as Scottish drinkers over Christmas. The brewery insists it is making a serious point about differing licensing laws.

Pool winner saves turkeys
Vegetarian Chris Bonner, 25, used part of his £1,000 winnings from a pool tournament in Leeds to buy two turkeys - Paxo and Cranberry - which will live at an animal sanctuary in Evesham, Worcestershire, instead of being Christmas lunch.

webTitle: Letters: Equitable Life: A blight on pensions

fields.headline: A blight on pensions
fields.trailText: I have a with-profits pension with Equitable Life and I have been drawing benefits now for about four years. This pension is an important part of my retirement funding. That retirement is now blighted.
fields.body:
I have a with-profits pension with Equitable Life and I have been drawing benefits now for about four years. This pension is an important part of my retirement funding. That retirement is now blighted (Equitable's life is over, December 9).

When I was sold this scheme, I was not told that there were different classes of policy holder within the fund, that my money could be made available to subsidise the inflated expectations of a minority of policy holders or that their greed could wreck the company. I was not told that I too could have a high guaranteed pension. I had joined a mutual society and expected mutuality of treatment.

If this process of predation by a minority upon the funds of the majority is allowed to continue then insurance companies beware. Who is going to entrust their long-term savings to them? The suspicion that the city slickers will manage to steal it one way or another will be overpowering. And several hundred thousand of us Equitable Life policy holders are going to be very vocal witnesses to this. What price stake holder pensions now?

What has happened is an outrage and the "City" that allowed it to happen has to put it right. For their own sakes.
Philip Thorn
Teignmouth, Devon
ThornSundancer@aol.com

 Mr David Hyman has good reason to feel "immensely sad": the Equitable Life Assurance Society's management may or may not have been incompetent, but his Pyrrhic victory has struck a further blow at mutuality, destroyed an important financial institution, and seriously prejudiced the interests of its members, including Mr Hyman himself.
Desmond Painter
Bournemouth

fields.headline: Copping it
fields.trailText: Glen Smythe (Letters, December 11) made his comments in a live interview on BBC Newsroom South East in response to a report about the CPS decision not to charge police officers involved in the death of Harry Stanley.
fields.body:
Glen Smythe (Letters, December 11) made his comments in a live interview on BBC Newsroom South East in response to a report about the CPS decision not to charge police officers involved in the death of Harry Stanley.

Glen Smythe described "facing an armed robber" as "a pretty exciting episode". Harry Stanley was unarmed. Our concern about shootings by police (25 since 1990), is that police are too often "excited" and fail to adhere to their training and guidelines, with fatal results.
Helen Shaw
Deborah Coles
Inquest

fields.headline: Yes, it's the throne - but not as we know it
fields.trailText: Congratulations on your debate on the monarchy. The only surprise has been the omission of any reference to the crown estates commission, through which the royals claim ownership of the immediate foreshore of any area within the British Isles.
fields.body:
Congratulations on your debate on the monarchy. The only surprise has been the omission of any reference to the crown estates commission, through which the royals claim ownership of the immediate foreshore of any area within the British Isles.

This has tremendous importance for communities like the Western Isles, as could be seen recently in the case of the small village of Locheynort in South Uist, where locals objected to the presence of a fish farm near the entrance to their harbour.

The crown estates, however, acting in its own commercial interests, over-ruled these objections.
Donald S Murray
Lionacleit, Isle of Benbecula
DonSheild@aol.com

 Julian Glover's list of 20 things only the monarch can do (December 6) reminded me of something that apparently the monarch-in-waiting can do.

Proceeding to work on my bicycle one morning a police motorcyclist overtook the traffic, signalling everyone to stop. I obeyed, thinking an ambulance was rushing an accident victim to hospital. Within a few minutes Prince Charles swept by in a limousine. I wonder who decides that a royal engagement takes precedence over people going to work.
Jane Tyler
Bath

 Getting rid of the parasitic Windsor clan is only the first step in what is required to bring the creaking medieval edifice that passes for this country into the new millennium.

As I see it, the shopping list would, as a minimum, consist of a written constitution, an elected second chamber (no Lords) and full regional devolution (with equal legislative and tax-raising powers to all the regional assemblies for England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland), combined with the transformation of Westminster into a federal parliament.
Steve Woods
Bristol
woodsy@theunstoppable.com

 Once again, opponents of the abolition of the monarchy have brought up the red herring of a President Thatcher (Letters, December 7). They should remember that under a democratic electoral system (one man or woman, one single transfer able vote) it is highly unlikely that anyone like Lady Thatcher would be elected president. The Conservatives under her leadership never received an overall majority of the national vote. Even if such a person were elected, he or she would at least possess the legitimacy of an overall majority of popular support.
Simon Fisher
Bradford-on-Avon, Wilts
srfisher@onetel.net.uk

 Following the Guardian's recent assault on the monarchy, was the choice of a photograph of Prince William cleaning around the base of a WC (Will power, December 11) designed to convey a possible new perspective on the place of the throne in our society?
Peter Barnes
Milton Keynes, Bucks
writer2guardian@yahoo.com

In the afternoon she described Jack Straw's u-turn on curfews as "A long overdue climbdown".

fields.headline: Women: another carve-up
fields.trailText: I was delighted when friends telephoned to tell me that part of my sculpture, a commission for the Medway towns representing the past and future of the River Medway, had appeared in your paper.
fields.body:
I was delighted when friends telephoned to tell me that part of my sculpture, a commission for the Medway towns representing the past and future of the River Medway, had appeared in your paper (December 6). For the record I am indeed Sam Holland, Samantha to my family and friends, and female in gender, or so I have always assumed. The Sam does lead to confusion but is useful since, even in the 21st century, male sculptors are often taken more seriously by those who have power in the art world.

This commission has been an exciting and demanding experience which has taken three years to complete. Although I'm sure my clients would have been delighted with the bargain price of £2,500, the finished work cost in excess of £150,000. This was raised by local business and the community at large.

I am a young sculptor (34, since when it's a woman you always like to know the age!). My studio is in the Historic Dockyard in Chatham, Kent and I have indeed worked at St Pauls and other wonderful venues. I am perhaps at my happiest when working on large public works and thank you again for printing the wonderful photograph
Sam Holland
Chatham, Kent

 I thought I was perhaps the only woman on the Public Appointees Register who was not getting any appointments, until I read your interview with Carol Tongue (Cherchez les femmes, December 7).

This government was elected with particular support from women, and an apparent commitment to involving the many in public life, and not the few under the Old Pals' Act we were only too familiar with from previous governments. The Labour government does indeed have prominent women, and all power to their elbows - but a very few are trying to do all the jobs. The political point about women is our sheer numbers. The Labour party also has in its own ranks a high proportion of able and active women. Our face, it now seems, doesn't fit. This relates, of course, to your campaign to challenge the monarchy and the culture of deference which monarchy symbolises and entrenches. Women - know your place! And that's not in public life, don't you know...

London

 I read with interest your article on contraception (Morning after pill to go on sale, December 11), not least for the assumptions contained within. First, it is assumed that contraception is the responsibility of the woman only

Dr Liam Fox appears to think that any female over 16 can be described as a "girl" who cannot make responsible decisions about sexual activity or contraception. The role of "boys" is conveniently forgotten. This is not helpful.

Second, many women who have used the morning after pill will have already made sound attempts to ensure that they do not become pregnant. Thus, many demands for the morning after pill will be the result of accidents such as a spilt condom, not casual, unprotected sex.

Third, the article assumes that any incidence of unprotected sex will result in conception. Many women will in fact not have conceived and the pill will be a precautionary measure only. The pill cannot be described as an "abortion pill".

Finally, it is disappointing that the pill may cost as much as £20, possibly beyond the budget of many of those who do not want to become part of that much-maligned population, the single mother.

webTitle: New lease of life for Battersea Power Station

fields.headline: Battersea revival revolves around a circus
fields.trailText: Battersea Power Station, a Grade I listed dilapidated building on the London skyline, is to become a permanent base for Cirque du Soleil, the award winning Canadian circus.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Battersea Power Station, a Grade I listed dilapidated building on the London skyline, is to become a permanent base for Cirque du Soleil, the award winning Canadian circus.

"We are people of passion and we will find a synergy with people of business," circus founder Guy Laliberte promised. In fact the circus he created in 1984, out of a motley crew of Quebec street entertainers, is already an enormous international industry.

It is based in Montreal but employs over 2,000 people on four continents, including 500 performers. Shows have sold an estimated 23m tickets worldwide and London will be the first permanent base outside North America.

Bread and circuses was a winning formula for the Romans. Developer Victor Hwang is convinced it will work for Battersea, a site haunted by the ghosts of previous schemes.

In 1987 prime minister Margaret Thatcher lit up the front of the building with lasers, and promised that she would be back the next year to open the Edwardian fairground theme park for Tory-sympathising impresario John Broome.

A year later the building was a gutted ruin, with costs spiralling out of control and planning battles raging, including bitter disputes with English Heritage over the treatment of the landmark building.

In the interim, the other listed London giant by architect Sir Giles Gilbert Scott, Bankside power station, was reborn as Tate Modern, and has attracted over 3m visitors in its first eight months.

Battersea, with its unmistakable upended table legs outline, is regarded as the more architecturally striking building.

Parkview, Mr Hwang's Hong Kong-based development company, acquired the Battersea site in south London in 1993, but it has taken until now to acquire planning permission for a complex of offices, shops, hotels, cinemas, restaurants and other leisure facilities, and the 2,000 seater circus space.

Final designs are still being discussed, but the space will be 50 to 70 metres high, to allow the spectacular aerial acts for which Cirque du Soleil is famous.

The company will open a new show, in a traditional circus tent on the site, on Thursday.

The circus will be the creative consultants and licensed jesters for the project. Mr Laliberte envisages business people working out in the gym on circus equipment, and juggling butlers appearing in the hotel with the morning coffee.

Work will take up to five years, but mindful of the history of the site, the two men refused to declare an opening date. "It will open when it is ready," Mr Laliberte said.

"And when we open, we will be here for more than one year," Mr Hwang added, mindful of that other notorious giant circus tent, just a few miles downstream.

fields.headline: Helping the global poor
fields.standfirst:
The government shows the way forward

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Eliminating the scourge of poverty is the greatest challenge facing the planet in the 21st century.
fields.body:
Eliminating the scourge of poverty is the greatest challenge facing the planet in the 21st century. Globalisation is often - and often unfairly - blamed for some of its worst manifestations but, unlike the Nice treaty, globalisation isn't something that Britain can exercise its powers of veto over.

Failing that, the two main weapons open to the UK to tame its excesses are negotiation and leadership by example. On the second of these two criteria, yesterday's white paper, Making Globalisation Work for the Poor, scores very highly. Britain will, unilaterally, stop granting aid to developing countries only when it is tied to buying goods from the donor country.

Tied aid is a very inefficient way of relieving poverty because it prevents recipients from buying the equipment that best suits their needs. It is difficult for one donor to break out of the loop because it could lose out if no other country follows its lead. This is why the government is to be applauded for taking the moral high ground, and doing it unilaterally in the hope that others will follow. The government has also done well to pledge that Britain's assistance to developing countries will increase from around 0.26% of gross domestic product to 0.33% by 2003/2004.

This is still shamefully short of the agreed 0.7% UN target. But, given the even more parsimonious approach of other countries, it is very welcome. Also welcome is the commitment to faster debt relief for heavily indebted countries, a target that Labour and Conservative governments have been been pushing for years.

Apart from these initiatives, the government has little choice but to negotiate with others to manage globalisation and to try to ensure that the ambitious international development targets - including a 50% reduction in the proportion of people living in extreme poverty - are achieved by 2015. The white paper is steeped in the new realism about globalisation - that it is not something that is intrinsically bad for poorer nations but a phenomenon that can be influenced.

Already, globalisation has produced an equal and opposite force in the global alliances of lobbies, linked through the internet, that have proved such a potent counterbalance to the powers of the multinationals. There is a grave danger that the information revolution could widen the already horrendous divide between the very rich and very poor continents like Africa, half of whose people have never even made a phone call let alone accessed the internet.

Faster economic growth, equitably distributed, is the engine that will generate increased wealth and reduce inequalities and education is the biggest long-term generator of economic growth. There is a lot poorer countries can do for themselves - including breaking up monopolies in key areas such as telecommunications, clamping down on corruption and negotiating fair trade agreements with the industrialised west. The biggest single thing the richer nations could do would be to eliminate the unacceptable debt burden of developing countries in exchange for progress in internal reforms such as poverty reduction and education.

Developing countries would be relieved of debt they are unlikely to be able to repay in exchange for a return to prosperity. This would enable them to buy more goods and equipment from the rich countries. Now is an excellent time to inject more purchasing power into developing countries because it would give a boost to the world economy just when the US economy, the engine of recent world growth, is slowing down. Seldom would such an act of enlightened self-interest be more appropriate than it is now.

fields.headline: Wave Bibi bye-bye
fields.standfirst:
This is one comeback that nobody needs
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Chutzpah is Yiddish slang meaning "shameless audacity" or "cheek". Of this commodity, Binyamin Netanyahu is not short.
fields.body:
Chutzpah is Yiddish slang meaning "shameless audacity" or "cheek". Of this commodity, Binyamin Netanyahu is not short. After losing badly to Ehud Barak in the May 1999 general election, Mr Netanyahu flounced off in a snit, peremptorily quit the Likud leadership and parliament, and embarked on a reportedly lucrative career as a consultant and overseas lecturer.

Now, with Mr Barak on the ropes, Bibi pops up at the airport, proclaims himself the country's saviour, and demands that Israel change its laws and rejig its elections - all just to allow him to stand again for the prime ministership. What swagger! What swank!

For three years, Mr Netanyahu distinguished himself as probably Israel's least distinguished prime minister ever. For three years, he never missed an opportunity to miss an opportunity for peace - with the Palestinians or anybody else. He alienated Israel's friends, enraged its enemies and divided his countrymen. His toxic legacy still influences the present day climate of sporadic violence, hate and stalled negotiations. It was in order to overcome it that Mr Barak was elected.

Even after his defeat, Mr Netanyahu and his wife were pursued by corruption investigations that eventually led the attorney-general to conclude that his conduct was not what might be expected of a high public official. Perhaps the only benefit of a Bibi comeback would be the ending of Ariel Sharon's leadership of the Likud. But what a price to pay. With the Middle East at crisis point, and Israel as usual its vortex, Mr Netanyahu is not the cavalry; he offers not rescue, only rancour redoubled.

According to the opinion polls, many Jewish voters disagree, giving him a margin of 15-20% over Mr Barak. This is no surprise. Picking the hard man is the easy option for that large section of the Israeli population which doggedly refuses to face up to the core issue - the need to address and correct the injustices done to the Palestinian people.

Until Israel forsakes its state of denial and accepts the need for fundamental compromises, there can be no lasting settlement. Mr Barak has made mistakes a-plenty. But his instincts for peace are sound. In resigning and seeking a new, personal mandate, he acts honourably and courageously and challenges every Israeli to do likewise. If the bombastic Bibi's hopes of instant resurrection are dished along the way, that's a bonus. He can always do a lecture tour.

webTitle: Half of German MPs have hearing problem

fields.headline: Half of German MPs have hearing problem
fields.trailText: We have known for years that politicians don't listen. Now, thanks to tests carried out in the German parliament, we know why: they can't hear - at least not properly.
fields.body:
We have known for years that politicians don't listen. Now, thanks to tests carried out in the German parliament, we know why: they can't hear - at least not properly.

Researchers who tested the hearing of 127 German MPs found that, whether because of the hours spent alongside megaphones on the hustings, or because of some previously unsuspected link between partial deafness and overarching ambition, 42% were aurally challenged.

Among MPs over the age of 40, the problem was especially worrying, the researchers said.

It was the second time in a few weeks that the German voting public has been given cause to worry about its MPs.

Last month, a current affairs programme reported that its researchers had found extensive traces of cocaine in lavatories throughout the Reichstag in Berlin, the home of Germany's lower house.

fields.headline: Nice enough
fields.standfirst:
But Blair could have done even more

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Tony Blair got what he wanted - right down to the predictable headlines about a Nice One in Nice.
fields.body:
Tony Blair got what he wanted - right down to the predictable headlines about a Nice One in Nice. He played the European summit like a politician and got a politician's rewards. He came home able to boast of victories, having got the most for Britain "out of Europe".

He even managed to perform that rarest of tricks for a Labour prime minister: using Europe as a weapon with which to beat the Conservatives in the Commons. All in all, a good weekend's work.

The victories were clear enough. Labour waved goodbye to the national veto in some 23 areas, but held onto it in the two "red line" matters of tax and social security. Any loss of a British veto on those twin issues would have certainly unleashed an onslaught on Mr Blair from the Tory front bench and, more frightening from his point of view, the Eurosceptic press.

Mr Blair and Robin Cook could also claim victory on the new rapid reaction force for Europe, ensuring the final treaty contained British-inspired language designed to make such a force compatible with, rather than undermining of, Nato. Lastly, he was able to leave Nice bragging that he was the first PM actually to have increased Britain's voting strength in European councils.

All smiles in London then? Not completely. For though Mr Blair has seen off a rightwing backlash in the run-up to an election, perhaps neutralising Europe as an issue in the coming campaign, some Labour supporters may feel a tad disappointed. Mr Blair promised to do more than simply fight Britain's corner, deploying the old Thatcherite language of victory and defeat in which "Europe" is a cunning, foreign enemy to be outwitted.

The PM once promised to lead in Europe, and that would have meant a quite different tone in Nice: less obsessed with Britain's narrow interest, more concerned with the larger European future. Mr Blair cannot be blamed for being a politician - but nor should we apologise for daring to hope for something better.

fields.headline: Minister attacks US missile project
fields.trailText: A huge debate is under way within the Foreign Office and the Ministry of Defence over American plans for a national missile defence system.
fields.body:
A huge debate is under way within the Foreign Office and the Ministry of Defence over American plans for a national missile defence system.

Foreign Office minister Peter Hain has submitted a strongly worded memo to the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, expressing outright opposition to the NMD programme.

"He has gone back to his CND days," said one of Mr Hain's supporter inside government, pleased to see him go back to his roots. The minister, unlike many other Labour colleagues, has retained his membership of the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament.

Mr Cook, who is more cautious and will be reluctant to end up at odds with Downing Street, has yet to reply.

At the MoD, the government's top military advisers have also privately expressed serious concern about the American plan.

The US president, Bill Clinton, is leaving to his successor the decision on whether to go ahead with the controversial £20bn missile programme intended to protect America from countries it regards as maverick, such as North Korea, Iraq, Iran and Libya.

During his election campaign, George W Bush pledged to deploy the missile system as soon as possible. While also in favour of the NMD system, his Democrat rival, Al Gore, was keen to wait until the technology had proved itself.

Mr Hain, in an echo of his younger days as a left-wing campaigner, argued in the minute that British participation in the missile programme risked a rerun of the Greenham Common demonstrations against Cruise missiles throughout the 1980s.

As part of the programme, the US wants to upgrade the early-warning system at Fylingdales on the Yorkshire moors. In the second stage of the project, it wants to build a 14-storey radar station, a project that could provide the focus for demonstrations.

Mr Hain is reflecting a feeling within the Foreign Office that the scale of the building has not yet been realised and that, as well as attracting peace campaigners, the site will become a hot issue at local level, with those living in the area likely to lodge objections.

Mr Hain is also concerned about the technological effectiveness of the missile umbrella: NMD tests so far have ended in failure.

On the bigger stage, the Foreign Office is more sceptical than Washington about dangers posed by the countries once labelled by the US as "rogue" states but now described as "states of concern". Unlike the US, Britain does not want to treat them as pariah states. It has re-established diplomatic relations with Iran and Libya and is looking at re-opening an embassy in North Korea.

Furthermore, the £20bn system would, in practice, be put in place for protection against one state, Iraq, and therefore the scale of the project is regarded as over the top.

If the US pushes ahead, it risks damaging relations with Russia and China, which are both opposed to NMD. France and Germany also object to the system.

A Foreign Office spokesman yesterday stuck to the official line: that it was too premature for Britain to take a stance.

He said: "We do not expect the US to site elements of NMD in the UK before next year and even that will depend on decisions taken by the next US administration."

He added that Britain welcomed the US commitment to consult widely before reaching a conclusion.

But scepticism about the system was expressed by a senior military source who said: "It will be very expensive and the question remains about whether it will work."

MoD officials admit that the issue is extraordinarily sensitive, at home and abroad.

"We've always shared risks," said a senior British military adviser, echoing concerns expressed by other European allies about the security implications of the US project for transatlantic relations. "The US has not thought it through," the source added.

Russia is also maintaining a strong line against NMD. The American programme would mean amending or abandoning the 1972 anti-ballistic missiles treaty, which Moscow insists is a cornerstone of international nuclear stability.

Igor Sergeyev, the Russian defence minister, raised the issue in talks with Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, in London last week.

Furthermore, the £20bn system would, in practice, be put in place for protection against one state, Iraq, and therefore the scale of the project is regarded as over the top. If the US pushes ahead, it risks damaging relations with Russia and China, which are both opposed to NMD. France and Germany also object to the system. A Foreign Office spokesman yesterday stuck to the official line: that it was too premature for Britain to take a stance. He said: "We do not expect the US to site elements of NMD in the UK before next year and even that will depend on decisions taken by the next US administration." He added that Britain welcomed the US commitment to consult widely before reaching a conclusion. But scepticism about the system was expressed by a senior military source who said: "It will be very expensive and the question remains about whether it will work." MoD officials admit that the issue is extraordinarily sensitive, at home and abroad. "We've always shared risks," said a senior British military adviser, echoing concerns expressed by other European allies about the security implications of the US project for transatlantic relations. "The US has not thought it through," the source added. Russia is also maintaining a strong line against NMD. The American programme would mean amending or abandoning the 1972 anti-ballistic missiles treaty, which Moscow insists is a cornerstone of international nuclear stability. Igor Sergeyev, the Russian defence minister, raised the issue in talks with Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, in London last week. fields.headline: Vlado Gotovac
fields.standfirst: Lifelong fighter for liberalism and democracy in Croatia
fields.trailText: Lifelong fighter for liberalism and democracy in Croatia
fields.body:
Vlado Gotovac, the father of modern Croatian liberalism and a tireless fighter for an independent, democratic, anti-nationalist Croatia, has died of liver cancer, aged 70.

A seminal figure, he was jailed by the Tito regime and marginalised by the nationalism and bloodshed that followed the collapse of communism in Yugoslavia. But his last year saw a glorious vindication of his life's work, with protégés and colleagues taking power in Zagreb and embarking on a radical reversal of a decade of the corruption, bigotry and despotism of the late President Franjo Tudjman.

Contemporaries and rivals, Gotovac and Tudjman represented the two poles of modern Croatian politics. They both came of age politically in the Croatian Spring of the late 1960s, when an intoxicating revival of culture, arts and politics was snuffed out by Tito. Both were jailed by the communists.

But by 1989, with communism collapsing and Yugoslavia disintegrating, Tudjman formed his nationalist Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ), while Gotovac founded the Croatian Social Liberal Union (HSLS), which is now in coalition government with the social democrats of Prime Minister Ivica Racan.

A warm and inspirational man, Gotovac was a workaholic - a poet, essayist, broadcaster, journalist, party leader, MP and presidential candidate. He was one of the finest public speakers in Croatia, but as party and opposition leader, his lack of organisational flair was his biggest weakness.

He was born in the dirt-poor mountain town of Imotski, in the Dalmatian hinterland. His father, a policeman in prewar royal Yugoslavia, was jailed for three years by the communists at the end of the second world war; his wife joined him in prison. In the 1950s, Gotovac studied philosophy and Italian in Zagreb, but, in 1972, he too was incarcerated in the same jail at Stara Gradiska after leading the Matica Hrvatska, the Croatian cultural organisation that was one of the engines of the Croatian Spring.

Released in 1974, he resumed his political activism, and was jailed again in 1977 after giving an interview to Swedish television which upset the Belgrade regime. During this second stint of imprisonment, he contracted hepatitis B, which is believed to have contributed to his death in a clinic in Rome, where his second wife works as a heart surgeon.

By the 1990s, Gotovac had become a father figure to a younger generation of Zagreb democrats and intellectuals, who likened his role in Croatia to that of Vaclav Havel in Prague or Adam Michnik in Warsaw.

On a rainy Zagreb evening in the summer of 1991, as Slobodan Milosevic's paramilitaries and the Yugoslav army launched their land grab in Yugoslavia, Gotovac transfixed a large crowd outside the Yugoslav military headquarters with an emotional address that was one of his finest moments. Hundreds wept openly as he provided a moral compass, just as ethnic cleansing and pogroms were being instigated.

"I love you," he told the crowd. "And if I have to choose between dying with you and living with the terrorist generals, I choose death. If we don't have weapons, we still have the power of our love, the power of our dignity, the power of our readiness to die if we can't live as human beings."

In 1997, Gotovac and Tudjman squared off in the race for the presidency, which Tudjman won comfortably, though not before one of his bodyguards had made an abortive assassination attempt on Gotovac while he was campaigning in the port of Pula.

Endless infighting among the opposition saw Gotovac quit the party he founded after a row with its leader, Drazen Budisa, in 1998. He established the smaller LS, or liberal party. He was an LS MP when he died. After his first wife, Vlasta, died, he married Simona Sandric in 1993. He leaves a daughter, Ana, from his first marriage.

webTitle: Rebels capture key city in Congo

fields.headline: Rebels capture key city in Congo
fields.trailText: Zimbabwean troops fighting in the Congo war have fled the strategic town of Pweto, which has fallen to the Rwandan-backed rebels, the Zimbabwean government confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
Zimbabwean troops fighting in the Congo war have fled the strategic town of Pweto, which has fallen to the Rwandan-backed rebels, the Zimbabwean government confirmed yesterday.

A contingent of 1,200 Zimbabwean and Congolese troops was pushed back across the border into Zambia, where they were disarmed and put into a refugee camp. The Zambians have asked Harare to take custody of its soldiers.

The Zimbabwean government called the fall of Pweto "regrettable" but added that the retreat of its troops was merely to avoid any breach of the ceasefire agreement signed in Harare last week.

More than 60,000 Congolese civilians have fled the fighting around Pweto and are currently in Zambia, according to UN estimates.

Fierce fighting has raged around Pweto, on Lake Mweru in south-eastern Congo, where a Zimbabwean MiG fighter jet was reportedly shot down by the rebels.

The fall of Pweto is a serious blow to the Zimbabwean forces backing the Congolese president, Laurent Kabila. It is on the main road to Lumbumbashi, the southern city that is the headquarters for the 12,000 Zimbabwean troops in Congo.

Zimbabwean and Congolese troops are now fortifying Kasenga, the only major town between Pweto and Lumbumbashi. The new campaign by the rebels of the Congolese Rally for Democracy and their Rwandan backers is pressing into territory that had been considered firmly controlled by the Zimbabwean and Congolese government forces.

Lumbumbashi, Congo's second largest city and the capital of Katanga province, is near Mr Kabila's home and the centre of his support. It would be a devastating blow to the president and his Zimbabwean allies if Lumbumbashi were to come under siege by the rebels.

Harare provides little information about its involvement in the distant and unpopular Congo war, more than 620 miles to the north. The high cost of the war has been blamed for the drastic decline in Zimbabwe's economy.

fields.headline: Fiona Macpherson
fields.standfirst: Gifted magazine editor in an age of changing fashions
fields.trailText: Gifted magazine editor in an age of changing fashions
fields.body:
It may seem a huge leap from the Dundee headquarters of the Beano comic to the international glamour circuit, but in the world of glossy magazines anything is possible, and it was a move that Fiona Macpherson, who has died aged 60, took in her stride.

Macpherson, who was editor of the upmarket Harper's and Queen for the past six years, began her career with the publishing house DC Thomson, in Dundee. It was the late 1950s, a period when the stirrings of what would become the teen market prompted the earliest magazines aimed specifically at under-18 girls.

Macpherson worked for one of those initial successes, Diana, as a sub-editor. She was also an early agony aunt, and wrote the odd piece of fiction for Diana's pages. A decade later, she would be in the shiny London offices of National Magazines, putting together pages on high fashion and high society.

Macpherson was born in London, but her family moved to Inverness when she was five. From her Vogue-reading household, she attended the Inverness Royal Academy, then read English and modern history at St Andrews University and took a post-graduate course at Edinburgh University before starting at Thomson's.

In 1963, she joined Woman's Own in London. Two years later, she became sub-editor, and then arts editor, on the glossy Queen magazine, under the editorship of Jocelyn Stevens. In 1970, Queen was taken over by Harper's, the offshoot of America's east coast Harper's Bazaar; Macpherson became deputy editor of the newly amalgamated titles.

In 1993, after a 17-year break to have a family and freelance, she was brought back to Harper's as editor by the management of National Magazines, who admired her style, her strength in the features field, and her encouragement of new writers, photographers and illustrators. It was, for example, Macpherson who convinced Patric Walker to become a magazine astrologer. She was particularly good at getting a different angle on profiles of the famous - the current Christmas issue, for instance, has Nanette Newman writing personal recollections of Katharine Hepburn.

Colleagues recalled that Macpherson handled herself in a self-contained manner, although she could be acerbic and also charming. A very private person, she was aware that the world Harper's reflected was dangerously seductive, and she avoided getting too drawn in. When attending fashion shows abroad, she would immediately exchange her catwalk seat for a bike, and career around the streets with fellow journalists; out-of-hours party invitations would be turned down in favour of the early-evening train to Bath and a comforting supper of shepherd's pie and peas with her family.

Despite the shift the magazine made towards a younger audience under Macpherson's editorship, some things remained sacrosanct: summer was still "the end of the party season", readers could still thrill to the temptation of nipping off for jewellery to Geneva or New York. And Jennifer's Diary continued its quaint custom of describing partygoers who were not "right honourable", with the prefix Miss, Mr or Mrs.

Just as she had hidden her first pregnancy from colleagues in the 1970s, so Macpherson hid the fact that she had a terminal illness. She wanted, she said, to die "in harness", and worked editing the January edition of the magazine until the last moment.

She leaves her husband Adrian Bailey, a daughter and a son.

Fiona Mary Macpherson, magazine editor, born September 2, 1940; died November 28 2000

fields.headline: Unicef redraws the battle lines
fields.standfirst: Lack of cash hampers efforts to aid child refugees
fields.trailText: Lack of cash hampers efforts to aid child refugees
fields.body:
Six-year-old Isidor huddles against his brother Melchior, eight, so tightly that he has one leg in Melchior's lap. He has refused to speak to anyone else since March, when the two boys fled into Tanzania after watching their parents die in Burundi's civil war.

Such stories are common among the 500,000 refugees from wars in Burundi, Rwanda and Congo who are camped along Tanzania's western border - and among refugees elsewhere in the world, be they in Eritrea or East Timor.

This year's Unicef report, The State of the World's Children 2001, which is published today, is not an easy read: 20m children have been displaced by conflict; more than 10m have been orphaned by Aids; and 11m under-fives have been killed by preventable diseases.

The 2000 report is dedicated to the early child development projects (ECDs) that cover children's formative first three years.

In western Tanzania's camps, there are already signs that ECDs are making headway. Thanks to Unicef's high-protein supplements for pregnant and breast-feeding women, the mortality rate among under-fives in the camps is down to one in 1,000, compared to 185 in 1,000 in nearby villages.

Hamukiza Gaudence, 18, is one such beneficiary. A Burundian Hutu, she fled her village when it was attacked by Tutsi government troops, her newborn child in her arms. When she arrived at Karago camp, home to 47,000 people, she had not eaten for three days. Unicef fed mother and child back to health.

Although Ms Gaudence's problems are not over - her husband is missing and she fears she will never return home - these dire circumstances have at least given her child access to healthcare.

Unicef is promoting ECD programmes as the most cost-effective aid available and is urging donor nations to shift their contributions to reflect Unicef's priority. For every $1 spent on early childhood care, there is a $7 return through cost savings later, its report claims. However, this may say as much about the agency's inability to alleviate present suffering as it does about its future planning.

More than six years after the Burundian genocide began, Unicef's Tanzania emergency programme this year received only two-thirds of the $7m it needs to meet the basic needs of refugee children.

"It's very unfortunate that funding depends so much on publicity," says Bjorn Ljungqvist, a Unicef representative in Tanzania. "When a woman gives birth in a tree in Mozambique, you get twice the money you need. But everybody forgets about the half-a-million refugees in Tanzania."

The shortfall hurts children such as Isidor. Terrified of everyone but his brother, he lives in a rickety lean-to that the boys built themselves. Melchior says he can cook and clean for them both but they are filthy, frightened little boys; one flinching, the other darting under a stool whenever an adult steps close.

Before an art class for traumatised children was started by Unicef's child protection coordinator at Karago, Jasna Balasko, there was no special provision for such boys. And with construction halted on two of the camp's six schools after the UN budget was cut, no extra provision seem likely.

But the benefits of Ms Balasko's efforts are clear. After three classes, Isidor now tolerates her questions about his drawings, although he answers through his brother.

"I like this class very much," says Melchior, speaking for Isidor. "When I am drawing I feel well."

One three-year-old girl is less receptive. Screaming in panic, she still refuses to enter the classroom. Ms Balasko knows nothing about her except that she was found alone in a burnt-out Burundi village.

Such children are not the only ones affected by the aid squeeze. Unicef sought to enrol all three- to six-year-old refugees in a pre-school training programme, to give respite to camp-weary parents. But a shortage of pens and paper has restricted lessons to the over-fives.

The week after the fortnightly food ration is doled out, there is a 100% turnout for the programme, says John Baptist Habimana, supervisor of non-formal education at Karago. But in the second week, the children drop out because they are hungry. This is what Mr Ljungqvist calls "the revolving wheel of shortage".

"Every agency is suffering cutbacks," he says. "And if the UN World Food Programme can't feed people, Unicef has to deal with child malnutrition and school drop-outs."

Under such constraints, there is no place for special cases. Ms Balasko describes an interview with a wounded 15-year-old who fought alongside Burundi's Hutu rebels. Ms Balasko hoped to enrol the boy in a reconciliation class that she tries to run at least every month. But before the next class, he disappeared, probably back to his unit.

The soldier, Isidor, Melchior and the others are all victims of Burundi's war. Unfortunately, Unicef does not have equal resources for them all.

webTitle: Water is missing in the middle of the sea

fields.headline: Water is missing in the middle of the sea
fields.trailText: A Norwegian company has begun an air and sea search for water in an area where there is nothing but water: the Mediterranean sea.
fields.body:
A Norwegian company has begun an air and sea search for water in an area where there is nothing but water: the Mediterranean sea.

But the missing water is special. It is fresh and was held in a giant bag developed to transport water to dry areas, Nordic Water Supply said yesterday.

The bag, filled with about 20m litres (about 5m gallons) of fresh water, broke free of the tugboat that was towing it to Cyprus.

The ship lost the water about five miles off Cyprus on Saturday. "The company is investigating the cause of the accident," a brief statement from Nordic Water Supply said, adding that the search for the missing bag was continuing.

The Oslo-based company developed its floating water bag in the mid-1990s and now uses it to supply fresh water in operations in many parts of the world.

The statement said that the bag was fully insured and could be quickly replaced so that supplies could be resumed.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Publisher fined over Hitler book
fields.body:
Publisher fined over Hitler book

The publisher of a Czech-language version of Hitler's Mein Kampf was given a three-year suspended sentence and a £35,000 fine by a Czech court yesterday for propagating racism.

Michal Zitko, who sold out an initial print run of 10,000 copies of the book, will appeal, his lawyer said.
Reuters, Prague

Wife 'killed for standing in poll'

A woman nominated to run in local elections in Pakistan was stabbed to death by her husband who objected to her candidacy, police said yesterday.

It is alleged that Nazia Mumtaz was killed by Munir Mumtaz on Friday after she refused to withdraw her nomination for local office in Bhalwal, 70 miles north-west of Lahore.

fields.headline: Ralph Bates
fields.standfirst: Writer who kept his devotion to republican Spain alive in his novels
fields.trailText: Writer who kept his devotion to republican Spain alive in his novels
fields.body:
Ralph Bates, who has died in New York, aged 101, was the oldest survivor of that legendary group of British writers who gave their energies, their writings, and - in some cases - their lives to the cause of the Spanish republic in its doomed fight against fascism in the 1930s.

At some point in the 15 years before the Spanish civil war broke out in 1937, he was a communist trade union agitator and organiser in the docks and fishing industries of Catalonia, where he became a fluent speaker of Spanish and Catalan. His knowledge of Spanish working-class and peasant life would turn him into one of the Comintern's best experts on Spain; it also gave his Spanish stories and novels their extraordinarily intimate power in realistic description.

Bates resigned from the Communist party when the cynical Stalin-Hitler pact was signed in 1939. In 1941, he settled in New York and wrote to urge the US's entry into the second world war. From 1948 to 1968, he taught creative writing and other literary topics at New York University. Like so many Spanish war returnees, he came to the baleful attention of the House UnAmerican Activities Committee. He refused to testify.

Bates was born into a family of railway engineers in Swindon, Wiltshire. Family stories about a seafaring great-grandfather, who captained his own trampsteamer around the Mediterranean and was buried in Cadiz, fuelled his boyhood dreams of adventure and Spain.

A musical child, he played the organ in local churches. He left school at a then normal early age, was apprenticed in the railway workshops, and served his time as a fitter, turner and erector. Aged 17, he volunteered for first world war service, and, after failing to get into the Royal Flying Corps (seemingly on medical grounds), served as an infantryman in the 16th Queen's Royal West Surreys, achieving the rank of lance corporal.

Demobilised, he returned to the Swindon railway works, where he started to be drawn into Labour politics. By 1923 he had joined the Communist party. But the childhood lure of further places was strong, and he was soon off to Paris, where he had a job as a street-cleaner. Then he worked his passage on a ship to Spain, where he bummed around, surviving on odd jobs. He also got to see his great-grandfather's grave.

Bates was a man of fabled energy - organising unions, swimming and climbing. The Spaniards dubbed him El fantastico . But he needed money, and that, he said later, was what drove him to take up writing. He was in touch with literary comrades and friends in London - indeed, he seems to have travelled back and forth quite a bit between Spain and London - and it was London publishers who took him up.

His first novel, Sierra (1933), went straight to the scenes and doings he knew at first-hand - the anxieties of a Spain oppressed in the agitated period before the civil war broke out in July 1937, by brutal policing, a bloodthirsty Roman church, and the utter harshness of the Spanish earth itself. The novel ends, characteristically, with civil guards gunning down a demonstration of republicans.

This was apprentice stuff, certainly, but Bates was speedily batting himself in as a fine, revolutionary realist. Quickly, he went on to produce two undoubted classics of uprising Spain: Lean Men (1934), about an English communist agitator - evidently based upon himself - up against an overwhelmingly cruel and powerful state, and The Olive Field (1936), a strong story of yet more unsuccessful revolutionary struggles, but with the emphasis much more on mere work, in this case life among the cultivators of olive trees.

The Olive Field will last. It stands out among the "proletarian" fiction of the 1930s as a revelatory and sympathetic inside story of people making a living at the jagged edges of survival. Rainbow Fish: Four Short Novels (1937), set widely across Europe, is far more ordinary; the shock mixture of Spanish violence, cruelty and utopian aspiration is clearly what Bates's imagination needed to thrive on.

When the civil war erupted, he was straightaway thrown into the heat of things. Well acquainted with the Pyrenees, he guided incoming volunteers across the passes and took part in fighting with the militias. He was quickly made a commissar in the International Brigades, edited their English-language paper, Volunteer For Liberty, and wrote propaganda pieces about the war for London journals, such as Left Review. Winifred, his first wife, worked as a nurse.

In 1937, Bates was sent by the Communist party to the United States to drum up financial support and attract more volunteers. There were huge rallies in venues such as Madison Square Gardens, and he became a darling of the American left. At one such meeting he met Eve Haxman, whom he married in 1942, following his divorce from Winifred.

When the Spanish republic collapsed at the beginning of 1939, Bates retreated to Mexico. His novel, The Fields Of Paradise (1941), is set there; but even though this story of civil conflict reads like a transposition of Spanish events to the New World, it lacks the Spanish force that energises Bates's fiction at its best.

In The Miraculous Horde, the collection issued in the autumn of 1939, the Spanish stories - about early-1930s trades union struggles, and famous battles involving the International Brigades, on the Jarama, at Brunete, in Aragon - are so much better than the Mexican ones. No one surpassed Bates for nice ironies about the mixed human material in the republican militias, or for movingly melancholic reflections on a struggle about which its participants felt increasingly pessimistic.

In one of his best Spanish pieces, Compañero Sagasta Burns A Church, published in Left Review in October 1936, Bates pays understanding tribute to the Spanish anarchist's need to calmly burn out the signs and symbols of religious oppression; he was very ready to go along with what WH Auden called "the necessary murder" in a revolutionary cause. But he also dwells compellingly on the fatalism of anarchists - the belief that, at bottom, anarchism, "noble, just and beautiful", is "unrealisable" and therefore doomed.

When he wrote this, Bates's line was that, by contrast, communism was not only noble but also realisable. Soon though, he was, like so many Spain veterans, thinking otherwise. It sounds as if he was helped to his disillusionment with politics by the dawning realisation that it was perverse, communist-led infighting, of the kind he was closely involved in, that had helped lose the war. (In Homage To Catalonia, George Orwell singles out Bates for mongering untruths about the "Trotskyite cowardice and collaborationism" of men Orwell knew had died fighting the fascists.)

After his experience with the House UnAmerican Activities Committee, Bates continued for a while to write. There were no successors in the biography line to his rather successful Life Of Schubert (1934), but he did try again with novels. His last published one, The Dolphin In The Wood (1950), manifestly a version of his own early years, ends with its hero travelling to the Spain he had always dreamed of living in. This sounds as if it may have had a projected sequel, but no successor came.

For the last 30 or so years, Bates and his wife divided their time between Manhattan and the Greek island of Naxos, which became the sort of pastoral dreamplace that neither Spain, nor communism, had succeeded in supplying him with in any permanent fashion. He leaves an unpublished book about the island, as well as a recently completed collection of poems written there. He is survived by Eve and their son.

Ralph Bates, writer, born November 3 1899; died November 26 2000
