webTitle: Japan's scandal-hit PM in photo mystery

fields.headline: Japan's scandal-hit PM in photo mystery
fields.trailText: Japan's unpopular prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, suffered a new setback yesterday with the publication of photographs that allegedly show him sharing a cosy drink with an alleged rightwing extremist and convicted murderer.
fields.body:
Japan's unpopular prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, suffered a new setback yesterday with the publication of photographs that allegedly show him sharing a cosy drink with an alleged rightwing extremist and convicted murderer.

Coming just weeks after Mr Mori scraped through a no-confidence vote in parliament, the pictures put fresh pressure on the gaffe-prone leader to stand down. They also raise questions about the tactics of Japanese tabloids.

The two black-and-white photographs appeared in the Weekly Gendai magazine, published yesterday.

The magazine says the first shot shows a beaming Mr Mori posing with the leader of a violent rightwing group during a party at an Osaka restaurant two years ago.

In the second picture, reportedly taken at an intimate bar, the man rests his hand with apparent familiarity on Mr Mori's shoulder. Gendai says the pictures were taken after a fundraising event in October 1998, when Mr Mori was secretary general of the ruling Liberal Democratic party (LDP).

The magazine describes the man with Mr Mori as a well-known rightwinger with links to the Japanese gangsters, known as yakuza . It claims he served several long prison sentences for murder and attempted murder.

But Gendai does not give his name and he is referred to only as "Mr A". His face is deliberately obscured by a computer-generated mosaic. The magazine said the disguise was necessary to protect the man's privacy.

Given such restrictions, the exposé raises more questions than it answers, but Gendai said it was up to the prime minister to clarify his relationship with the man.

Mr Mori has responded by suing the magazine, denying any knowledge of the man's identity. "This involves the prime minister's personal honour," said Yasuo Fukuda, a government spokesman.

Weekly magazines in Japan often break important stories that the staid broadsheets are reluctant to touch, but their methods are controversial.

It is not the first time that Mr Mori has been linked to mobsters and extremists. In May he admitted giving a speech at a wedding attended by the head of a major crime syndicate, though he said he did not know who would be on the guest list.

Last month his right-hand man, Hidenao Nakagawa, was forced to resign as chief cabinet secretary amid claims of drug use and alleged ties with an ultra-nationalist group.

Such scandals and a prolonged succession of gaffes have made Mr Mori one of the most loathed prime ministers in Japanese history.

He was almost deposed last month by a rebellion in his party, but he managed to cling to power, thanks mainly to the support of heavyweight LDP politicians.

The latest sign of his weakness came last week when he appointed two former prime ministers - Kiichi Miyazawa and Ryutaro Hashimoto - and a handful of potential rivals to his cabinet, over which he will find it hard to exert leadership.

Until yesterday the reshuffle appeared to have halted the slide in his popularity. In the latest poll by the broadcaster NHK, Mr Mori's approval rating has risen to 22% from 17% the previous month. This latest scandal threatens to send him back under 20%, which is considered the make-or-break mark.

LDP powerbrokers are said to be plotting a way to remove Mr Mori before he further damages its chances in this summer's upper house elections.

His position seems weaker than that of the alleged rightwinger in the photographs. It has been claimed that Gendai's protection of the man's identity suggests that taking on Mr Mori is less frightening than taking on the mob.

fields.headline: Writer's farewell
fields.standfirst: Chinese internet diarist dies
fields.trailText: A Chinese cancer patient who published a diary about his last months and provoked a national debate died in Shanghai yesterday.
fields.body:
A Chinese cancer patient who published a diary about his last months and provoked a national debate died in Shanghai yesterday.

Lu Youqing's death from cancer was announced by the literary website Rongshu.com where extracts from his journal, which became known as the "Diary of Death", appeared until he was too ill to continue. "This [my diary] is like a conversation between illness and life over a fragrant cup of afternoon tea," he wrote.

In a country unused to confessional literature, Lu's candour upset readers who felt death must be treated with the traditional reticence. But others applauded his courage and sent messages of support to him and his family.

Yesterday, grieving fans were posting messages on Rongshu's bulletin board. One praised Lu's commitment to life even as he was dying: "If a person lives with real emotion, then there should be no regret at death."

The 37-year-old Lu, a journalist turned businessman, had developed a tumour on his neck. He began writing in August when he heard that he only had three months to live. He charted his decline, often with a touch of humour.

"Life when you are sick tastes bitter, but there is also some fun,"he wrote. The advantages included not needing to dress properly and "never worrying whether the battery will run out of your mobile".

Last month the full text of Lu's diary was published in book form, with more than 100,000 copies distributed in Shanghai alone.

Lu's wife Shi Muyan, who published bulletins when her husband was too ill, was distressed to learn that a pirated edition appeared instantly. "I dare not tell Lu," she said. "The news would break his heart."

Lu said that his book was intended as a memorial - and also as a way of earning income for his wife and daughter when he could no longer provide for them.

He stopped taking medication for the tumour earlier this year, and was critical of the inadequate provision for cancer patients in the Chinese medical system such as the need to bribe doctors in order to get proper treatment.

webTitle: Fugitive Fujimori finds sanctuary in dual nationality

fields.headline: Fugitive Fujimori finds sanctuary in dual nationality
fields.trailText: Alberto Fujimori may have been president of Peru for 10 years, but it will be confirmed this week that he is, and always has been, Japanese.
fields.body:
Alberto Fujimori may have been president of Peru for 10 years, but it will be confirmed this week that he is, and always has been, Japanese.

The Japanese government has concluded that Mr Fujimori, who fled to Tokyo last month to escape corruption charges in Peru, never revoked his citizenship.

The decision is expected to enrage Peruvians, who voted Mr Fujimori into office three times in the belief that he was a fellow citizen.

It is also likely to open a legal can of worms. Peru's constitution says only a national of the country can hold the country's highest elected post and Japan refuses to recognise dual nationality for adults.

Mr Fujimori made an unscheduled stopover in Japan on November 17, shortly after his political opponents took control of the Peruvian congress in his absence. He has since resigned and made it clear that he wants to stay in Japan indefinitely.

His request has thrown Japanese officials into a panic. Though Tokyo has always had close relations with Mr Fujimori, it has a policy of refusing requests for political asylum.

It is also difficult for the Japanese government to turn a blind eye to the fact that Mr Fujimori adopted a second nationality.

According to reports in the Japanese media yesterday, officials have decided that Mr Fujimori never revoked his citizenship, to which he is entitled because his name is listed on a family register in Kumamoto, south-west Japan. An announcement on the issue is expected as early as today.

Mr Fujimori's parents were born in Japan and emigrated to Peru in 1934. While he was in office, Mr Fujimori denied speculation that he retained Japanese citizenship, though he kept close ties with the country and his son lives there.

The Peruvian authorities want to question Mr Fujimori about his relationship with his former spymaster Vladimiro Montesinos, who is at the centre of a money-laundering, drug-dealing and bribery scandal.

As a Japanese national, Mr Fujimori would not have to fear extradition, but human rights groups say he should still answer the charges against him.

"We have documented numerous human rights violations in Peru under Fujimori, including extra-judicial execution," said Pierre Sane, secretary general of Amnesty International. "Even if Fujimori has citizenship, Japan should try him for crimes committed in other countries. It is a case that could make history for international justice."

webTitle: Ultrasound ban to tackle boy baby bias

fields.headline: Ultrasound ban to tackle boy baby bias
fields.standfirst: Beijing takes action as desire for sons pushes sexes out of balance
fields.trailText: Beijing takes action as desire for sons pushes sexes out of balance
fields.body:
Parts of China are taking action to stop parents from choosing the sex of their children after the publication of alarming figures which suggest that far more boys than girls are being born.

A new regulation in Anhui province, banning the use of ultrasound scanners to determine the gender of foetuses, has been given national publicity after a survey from the region, reported by the official New China News Agency, revealed that "an unbalanced proportion [of boys]" had been born over the last six years.

Figures for mothers giving birth to a second child showed that three boys were being born for every girl. This discrepancy is attributed to the "deliberate termination of the child" by parents who discover through ultrasound examination that the foetus is female.

Researchers say that many couples still cling to the traditional preference to have at least one boy, especially if their first child is a girl. Male offspring are regarded as having more value in China's privatised rural economy.

The ban in Anhui is intended to reinforce a widely ignored national prohibition on the use of ultrasound in pregnancy, except for medical reasons.

The 1995 Maternal and Child Health Law already bans the termination of pregnancies because of the sex of the foetus.

However, the law is unlikely to be enforced locally unless backed up by provincial legislation.

"Ultrasound for [sex] selection is rampant," a UN health expert in Beijing said. "There is no regulation on who can own them or not, and people can generate a good return by charging for their use."

Rural government health centres, where doctors' incomes are now largely dependent on patients' fees, have been defying the national ban for years. Almost all rural hospitals have an ultrasound which is used, according to the UN expert, to raise income.

Despite China's one child-only policy, Anhui - with a population of 61m - is one of many areas where the rules have been generally relaxed to allow two children per family. Figures for the first half of this year from hospitals in the provincial capital, Hefei, showed that the male-female ratio for first births was 111:100, but rose to 317:100 for second births.

There is considerable confusion about gender statistics across China and some demographers doubt whether a complete picture can even be expected from the recent national census.

Chinese government statistics have put the national ratio for male-female births at 114:100 while the World Health Organisation estimates it at 117:100. These compare with the expected statistical norm of 106:100.

"I am seeing different health statistics from the countryside all the time," the UN expert added. "Whenever I break them down, I find a 20% discrepancy [between male and female births]."

The use of abortion following ultrasound is only one reason for the discrepancy. An unknown number of female births are underreported so that parents can keep trying to conceive a boy without falling foul of planned family limits. These extra births may not be picked up by the census.

A third reason is the neglect of baby girls resulting in lower female survival rates. Research in Anhui has shown that female infants are breastfed for shorter periods than boys, which may reduce their natural immunity to disease.

In some cases the neglect of baby girls may extend to infanticide or abandonment. A very high proportion - in some areas, up to 90% - of young children in Chinese orphanages are female.

Last year Jiangxi province - which like neighbouring Anhui is predominantly rural - imposed its own ban on sex identification through ultrasound. Statistics showed that the male to female ratio there was 10% higher than the norm. An official statement blamed "feudalist ideology which gives priority to males".

A rural county in the north-east province of Liaoning which has specialised in ultrasound tests since 1992 was recently reported to have a male-female birth ratio of more than three to one.

webTitle: Aide claims Filipino leader took bribes

fields.headline: Aide claims Filipino leader took bribes
fields.trailText: An aide to a provincial governor in the Philippines testified yesterday in the impeachment trial of the president, Joseph Estrada, that she delivered 5m pesos (£70,000) in payoffs from illegal-gambling lords to Mr Estrada's personal secretary.
fields.body:
An aide to a provincial governor in the Philippines testified yesterday in the impeachment trial of the president, Joseph Estrada, that she delivered 5m pesos (£70,000) in payoffs from illegal-gambling lords to Mr Estrada's personal secretary.

Hers was the first evidence to link alleged payoffs from the jueteng gambling game to the president.

Emma Lim, an aide to Luis Singson, testified that she took 5m pesos to the presidential palace at Mr Singson's request. The governor triggered the trial in October when he claimed to have given the president more than 400m pesos from jueteng and 130m pesos from taxes intended to help tobacco farmers.

The 11 congressmen acting as prosecutors opened Mr Estrada's trial last Thursday, spinning a tale of money, mansions and mistresses, and claiming that he was unfit to govern.

The president denies the charges of bribery, betrayal of public trust and violation of the constitution.

Many business groups have urged him to resign to spare the country a divisive trial.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Gloria | The Witches Of Eastwick | Three Colours: Blue | Cutter's Way
fields.body:
Gloria

(Sidney Lumet, 1999)

8pm, Sky Premier

Ambitious remake of John Cassavetes classic 1980 thriller. Sharon Stone makes a creditable attempt at Gloria, the hard-as-coffin-nails moll who takes a young orphan (Jean-Luke Figueroa) under her wing to protect him from the mob; trouble is, Cassavetes' wife Gena Rowlands pretty much made the role her own in the original. Add Lumet's oddly distracted direction, and despite some sterling work from all concerned, it all looks and feels just a little bit redundant.

The Witches Of Eastwick

(George Miller, 1987)

10pm, Sky Cinema

Jack Nicholson (pictured) is Daryl Van Horne, "a horny little devil" dreamed up by sultry trio Cher, Susan Sarandon and Michelle Pfeiffer to banish their Eastwick ennui; but he proves rather too stimulating. A spellbinding, sexy comedy, retaining the latent threat of John Updike's clever novel, though the overheated finale is disappointing.

Three Colours: Blue

(Krysztof Kieslowski, 1993)

8pm, FilmFour

The first part of Kieslowski's Colours trilogy is the mood-indigo blue, a sombre reflection on grief and the doubtful freedom of a suddenly unattached life. Juliette Binoche, as the woman who loses composer-husband and daughter in a car crash, has a face you could watch all day, but there is depth to her performance too. And the late, lamented Kieslowski's intense east-European gloom is a thing of exotic beauty - if lacking the emotional charge of his Polish Dekalog.

Cutter's Way

(Ivan Passer, 1981)

10pm, FilmFour

A powerful thriller with Jeff Bridges as Richard Bone, a man convinced that oil tycoon JJ Cord (Stephen Elliot), is a murderer. His suspicion is soon hijacked by his Vietnam-vet buddy, Cutter (John Heard) and his despairing wife (Lisa Eichhorn); and Cutter's obsession leads the trio into death and defeat.

webTitle: Lack of ramp mars athlete's glory

fields.headline: Lack of ramp mars athlete's glory
fields.trailText: Paralympian Tanni Grey-Thompson has got used to receiving awards in recognition of her outstanding sporting ability, but a simple oversight by the BBC denied her the chance of collecting her latest accolade in front of an audience of millions.
fields.body:
Paralympian Tanni Grey-Thompson has got used to receiving awards in recognition of her outstanding sporting ability, but a simple oversight by the BBC denied her the chance of collecting her latest accolade in front of an audience of millions.

A failure by television bosses to provide a ramp to enable the athlete to access the stage in her wheelchair meant that she could not go up and accept her third prize at the Sports Personality of the Year awards screened on Sunday night.

The disabled athlete was being honoured for winning four gold medals in the Sydney Paralympics, which brought the total number of medals she has amassed in her long Paralympic career to nine.

The lack of a ramp at the Television Centre studios in west London meant that she was unable to join rower Steve Redgrave, winner of five Olympic gold medals, and Olympic heptathlon gold medallist Denise Lewis when they went up to collect the first and second prizes.

The oversight was criticised by the Disability Rights Commission, which yesterday launched its first campaign, backed by the prime minister Tony Blair, aimed at getting organisations to make a practical commitment to helping disabled people participate more fully in society.

Bert Massie, chair of the DRC, said the incident high lighted how disabled people were prevented from fully participating in all sorts of ways. "Tanni Grey-Thompson's experience shows even the most successful disabled people face discrimination. There is a need for action and it is needed now," he added.

The BBC, which is one of the signatories to the campaign, yesterday apologised to Mrs Grey-Thompson, who accepted it was an oversight.

The BBC's director of sport, Peter Salmon, said: "Failing to meet the needs of Tanni during the programme was an error from which we will learn.

He added: "Disabled athletics has come to the fore partially as a result of our efforts and we want to improve our coverage still more."

In a joint press release with the BBC, Mrs Grey-Thompson said that she did not want the oversight to be turned into an issue. She added: "There is a danger that the unfortunate error of the missing ramp on the programme will be exploited as an issue and undo much of the good work that has been achieved for disabled athletics. I want to continue working with the BBC to increase recognition and support for disabled people."

She also won last night's special accolade, the Helen Rollason award, for outstanding achievement in the face of adversity.

She was presented with the award by last year's winner, racehorse trainer Jenny Pitman.

webTitle: Portillo tries to deflect tax attack

fields.headline: Portillo tries to deflect tax attack
fields.standfirst:
Pledge to keep spending in line with economic growth still means £16bn cuts, claims Labour

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Pledge to keep spending in line with economic growth still means £16bn cuts, claims Labour
fields.body:
Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, yesterday laid out the economic rules to be followed by a future Conservative government in a bid to deflect growing Labour attacks over William Hague's tax cutting agenda.

Mr Portillo said his proposals would include making the Bank of England more independent of Whitehall, setting up a fiscal watchdog to monitor the performance of the chancellor and establishing a national accounts commission to ensure government accounts were accurate and transparent. The shadow chancellor also stressed that a Hague administration would keep Britain out of the single currency and would keep increases in government spending in line with the economy's long term average growth rate of 2.25%-2.5%.

Speaking at the London Business School, Mr Portillo said government plans to increase spending by 3.4% a year over the next three years were unsustainable, and would be followed either by smaller rises in future years or by higher taxes. He added that instead of spending an extra £70bn, a Conservative government would spend £62bn, with the other £8bn used to cut taxes for "those groups such as families and pensioners who are now paying too much tax".

Responding to Labour claims that the Conservative plans lacked any intellectual underpinning, Mr Portillo said: "Guiding all our policy making is a clear appreciation that in a highly competitive global economy, each country's economic policy mix is completely transparent. There is no hiding place for bad policy, and policy errors will be punished rapidly by a flight of talent and investment."

The shadow chancellor added that the rules for the conduct of economic policy laid down by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, since the last election, were less impressive than they looked. "We need more rigorous disciplines and ones that are more likely to serve in more adverse world economic circumstances."

Mr Portillo restated Conservative plans to cut future public spending by allowing younger workers to opt out of state pensions and invest their national insurance contributions instead in funded schemes, which he said could "relieve or eliminate" the state's very high future liabilities for pensions.

He also outlined plans for the use of windfall receipts - such as the proceeds of mobile phone licence sales - to endow universities, taking their funding out of the hands of the state. He also repeated Tory proposals to encourage more private spending on health, while insisting the Conservatives would match Labour pledges on public funding for the NHS.

Andrew Smith, chief secretary to the Treasury, last night said Mr Portillo's pledge to keep spending in line with economic growth confirmed that the Tories were on course to cut £16bn from Labour's plans. "Michael Portillo fails to spell out where the cuts would fall," Mr Smith said. "The black hole in his spending plans remains."

His criticisms showed that Labour is determined to place tax and spending at the top of the election agenda. Labour claims that the Tories will be unable to live up to their commitment to ringfence spending on health and education because they will be forced to cut more than the £8bn identified so far by Mr Portillo. The shadow chancellor last week unveiled plans to slash £8bn from Labour's spending plans, a figure which the government dismissed as unrealistic.

Mr Portillo was only able to identify £5.3bn in cuts, saying that the rest would follow in the next few months. Labour claimed some of the cuts, such as a plan to slash more than 10% from Whitehall costs, were wildly unrealistic.

fields.headline: The great pretender
fields.standfirst: When artist Rodney Graham isn't producing odd records and even stranger novels, he dresses up in a top hat and kicks himself in public. It's all perfectly logical, says Adrian Searle.
fields.trailText: When artist Rodney Graham isn't producing odd records and even stranger novels, he dresses up in a top hat and kicks himself in public. It's all perfectly logical, says Adrian Searle.
fields.body:
It is a mild autumn day, a little after noon, in a French town in the mid-19th century. A black top hat rolls on the cobbles. Its owner, whose face is oddly familiar, despite the fact that he is some nondescript middling fellow who belongs more to the fields and farmland than to the town itself, has just suffered an astonishing and quite unprovoked indignity.

A few minutes before, this bumpkin was taking a turn on the street. A bird sang on the far side of an ivy-covered wall, a jackdaw cawed around the old church spire. An innocent abroad, he was crossing the street as a horse-drawn carriage with two men in fine green livery clattered past when, as a clock struck the hour, he was kicked in the pants by a complete stranger - kicked, kicked and kicked again by a finely tooled, pointed leather boot, whose owner is the bumpkin's exact double, but a double who has gone up in the world - a dandy who lashes out, we suppose, just because he can.

It is rare that an artist produces a helpful little pocket guide to his own exhibition. The Canadian Rodney Graham has written about his film City Self Country Self (Paris Street Scene, 1865) in the guide to his current Lisson Gallery show. The dandy, the bumpkin and Graham are one and the same. And Rodney Graham, the hot-shot avant-garde Vancouver artist, is also the Rodney Graham who, wearing a sensible jumper, sits at the foot of a tree, guitar in hand, on the cover of the album Getting It Together in the Country, a record that, by the look of it, belongs in the MOR/folk section of a second-hand record store.

It is not unknown for artists to also write, play and sing their own songs on well-produced CDs. Lots of artists have bands (Martin Creed's art band OWADA, for example), but they don't generally deserve to make it big. I am playing one of Graham's other recordings as I write this - The Bed-Bug, Love Buzz "and other short songs in the popular idiom", produced for Graham's Dia Foundation double-handed show with Bruce Nauman earlier this year.

Graham's wry, witty electro-pop and acoustic tunes have beaten everything else to take this week's top slot in our flat. Graham sometimes sounds a bit like Nick Cave, is reminiscent at times of Stereolab and Nirvana, among others, but is mostly, unmistakably himself. The songs, and his laconic vioice, stay in your head, just the way good pop ought to. There can't be anything wrong with a smooth easy-listening number called Man, I Really Miss the Coast, which contains the rhyme "Sigmund Freud is still The Most".

For the Lisson Gallery, Graham has brought out a new CD, What Is Happy, Baby?, a short set of five acoustic tracks, including a cover of George Harrison's Blue Jay Way (from the Beatles' Magical Mystery Tour album). All this is confusing, given Graham's reputation as a sometimes daunting, fearsomely intellectual artist who once took a couple of years out from his practice as an artist to study Freud's dropping of his medical vocation in favour of what, in essence, was a science of his own invention. But perhaps here is the key to Graham's own waywardness.

Graham has also written a novel - The System of Landor's Cottage - which the author describes as "a pendant to Poe's last story... itself described by Poe as a pendant to an earlier tale", which was called The Domain of Arnheim. Graham's novel appears in the show, but in the form of 158 framed pages, translated back into English, by 14 commercial translation companies, from an earlier translation into French of Graham's "original" story. You don't actually want to read a novel presented like this. Why did Graham go through this crazy procedure? At one level, like his dandy, because he could.

"I have always wanted to be a French novelist, particularly Raymond Roussel," notes Graham. The sheer copiousness of much of Graham's oeuvre, its proliferating footnotes, its cross-references and self-annotations - wheels within wheels, endless cycles, great arcing digressions and metaphoric lunacies - can wind even the hardiest. Life is too short for this, I hear you say.

Anyway, what's the point? It turns out that much as Graham's work is a kind of language game, he lives in the real world, unlike Roussel, whose entire life was one vast exquisite evasion. Graham's work is as often light-hearted and entertaining as it is mysterious, serious, troubling and full of conundrums. It is filled, too, with ordinary human foibles, failings and enthusiasms.

"Say what you will, modern life remains a bitter pill... what is happy baby?" sings Graham. Happiness, it turns out, can only ever be a matter of making associations, giving meaning to things, but remembering that the real is out there somewhere too, as yet unmediated by thought or art.

Here's Graham, fishing on a jetty, rod in hand. Vancouver rises across the bay behind him. When I first saw it in New York, this photo-piece bothered me, but more as a fisherman than as an art critic. Not even on the poshest Scottish salmon beat would anyone dress as nattily as Graham does here: crisp white shirt, sharply pressed slacks, immaculate trilby and cool black waistcoat. His tackle is also unbalanced, and Graham piscator doesn't look like he knows how to hold his reel.

It turns out that he is only pretending to fish, and the entire constructed and digitally reworked image is a copy of a still from Hitchcock's To Catch a Thief, in which Cary Grant pretends to fish as a ruse to go unnoticed in Hong Kong. Pretence is at the heart of this work. I was bothered then for the right reason, and had seen through Graham's (and Grant's) disguise. Cary Grant, playing John Robie, was really called Archibald Leach. Graham's work is about not working, but fishing, not even fishing but... you get the point.

It is the middle of the 19th century, a mild autumn day, a little before noon. A pompous self-satisfied bourgeois dandy checks his pocket-watch. His face is oddly familiar. He has just had his shoes shined. Crossing the street as a carriage with two liveried men clatters past, and on the stroke of 12, he comes up behind some country fellow and kicks him up the arse, because he can.

A black top hat rolls on the cobbles. The dandy finds his mark. Rodney Graham, with what he calls an "injury laugh", a bit of clownish busi ness as old as the hills, finds his mark too, again because he can.

Graham's film, in which his city self and country self (with a bit of help from a body double in a latex face mask) re-enact their endless cycle of oppression, is a narrative engine that plunges us into strangeness. We are amused, and struck by a multitude of enjoyable little filmic details.

This vignette - based on an image in a French children's book that Graham once saw, and then misplaced, might remind us of Dostoevsky's The Double, except that here we do not know which is the doppelgänger, which the authentic personage of the film, or which is the real Rodney Graham. Who cares - just dig the music.

 Rodney Graham: What Is Happy, Baby? is at the Lisson Gallery, London NW1 (020-7724 2739), until January 27.

An innocent abroad, he was crossing the street as a horse-drawn carriage with two men in fine green livery clattered past when, as a clock struck the hour, he was kicked in the pants by a complete stranger - kicked, kicked and kicked again by a finely tooled, pointed leather boot, whose owner is the bumpkin's exact double, but a double who has gone up in the world - a dandy who lashes out, we suppose, just because he can. It is rare that an artist produces a helpful little pocket guide to his own exhibition. The Canadian Rodney Graham has written about his film City Self Country Self (Paris Street Scene, 1865) in the guide to his current Lisson Gallery show. The dandy, the bumpkin and Graham are one and the same. And Rodney Graham, the hot-shot avant-garde Vancouver artist, is also the Rodney Graham who, wearing a sensible jumper, sits at the foot of a tree, guitar in hand, on the cover of the album Getting It Together in the Country, a record that, by the look of it, belongs in the MOR/folk section of a second-hand record store. It is not unknown for artists to also write, play and sing their own songs on well-produced CDs. Lots of artists have bands (Martin Creed's art band OWADA, for example), but they don't generally deserve to make it big. I am playing one of Graham's other recordings as I write this - The Bed-Bug, Love Buzz "and other short songs in the popular idiom", produced for Graham's Dia Foundation double-handed show with Bruce Nauman earlier this year. Graham's wry, witty electro-pop and acoustic tunes have beaten everything else to take this week's top slot in our flat. Graham sometimes sounds a bit like Nick Cave, is reminiscent at times of Stereolab and Nirvana, among others, but is mostly, unmistakably himself. The songs, and his laconic vioice, stay in your head, just the way good pop ought to. There can't be anything wrong with a smooth easy-listening number called Man, I Really Miss the Coast, which contains the rhyme "Sigmund Freud is still The Most". For the Lisson Gallery, Graham has brought out a new CD, What Is Happy, Baby?, a short set of five acoustic tracks, including a cover of George Harrison's Blue Jay Way (from the Beatles' Magical Mystery Tour album). All this is confusing, given Graham's reputation as a sometimes daunting, fearsomely intellectual artist who once took a couple of years out from his practice as an artist to study Freud's dropping of his medical vocation in favour of what, in essence, was a science of his own invention. But perhaps here is the key to Graham's own waywardness. Graham has also written a novel - The System of Landor's Cottage - which the author describes as "a pendant to Poe's last story... itself described by Poe as a pendant to an earlier tale", which was called The Domain of Arnheim. Graham's novel appears in the show, but in the form of 158 framed pages, translated back into English, by 14 commercial translation companies, from an earlier translation into French of Graham's "original" story. You don't actually want to read a novel presented like this. Why did Graham go through this crazy procedure? At one level, like his dandy, because he could. "I have always wanted to be a French novelist, particularly Raymond Roussel," notes Graham. The sheer copiousness of much of Graham's oeuvre, its proliferating footnotes, its cross-references and self-annotations - wheels within wheels, endless cycles, great arcing digressions and metaphoric lunacies - can wind even the hardiest. Life is too short for this, I hear you say. Anyway, what's the point? It turns out that much as Graham's work is a kind of language game, he lives in the real world, unlike Roussel, whose entire life was one vast exquisite evasion. Graham's work is as often light-hearted and entertaining as it is mysterious, serious, troubling and full of conundrums. It is filled, too, with ordinary human foibles, failings and enthusiasms. "Say what you will, modern life remains a bitter pill... what is happy baby?" sings Graham. Happiness, it turns out, can only ever be a matter of making associations, giving meaning to things, but remembering that the real is out there somewhere too, as yet unmediated by thought or art. Here's Graham, fishing on a jetty, rod in hand. Vancouver rises across the bay behind him. When I first saw it in New York, this photo-piece bothered me, but more as a fisherman than as an art critic. Not even on the poshest Scottish salmon beat would anyone dress as nattily as Graham does here: crisp white shirt, sharply pressed slacks, immaculate trilby and cool black waistcoat. His tackle is also unbalanced, and Graham piscator doesn't look like he knows how to hold his reel. It turns out that he is only pretending to fish, and the entire constructed and digitally reworked image is a copy of a still from Hitchcock's To Catch a Thief, in which Cary Grant pretends to fish as a ruse to go unnoticed in Hong Kong. Pretence is at the heart of this work. I was bothered then for the right reason, and had seen through Graham's (and Grant's) disguise. Cary Grant, playing John Robie, was really called Archibald Leach. Graham's work is about not working, but fishing, not even fishing but... you get the point. It is the middle of the 19th century, a mild autumn day, a little before noon. A pompous self-satisfied bourgeois dandy checks his pocket-watch. His face is oddly familiar. He has just had his shoes shined. Crossing the street as a carriage with two liveried men clatters past, and on the stroke of 12, he comes up behind some country fellow and kicks him up the arse, because he can. A black top hat rolls on the cobbles. The dandy finds his mark. Rodney Graham, with what he calls an "injury laugh", a bit of clownish busi ness as old as the hills, finds his mark too, again because he can. Graham's film, in which his city self and country self (with a bit of help from a body double in a latex face mask) re-enact their endless cycle of oppression, is a narrative engine that plunges us into strangeness. We are amused, and struck by a multitude of enjoyable little filmic details. This vignette - based on an image in a French children's book that Graham once saw, and then misplaced, might remind us of Dostoevsky's The Double, except that here we do not know which is the doppelgänger, which the authentic personage of the film, or which is the real Rodney Graham. Who cares - just dig the music.  Rodney Graham: What Is Happy, Baby? is at the Lisson Gallery, London NW1 (020-7724 2739), until January 27.

fields.headline: Judges block Pinochet arrest
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: The appeal court in Santiago has overruled an order placing General Augusto Pinochet under house arrest to await trial on charges relating to murders and kidnaps carried out by his regime
fields.body:
The appeal court in Santiago has overruled an order placing General Augusto Pinochet under house arrest to await trial on charges relating to murders and kidnaps carried out by his regime

Three justices ruled unanimously that Judge Juan Guzman had not followed the correct legal procedures when charging the former general and ordering his detention, because he had not yet been questioned by a judge. Prosecutors argued otherwise.

"This is just a technicality," said Carmen Hertz, for the prosecution. "The ruling does not involve the essence of the case against him."

Human rights lawyers immediately filed an appeal to the supreme court, which is expected to hear the case tomorrow.

The 85-year-old general is expected to lose that round and be left facing the charges relating to 70 murders and kidnappings carried out in 1973 by a military squad known as the Caravan of Death.

Since Judge Guzman issued his decision 10 days ago the general's supporters have attacked the judiciary, saying that a trial would only further destabilise Chile.

In a sign of military discontent last week, armed forces chiefs forced the Socialist president, Ricardo Lagos, to convene the national security council, to voice reservations.

General Pinochet is being pursued by international judges who are exchanging information and sources. Investigations are taking place in Argentina, Italy, Mexico, the US and Spain, in addition to the 189 cases against the general in Chile.

fields.headline: Nappy Christmas
fields.standfirst: Blairs parade Leo
fields.trailText: Blairs parade Leo
fields.body:
It is an image to warm the nation's heart, which will no doubt come in handy as the general election looms.

Abandoning formality, Tony and Cherie Blair have decided to show off the latest addition to their family in this year's Downing Street Christmas card.

Baby Leo is cradled by his father in the picture taken by Mary McCartney, daughter of Sir Paul, soon after his birth last May.

Dressed in a blue denim shirt, a tanned-looking prime minister is hugged by his wife.

The Blairs' other children, Euan, Nicky and Kathryn, who have featured in past Downing Street Christmas cards, are nowhere to be seen, possibly reflecting their parents' renewed determination to protect their privacy.

A Downing Street spokeswoman said the Christmas card was a reflection of how the arrival of Leo had transformed the Blairs' lives.

"The picture shows the most important thing that's happened to them personally this year," the spokeswoman said.

The card is in marked contrast to last year's card in which the Blairs, minus their children, were pictured beneath a chandelier in the Downing Street state room.

webTitle: Vodafone takes on BT in Japan

fields.headline: Vodafone takes on BT in Japan
fields.trailText: Britain's two largest telecoms firms appeared to be positioning for a potentially bruising battle to gain a stake in the most coveted area of Japan's wireless industry.
fields.body:
Britain's two largest telecoms firms appeared to be positioning for a potentially bruising battle to gain a stake in the most coveted area of Japan's wireless industry.

Vodafone Group, has agreed to buy a 15% stake in Japan Telecom, Japan's third largest telecoms operator, for about $2.5bn (£1.7bn) in cash, according to reports yesterday.

The deal would provide the British mobile phone firm with a cheap and convenient testing ground for third-generation phones, to kick off for the first time in Japan next year, analysts said.

The world's biggest cellular phone operator would win hands-on experience in the most coveted area of the wireless industry before most of its rivals worldwide, they said.

Japanese business daily Nihon Keizai Shimbun claimed that BT was considering raising its own stake in Japan Telecom by purchasing shares from US long-distance phone carrier AT&T.

The news reports of the flurry of British interest sent Japan Telecom's shares soaring 16.85% to close at 2.08m yen (£12,900). The price, however, was still off nearly 65% from its year-to-date high posted in May.

Vodafone, whose shares rose yesterday, has said that it is continuing to look for acquisition opportunities worldwide, underpinned by one of the strongest balance sheets in the industry.

A Japan Telecom deal would allow it to test its 3G applications without paying for a licence, by giving it a controlling stake in Japan Telecom's mobile communications unit, J-Phone, said Yasumasa Goda, senior analyst at Merrill Lynch. Vodafone already owns 26% of J-Phone and Japan Telecom owns 54%.

Japan Telecom is one of three Japanese firms licensed to offer 3G phones, which offer faster audio and video capabilities. It plans to begin offering the service through J-Phone by next autumn, after a May launch by NTT DoCoMo.

Vodafone could also offer J-phone users internet content services it has honed through a joint venture with French telecoms firm Vivendi, Mr Goda said.

Vodafone declined to comment. BT said it was interested in raising its stakes in strategically important areas, but declined to comment specifically on Japan Telecom.

However, analysts said even if Vodafone bought those shares, the deal would have little impact on the overall mobile phone market, and market share distribution would likely remain unchanged.

As of November, J-Phone accounted for 16.35% of the mobile phone market in Japan. The firm is 54% owned by Japan Telecom, 26% by Vodafone and 20% by BT.

fields.headline: Mafia rebirth dismays UN conference
fields.standfirst: New report names 329 officials thought to have colluded with Sicilian families
fields.trailText: A United Nations conference on fighting organised crime will open in Sicily today as new evidence emerges that the Mafia is reclaiming the island.
fields.body:
A United Nations conference on fighting organised crime will open in Sicily today as new evidence emerges that the Mafia is reclaiming the island.

The organisers had hoped that the improvement in the island's image after an eight-year crackdown on the Mafia would encourage the representatives of 110 governments to sign an anti-mafia treaty.

But a report leaked yesterday from the prosecutor's office in Palermo named 329 politicians, law enforcers and businessmen suspected of colluding with the criminal clans.

Judges admitted that the clans, far from being smashed, had rebuilt their networks and begun infiltrating Sicily's new generation of leaders.

The report, drawn from evidence given by supergrasses, identified those the Mafia considered allies or potential allies.

In descending scale of their alleged involvement, magistrates, policemen, civil servants, doctors, bankers, entrepreneurs and mayors were listed as being "men of honour", "approachable", or "available".

La Stampa, the newspaper which broke the story, said the rollcall raised the question whether Sicily had indeed been freed from fear.

Improved communications and more fluid borders have been a boon to money laundering and trafficking in humans, drugs and weapons.

The treaty, which must be signed and ratified by at least 40 governments to become international law, will try to close the criminal opportunities offered by globalisation. Its signatories will be committed to adopting uniform laws, streamlining extradition, protecting witnesses, confiscating criminal assets and pooling information.

The UN billed the conference as a breakthrough in empowering law enforcers to fight transnational crime.

Its organisers chose Palermo because it was the symbol of victory against organised crime.

Sicily was to be the model for tackling criminal networks spanning the far east, Russia, the Balkans, western Europe and the Americas.

Included on the list of alleged Mafia contacts was the summit's host, Leoluca Orlando, mayor of Palermo.

Perhaps Italy's best known anti-mafia crusader, his complicity if proved would be a sensation, but even his critics poured scorn on the accusation.

Prosecutors said the allegation was made long ago by an unreliable supergrass, and no investigation is expected.

La Stampa admitted that the supergrass accounts were at times contradictory and incoherent. Mr Orlando, 53, has been on a death list for most of the time he has overseen Palermo's rebirth.

A Mafia challenge to the state in 1992, climaxing in the car-bomb murders of judges Giovanni Falcone and Paolo Borsellino, prompted new laws and a prolonged crackdown. Mobsters such as Giovanni Brusca, who were persuaded to break omerta, the code of silence, implicated hundreds of colleagues in so-called "maxi" trials.

Toto Riina, the boss of bosses, was sentenced to life and the former prime minister Giulio Andreotti, the organisation's alleged protector in Rome, was put on trial.

The Mafia was brought to its knees. Little has been heard of it in recent years, not because it has disappeared but because it is lying low, regrouping and consolidating for a rebirth, judges and prosecutors say.

The internal bloodletting of Riina's era has given way to cooperation and the return of the once formidable pyramidal structure, whereby a committee of clan representatives make policy and issue orders.

Its latest known additions are updated on a heavily guarded CD-Rom in Palermo's prosecutors' office. The latest count is 190 clans with 5,192 members.

The Palermo region alone has 89 families with 3,201 members. They range from the Brancaccios, whose 203 members run rackets and drugs, to a two-member operation in the Vucciria food market.

Trapani, on Sicily's western tip, comes next with 982 members, followed by Agrigento, Caltanissetta, Catania, Enna, Messina and Syracuse. Historically the Mafia has been weaker in the east.

Running the show is the new boss of bosses, Bernardo Provenzano, known as "the tractor" for mowing people down. He has been on the run since 1963, raising the suspicion that he has bought off the police.

Judicial morale has been sapped by the failure to convict Mr Andreotti and the gradual breakdown of the supergrass system, tarnished by false testimonies and crimes committed by those on witness-protection programmes.

The burgeoning trade of people trafficking has been boosted by alliances with Balkan and Chinese gangs.

Quietly cultivating new friends, the Mafia has also plugged into the legitimate economy, buying into supermarkets, banks, government bonds and internet companies.

"The Mafia searches not only for profits but also power. It needs rapport with politicians and institutions," said Piero Grasso, the head of Palermo's prosecution service.

Traditional tactics of usury, bribery and extortion are reaping huge dividends. A parliamentary report issued last month said the Mafia controled 30% of Italy's rubbish disposal companies, including toxic waste disposers, generating £4.6bn annually.

According to Confcommerci, a business association, mobsters control 20% of the shops and 15% of the factories, generating around £92bn a year.

Their combined assets are thought to be enough to pay Italy's national debt.

fields.headline: Blow for electricity regulator
fields.trailText: Energy watchdog Ofgem yesterday suffered a heavy blow when the competition commission threw out regulations designed to curb abuses of the wholesale electricity market.
fields.body:
Energy watchdog Ofgem yesterday suffered a heavy blow when the competition commission threw out regulations designed to curb abuses of the wholesale electricity market.

In a decision that could encourage other utilities to challenge their regulatory regimes, the commission ruled that Ofgem could not impose "good behaviour" clauses in the licences of two big generators, British Energy and AES.

Ofgem director general Callum McCarthy attacked the decision, saying that it would handicap the regulator's efforts to protect consumers. Ofgem would have to withdraw similar clauses already inserted in the licences of other big generators.

But the commission ruled the wholesale electricity market was becoming more competitive, licence conditions would increase uncertainty and the existing trading regime, the pool, would soon be superceded by a new system under which generators would have less scope to use their market power.

Under the present pool system prices can be driven higher if generators withdraw capacity. Ofgem argued that this gave the generators scope for market abuse. The "good behaviour" clauses allowed it to prevent deliberate withdrawal of capacity to force up prices.

But the generators had protested against the clauses, arguing that they gave Ofgem too much power.

Yesterday Mr McCarthy said Ofgem was "deeply disappointed." The decision meant "a substantial loss of measures needed by Ofgem to do our job".

The commission argued that whatever the defects of the pool, the New Electricity Trading Arrangements (NETA) had "been designed to minimise the opportunities for manipulation of the market." Imposing the "good behaviour" clauses on the two companies "would cause uncertainty, because of the difficulty of distinguishing between abusive and acceptable conduct and would risk deterring normal competitive behaviour."

"It is a big loss of face for the regulator," said one utilities analyst. Other companies may now challenge regulatory regimes, he said.

 David Jones is to retire as chief executive of National Grid Group next March. He will be replaced by Roger Unwin, head of the company's UK and European operations.

webTitle: BP brings power of the sun to pumps

fields.headline: BP brings power of the sun to pumps
fields.trailText: Oil group BP's attempt to reinvent itself as an environmentally friendly, customer-focused retailer for the new millennium moved on a step yesterday with the opening of a concept site complete with solar-powered petrol pumps, internet access and an extensive food menu.
fields.body:
Oil group BP's attempt to reinvent itself as an environmentally friendly, customer-focused retailer for the new millennium moved on a step yesterday with the opening of a concept site complete with solar-powered petrol pumps, internet access and an extensive food menu.

Fresh from a multi-million pound rebranding exercise, BP says the west London site is the first of 300 it plans to open globally in 2001. The concept's title is BP Connect and it aims to strengthen the firm's position in the convenience goods market.

Motorists will be able to buy fuel and read traffic and weather information from internet screens attached to the pumps. Power will be provided by solar panels embedded in the forecourt canopies.

Customers will be able to pay at the pump or instore, where freshly baked pastries and coffee will be on sale. One thousand trees are being planted to commemorate the first site and 100 more will follow for every centre opened.

"We will give our customers what we know they want: more convenience, more choice and more help in their busy lives," said Doug Ford, chief executive of refining and marketing.

Chief executive Sir John Browne said in July that he planned to spend £100m over the next year reinforcing BP's greener image as it moves "beyond petroleum".

Environmentalists say it is a cynical ploy to divert attention from BP's core business of oil production.

One thousand trees are being planted to commemorate the first site and 100 more will follow for every centre opened. "We will give our customers what we know they want: more convenience, more choice and more help in their busy lives," said Doug Ford, chief executive of refining and marketing. Chief executive Sir John Browne said in July that he planned to spend £100m over the next year reinforcing BP's greener image as it moves "beyond petroleum". Environmentalists say it is a cynical ploy to divert attention from BP's core business of oil production.

webTitle: Carlton sells Technicolor to Thomson for £1.43bn

fields.headline: Carlton sells Technicolor to Thomson for £1.43bn
fields.trailText: Carlton Communications yesterday agreed the £1.43bn sale of Technicolor to Thomson Multimedia, achieving a price at the top end of most analysts expectations.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications yesterday agreed the £1.43bn sale of Technicolor to Thomson Multimedia, achieving a price at the top end of most analysts expectations.

The sale will leave Carlton with proceeds of £93m in cash and 15.5m shares equivalent to 5.5% of Thomson. The deal will provide the basis for a broader ongoing alliance between Carlton and the French technology group.

Carlton chief executive Gerry Murphy said the agreement had been unaffected by market turbulence which had led to some speculation that the company might call off the sale. Carlton first announced its intention to dispose of the Hollywood film processing business in November, in line with plans to focus on free-to-air and pay TV.

"Thomson are taking a 10-year view of the business not a week by week view of the market," he said. "When you have a willing buyer with a long term strategic agenda and a willing seller then blips in the market don't derail that kind of deal."

As well as the film processing business, Technicolor is the world's largest manufacturer of video cassettes and their replacement technology DVDs.

fields.headline: Shire in £5.9bn merger
fields.standfirst: Tie-up with BioChem Pharma reduces the company's reliance on one drug
fields.trailText: Tie-up with BioChem Pharma reduces the company's reliance on one drug
fields.body:
Psychiatric drugs specialist Shire Pharmaceuticals yesterday agreed a £5.9bn merger with Canada's BioChem Pharma, in a deal that allows it to join the race to develop treatments for diseases such as Aids and cancer.

The tie-up marked a further step in the phenomenal growth of the Hampshire-based firm, which recently joined the FTSE 100.

However, there were immediate concerns about the $4bn (£2.7bn) price attached to the BioChem side of the deal. Shire is issuing equity to buy BioChem, and fears that it was overpaying sent the Shire's shares down 194p to £10.32.

Shire's chief executive, Rolf Stahel, said the merger would reduce the company's reliance on Adderall, the controversial drug for hyperactive children that contributes nearly half its annual sales. "Adderall's going so well that it's been giving us a headache. We don't want to become dependant on one product alone."

Adderall is used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder - a condition which has been diagnosed in more than 4m American children.

A combination with Montreal-based BioChem will dramatically change Shire's product portfolio, bringing in a big programme of research into vaccines, as well as leading treatments for HIV and hepatitis B.

Mr Stahel said: "Our portfolio's been a bit lop-sided - it has a lot of late-stage projects but until now, not enough early ones."

The deal takes Shire ahead of rival Celltech, making it Britain's fourth largest drugs company behind Glaxo Wellcome, SmithKline Beecham and AstraZeneca.

The combined company will have 1,500 employees, although the majority of staff and sales will be in north America.

Mr Stahel warned that the group could be moved across the Atlantic unless the government gives it a good reason to stay in Britain. "We've currently got no intention of moving but we're watching government policy. If they help support the industry, we'll stay but if they damage it, we'll consider going to America."

Such a move would be a severe blow to the prestige of Britain's pharmaceuticals industry. Companies have complained bitterly this year about changes to the way the NHS chooses drugs, and about a pricing structure that allows continental companies to flood the market with cheap "parallel imports".

There was a mixed reaction in the City to Shire's latest deal, which follows a £1.5bn merger with US firm Roberts Pharmaceuticals last Christmas.

One analyst pointed out that Shire was paying a hefty 40% premium to BioChem's share price. "I do think they've overpaid a little bit. They're buying a cash cow - it'll provide money for more mergers and acquisitions," he said.

There was surprise that Shire was merging with a company that does early-stage research. The company has traditionally had a strategy of buying up drugs discovered by smaller biotech firms. An analyst said: "It won't be long before they have their own genomics platform."

Founded in Montreal 14 years ago by three Canadian scientists, BioChem made profits of $112m on sales of $186m last year. Its margins are high because of an agreement under which Glaxo Wellcome bears the cost of distributing its top drugs but its immediate growth prospects are considered to be limited.

BioChem hit the headlines three years ago when terrorists detonated four bombs at the company's factories in Quebec.

The key products

From Shire

Adderall Controversial treatment for attention deficit disorder, prescribed to millions of hyperactive children in the US

Reminyl New drug for Alzheimer's disease, originally formulated from daffodils

Carbatrol Rapidly growing treatment for bone marrow disease

Lambda New treatment for kidney failure, recently delayed by US regulators

From BioChem Pharma

3TC/Epivir Leading therapy for HIV which has dramatically cut the number of pills patients need to take daily

Zeffix Hepatitis B drug largely targeted at Asia, marketed by Glaxo Wellcome

Pacis Bladder cancer medicine, launched this year

Fluviral Flu vaccine used for large-scale immunisations, produced on eggs

fields.headline: UK slips down profits league
fields.trailText: Britain has slipped from second to fifth place in an international league table of company profitability, dragged down by the performance of the manufacturing sector, according to a study published yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain has slipped from second to fifth place in an international league table of company profitability, dragged down by the performance of the manufacturing sector, according to a study published yesterday.

The fall in industrial profits was partly due to the strength of sterling and a sharp increase in raw material costs, especially oil, said Richard Walton, who compiled the report for the Office of National Statistics. But it also reflected a failure to invest as much in IT as other countries did, he added.

The study found that the net rate of return on capital fell to 12% in 1999 after averaging between 12.8% and 12.9% in the previous three years.

It was the weakest performance by the UK corporate sector, excluding financial services companies, since 1994.

In manufacturing the average rate of return dropped from 11% in 1997 to 6% in the second quarter of 2000.

Margins for manufacturing were reported to have been cut, both in home and export markets.

But other countries, such as the US, managed to increase manufacturing profits despite also facing exchange rate and oil price pressures. Countries with high investment in IT also did well.

In Finland, for example, which has been at the forefront of the IT boom, the return on capital for manufacturers rose to 16.3% in 1999 from 3.3% in 1991.

There the success of Nokia, the world's largest producer of mobile phones, and some highly profitable "old economy" pulp and paper companies contributed to the increase.

"Finnish companies have outstripped the US and the rest of the EU in applying for patents for high technology applications, and they score highest in business expenditure on research and development," said Mr Walton.

His study also found that although UK service sector profitability fell last year and in the first half of this year, it remained relatively robust.

webTitle: Coats Viyella heirs take axe to workforce

fields.headline: Coats Viyella heirs take axe to workforce
fields.trailText: Senior managers who paid £10m buying out the clothing division of Coats Viyella last week are to axe 1,200 of its 2,000 British jobs before Christmas - further fallout from the problems at Marks & Spencer.
fields.body:
Senior managers who paid £10m buying out the clothing division of Coats Viyella last week are to axe 1,200 of its 2,000 British jobs before Christmas - further fallout from the problems at Marks & Spencer.

Factories are to be closed in Alfreton, Derbyshire and Sutton in Ashfield, Notting hamshire, by Marplace, the newly created company run by former Coats Viyella managers Richard Tonge and Mike Shotton.

A thousand textile workers in Mauritius, Morocco and Sri Lanka also employed by Marplace will be retained. They are paid as little as £4 a week compared with the £200 a week for UK staff.

A spokesman for Marplace said he regretted the job losses but believed that the anouncement represented an end to the uncertainty that had been hanging over staff for a long time.

The GMB union described the cuts as "disastrous" both for the individuals and the local communities. A union spokesman said that the GMB was seeking urgent talks with management.

The former Coats Viyella business was built around being a major supplier to Marks & Spencer. But before the buyout, Coats Viyella directors told M&S they could no longer compete against lower-cost foreign suppliers.

The Marplace managers had been back to M&S to try to reinstate some of this work but it had already been handed over to a third party.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: The price of goods leaving the factory gates rose to its highest level for six months in November, fuelled by the cost of oil.
fields.body:
Oil prices hit manufacturing

The price of goods leaving the factory gates rose to its highest level for six months in November, fuelled by the cost of oil.

The office for national statistics reported that the annual rate of factory gate inflation in November was 2.9%, the highest rise since June and up from 2.8% in October.

The ONS said the increase was largely because of a rise in the price of petrol products, although this was offset by a decline in motor vehicle prices.

Imperial buys vending firm

Imperial Tobacco said its subsidiary Sinclair Collis has acquired the cigarette vending operations of Mayfair Vending from the TM Group and has agreed to supply tobacco display fixtures to TM retail shops. Imperial is paying approximately £38m for the two transactions, of which approximately £33m was paid on completion and a further £5m is payable over the next four years.

Tomkins adds two directors

Tomkins, the engineering company, said it has appointed Norman Broadhurst and Ken Minton as non-executive directors.

Mr Broadhurst will become chairman of the audit committee, a post formerly held by Ali Wambold. Mr Minton becomes chairman of the remuneration committee, a post formerly held by Roger Holland.

Mannesmann delays float

Mannesmann Arcor, the German fixed-line telecoms unit of mobile phone company Vodafone, said yesterday it had postponed its planned stock market listing indefinitely.

A spokeswoman for Mannesmann Arcor said: "Vodafone and Deutsche Bank want to continue supporting growth." Deutsche Bank has an 8% stake in Arcor. Vodafone is majority shareholder.

Sources said Deutsche Bahn, which has an 18.8% stake in Arcor, was behind the delay in the listing.

OFT invites comment

The office of fair trading is inviting comment on the acquisition of Express Newspapers from United News & Media by Northern and Shell Group to see whether the takeover infringes competition rules.

If the acquisition qualifies for investigation, OFT director general John Bridgeman will consider advising trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers on whether the merger should be referred to the competition commission.

webTitle: Tories left floundering by EU deal

fields.headline: Tories left floundering by EU deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Tony Blair neutralised Europe as the Conservatives' most effective election weapon when he returned from the European Union's Nice summit  yesterday
fields.byline: Michael White  and  Ian Black  in Nice
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday neutralised Europe as the Conservatives' most effective election weapon when he returned from the European Union's Nice summit with a compromise treaty good enough to meet his key political objectives.

Far from paving the way to a European superstate, as his Conservative critics alleged, Mr Blair, Chancellor Schröder of Germany and the summit's host, President Jacques Chirac of France, have reasserted the inter-governmental model for Europe - leaving the Brussels commission in retreat before the national power of the "big three".

In contrast to Tory charges of a sell-out to EU federalism at Westminster, one disappointed Dutch parliamentarian declared that "the French elephant has given birth to a mouse." A French socialist MP dubbed it "a mediocre, disappointing and insufficient deal."

After an unprecedented four days and nights committed to rescuing the much-delayed EU objectives - greater numbers of EU members following enlargement to the east, matched by greater effectiveness - the prime minister proclaimed the summit's success to the Commons in terms which avoided the national triumphalism which marred John Major's pre-election negotiations at Maastricht in 1991.

"It is possible to fight Britain's corner, get the best out of Europe for Britain and exercise real authority and influence in Europe. That is as it should be. Britain is a world power. To stand aside from the key alliance - the EU - right on our doorstep is not advancing Britain's interests. It is betraying them," he insisted.

In exchanges that will set the tone for the election expected in early April or May, William Hague accused Mr Blair and his co-negotiator, the foreign secretary Robin Cook, of a sell-out. "Isn't the truth, when you cut through the spin, that this agreement represents major steps towards a European superstate?" the Conservative leader asked.

Mr Cook retaliated that the Tories were moving further and further apart from any of their "sister" parties in Europe, leaving them the only party in Europe effectively wanting to delay enlargement. Euroscepticism would become an electoral albatross around the party's neck, he warned, while a refusal to adopt the Nice treaty would only play into the hands of ultra-nationalists in the former eastern European countries.

The underlying sub-text of Nice saw much of the summit's energy consumed by battles between the "bigs" and the "smalls" - so much aware that their leverage is being diminished that they staged a Belgium-led revolt which delayed the summit's conclusions until 4.30am yesterday.

As the summiteers left Nice in the early morning, exhausted and irritated by the unseemly pre-dawn haggling and compromises, they could at least claim that the central goal of preparing for enlargement had been achieved.

"Not everything has been done," acknowledged President Chirac just before the agreement on votes. "But we did make substantial progress."

There were expressions of frustration from the European Commission team, dealt a grave blow by the failure to persuade Britain and its allies to remove national vetoes on indirect tax and social security issues - and by the explicit dominance of the big three member states. Romano Prodi, president of the commission, openly lamented the lack of radical reform in the treaty.

"I cannot hide from you a certain regret that we did not manage to go further," he said.

Downing Street said it did not blame France for the bitter and nail-biting denouement, but argued that better pre-planning and discussion would not have wasted the first two days. "We cannot do business like this in the future," Mr Blair said.

One of the few leaders to win plaudits was the Belgian prime minister, Guy Verhofstadt, who brokered the final deal that gave more votes to Lithuania and Romania and saved the summit from disaster. "There were some people around the table -but not many - who were working for the common good of Europe and not for me! for me! for me!" he said. "We fought very hard ... and it is still too little."

Germany, another big winner, was delighted, but said more could have been done.

Applicant nations from former communist eastern Europe were delighted at what was supposed to be the prime motive for the new treaty, which must be finalised and signed next year, then ratified by all 15 existing members.

webTitle: They came to Britain to earn 30p an hour. But they will return home as wealthy men

fields.headline: They came to Britain to earn 30p an hour. But they will return home as wealthy men
fields.trailText: With a thick scarf swaddling his ears from the bitter wind, Suresh Suthar grinned and repeated the one English phrase he recognised: "minimum wage."
fields.body:
With a thick scarf swaddling his ears from the bitter wind, Suresh Suthar grinned and repeated the one English phrase he recognised: "minimum wage."

One of 19 stonemasons brought from a remote, rural corner of northern India in April last year, he and his comrades have been paid a pittance to work on an elaborate Hindu temple under construction in Wembley, north London.

Now, under threat of prosecution, the company that employs them has been forced to raise their wage from 30p an hour to the guaranteed minimum of £3.70.

It is still only a fraction of the £6.35 an hour going rate for British stonemasons, but, with back pay, the Indian workers will get a £110,000 payout.

A delighted Mr Suthar said that his share would go to pay for a "big house" for his wife and children, and perhaps help towards setting up a business in his native province of Dungarpur, in Rajasthan.

The case has highlighted the risks of exploitation faced by foreign workers. Union campaigners spoke yesterday of the "inhuman" conditions in which the men have lived - in cramped, prefabricated huts on the building site with primitive kitchens and squalid toilets.

A clause in the workers' contracts specified that the electricity supply would be cut off each night at 11pm on days when they were not working. Many of them were stripped of their passports and risked being deported if they complained.

On the work permits on which the men were brought from India, they were promised between £160 and £190 a week, plus allowances, food and lodging. With an average annual salary in India of only £275, this was an excellent wage. But they were actually receiving only around £125 for a month of six day weeks. Their wages were paid in rupees to their families in India.

George Brumwell, general secretary of the Union of Construction, Allied Trades and Technicians, said: "We're delighted we've been able to highlight this, but we believe it is the tip of the iceberg in Britain's construction industry.

"We discovered this kind of thing going on as far back as eight years ago, when we found 24 Polish carpenters on a site in Yorkshire being paid £2 an hour and they were living in a steel container."

Mr Brumwell added: "We welcome foreign skilled workers who can make a real contribution to the British economy, but what we won't have is people being ... exploited to line the pockets of employers."

The company building the temple, Shrico, had argued that the men worked for its sister firm in India, which had drawn up the contracts. The men were then seconded to Britain to assemble the intricately carved blocks of stone which make up the temple building.

It is understood that Shrico directors agreed to start paying the minimum wage, and make up the back pay, following the threat of a prosecution by Inland Revenue inspectors.

Shrico is a subsidiary of the Shri Vallabh Nidhi charity, which is being investigated by the Charity Commission relating to "administration and finances, particularly regarding the building of the new temple in Wembley", a spokeswoman said.

In September, the government relaxed rules on foreign workers coming to Britain to fill skills shortages. Under a pilot scheme, multinationals have been allowed to issue their own work permits to foreign staff. There were up to 20,000 applications to the scheme and companies including Rolls-Royce, Ernst & Young and Sony UK have benefited. Howard Ewing, general secretary of the Low Pay Commission, said of the temple workers: "This demonstrates that even if you import your workers and employ them in this country, you have got to pay at least the national minimum wage."

There is concern among Britain's 1m-plus Hindu community that the scandal will tarnish their reputation.

Yesterday, the Wembley temple's leaders seemed to pay little heed to good PR. When two of the workers approached a chainlink fence to speak to reporters, a member of the management committee shouted "get back to work" at them and threw the journalists off the site.

The pubs, grey pavements and double-decker buses of Wembley would have been an exotic sight for the Indian stonemasons, who all hail from the rural province of Dungarpur in the arid northern state of Rajasthan.

A more familiar sight at home are the sacred cows who wander the hot and dusty streets chewing vegetable peel, and the ox carts lugging cargos of timber.

A temple source said: "These are not middle class people. They live in villages which have electricity - but only just about.

"You can see that from what they are going to do with the money. They are going to build proper houses with a good roof, and running water.

"In terms of the global marketplace, these people are towards the bottom."

The men, who practise a skill handed down from father to son, were lured by promises of a wage that was good by Indian standards.

"But when they got here they were virtual prisoners, with their movement restricted and electricity cut off at night," the source said.

Rajasthan is a popular destination for western travellers, and tourist guides describe Dungarpur as an area rich in teak and mango trees and noted for its wildlife.

fields.headline: QMV or veto?
fields.standfirst:
How red lines shifted

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: How red lines shifted
fields.body:
Main policy areas where the national veto has been replaced by qualified majority voting:

 International trade agreements covering most services, investments and intellectual property rights

 External EU border control and certain visa rules - a sensitive area for most member states, therefore many core immigration issues remain subject to unanimity

 Freedom of movement for non-EU nationals in the EU

 Other asylum and immigration rules including the treatment of illegals

 Intra-EU judicial cooperation in civil cases

 Cooperation between home affairs ministries

 Emergency supplies in times of economic crises, natural disasters or force majeure

 Technical measures to speed up introduction of the euro

 Social security provisions to fight social exclusion and modernise social welfare

 State aid for EU industry

 EU regional subsidies/aid for poorer areas known as structural and cohesion funds will be subject to qmv from 2007. A real breakthrough since countries that do best out of current arrangements - Spain, Greece and Portugal - were very reluctant to surrender their vetoes

 Financial and technical cooperation with non-EU states

 Dealings with former French colonies

 Pay and conditions for Euro MPs.

 Pay and conditions governing pan-European political parties

 Rules and pay for the European court of justice

 Rules and pay for the European court of auditors

 General financial control

 Appointments to all EU foreign policy jobs

 Appointment of secretary general and deputy sec gen of the EU's council of ministers

 Appointment of EC president

 Appointment of members of the court of auditors

 Appointment of economic and social committee

 Appointments to the committee of the regions

'Red lines' - areas where member states refused to surrender the veto:

 All tax matters - fearing pan-European harmonisation of national tax and corporate tax rates, the UK, Sweden, Ireland and Luxembourg blocked moves to abandon the veto in fiscal matters.

 Core social security policy - the UK and Sweden were again adamant that they would not give up their vetoes

 Trade issues affecting cultural and audiovisual issues - France dug its heels in to protect the 'unique character' of its film industry

 Regional aid/state subsidies - Spain succeeded in putting off qmv until 2007, so Madrid can secure a generous aid package when the next EU budget is drawn up in 2006

 Core immigration policy - key matters will still be decided by unanimity, with some exceptions. Germany's fear of an influx of poor eastern Europeans across its long border, and Britain's reluctance to give up control of such a sensitive policy area mean countries retain their veto when it really counts
