fields.headline: Depression link to girls' deaths
fields.standfirst: Teenagers who died after party 'may have yearned for South Africa'.
fields.trailText: Teenagers who died after party 'may have yearned for South Africa'.
fields.body:
Two teenage girls found dead in a car in West Sussex after a friend's party may have committed suicide because they were homesick, relatives believe.

Elizabeth Gold, 17, from Crawley and Jennifer Prin, 16, from Balincholligh in County Cork, Ireland, were found in the garage of a house in Crawley early on Sunday. Police are not looking for anyone else and have refused to disclose the contents of notes found at the scene.

The two friends had first met while their families were living in South Africa and continued to visit each other after their parents moved back to the UK and Ireland.

Miss Gold's friend Andrew Sutton, 17, found their bodies in the fume-filled garage of his home in the Pound Hill area of Crawley. A length of hose ran from the exhaust pipe to the car. He had invited the girls to a small party at his house while his parents were away for the weekend.

The family of Miss Prin, the only girl of five children, believe they may have yearned to return to their former home, South Africa.

Her father Bert said last night: "Jenny moved from South Africa to Ireland about 18 months ago. She was homesick and never really settled. One of her South African friends had already moved to Crawley and they used to visit each other.

"There's no reason why they should have committed suicide other than depression."

Her headteacher, Pat Kinsella, said she had been popular and had seemed happy during her studies at her school, Colaiste Cholim.

Miss Gold moved to Crawley in 1997 with her parents, two sisters and three brothers. She seemed to be settling in better than her friend.

Her father Campbell, a writer, said: "Tizzy was very friendly, and outgoing and was always an excellent student. She was counsel to friends and a shoulder to cry on.

"She was looking forward to university and loved travelling. She won many awards and was well-loved by both students and friends both here and in South Africa."

The headmaster of her Roman Catholic school, St Wilfreds, said she had appeared to adjust to her new surroundings very quickly. Bernard Smith described her as "talented, thoughtful and full of life. From her first day in the school she made friends easily."

Miss Gold had taken part in a school pilgrimage to Lourdes, caring for sick and disabled visitors there, and was studying for an A-level in theology as well as English and drama.

Detective Inspector Jason Taylor, who is leading the inquiry, said: "This is a complete tragedy. We are supporting the young people who were at the party and the bereaved parents.

"They are in a deep state of shock. They are very distressed."

fields.headline: Catamaran's crew seek salvage ship
fields.trailText: The Team Philips project has appealed for a vessel to salvage its abandoned £4m catamaran, left to drift in the stormy Atlantic some 750 miles west of Ireland.
fields.body:
The Team Philips project has appealed for a vessel to salvage its abandoned £4m catamaran, left to drift in the stormy Atlantic some 750 miles west of Ireland.

Skipper Pete Goss and his six-man crew yesterday abandoned the carbon fibre racer Team Philips after its steering was damaged by huge waves during sea trials. They are on their way to Halifax, Nova Scotia, on a German container ship.

Their unmanned boat, its drifting slowed by trailing ropes and anchors, would be a valuable salvage prize for any vessel which gets a line on her.

Project manager Mark Orr said they were planning with insurers to salvage the catamaran, a process that could take some days. "We are trying to find a suitable vessel, so if anyone out there has one, please contact us," he said.

Mr Orr said he was aware that if another vessel salvaged the boat, Team Philips would have to pay to get her back.

He declined to comment on one marine expert's estimate that it could cost the project up to £1m if someone else salvaged the catamaran.

He said they were looking at "all options" to get the craft salvaged, adding: "We need to talk to the crew about what damage there was on board."

More bad weather was predicted, which would hamper immediate salvage attempts.

Spokeswoman Patricia Jaurez said the team were not too worried about suggestions that pirate salvagers could try to stake a claim to the catamaran. "It would be very foolish for anyone to go and try to get her," she said. "She is a unique vessel, so it would be impossible without experience to know what she would do.

"Even trying to attach a line to her would be very dangerous, as she is so aerodynamic. We hope anyone who comes across her is sensible."

The catamaran was built at Totnes in Devon for The Race, a no-holds-barred round-the-world event which leaves Barcelona on December 31.

Team Philips will not now take part, but the possibility of entering other events has not been ruled out.

Mr Goss was forced to abandon Team Philips during her fifth sea trial session - her most successful to date, reaching 35 knots in gale force winds and heavy seas.

During the first trial in March a bow snapped off, and during her second in October problems developed with her unstayed 135-foot masts. Then crew member Mike Calvin quit, claiming to go for The Race would be "madness" because of insufficient time to prepare.

When she set sail with on December 2, the racer seemed to have her problems behind her. She clocked up the 2,500 mile qualifying distance for The Race on her toughest voyage yet before disaster struck again.
Press Association

webTitle: No booking, no travel says GNER

fields.headline: No booking, no travel says GNER
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Thousands of potential passengers blocked telephone lines yesterday after a train company said travellers on one of Britain's busiest lines would have to book all seats in advance over Christmas.
fields.body:
Thousands of potential passengers blocked telephone lines yesterday after a train company said travellers on one of Britain's busiest lines would have to book all seats in advance over Christmas.

Great North Eastern Railway, which operates the east coast main line between London and Edinburgh, said all passengers between December 21 and January 3 would have to book to avoid overcrowding when only 40% of normal services were running over Christmas, as a result of restrictions after the Hatfield rail crash. A spokesman said: "We have got to control the numbers or there could be severe overcrowding."

GNER would normally carry 60,000 people a day but is currently able to take 24,000. Within hours of the announcement telesales staff had taken 10,000 reservations.

webTitle: Blair balancing act tips election scales

fields.headline: Blair balancing act tips election scales
fields.standfirst:
Tories left floundering as prime minister succeeds in portraying new treaty as a success

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Tories left floundering as prime minister succeeds in portraying new treaty as a success
fields.body:
Just before dawn broke over the French Riviera yesterday, Tony Blair cleared one of the most difficult hurdles which lie between him and the general election victory - probably on May 3 - that will clinch Labour's elusive second term.

By getting agreement to a treaty of Nice without giving up important national vetoes, he has covered his flank. If there was any remaining doubt at dawn, it was dispelled by William Hague's implausible bombast across the Commons dispatch box after lunch. Despite his exhaustion, Mr Blair was still master of his subject and saw off waves of Tory challengers, notably in an exchange with Mr Hague which may reverberate through the coming campaign.

In it he mocked his rival's political isolation - even among EU conservative parties - and his improbable threat to veto the Nice treaty ("a Conservative government will not ratify it as it stands") because, among other worries, qualified majority voting (QMV) has been conceded on such modest matters as the court of auditors' pensions.

Mr Hague had also called for a referendum on such issues, Mr Blair added. Yet Margaret Thatcher had signed the Single European Act of 1986, which gave up 30 vetoes without a referendum.

"We [the Tories] do not even have [a referendum] on the single currency. But on the vital strategic interest in the pensions of the court of auditors we would all troop off to the polling station."

Cheap, but effective and Labour MPs roared their support. As Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, later said: "The Tory fox on Europe has been well and truly shot". The pro-European Tory MP, David Currie, proclaimed the common interests between the British and German view of Europe's future - a judgment Mr Blair privately shares.

Ministers and their Eurosceptic opponents all know that the arcane details of the new treaty will not cut much ice with most voters. It is one of the complaints frequently made about "Europe" - that much of its debate and most of its clumsy, much-translated language is voter-unfriendly.

But both sides also know that to be seen as "weak" on Europe, unable to defend the national interest or engaged in creating a "superstate" by stealth is a charge that British political leaders feel the need to defend themselves against more than most of their 14 EU counterparts.

In some ways, the situation is like John Major's between the Maastricht treaty negotiation of December 1991 and the April 9 election the following year.

Mr Major got his famous "opt-out" on joining the euro - and won his election, only to see sterling humiliated and his party fatally split on Black Wednesday six months later.

If Mr Blair misjudges his efforts to persuade voters to join the euro-zone (not on the Nice agenda) a similar disaster may engulf him. Given his natural caution, it seems unlikely, though he has become bolder in attacking the Eurosceptic media in recent weeks.

Either way, yesterday's pre-dawn climax of the four-day summit was important to Labour election planners. Mr Blair had gone to the French Mediterranean resort determined to promote enlargement of the EU to the south and east, not least by making its decision-making machinery slimmer and faster.

But he also had to be seen "standing up for Britain's national interest." He had to strike a balance between what he was prepared to give away for the greater EU good and what he would fight to the death to defend.

Reporting to the Commons yesterday after a couple of hours sleep in the West End hotel on the Promenade des Anglais and a quick flight home, the prime minister claimed to have succeeded on both counts.

Newspapers, pundits and rival EU leaders will score him differently today. Some will attack him from the integrationist perspective for reaching such a limited treaty deal, moreover one which reasserts the power of the "bigs" - Germany, France and Britain - over the EU "smalls."

Rather more, especially in the media, will accuse him of a "salami-style" series of concessions that will contribute to "the relentless ratchet of integration" towards the federal Europe they fear.

In yesterday's exchanges, Mr Hague made three specific charges: that the Nice package is "more about integration than enlargement"; that it failed to return more decision-making to nation states; and that it increases EU legislation, not diminishes it.

National interest

Mr Blair duly paid lip service to enlargement - from 15 to 27 - when he faced MPs. But, with an election looming he also stressed the national interest: chiefly "getting more voting strength for the UK" after years when three successive enlargements has eroded the influence of the "big three." By that he meant:

 a larger share of the votes in the council of ministers, 29 out of 237 instead of 10 out of 87, 12.24% instead of 11.49%;

 a higher threshold for a qualified majority vote (QMV) 74% of the 239 votes instead of the current 71.4%, underpinned by 62% of the EU's population;

 23 new areas of QMV voting by EU ministers, mostly about rules of procedure, freedom of movement and the single market, none of them in areas Britain was defending.

For good measure he insisted that the rapid reaction force is not the Euro-army of Tory nightmares.

But Mr Blair's most telling point was that, in effect, the Tories have cried wolf too often since 1997: on border control, the UK rebate, on defence, on the tax and social security vetoes, on economic reform and the famous "withholding tax" on savings. All had been seen off, he said. Provided he is not caught out in the days and months ahead by setbacks more serious than a federalist speech by a German or Italian politician, he should go into the campaign with confidence.

Most polls suggest voters mistrust the EU. But they also suggest it is not a priority. The team player of Nice will want to keep it that way.

It is one of the complaints frequently made about "Europe" - that much of its debate and most of its clumsy, much-translated language is voter-unfriendly. But both sides also know that to be seen as "weak" on Europe, unable to defend the national interest or engaged in creating a "superstate" by stealth is a charge that British political leaders feel the need to defend themselves against more than most of their 14 EU counterparts. In some ways, the situation is like John Major's between the Maastricht treaty negotiation of December 1991 and the April 9 election the following year. Mr Major got his famous "opt-out" on joining the euro - and won his election, only to see sterling humiliated and his party fatally split on Black Wednesday six months later. If Mr Blair misjudges his efforts to persuade voters to join the euro-zone (not on the Nice agenda) a similar disaster may engulf him. Given his natural caution, it seems unlikely, though he has become bolder in attacking the Eurosceptic media in recent weeks. Either way, yesterday's pre-dawn climax of the four-day summit was important to Labour election planners. Mr Blair had gone to the French Mediterranean resort determined to promote enlargement of the EU to the south and east, not least by making its decision-making machinery slimmer and faster. But he also had to be seen "standing up for Britain's national interest." He had to strike a balance between what he was prepared to give away for the greater EU good and what he would fight to the death to defend. Reporting to the Commons yesterday after a couple of hours sleep in the West End hotel on the Promenade des Anglais and a quick flight home, the prime minister claimed to have succeeded on both counts. Newspapers, pundits and rival EU leaders will score him differently today. Some will attack him from the integrationist perspective for reaching such a limited treaty deal, moreover one which reasserts the power of the "bigs" - Germany, France and Britain - over the EU "smalls." Rather more, especially in the media, will accuse him of a "salami-style" series of concessions that will contribute to "the relentless ratchet of integration" towards the federal Europe they fear. In yesterday's exchanges, Mr Hague made three specific charges: that the Nice package is "more about integration than enlargement"; that it failed to return more decision-making to nation states; and that it increases EU legislation, not diminishes it. National interest Mr Blair duly paid lip service to enlargement - from 15 to 27 - when he faced MPs. But, with an election looming he also stressed the national interest: chiefly "getting more voting strength for the UK" after years when three successive enlargements has eroded the influence of the "big three." By that he meant:  a larger share of the votes in the council of ministers, 29 out of 237 instead of 10 out of 87, 12.24% instead of 11.49%;  a higher threshold for a qualified majority vote (QMV) 74% of the 239 votes instead of the current 71.4%, underpinned by 62% of the EU's population;  23 new areas of QMV voting by EU ministers, mostly about rules of procedure, freedom of movement and the single market, none of them in areas Britain was defending. For good measure he insisted that the rapid reaction force is not the Euro-army of Tory nightmares. But Mr Blair's most telling point was that, in effect, the Tories have cried wolf too often since 1997: on border control, the UK rebate, on defence, on the tax and social security vetoes, on economic reform and the famous "withholding tax" on savings. All had been seen off, he said. Provided he is not caught out in the days and months ahead by setbacks more serious than a federalist speech by a German or Italian politician, he should go into the campaign with confidence. Most polls suggest voters mistrust the EU. But they also suggest it is not a priority. The team player of Nice will want to keep it that way. fields.headline: MPs may scrutinise university funding
fields.trailText: MPs are to consider investigating the funding links between universities and big business following the row over British American Tobacco's sponsorship of two institutions.
fields.body:
MPs are to consider investigating the funding links between universities and big business following the row over British American Tobacco's sponsorship of two institutions.

Barry Sheerman, chairman of the Commons education committee, will recommend a short investigation when the all-party body tomorrow discusses its future sessions.

His intervention follows Nottingham University's decision to take £3.8m from BAT to open a centre for corporate social responsibility and the acceptance by the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology of £50,000 for a master's degree course.

Academics, medical groups, anti-smoking campaigners and an MP have voiced opposition, while Nottingham in particular has insisted the deal complies with sponsorship rules agreed by the Cancer Research Campaign and vice-chancellors. Mr Sheerman, Labour MP for Huddersfield, said: "Before leaping to judgment I would like to see precisely how the two cases, Nottingham and Umist, sit with the Cancer Research Campaign and universities' guidelines."

BAT, accused of exploiting tobacco smuggling in Britain and abroad, is under investigation by the Department of Trade and Industry, but denies breaking any laws.

At least four universities have said no to tobacco firms.

Newcastle University turned down on ethical grounds a substantial grant from a cigarette company within the past six months. Birmingham University and Imperial College London have also rejected approaches from tobacco manufacturers. In June last year a Bath University research team, funded by BAT, decided not to seek further funds.

fields.headline: Europe points finger at Chirac
fields.standfirst:
French leader blamed for bad atmosphere

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: French leader blamed for bad atmosphere
fields.body:
A few hours after the marathon five-day Nice summit ended, even its not-so-genial, puffed-up host, President Jacques Chirac, could only muster the word "acceptable" to describe the shambolic proceedings.

It may be that Europe's leaders went to Nice in a frame of mind that ensured the end result would fall far short of expectations. But for many, Mr Chirac - variously described as mercurial, arrogant, inconsiderate, self-interested and a bully - bears a large part of the blame.

He managed to infuriate just about every non-French politician, diplomat and journalist with whom he came into contact. He wasted much of the first two days in rehearsing positions that were already clear from his tour of EU capitals over the previous weeks.

"This guy, he talks, he talks, he talks," Guy Verhofstadt, the Belgian prime minister, said to his Danish colleague, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, at one stage, before realising that the cameras were still rolling.

Wim Kok, the Dutch prime minister, was equally disheartened by Mr Chirac's bullying bonhomie and single-minded pursuit of France's national interests during Friday's bilateral confessional meetings.

Mr Chirac upset Britain with his continued attempts to force Tony Blair to drop his tax veto demands and annoyed his German counterpart, Gerhard Schröder, further straining already tense Franco-German rela tions. "Good relations? What good relations?" Mr Schröder was reported to have asked.

Mr Chirac also offended the president of the European commission, Romano Prodi, by shutting him out of key summit bilateral meetings and criticising him in front of fellow leaders for alleged mismanagement of the mad cow crisis.

One German diplomat, who wanted to remain nameless, said: "This whole thing, this summit, is being run according to the rules of a Middle-Eastern bazaar."

The German press was vitriolic. "Never was a summit conference so miserably prepared, rarely did one feel so little of the European spirit as during the days and nights at Nice," commented the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung.

Mr Chirac may yet suffer on the domestic stage once the French public realises that the compromise rule agreed with Germany enables Berlin to block EU decisions by allying itself with Italy and Britain.

But for many, the Nice summit will go down in history as a reflection of the man who presided over it: illogical, irrational, given to tantrums, keen to score political points, preoccupied with national concerns - and bereft of any grand vision of Europe.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • When will those who Mr Tony Blair and myself dismiss as "the sneerers" stop putting it around that New Labour lacks heart? Sylvia Parsons contacts us from Nottingham about a letter from the party, signed by Lord Healey, that arrived on her 65th birthday. An old Labour type who first canvassed in 1945, Sylvia was touched by Denis's references to Keir Hardie, the NHS and other Labour achievements. "Would you," went on Lord H, coming to the point, "remember them in your will with a legacy to the Labour party?"
fields.body:
 When will those who Mr Tony Blair and myself dismiss as "the sneerers" stop putting it around that New Labour lacks heart? Sylvia Parsons contacts us from Nottingham about a letter from the party, signed by Lord Healey, that arrived on her 65th birthday. An old Labour type who first canvassed in 1945, Sylvia was touched by Denis's references to Keir Hardie, the NHS and other Labour achievements. "Would you," went on Lord H, coming to the point, "remember them in your will with a legacy to the Labour party?"

Marvellous. Now the kids at Millbank have programmed the computer to spit out begging letters to members when they reach 65. But this is only the start: surely there's a way of accessing the NHS's central database so that members of whatever age are tapped as soon as a life-threatening illness is diagnosed. As for Sylvia, who recently let her membership lapse, she was considering bequests even before Lord Healey's letter arrived. "I'm thinking of leaving them my socialist principles," she explains. "Them and the 75p increase for pensioners."

 Interviewed in the Daily Telegraph Lady Victoria Hervey, the Sunday Times columnist who makes Tara P-T read like Maya Angelou, raises fresh concerns about an old friend. Last month she appeared on the front page of the Sun when one of her nipples (we forget which) was caught on camera at a charity do. It was not a total shock, admits Victoria, because the alopecian Sun editor rang her at home to warn her in advance. "Actually he has got a crush on me. He keeps calling me up," blurts Victoria looking a little worried. "He tells me that all the pictures of me keep disappearing off desks in the office." And people say romance is dead. Watch yourself, Slappy lad. Watch yourself.

A schism develops between our two best-loved TV political editors, but thank God it's only cosmetic. About to broadcast live from outside No 10 recently, Andrew Marr's Macaulay-Culkin-style love lock was flapping across his forehead. Someone said: "Hang on, it's OK, he can borrow John Sergeant's hairspray." But the butch BBC man wasn't having it and used some spit instead. As you can see, ITN's Mr Sergeant takes a different approach, and last week in Selfridge's approached the cosmetics counter.
"I'd like some make-up please," he said.
"Yes, of course, dear, that's fine," replied the sales assistant, smiling knowingly.
"No, you don't understand. I'm John Sergeant from ITN."
"Yes, dear, of course," said the woman, reassuringly. "We're not here to judge."

 To the list of candidates for the Turncoat of Turncoats competition, regretfully we must add Chris Mullin. Chris, Chris, Chris, whatever happened to you - a fine campaigning journalist with a decent heart and a nice, self-effacing manner. There is no room for sentiment, however, not in this game, and for taking charge of selling off air traffic control, Chris takes his place alongside Clare Bomber Short, Peter Hain, Cookie and the rest.

 Our first Turncoat nomination arrives, meanwhile, from Derek Middlemiss. "I was attending a black tie dinner in London recently when I found myself in the Gents toilets with Paul Boateng," Derek reports. "Making idle conversation I said 'Don't you feel like a prat dressed up like this?' 'No actually I don't,' he replied. I rest my case."

 And my thanks to the three costume designers who have volunteered to make the coat (red with 30 yellow circles for pieces of silver on one side; yellow with red rectangles for red boxes on the other). Barley Massey, Jan Whitfield and Zoe Taylor have all applied for the £250-plus materials commission. Frankly, I have no idea how to resolve this Judgment of Paris, so perhaps the fairest thing is to ask them to make one each - a large one for the winner, and two smaller ones for the runners-up.

webTitle: Nice: Nerve-racking end to tiring, tortuous talks

fields.headline: Belgian hero broke deadlock
fields.standfirst:
Nerve-racking end to tiring, tortuous talks
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: It was 4.15 in the morning when the deal was finally done, and for the Nice summiteers, pale and drained by hours of brutal bargaining, it was not a moment too soon.
fields.body:
It was 4.15 in the morning when the deal was finally done, and for the Nice summiteers, pale and drained by hours of brutal bargaining, it was not a moment too soon.

Guy Verhofstadt, the boyish Belgian prime minister, was the one who claimed triumph in a nerve-racking finish that had teetered precariously between failure and what in the end passed for success - of a kind.

As the 15 heads of government and their senior aides thrashed out the agreement in the Acropolis conference centre, it was becoming the longest EU summit ever held. Each time a new draft paper emerged, spokesmen were mobbed by journalists. In the event, it was another French proposal, rejigging carefully balanced voting weights, that did the trick.

Yet few could make sense of the complex arithmetical formulae used to decide the number of votes member states would have under the planned reforms - or how fair they were. "We've got the software," snarled one official. "You haven't."

By the end, it was the overall exhaustion that was the most striking feature of the weary Nice endgame. Hubert Vedrine, the French foreign minister, insisted that things were moving, albeit glacially slowly: "You get the impres sion of being on a tow path, and we're playing the part of the barge horses."

But there was some light in the darkness: Belgium, a founder member and champion of the small states, was frustrated that both the maths and the politics of the emerging deal meant that the Netherlands stood to get one more vote than itself.

So, plumping for that rare thing, altruism, Mr Verhofstadt's tough talk wrung more votes for candidates Romania - discriminated against in relation to other enlargement candidates - and Lithuania, two votes behind Ireland, with a similar population.

"Verhofstadt is the hero of the night," exulted Pavo Lipponen, the prime minister of Finland. "We owe the treaty of Nice to the Belgian prime minister," said Brian Cowen, the Irish foreign minister.

Relieved applause broke out from presidents and prime ministers when agreement was reached. Jacques Chirac, the host, who had to be in Paris within a few hours to see Nelson Mandela, declared: "It's been long and tiring but it's been a success."

But even then, there was confusion over exactly what had been agreed: final texts were still being examined yesterday, just to make sure no errors had crept in.

No wonder then, that aside from claiming triumph, Tony Blair had one practical comment as he went off for a few hours rest in his hotel before flying to London: "As far as Europe is concerned," he said, "we cannot do business like this in the future." If that message gets through, Nice will have had one very useful outcome.

webTitle: How big powers won big benefits

fields.headline: How big powers won big benefits
fields.standfirst:
Defeat and humiliation for integrationists

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Defeat and humiliation for integrationists
fields.body:
Histories of the European Union will remember the Nice summit as a landmark moment when big governments won the big arguments - and left the integrationists reeling and humiliated at their loss of power.

That much was clear in the early hours of yesterday morning, when exhausted leaders emerged pale and blinking from their marathon talks with a new treaty that delivers only modest reforms except in one area - confirming the unassailable dominance of the largest member states.

Germany, Britain, and France, with the required 62% of the EU's total population, can now form a "directory" able to block virtually anything they want as the enlargement process gets under way.

Re-weighting votes in the decision-making council of ministers - where the 15 governments cooperate to make policy - sets in concrete the drift towards a Europe not only of nation states, but of the biggest players in the bloc.

Nice thus confirmed a trend evident for some time: at last March's Lisbon economic summit, prime ministers set a liberalising reform agenda and left the European Commission to play little more than a back-up role.

In the summer, as leaders competed to make visionary speeches about the future of the union, France's Jacques Chirac failed to even mention the commission - the EU's unique supranational element where members agree to pool some sovereignty for the common good.

Instead, to the horror of its battered president, Romano Prodi, the Gaullist president talked of a "secretariat" to service a "pioneer group" of big countries.

It has not quite come to that, because the EU means different things to different people. Tony Blair signed up to a clause allowing "flexibility" so that integrationist-minded states which wish to act on their own can do so, as long as fundamentals like the single market are unaffected.

Nice's advance on "reinforced cooperation" in Brussels jargon means, crucially, that the 12 members of the single currency cannot create new institutions that exclude non-participants like Britain, Denmark and Sweden.

Mr Blair achieved most of what he set out in his recent Warsaw speech, when he linked institutional reforms to enlargement and advocated a bigger role for the council.

Another big player, Gerhard Schröder, under pressure from Germany's federal states, got what he needed: a new intergovernmental conference in 2004 - a constitutional review, in other words - of the delimitation of powers between Brussels and national capitals. Future summits - at Goteborg in Sweden and Laeken in Belgium - will work out the contentious details. Chancellor Schröder also won more power, but without having to bludgeon France into conceding that Germany's greater population size should mean that it has more votes.

Nice's biggest loser is without doubt Mr Prodi, the former Italian prime minister chosen to head the commission after last year's sleaze scandals.

"I cannot hide from you a certain regret that we did not manage to go further," he said bravely. Five days haggling on the Riviera did remove some of what Mr Prodi calls the "manacles" of the national veto. Moves to majority voting in some 25-30 areas will help speed decision-making, with immigration matters (not affecting opt-out Britain) at the top of the list.

Other articles will move to majority voting, but there are snags: Spain, backed by Portugal and Greece, ensured that funds for poorer states would be allocated by majority voting only from 2007, after the next EU budget in 2006, which runs for six years. That postpones real change until 2013. Worse still for Brussels, Nice excludes Britain's no-go areas of majority voting on indirect taxes in the single market and social security measures to facilitate the free movement of people.

Jacques Chirac, who had repeated spats with Mr Prodi, held firm on trade policy, agreeing to drop his veto in new areas but excepting France's film and audio-visual industry to protect it from Hollywood and the global competition.

Pascal Lamy, the trade commissioner, thus failed to see the union equipped with a single position for key negotiations with the World Trade Organisation. Small countries will regret the outcome: true, they held on to their commissioner, but in a battle whose terms were dictated by the big three states, they allowed themselves to be picked off.

Members of the European Parliament were unhappy too as agreement to raise the previous threshold of MEPs to a record 740 reinforced the impression that it is little more than a consolation prize.

Parliament has no power to throw out EU treaties, but Italy and Belgium have signalled that they will listen to its views when ratification comes round. Elmar Brok, a leading Christian Democrat, was scathing about the Riviera endgame: "It will be more difficult to get a majority and makes procedure more difficult," he concluded grimly. "The whole system becomes more and more complicated. I cannot see how citizens can understand it."

It has not quite come to that, because the EU means different things to different people. Tony Blair signed up to a clause allowing "flexibility" so that integrationist-minded states which wish to act on their own can do so, as long as fundamentals like the single market are unaffected. Nice's advance on "reinforced cooperation" in Brussels jargon means, crucially, that the 12 members of the single currency cannot create new institutions that exclude non-participants like Britain, Denmark and Sweden. Mr Blair achieved most of what he set out in his recent Warsaw speech, when he linked institutional reforms to enlargement and advocated a bigger role for the council. Another big player, Gerhard Schröder, under pressure from Germany's federal states, got what he needed: a new intergovernmental conference in 2004 - a constitutional review, in other words - of the delimitation of powers between Brussels and national capitals. Future summits - at Goteborg in Sweden and Laeken in Belgium - will work out the contentious details. Chancellor Schröder also won more power, but without having to bludgeon France into conceding that Germany's greater population size should mean that it has more votes. Nice's biggest loser is without doubt Mr Prodi, the former Italian prime minister chosen to head the commission after last year's sleaze scandals. "I cannot hide from you a certain regret that we did not manage to go further," he said bravely. Five days haggling on the Riviera did remove some of what Mr Prodi calls the "manacles" of the national veto. Moves to majority voting in some 25-30 areas will help speed decision-making, with immigration matters (not affecting opt-out Britain) at the top of the list. Other articles will move to majority voting, but there are snags: Spain, backed by Portugal and Greece, ensured that funds for poorer states would be allocated by majority voting only from 2007, after the next EU budget in 2006, which runs for six years. That postpones real change until 2013. Worse still for Brussels, Nice excludes Britain's no-go areas of majority voting on indirect taxes in the single market and social security measures to facilitate the free movement of people. Jacques Chirac, who had repeated spats with Mr Prodi, held firm on trade policy, agreeing to drop his veto in new areas but excepting France's film and audio-visual industry to protect it from Hollywood and the global competition. Pascal Lamy, the trade commissioner, thus failed to see the union equipped with a single position for key negotiations with the World Trade Organisation. Small countries will regret the outcome: true, they held on to their commissioner, but in a battle whose terms were dictated by the big three states, they allowed themselves to be picked off. Members of the European Parliament were unhappy too as agreement to raise the previous threshold of MEPs to a record 740 reinforced the impression that it is little more than a consolation prize. Parliament has no power to throw out EU treaties, but Italy and Belgium have signalled that they will listen to its views when ratification comes round. Elmar Brok, a leading Christian Democrat, was scathing about the Riviera endgame: "It will be more difficult to get a majority and makes procedure more difficult," he concluded grimly. "The whole system becomes more and more complicated. I cannot see how citizens can understand it." fields.headline: Iraq levies oil surcharge
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Iraq threw down a new challenge to the United Nations yesterday by announcing that anyone who wants to buy its oil will have to pay a 40-cent surcharge on each barrel directly into an Iraqi bank account.
fields.body:
Iraq threw down a new challenge to the United Nations yesterday by announcing that anyone who wants to buy its oil will have to pay a 40-cent surcharge on each barrel directly into an Iraqi bank account.

Earlier in the day, however, Iraq had written to the UN, agreeing to its terms for the next phase of the oil-for-food programme.

In the letter the foreign minister, Mohammed Saeed al-Sahhaf, said Iraq was accepting the terms "so that our behaviour is not seen as negative and to expose further those with bad intentions".

But oil supplies did not resume as expected yesterday. Iraqi sources at first attributed this to bad weather in the Gulf and a lack of tankers at Ceyhan, Iraq's outlet on the Turkish coast.

Iraq cut off its exports - about 5% of the world's total - on December 1 after UN overseers rejected Baghdad's pro posal to charge less than the market price. By reducing its official prices, Iraq had hoped to be able to levy a 50-cent-a-barrel surcharge on customers, payable to an account outside the UN's control.

This would have diverted about $420m (£290m) a year from the oil-for-food programme into the pockets of the Saddam Hussein regime.

When Iraq accepted the UN's terms yesterday, dealers initially assumed that it had abandoned the surcharge plan - only to see it return at 40 cents rather that 50.

"No way are we going to be turning a blind eye to this," a diplomat at the UN in New York said last night.

In London, the Foreign Office said it regarded the surcharge as illegal and expected customers would refuse to pay it.

"We are not unduly concerned, because the International Energy Agency has said recent developments should not be exaggerated and major oil-producing countries have declared their readiness to meet any serious international oil shortages," a spokesman said.

Even so, the continued stoppage helped push North Sea oil prices up 82 cents to $27.40 (£19) after a $6.50 slump during the past two weeks.

Iraq is also seeking to divert €1bn (£610m) from the oil-for-food programme during the next 12 months to support the Palestinians in their conflict with Israel.

The UN's position is that revenue from the programme should be used to feed the Iraqi people and compensate victims of the 1990 invasion of Kuwait, not to support the Palestinians.

To allow payments to Palestinians through the oil-for-food programme would require a special security council resolution, a Foreign Office spokesman said last night.

In the absence of that, Iraq may try to allocate part of the surcharge for this purpose - in effect imposing a "Palestine tax" on oil companies.

webTitle: Tories hit at 'big lie' over the number of nurses

fields.headline: Tories hit at 'big lie' over the number of nurses
fields.trailText: Conservative and Labour health spokesmen accused each other yesterday of lying about the number of nurses needed to implement the NHS plan.
fields.body:
Conservative and Labour health spokesmen accused each other yesterday of lying about the number of nurses needed to implement the NHS plan.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, said Tony Blair's promise in July to recruit 20,000 more nurses by 2004 had been exposed as a complete fabrication.

He seized on a workforce analysis by the Royal College of Nursing suggesting that the 20,000 would include part-timers. If the government had presented its figures as full time equivalents, the proposed increase in staffing would have been between a quarter and a third smaller - easier to achieve, but less likely to be sufficient.

"Labour have constantly given the impression that the 20,000 will be working full time. Now the government has been forced to back-track into admitting they are nothing of the sort," Dr Fox said.

"Labour have lied in previous NHS announcements, with triple accounting about funding and double counting of doctors. Now they have been caught out on nurse recruitment. It is difficult to see how anything the government says on health can now be trusted.

"There is an increasing gap between the NHS that ministers talk about and the real NHS which nurses work in and patients are treated by," he said.

The first response from the Department of Health was to deny that the extra nurses were presented as full-timers. "We have made repeatedly clear to media and the nursing profession that our 20,000 target is a headcount figure. As whole-time equivalents usually make up around 65%-75% of a headcount figure, that equates to about 12-15,000 whole time equivalents."

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, capped this by accusing Dr Fox of inventing "the big lie" to undermine the NHS plan and prejudice the public against state provision for health.

The RCN report said the NHS would need to fill 110,000 vacancies by 2004. If retirements and other staff losses continued at their current rates the service would need to find 90,000 replacements before embarking on recruitment of the extra 20,000 promised by the prime minister.

With 53,000 new nurses expected to qualify over the next four years, the government would have to find 57,000 more by recruiting overseas or tempting back some of the 70,000 registered nurses who have left the profession.

The warning came a week before ministers publish recommendations from the nurses' pay review body.

 Few GP practices carry out even the most basic of checks on locums they employ, allowing incompetent or bogus doctors potentially to pick up temporary work where they could damage patients, acccording to the Consumers' Association.

Research by the association reinforces the concerns spelled out recently by the audit commission and which the government has promised to address. The association interviewed locums and the surgeries that take them on. They found that vetting was poor, too much rested of word of mouth, recruitment agencies could not be relied on to make necessary checks, and locums themselves were unhappy with the situation.

A survey in Health Which?, published by the association, found that 13% of the locums questioned were asked for their references the last time they worked in a new GP surgery. Only 4% were asked for proof of their identity and less than a third were asked to provide a copy of their CV.

Even though it is illegal for surgeries to employ locums who do not have the right GP qualifications, only 37% of locums were asked for proof of GP training. Fifty eight per cent were asked about medical defence insurance and a similar number for proof of GMC registration without which no doctor can practise.

webTitle: Search resumes for body of estate agent

fields.headline: Search resumes for body of estate agent
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating the disappearance of Suzy Lamplugh, the estate agent abducted and presumed murdered in 1986, yesterday began searching land where they believe her body may have been buried.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating the disappearance of Suzy Lamplugh, the estate agent abducted and presumed murdered in 1986, yesterday began searching land where they believe her body may have been buried.

A Metropolitan police search team yesterday began examining several acres of land and a lake on the site of a former brickworks near the village of Norton, Worcestershire. More than 30 officers, with search dogs, forensic archaeologists and divers, began a fingertip search of fields, a copse and a lake which was expected to last between three and five days.

Ms Lamplugh, 25, was abducted in July 1986 after going to meet a client known only as Mr Kipper at a property in Fulham, West London. The murder investigation was reopened by police in May after new witnesses reported sighting Ms Lamplugh.

Her white Ford Fiesta, found abandoned a mile from the property, and another car recovered from a scrap yard have been subjected to forensic examination including DNA testing techniques not available at the time of her disappearance.

Last week police questioned John Cannan, a murderer serving life in Full Sutton prison in North Yorkshire, for five days.

Cannan became a suspect when a former girlfriend alleged that he had told her he had dumped Ms Lamplugh's body near the M5 motorway, which overlooks the search area. Detective Superintendent Shaun Sawyer, leading the investigation, stressed yesterday that the decision to search the land in Norton was not connected with the questioning of Cannan but confirmed he was still a suspect.

Explaining the decision to search the area, Mr Sawyer said: "During the past year we have reassessed the original inquiry's information and there has been some speculation that Norton may have been involved as a deposition site for Suzy's body.

"The original inquiry team looked at the site and another site at Norton barracks, but there was insufficient detailed information to justify a search. Time has moved on and critically the technology that is available has moved on too."

The search team has compared aerial photographs and ordnance survey maps dating from the mid-1980s and used GPS satellite positioning technology to establish which features of the land visible today were present at the time of Ms Lamplugh's disappearance.

The brickworks area is adjoined by a freight transport warehouse and three car parks built in the past five years. The site used to be crossed by a "lovers' lane" which is no longer visible. Officers crawled across a field adjoining the site of the brickworks as divers searched the lake.

Mr Sawyer said police would not search the barracks area, now a housing complex. The search will resume today.

fields.headline: Taunting robber jailed for 11 years
fields.trailText: An armed robber who taunted police while on the run abroad with postcards bragging about the £16,000 he stole from a supermarket was jailed for 11 years yesterday.
fields.body:
An armed robber who taunted police while on the run abroad with postcards bragging about the £16,000 he stole from a supermarket was jailed for 11 years yesterday.

Darren Protheroe, 22, unemployed, from Swansea, sent photographs of himself to the head of Swansea CID.

Protheroe stole the cash after threatening staff with a starter pistol and handcuffing them to a safe in July. The next day he flew to Spain with his girlfriend for a holiday and spent two months spending the money he had stolen.

He could not resist taunting police with a series of snaps showing him living the high life. In one, he positioned £4,000 of cash and jewellery on a bed with a note on the back saying "Is this enough evidence for you?"

On the back of another picture, showing him partying with a group of friends, he wrote: "I'm a naughty boy, a 100% outlaw. I'm one of a kind - unstoppable." The photos were taken from various holiday resorts.

Protheroe was arrested when he ran out of money and returned to Swansea to live in a homeless hostel called the Lodge. When police arrested him in September he could not resist one last taunt and asked them why it had taken so long to catch him.

Swansea crown court heard that Protheroe hid in a cupboard of the CK's supermarket at Penclawdd, near Swansea, until the shop closed.

He waited until two female staff went upstairs to count the takings before telling two 16-year-old male employees he would shoot them in the legs if they did not do what he said.

After forcing them to lay face down on the floor he ran upstairs and demanded the two women hand over the weekend's takings. He handcuffed them to the office safe.

His lawyer Elwen Evans called taunting the police "immature bravado".

Judge Huw Williams said: "It is your youth and insecurity which drives you to compulsory showing off. Your target was a vulnerable one. Two women and two 16-year-old boys. Those four people had no time to prepare themselves."

Protheroe, of the Lodge, Swansea, was jailed for 11 years for burglary, robbery, possession of an offensive weapon and a drugs offence.

fields.headline: A fishy tale
fields.standfirst: The sturgeon has a high price on its head, which is endangering its survival. Jerome Monahan  reports
fields.trailText: The sturgeon has a high price on its head, which is endangering its survival. Jerome Monahan reports.
fields.body:
Scientists meeting in America have discussed the fate of some of the planet's most threatened creatures. Last week, they gathered at a special "animals session" of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (Cites, pronounced "sightease"). High on their list were several types of a fish called sturgeon - at risk because, when carefully salted, the females' unfertilised eggs become caviar, a top luxury food.

In recent years, an international business in smuggled caviar has developed. This has encouraged illegal over-fishing in and around the Caspian Sea (to the north of Iran) where 90% of the world's caviar comes from. Stocks of sturgeon in this region have fallen so much that some experts think they will die out there in as little as three years. But deciding what to do about the problem has not been easy.

There are 155 countries signed up to Cites. It is one of the largest conservation agreements in existence. Under its rules, particularly rare wild plants and animals such as apes and tigers can get Appendix I registration. This bans all international trade in them. Since 1997, sturgeon products have been in Appendix II. This means someone wanting to export a Caspian sturgeon (or its caviar) has to get a special permit from the country where it was caught. There are five countries involved - Iran and four states created by the collapse of the Soviet Union (Russia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan). They set limits (quotas) on the amount of sturgeon that can be caught and processed within their borders.

It would help if all these countries' quotas could be trusted but they are very doubtful, since they only refer to sturgeon products meant for legal export. Fish caught and eaten locally are not part of the calculation. It is estimated, for example, that Russians get through between three and five times more sturgeon than the authorities allow to go abroad.

Also, the quotas do not stop the illegal caviar production and smuggling controlled by powerful criminal gangs. Since 1998, 1,300 kilos of unlicensed caviar imports have been seized by UK customs alone. Perhaps the only proper solution is a recommendation from the Cites animal committee that sturgeon receive Appendix I status.

According to the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) an Appendix I listing only makes sense if the governments of the countries around the Caspian do everything they can to protect sturgeon stocks and clamp down on criminals. For example, the so-called caviar pirates often use fine mesh nets that cover hundreds of kilometres of sea and result in the destruction of many immature fish.

It can take a female Beluga sturgeon 25 years to produce her first eggs. Other dangers faced by the Caspian sturgeon that need tackling include pollution from the region's industries and dams that prevent the fish reaching their up-river egg-laying sites (spawning grounds).

But does it really matter if these creatures vanish? Yes, say scientists. Sturgeon have been swimming in the seas for over 250m years and as the world's largest freshwater fish - some live for 150 years and reach six metres in length - they have an important part to play in their biological environment (ecosystem). Yes, say the legal fishermen who have been earning a living from Caspian sturgeon for centuries. It takes 15 years' training to grasp the proper caviar-making process - one explanation for its rarity and expense. Whole communities that depend on this ancient trade will vanish if the fish goes.

Sadly, Caspian sturgeon have much in common with other endangered species. Their rarity only adds to their value, making them attractive to illegal hunters often driven by extreme poverty. Also, their survival depends on countries in which poorly funded local police forces are vulnerable to bribes and death threats and lack the equipment needed to protect animal species.

Meanwhile, for those rich enough to have developed a taste for the stuff, this Christmas a London store is selling a kilo of the rarest caviar for £3,950. Who knows what price they will have to pay soon, if a ban causes legal supplies to dry up and nothing effective is done to halt the criminals fishing the Caspian sturgeon to extinction.

 With thanks to Sabri Zain of Traffic International

Curriculum links and activities: KS3 English (En1, En2, En3)
Research your library or the internet for resources to back a class discussion or assembly about the work of Cites and the trade in endangered species. Write a letter to a friend telling them to stop keeping exotic species, and their reply. Design a leaflet explaining the dangers of the trade in rare and endangered species.

Science KS3 (Sc1, Sc2)
Assess the evidence suggesting a need for controls on the caviar trade. Study the life processes governing the survival of sturgeon in their environment. In particular: the importance of sustainable development and the factors affecting animal population sizes.

Geography KS3
Breadth of study - ecosystems/ populations and resources

webTitle: Education: Learning about air traffic control

fields.headline: Taking control of air traffic
fields.standfirst: Air traffic control is to be part-privatised despite much opposition.  John Crace examines the issues
fields.trailText: Air traffic control is to be part-privatised despite much opposition. John Crace examines the issues.
fields.body:
The government's bill to part-privatise the air traffic control system (Nats) will finally go ahead in three months' time. It has been opposed by some of its own back benchers in the House of Commons and was initially rejected by the House of Lords. The Lords finally passed the bill after the transport minister agreed to further consultation. Under the proposals for part-privatisation, 46% of Nats will be sold into private hands, 5% will go to Nats employees with the government retaining the other 49%, enabling it to dictate how the company will be operated in the future.

The reasons for

The volume of air travel in the UK is rising by 5% to 6% per year and the government believes that the only way it can realistically raise the £1.4bn needed to update the computer and technological infrastructure necessary to handle the increasing number of air traffic movements is by part-privatisation. Already the new air traffic control centre at Swanwick, Hampshire, is four years late in opening but it is now on schedule to meet its new target date of 2002. Nats fully supports the government proposals, arguing that the cash injection will make it a major player if plans to merge Europe into a single air traffic system go ahead.

The reasons against

Any private partner would expect a return on its investment. Many doubt whether Nats can make a profit without compromising its excellent safety record. They argue that private investors are bound to be looking to cut costs at a time when the computer systems are already under pressure and air traffic controllers are complaining of being overstressed at work.

Curriculum links

Citizenship KS3: 1c) central and local government, the public services they offer and how they are financed, and the opportunities to contribute.
Citizenship KS4: 2a) research a topical political, spiritual, moral, social or cultural issue, problem or event by analysing information from different sources, showing an awareness of the use and abuse of statistics.

fields.headline: Internet know-how
fields.standfirst: Troubleshooting
fields.trailText: Troubleshooting
fields.body:
A recent survey of our readers found that what you wanted most from an ICT column was a guide to sorting out computer-related problems - unjamming paper blocks, retrieving lost data, connecting printers to computers, and all the other glitches.

That might just be possible if everyone used the same brand of computer and printer and the same browsers and programs. And the following advice will, of course, only be of value if your browser is working and you can go online. But several useful sites do exist - make sure the one you're reading applies to the UK, as US hardware often differs from ours.

UK Online's well-written pages are an invaluable starting-point, even if you're not a subscriber. They explain basic problems - "Why did my email bounce back? How do I download a file? The website I'm looking for isn't there ..." - with real clarity.

Printers are often a source of frustration, especially when they jam. If yours is a Hewlett Packard, the support at HP has illustrated advice on clearing paper jams and other common difficulties. Much of the advice at Russ Wright's Canon Support Pages, although Canadian, applies to British Canon printers too. Epson also has dedicated advice, while the Waterwheel guide to troubleshooting printers is basic but generic.

If you haven't even managed to link the printer to the computer, let alone dealt with a breakdown, eHow's guide is the best place to begin. The rest of eHow tackles hundreds of similar themes - buying a mouse, cleaning a scanner, setting up a Macintosh.

Apple and IBM produce their own support guides. Of the two, Apple's is the easier to use and better designed.

If you know the difference between POP3 and SMTP or Netscape 6 and IE5 and simply want to make your desktop faster and more reliable, try Help or ZDNet help.

Lastly, new internet users often worry about cookies - tiny files that some websites store on your hard drive when you visit. If you share this particular worry, Cookie Central explains why they are eschewed by some and ignored by the majority.

fields.headline: Caffeine is not enough
fields.standfirst: Exhausted A-level students need help says Rachel Parker
fields.trailText: Exhausted A-level students need help says Rachel Parker.
fields.body:
Pro plus, caffeine, Red Bull; not the ingredients that would automatically spring to mind when asked what most A-level students need to succeed. Yet this is the unhappy situation many 16- to 18-year-olds find themselves in when faced with the massive workload of A-level studies.

As an A-level student myself, when asked what would help me achieve more the answer is not a simple one of more money for equipment or better tutors. Although these are undoubtedly critical, the real key lies in my mental and physical well-being.

A-level studies are one of the most intensive and highly pressured stages in the educational life of many young people in this country. A typical day for many people is a 7am start, a long and tiring journey to college for 9am. Then lessons for most of the day, homework during your "free" time and the journey home again. Some students do not get home before 6pm, and even when they do, are faced with the prospect of hours of homework.

At an age when many young people are still going through puberty, a time when your social life suddenly expands and becomes immensely complex and time-consuming, the pressure of college and the burden to achieve is extremely tiring. It is no wonder that rates of depression and other mental health disorders are on the rise amongst students.

"Over 20% of the nation's children suffer some degree of mental or emotional problem ... there is evidence that the overall incidence of diagnosed distress is rising," says Mind - the mental health charity.

On top of this, students are also faced with another problem, one that is familiar to us all, that of money. College is expensive. Even for local colleges travel there and back can cost upwards of £200 a year, and that is on a coach service which is subsidised by the college itself. Another drain on finances is food, in my experience buying lunch from college can cost an average of £10-£15 a week.

This is a strain on most family incomes, so often students are forced to get a part-time job as well as being in full-time education. It is no wonder many of my friends and acquaintances have turned to mild stimulants to get them through the day!

How can we be expected to meet our full academic potential as well as leading active and healthy lives when this is what we are reduced to?

So what can be done? The Education Secretary David Blunkett has promised an increase of £600m for the education budget. I feel that to really help young people achieve in this country both academically and socially, it would be money well spent if travel and food were fully subsidised by the government. It will not solve the all the problems for students but it may go some way to reducing the stress and pressure on them and their families.

 Rachel Parker is an A-level student at Winstanley College, Wigan.

fields.headline: Furthermore
fields.standfirst: Francis Beckett seeks a new career - as Chris Woodhead's ghostwriter
fields.trailText: Francis Beckett seeks a new career - as Chris Woodhead's ghostwriter.
fields.body:
Three years after extending his empire into further education, the Ofsted chief resigned, so that he could tell us what he really thinks.

So, beneath that diplomatic, emollient exterior, what does Woodhead really think? A leak on the Daily Telegraph means that I can now reveal his first opinion piece for that paper. You read it first here.

"Mr David Blunkett, the sort of sixties leftist who has got our beloved country into the mess it's in today, has apparently embraced something called 'lifelong learning'. This, I am given to understand, involves taking elderly and retired proletarian persons away from the armchairs and bingo parlours which are their natural habitat, and bringing them into institutions of learning.

Mr Blunkett, who hails from Sheffield and may perhaps not understand the nature of academic rigour, has even allowed himself to be saddled with a Minister for Lifelong Learning. This personage, a Mr Wicks, apparently organised a jolly competition to find Britain's oldest learner, as though learning could be done in some geriatric Butlins, with the lecturing presumably conducted by grinning redcoats.

The winner was a gentleman of 107 who had apparently done rather badly at school, which you would have thought might have told him that education was not for him. Apparently incapable of benefiting from his mistakes, this gentleman failed to realise that it would be courting derision for him to re-enter education in his declining years.

According to Mr Wicks' press release, the old gentleman claimed that his early academic failure was caused by the fact that the authorities tied one of his hands behind his back in a bid to stop him from being left-handed. This is exactly the sort of excuse that I used to hear when I was Her Majesty's Chief Inspector. Such irrelevancies as poverty, hunger and violent parents were regularly trotted out as excuses for academic failure.

Salus populi suprema est lex. For excuses for failure are precisely what are now being made by some of those who masquerade as lecturers.

When I was Chief Inspector, I offended the ragged army of the politically correct by describing media studies courses as 'vacuous'. I now regret having used up so useful a word, for it leaves me speechless to describe the courses I find in just one college prospectus: Media, Communication and Production; Multi Media and Performing Arts; Popular Music.

Such subjects do not require teaching in an academic establishment. They require explaining, in words of one syllable, to the people whose ignorance and unfitness for better work obliges them to labour in such fields. Such persons have no place in colleges.

Neither have most of our present lecturers. Clearly we need to change both the teachers and the students. It is not sufficiently well known that there is a network of private sixth-form colleges, the equivalent of the private schools whose conference I regularly attended as Chief Inspector. I think it a fair guess no student of popular music would find a place in most of them.

A programme of wholesale privatisation, subjecting colleges to market disciplines, might work a revolution. The fact that substantial fees would then be charged seems to me to be no disadvantage, in fact possibly the reverse. Odi profanum vulgus et arceo."

fields.headline: We got it first!
fields.standfirst: Wales is going to pioneer its own baccalaureate. Will England follow, asks  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Wales is going to pioneer its own baccalaureate. Will England follow, asks Peter Kingston.
fields.body:
The day the Liberal Democrats got their feet under the top table at the Welsh Assembly two months ago it didn't grab a lot of newspaper space across the border in England.

There was even less excitement about their terms for agreeing to enter a three-year coalition with the minority Labour administration. But one of these demands deserves scrutiny, for it may one day spark a revolution in the English education system - it may finally shatter the pre-eminence of that fabled gold standard, the A-level.

It will all depend on how the Welsh take to the baccalaureate. One of the Lib Dems' conditions for entering the coalition was that a Welsh Baccalaureate be tried out in schools and colleges.

A Welsh Bac? Is there such a thing?

Why, yes. And what is more, it promises much broader charms than the rather fearsomely academic International Baccalaureate, which a few institutions in England have been trying out.

The Welsh Baccalaureate model which the assembly last week agreed to fund promises equal weight to vocational and to academic subjects. It can be achieved through a predominantly vocational route with lesser academic components, and vice versa.

It is, according to the people who have been developing it for the last seven years or so, accessible to 80% of the 16-19 population, roughly four times the percentage, they say, who could realistically tackle the International Baccalaureate.

The Welsh Bac is the child of the Institute of Welsh Affairs (IWA), a non-aligned policy thinktank. In the early 1990s, alarmed at Wales's flagging prosperity compared to the rest of the UK and Europe - Welsh gross domestic product per head of population comes out about 80% of the UK average - the IWA concluded that a large dollop of the remedy lay in tertiary education.

Its director, John Osmond, says: "We did a lot of work looking at Ireland's experience. One of the key reasons for Ireland's success in the last decade has been investment in education, not least in tertiary education."

In 1993, the IWA published a report - Wales 2010 Creating Our Future - which recommended looking at a baccalaureate approach to post-16 education built on the International Baccalaureate model.

But why baccalaureate? What is wrong with the tried and tested A-levels?

"There is a broad consensus that the subjects studied at A-level are too narrow," says Osmond. "And there's a broad consensus that we need to do something about vocational qualifications. They are not held in high enough esteem."

Fair enough. But haven't those criticisms been addressed by Curriculum 2000, with its expectations that youngsters should do a fourth, even a fifth subject at AS level, and its intention to raise the status of vocational courses?

The IWA doesn't believe that it has, and it cites support from the higher education sector. Its researchers surveyed and visited admissions staff at 20 universities and higher education institutions to explore the acceptability of the Welsh Bac.

According to one of the IWA team, Cerian Black, they encountered concern from admissions tutors that Curriculum 2000 reforms "would not significantly broaden the studies of the majority of students". There were also serious reservations about "a gap between the rhetoric and aspirations of the government and the actual provision of AS, key skills and vocational education being made in schools and colleges".

The government's hopes that students would study five subjects at AS-level, before slimming down to three A2 A-levels in their second years don't appear to have been borne out. In fact, a survey conducted by the University and Colleges Admissions Service concluded in June that 83% of students would do four AS-levels. And that nine out of 10 Welsh colleges and schools would encourage students to take four.

"There is an avoidance culture," says Osmond. "Young people will do the minimum they think necessary to get where they want to go."

This also means, he says, that many will not seize the chance of keeping up with a subject outside their eventual cluster of A-levels but will stay close to home. Scientists are likely to choose another science rather than English literature or a foreign language, for instance.

The Welsh Bac, like the IB, will force students to carry on with subjects they might not see as their strong suits.

A student has to pick a subject from each of six subject groups: 1 English, Welsh; 2 second languages; 3 Wales studies, history, geography, economics, sociology, politics; 4 maths, biology, chemistry, physics, design technology, environmental systems; 5 art, music, theatre studies; 6 any subject from one of the other groups.

Each subject comes at two levels: higher and standard. A student must do three at higher, and three at standard. The academic options are based on existing International Baccalaureate courses.

Six subjects is also the rule for the vocational route, involving a mix of advanced, intermediate or foundation GNVQs and national vocational qualifications (NVQ). The WelshBac can't be done entirely vocationally: everybody must do the second language and a subject from group 1.

In addition students must do a "core studies" course covering a broad range: for instance, theory of knowledge, global concerns, RE, PE and IT. And to top it off, there is serious consideration being given to requiring all students to do a 5,000-word essay.

For the next year, at least, the Welsh Bac will be refined and twiddled. Then the intention is that two cohorts of students will do the two-year programme. It looks as if the pilots will be spread across 12 centres around Wales, and be jointly carried out at each by a school-college partnership. Meanwhile tenders will go out for an exam body to get involved.

Labour was keen on the baccalaureate notion before the 1997 election. But this enthusiasm has since apparently cooled. Apart from anything else, a baccalaureate system would not come cheap. Now that Wales is obligingly test-driving, English attention will be keenly focused on the outcome. And if it proves a success, then pressure will surely be felt in government at Westminster to follow.

As one Cambridge science admissions tutor said: "I hope it will succeed and give a positive lead in curriculum development in the rest of the UK."

Bac in England

At Exeter College, they've been doing the International Baccalaureate for nine years. Only a small proportion of students tackle it, though - 65 against 2000 or so doing A-levels - and about three times as many girls as boys, according to Dr Andy Truscott, who teaches biology.

"There's a definite type who are attracted to the IB," he says. "They tend to be outgoing freethinkers. They argue, they express their opinions quite forcibly. They question things. They are very much more dynamic. They are harder to control than the average A level group."

But they are very rewarding to teach, says his colleague Claire Willman, who teaches them maths and coordinates the college's IB programme. She also teaches GNVQ art students the compulsory maths key skill - "application of number".

"Half of them really resent it," she says. "The IB students are totally the other way. They know they've got to take maths and they're very willing to have a go. Even the weakest is going to try to get something out of it."
