Apart from anything else, a baccalaureate system would not come cheap. Now that Wales is obligingly test-driving, English attention will be keenly focused on the outcome. And if it proves a success, then pressure will surely be felt in government at Westminster to follow. As one Cambridge science admissions tutor said: "I hope it will succeed and give a positive lead in curriculum development in the rest of the UK." Bac in England At Exeter College, they've been doing the International Baccalaureate for nine years. Only a small proportion of students tackle it, though - 65 against 2000 or so doing A-levels - and about three times as many girls as boys, according to Dr Andy Truscott, who teaches biology. "There's a definite type who are attracted to the IB," he says. "They tend to be outgoing freethinkers. They argue, they express their opinions quite forcibly. They question things. They are very much more dynamic. They are harder to control than the average A level group." But they are very rewarding to teach, says his colleague Claire Willman, who teaches them maths and coordinates the college's IB programme. She also teaches GNVQ art students the compulsory maths key skill - "application of number". "Half of them really resent it," she says. "The IB students are totally the other way. They know they've got to take maths and they're very willing to have a go. Even the weakest is going to try to get something out of it."

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: I think the ability to speak a language is vital for a good career, but I'm worried that my son cannot get the sort of personal guidance at school that would help him to make real progress. Is private tuition a good idea or does it lead to clashes with school-based learning?
fields.trailText: I think the ability to speak a language is vital for a good career, but I'm worried that my son cannot get the sort of personal guidance at school that would help him to make real progress. Is private tuition a good idea or does it lead to clashes with school-based learning?
fields.body:
Annette Rees is a member of the Campaign for State Education

If you're considering private tuition, talk it through with the appropriate teacher at the school. It's always worth encouraging what is a vitally important home-school partnership.

As an ex-French teacher I'd recommend any contact with a native speaker of another language, either at conversation groups or while on holiday abroad. But if you're talking about a career involving a foreign language, there is ample opportunity at degree level, and often A-level, to get immersed in the culture and language of another country. Of course, children brought up in a bilingual household do have a massive head start on children who learn another language at school, but this way of learning is not open to many.

As a parent I would say that learning languages can become a chore if you put too much stress on extra tuition. You need genuine curiosity and enjoyment to learn a language, and this tends to come when children are naturally attracted to a particular language or recognise the relevance of it to their own life.

Finally, "real progress" can be made at school, and with parental encouragement, enjoyable foreign holidays, and the wide array of courses in further and higher education, our children can, and do, acquire first-class foreign language skills.

Kim Jackson is a former secondary-school teacher, who specialises in private language tuition

In a classroom situation pupils are often intimidated by their peers, particularly in mixed ability classes, and this fear can manifest itself as a withdrawal from active participation. Pupils may become fearful of making mistakes or looking foolish in front of the class and this lack of confidence makes them scared to experiment with the language. Language needs to be spoken for it to become alive and a pupil who lacks the confidence to speak will make slow progress.

In a one-to-one situation, pupils can move at their own pace. They become confident enough to try the language, or ask for clarification about particular points, safe in the knowledge that they are not going to be ridiculed or made to feel uneasy. They also learn that it is OK to make mistakes and that it is part of the natural process of language learning.

A private tutor is an excellent means of complementing school-based learning. With the national curriculum now firmly in place, the private tutor knows exactly what the aims of the subject are at any given stage. Private tuition enables lessons to be tailor-made to the needs of the individual. Time is therefore spent focusing on the aspects of language learning which are problematic.

However, private tutors are not magicians. There needs to be a desire and commitment to learn from the pupil concerned for the partnership to work. Parental concern alone is not enough.

Sophie Stringer-Lamarre is a teacher adviser at the Centre for Information on Language Teaching and Research (CiLT)

A trip abroad with a reputable organisation, an exchange with a pen friend, a subscription to a foreign language TV channel and listening to the radio are all useful ways of supporting language learning. The most common form of support, though, is to hire a private tutor and here you have to ask yourself some searching questions.

Firstly, as a parent, I would decide why I want my child to have a tutor. Are the school marks low, do I want quick help or just general support? Is the learner weak in particular areas or is mainly oral practice required? A tutor would discuss with parent and child what is required and suggest a working plan.

Tuition could include reviewing the week's work and explaining points that were not understood or needed reinforcing. Language learning requires a lot of practice and pupils may find it daunting to express themselves in front of others or not get many opportunities if the class is large.

The advantage of employing a good professional tutor is that he or she will be able to appraise quickly what the pupil needs and respond accordingly. The tutor does not need to teach additional elements - this would interfere with school learning and may confuse a young learner. Explanation, additional practice opportunities and some cultural input would be an effective combination.

fields.headline: So you want to be learn about ...
fields.standfirst: Waiting
fields.trailText: Waiting
fields.body:
Waiter. Yes, sir

This beef. What about it, sir?

Is it French? I don't know, sir, has it said anything?

What on earth do you mean? Well, you can't tell until it moos, sir.

Rubbish! Unless it's got some distinguishing mark.

Well, there is a sort of tattoo. There you go, sir, it must be Aberdeen Angus.

That's a relief. Quite, sir

You didn't mind my asking? All part of the job, sir.

I suppose the rest is just sort of standing around. You jest, sir.

Well, what does being a waiter or waitress entail? In general we've three main roles: to prepare the restaurant area, serve the food and then clear away afterwards.

And generally chat us up, ask us if everything is satisfactory etc. When diners enter the restaurant we will often show them to their table, discuss the menu and wine list and listen carefully to individual orders.

What about actually serving the grub? Many restaurants these days bring the plated meal to the table, but if the restaurant provides silver service then we bring individual items to the table and serve with spoons and forks.

Then you clear the decks. Yes, in preparation for the next item, and at the end of the meal, we often have to prepare the bill.

What skills does the job need? First and foremost we need to be good at dealing with the general public, and with problems or complaints if they occur. So we've got to be friendly, polite ...

Right. Don't interrupt ... and show knowledge of the food and wines on the menu so we can give recommendations to the punters. We need to be able to work under pressure, and always look professional in manner and appearance. Good grooming is essential. The last thing you want is to be served by staff who do not look clean and presentable. And a good memory is vital.

Why? Why, what?

Never mind. And finally, a good memory is very important.

Right. What about entry requirements? Nothing formal, which is why young, unskilled people are attracted to the job on a part-time basis. Many restaurants, quite often the large chains, will employ people with no experience at all and train them on the job. Larger or more prestigious restaurants will require their staff to have formal qualifications, which can be got at college before starting employment. There is a GNVQ in Hospitality and Catering and NVQs 1-3 in Food and Drink Service.

fields.headline: Rostrum
fields.standfirst: Cutting benefits won't work; people should be paid to learn, says  Linda Butler
fields.trailText: Cutting benefits won't work; people should be paid to learn, says Linda Butler.
fields.body:
Twenty-five years ago, I volunteered to teach adults to read and write. A close relative, who was brilliantly clever, had left his secondary modern school still unable to read after 10 years of the state's efforts, and those of the spelling teacher his mother had employed. Within 10 years, he had made so much money in his business that he had to take a year's tax holiday. I, meanwhile, had gone to university and was now earning next to nothing as a lecturer in a college outside Leeds. The irony of this situation has regularly visited me.

Not all non-readers or non-writers are the same, and neither do they have the attitude to their lack of knowledge that tutors like me were led to expect. My first student, Colin, was a blacksmith. When I first knocked on his door - lessons were done at home because students would be too embarrassed to come to college - I whispered that I had come from the college. "This woman's turned up to teach me to read and write," he bellowed from the doorstep to his wife, who was chatting in the front garden to a neighbour. "Oh," she said, "That's nice." The neighbour asked how long it would take "to get him put right".

I had no answer. Nor, I discovered, had anyone else. As David Blunkett wrote last week, the Moser report, A Fresh Start, describes a situation where "generations of neglect had meant that there were no clear standards, tests or basic curriculum for adult literacy and numeracy. Teachers were poorly trained, if at all."

Rapidly rejecting the available school-based materials, Colin and I embarked on a three-year journey towards literacy via the headlines in The Sun. By that time he had got far enough to satisfy himself and me that he could read if and when he wanted to - which, by the way, was never during working hours. A year or two later, he rang to tell me that two of his sons had been diagnosed as dyslexic. He was very pleased and also pretty angry because it had not been picked up before.

Things have certainly improved since then, thanks to the Basic Skills Agency and others who have kept adult skills on the agenda, but also because of the increasing acceptability of dyslexia.

Anyone involved in helping adults learn to read and write to the level they wish will recognise this story. I am sure they will also share David Blunkett's courageous commitment to the start of such a vital, such a curiously neglected, national programme.

But there are some questions to ask about one possible policy strand, which is to withhold unemployment benefit payments from claimants with poor basic skills who refuse to get help with improving them. People have all sorts of reasons for not wanting to go onto a formal learning programme of this kind.

Colleges and other providers will have rich past experiences of being asked, in effect, to purvey learning as a punishment. And let's be clear, there still are some, perhaps just a few, poor quality programmes out there. The alternative suggested by the Basic Skills Agency, to pay people to learn, seems much more likely to succeed.

Most of the seven million Moser adults will be employed or "non-employed" and some of those will take up the positive cash incentives offered by Individual Learning Accounts, so for joined-up government, why treat unemployed people any differently?

But how much should be offered as an incentive? Would the £100 suggested by the Basic Skills Agency actually make much difference, given the amount of work involved for many learners to go from, say, a reading age of nine to 14? And how long would learners be given to reach their target? What if they came off benefit and started earning? Despite these and many such questions, positive as opposed to negative incentives must make better sense as a support to adults' learning. This is a project that just has to be carried through.

Meanwhile, I'm just thankful that "incentivisation" never appeared in a Sun headline in the late 70s.

 Linda Butler is Director of Communications at the Association of Colleges, but the views expressed are her own.

webTitle: Education: An ad agency that trains its staff

fields.headline: Buy this
fields.standfirst: John Crace discovers an ad agency that does not sell its staff short
fields.trailText: John Crace discovers an ad agency that does not sell its staff short.
fields.body:
List your favourite advertising stereotypes. Asymmetric haircuts, poseur retro-chic, long, expensive lunches at The Ivy, heavy cocaine habits, overpaid, talking drivel. That's the prejudices taken care of. Now free your mind and try and come up with something a little more positive. You can't? Never mind, I'll help.

How about the creation of entertaining, thought-provoking, sophisticated artistic sales messages? One could go on, but even the industry's most enthusiastic advocates would have to concede that advertising agencies don't exactly have the best reputation when it comes to training their staff. Indeed many agencies seem to make a virtue of not training their staff..

So when you hear of an agency that spends more on training its staff than on finding new business and which had the idea of lifelong learning written into its core ethos long before it was even a twinkle in the DfEE's mind, then you tend to take notice.

St Luke's was formed five years ago after the London office of the American agency Chiat/Day was about to be acquired by another agency, TBWA. Rather than be subsumed into the new business, Andy Law, Chiat/Day's managing director, and 34 other members of staff left to form their own agency.

"We wanted to create a company that put human capital to the fore," says Law, St Luke's chairman. "Bosses of traditional companies see people as overheads who can be got rid of; we see people as our main asset - an asset that will appreciate in value over time. In the knowledge economy, the means of production is in the minds of people. In the business world there is an ongoing war for human talent and we wanted an environment where people would want to stay and work."

If this sounds like a curious mix of Socialist Worker and adspeak, then check out the results. In five years, the company has grown from a staff of 35 to 115, has seen its pre-tax profits increase eightfold in three years, has won 25% more new business than any other UK agency, has top clients including Ikea, BT and Sky Television and has won awards and acclaim both for its business ethics and creative work. Most significantly, although 10% of its staff have moved on, only 1% has left to join a competitor; elsewhere in the industry a turnover rate of 25% is typical.

There is no hierarchy at St Luke's; every member of staff is a co-owner within a co-operative framework. All personal computers have been thrown out and replaced by public workstations that can be used by anyone at any time. No one even has a desk or an office of their own and anyone is free to attend any meeting.

People are at the heart of this business experiment, which is why training and personal development are given such prominence. In many companies, the training budget is an area where savings are hoped for. Not so at St Luke's where their annual budget is over £100,000. Each member of staff gets an annual review where strengths and weaknesses are assessed and the appropriate training recommended.

"Some of the training might be basic management courses run by the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising," says Andy Palmer, managing partner and head of training, "but we also send people on courses to build confidence and to learn new skills in areas, such as new media. We also run internal courses; most Fridays we have an afternoon lecture on which someone will talk on a subject that may or may not be work-related."

And then there is the "Make Yourself a More Interesting Person Fund". Each member of staff can draw £150 per year to do something that interests them. "People have used it to do all sorts of things from learning a language, to screenwriting, to head massage, to parachute jumping to swimming with dolphins," says Law.

"The only thing we ask is that people share their experiences with us." So what did Law do? "I learnt html," he admits. "I'm not sure whether it made me more interesting." Many companies obey the credo of "speculate to accumulate"; few do it like St Luke's, by speculating in people. They recently funded one member of staff to the tune of £80,000 to get a 40-minute short crime film made; like most things at the agency, the investment turned to gold as the film was nominated for an award at the Sundance festival. It's enough to make you consider an advertising career.

fields.headline: Studies abroad? £520, please
fields.standfirst: Helen Oldfield is left fuming after being asked to stump up university fees for her daughter during her year in Spain
fields.trailText: Helen Oldfield is left fuming after being asked to stump up university fees for her daughter during her year in Spain.
fields.body:
At first I thought it was a scam being pulled by the university my daughter attends - charging fees for a year when she's not there, I mean. Eventually, after a protracted exchange of letters, it became clear that this was sleight of hand common to all universities this year. I should have known. It's not Oxford being greedy, it's the government weaselling its way out of another small chunk of funding for higher education.

My daughter Jane, in common with most modern language students, is spending her third year working abroad, in her case in Madrid. We were not so much surprised as outraged when a bill arrived for £520, just about half the regular tuition fee. This is the first year this has happened, I gather, as this is the first wave of students to reach their third year since fees were introduced.

Jane has to do two essays during the course of this year, which presumably will get marked at some stage. Otherwise, she's on her own. £520 seems a rip-off.

The university says there is "no immediate or direct relationship between the fees paid by an individual student at any particular stage of his or her course, and the specific provision they will receive at any point during that course". That doesn't alter the fact that modern language students will be paying £3,500 odd for their course, rather than the £3,000 most of the rest will pay. "Your daughter is personally liable for the fee." Oh fine, we need worry no longer, she can find the £520 out of her £6,000 a year salary in Madrid. "The university does use the general resources available to provide colleges with funds to support students during the year abroad." Funny, we didn't get to hear about that at the start of the year.

And the clincher. Universities are forced to charge the fee because the Higher Education Funding Council for England assumes they will, and calculates the teaching grant accordingly - so, if the universities forbear, they'll fall short in their finances.

Still not paying, still pretty annoyed, I approach the Department of Education (the press office - no one, apparently, neither parent nor journalist, can speak to an official direct - and very matey it is too, "Hello, Helen, this is Ben"). The department admits: "Yes, it's true!" Not that it's a scam, but that £520 fees are charged to students on years abroad and on industry placement. The fee must be even more galling for them, contributing as they are to the economy. The department further admits, as it phrases it, "there will be limited involvement for the institution in respect of the period spent on the placement", but ... there are tuition and pastoral overheads to think of ... assessment of students may continue ... if students need help or guidance they would have "access to resources" (there's a comfort).

Enough. I suppose we'll pay, though I'd be interested to know whether any modern language students or parents have been creating a stink and whether they've had any joy. The fact is the £520 seems like pocket money in comparison with other wheezes the university vice-chancellors are dreaming up. To raise the extra billion pounds they need, so I read, they're suggesting raising the fees for the more expensive-to-run courses, such as medicine, which lead to lucrative careers, to anything from £3,000 to £14,500 a year.

Whatever happened to the idea of education as a good thing in itself? Or the notion that society as whole gains from having as many people as possible as well educated as possible? Even the vice-chancellors seem to have given up on that. Or perhaps they have learned from bitter experience to talk in terms of education as a selfish personal investment, and have already given up hope of the government doing what it ought to do - stump up a bit more of our money.

fields.headline: Bullet points
fields.trailText: Let them grow rice | That'll be the day
fields.body:
Let them grow rice

Ooh aar! What havoc this appalling weather is playing with agricultural colleges. A distress call issues from Moulton College near Northampton. The roof blew off its gamekeeping centre in the gales. Even worse, water has completely devastated the crop programmes. They can't drill the winter wheat ground because it's waterlogged.

And now the date for planting it has passed they will have to try to get some spring wheat down in the two remaining fields. But spring wheat can't be had because farmers nationally are grabbing for it. Oats have been planted in the maize fields in the hope that the proper oat fields will dry out in time for maize drilling next April. "Perhaps we should consider teaching our students how to grow rice," wails a college official.

That'll be the day

How do we know there'll be a new education secretary after the election? The strongest hint comes in a recent communique from the Department for Education and Employment. David Blunkett is clearly ignoring our warning against diddling lecturers and teachers out of the national day off for the queen's golden jubilee in 2002.

He's written to local authorities advising them to shift the summer half-term break so it straddles not just the jubilee day - Monday June 3 - but the annual May bank holiday - June 4. He's suggested that local authorities give teachers an extra day off at the end of the summer term instead. Which means he has no intention of being around in June 2002 to face the flak. It'll be somebody else. Just so long as Jack knows.

webTitle: Education: Lecturers' Union demands pay rise

fields.headline: Time to close the gap
fields.standfirst: Union demands catch-up pay rise for all lecturers. Report by  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Union demands catch-up pay rise for all lecturers. Report by Peter Kingston.
fields.body:
Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, is expected to give broad approval today to colleges' and unions' suggestions for distributing an extra £150m for pay.

The government has announced that the cash will be available for salaries in the further education sector over the next two years.

But employers and unions must first come up with acceptable formulae for its use according to the now familiar "something for something" principle.

After lengthy negotiations, the sector's unions and the Association of Colleges have reached common ground about the need to restore some of the now yawning salary gap between lecturers and their teacher counterparts in schools.

But Natfhe, the lecturers' union, is drawing a line in the sand at performance related pay.

It is also calling for a "general catch-up" payment to all lecturers. The union's general secretary, Paul Mackney, will point out to Wicks that a sum of, for instance, £500 would recognise "the something that has already been given by all lecturers over the seven years of cost-cut expansion".

This proposal does not look like being supported by the AoC, where it is felt that the extra millions, substantial though they are, will not stretch to such a flat-rate one-off payment for all. The AoC estimates that the additional money would work out at about £200,000 to £300,000 for an average sized college.

Sources within the department hinted that the minister is likely to approve the outlines of the proposals and to request all parties to proceed to filling in more details.

A final agreement needs to be clinched by next spring. The first tranche - £50m - of the extra money is due to be released for the period September 2001 to April 2002. Then an extra £100m will be available for April 2002 to April 2003.

The common ground is larger than the differences, say the parties. According to the AoC, a growing dis parity between the pay levels in schools and colleges has to be narrowed in order to address recruitment and retention problems.

The starting salary scale for a school teacher starts at £15,141, 10% higher than for a further education lecturer. The gap widens up the scale. The new schools' advanced teacher scale runs from £26,943 to £42,981. The comparable scale for a senior further education lecturer runs from £24,039 to £31,771.

Both Natfhe and the AoC are proposing the establishment of an advanced lecturers' salary scale comparable to the teachers' set up.

There is also consensus on the need to put some of the money into ensuring equal pay for part-timers, and to reward the attainment of new qualifications by lecturers.

 Natfhe leaders are smarting at the final tally of its members who have made it onto the 47 Local Learning and Skills Councils.

Only three members have managed to gain the union places on the councils which will oversee the distribution of about £100m apiece.

The general secretary, Paul Mackney, said: "We are disgruntled. It was Natfhe which alerted the world to many of the problems in colleges when the Further Education Funding Council ran things.

"If you don't have the voice of the practitioners in there, they won't know how the money is being spent or misspent."

fields.headline: College days
fields.standfirst: Wolfgang Tillmans
fields.trailText: Wolfgang Tillmans
fields.body:
Born August 16, 1968

Occupation Photographer; winner of this year's Turner Prize

College The Arts Institute at Bournemouth, which clearly has a reputation in Germany, where Tillmans came from

Attended 1990 - 1992

Course HND photography

A tutor recalls "Wolfgang was very quietly determined. He was always taking pictures, particularly of people.

"He always wanted to debate about photography and he was always full of bright ideas."

Principal Stuart Bartholomew says "I'm delighted that Wolfgang's work has been exposed to the wide audience that the Turner Prize brings.

"The Turner prize is the cutting edge and it's great to see specialist institutions generating winners."

webTitle: Education: Can universities accept tobacco companies' funding?

fields.headline: Fag end of funding
fields.standfirst: Universities are desperate for money and tobacco companies are awash in it. Why can't they just be friends?  Lee Elliot Major  reports
fields.trailText: Universities are desperate for money and tobacco companies are awash in it. Why can't they just be friends? Lee Elliot Major reports.
fields.body:
The fevered debate over whether universities should accept tobacco industry money looks set to re-ignite, with the news that Newcastle University turned down a substantial grant from a cigarette company in the past six months on ethical grounds.

At least two other universities - Birmingham and Imperial College London - have also rejected approaches from tobacco companies, the Guardian has learned.

In June 1999 a research team from Bath University funded by BAT also decided not to seek repeat funding in order to prevent antagonising other potential sponsors.

Evidence that the tobacco industry is increasingly targeting universities for sponsorship emerges as the head of the Cancer Research Campaign charity renewed threats to withdraw funds from Nottingham University, which last week accepted £3.8m from British American Tobacco to set up a centre for business ethics.

The world's second largest tobacco company, now facing accusations that it has exploited smuggling in Britain and abroad, is also spending £50,000 on a new masters degree course at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology.

The issue threatens to split the academic world, with a deepening divide between universities accepting tobacco funds and those turning contracts down. Academic institutions, increasingly dependent on private income, will become even more attractive targets for tobacco sponsorship after government moves towards a tobacco advertising ban, confirmed in the Queen's speech last week.

Newcastle's decision represents a dramatic turnaround from events only three years ago. The university was itself the centre of a controversy over tobacco funding, when a senior Medical Research Council official was sacked after expressing reservations over an MRC research project at Newcastle, jointly funded with tobacco companies. (The project eventually failed to identify any positive health benefits from smoking for Alzheimer's sufferers.)

Charities such as the Wellcome Trust and Cancer Research Campaign now say they will withdraw grants from academics also supported by tobacco money, due to the overwhelming evidence that active and passive smoking cause major diseases. But the MRC, the government's central funding agency for medical research, rejects that stance.

Newcastle University now adopts its own ethical policy, which states that it will not accept sponsorship where either the motives of the sponsor are not in line with the university's aims, or where the suppression of academic results is likely to lead to "substantial ethical difficulties".

Last week the university said: "It is in the highest degree unlikely that the university would accept sponsorship from any company engaged in the manufacture of tobacco products, given that it would be extremely difficult to believe that the motives of such companies did not include the increase in the sales of their products, which are known to be both addictive and extremely hazardous to health."

The university turned down a substantial grant proposal from a tobacco company on the basis of its guidelines. The University of Oxford, which has received no donations from tobacco companies, also says it would not accept funding if it were judged to be "benefiting the tobacco company or encouraging smoking".

All this appears to contrast starkly with attitudes at Cambridge which, like Nottingham, sparked off controversy four years ago after accepting tobacco money. BAT gave £1.5m to found a Patrick Sheehy chair of international relations to mark the retirement of the tobacco firm's chairman.

Sir Colin Campbell, the Nottingham vice-chancellor, known as one of the most enthusiastic backers of differential top-up fees, has for many years been on close terms with Nottinghamshire MP Ken Clarke. The former Tory chancellor is now paid £100,000 a year as BAT deputy chairman. The two have crossed paths several times over the years, and often share a box at the local Nottingham Forest football club.

The deal was on the cards for many months. Campbell visited Gordon McVie, CRC's director-general, two months before the BAT deal was finalised - a reconnaisance mission designed to ensure that the move would not precipitate the loss of CRC money from the university's medical school.

The decision now appears to have raised the stakes further. CRC has yet to withdraw funding from a university department, as the tobacco funds are always carefully ring-fenced elsewhere in institutions. But McVie says that the CRC will withdraw funds "if it is found that Nottingham's name has been used by BAT as part of its marketing abroad". BAT says that the Nottingham investment is part of a "long-standing commitment to tertiary and management education" helping it to "gain deeper insights into developing best practice in corporate social responsibility".

All the UK medical schools, with the exception of Glasgow, have accepted tobacco money in the recent past. A study by the Wellcome Trust in 1997 revealed that two charitable trusts established by tobacco companies had poured more than £10m into UK academic coffers. Nearly 300 biomedical research papers were published over ten years acknowledging funding from the tobacco industry. One problem is that such charitable bodies often bear no obvious connection to their donors.

Two key arguments against tobacco funding have been voiced in the wake of the Nottingham deal.

First, it is said to lend legitimacy and respectability to an unethical industry. The industry has in fact enjoyed a long and fruitful relation ship with academics. Less than 50 years ago Scientific American magazine carried adverts with researchers endorsing favourite cigarette brands, and some universities owe their very foundations to local cigarette tycoons. Bristol University's Wills Memorial Building is a lasting testament to the tobacco family whose funds helped to build the university 100 years ago.

But now that the carcinogenic effects of smoking are known, the tobacco industry is singled out as the most unethical benefactor of all, as it can only operate and make money by harming people's health. Even arms manufacturers can argue, for example, that new weapons can be used as deterrents against warfare. Smoking has no redeeming features.

The second argument against tobacco funding is that cigarette companies try to subvert and obfuscate the scientific debate over the effects of smoking. The industry's reputation has not been helped by thousands of incriminating internal documents put on websites after US court cases. They show tobacco-company scientists were fully aware of links between lung cancer and smoking years before the industry conceded them publicly. Also exposed are efforts to recruit scientists. Project Whitecoat aimed to provoke controversy in the academic debate over passive smoking.

Yet a revolt against the BAT deal urged by some university staff at Nottingham has failed to materialise. There are both pragmatic and philosophical arguments which make tobacco funding acceptable for many academics. Universities need money. And academics must be free to investigate topics, arguments and points of view, no matter how unpopular.

This divide also appears to exist among students. Nottingham's student union president, Alain de Sales, said that some students were unbothered by the BAT grant and were quite keen on the increased funding for higher education. Others were shocked, feeling that it tarred the reputation of the university.

webTitle: Education: Universities can do more for religious needs

fields.headline: We must try the American way
fields.standfirst: British universities must try harder to accommodate the the religious needs of students, says  Geoffrey Alderman
fields.trailText: British universities must try harder to accommodate the the religious needs of students, says Geoffrey Alderman.
fields.body:
It is commonplace in intellectual circles to speak of multicultural Britain, and to celebrate its ethnic diversity. These concepts have found their way into university management strategies and mission statements. But what about religious diversity?

In a previous article, Abul Taher painted pictures of unhappy Muslim girls, torn between loyalty to family and the wish to take advantage of educational opportunities Britain offered them. It was not so much the education itself that worried the parents as the social side of university life, the participation in and absorption of an alien culture, and social interaction with non-Muslim men.

Are institutions of higher education really attuned to the implications of Britain's religious diversity and are they actively addressing the needs of its religiously diverse set of communities? More basically, in spite of all the hype about "increasing access" and "equal opportunities", what are places of higher education doing to make the education they provide accessible by members of "strictly observant" religious groups?

Optimists might argue that a great deal has been done. After all, religious tests for entry into Oxbridge were abolished more than a century ago. At the Oxford I attended in the 1960s orthodox Jewish students had to pay for non-kosher dinners they would never eat. Lectures and tutorial classes were held on Saturday mornings (the Jewish sabbath).

It was only after the second world war that Oxford adopted special regulations to deal with orthodox Jews who were unable to sit public examinations on a Saturday. My daughter (same university) had a much easier time. She did not have to pay for any meals she did not want, and her college even supplied her with a microwave oven so that she could cook her own kosher meals.

Similar concessions were afforded my son (Cambridge). Although there was still teaching on a Saturday, arrangements were made for him to be provided with tape recordings of the lectures he was unable to attend and a tape recorder on which to play them. But why were - and are - lectures held on a Saturday at all?

British universities should be doing a great deal more to accommodate the religious sensitivities of their students and potential students. They need to re-examine some beliefs and practices that received wisdom might misguidedly classify as sacrosanct. If women (or men, for that matter) from very strict religious backgrounds wish to attend university in a co-educational environment, they should certainly not be prevented from doing so merely because of parental opposition.

But suppose they wish, of their own volition, to benefit from the education, but without being compelled to do so in a coeducational setting? In these days, when it is possible to obtain a university qualification without physically attending a university at all, it is silly to argue that immersion in a coeducational environment is any longer (if it ever was) an essential component of higher education.

Are women whose religious beliefs prevent them from participating in mixed-sex higher education really being denied "equal opportunities"?

The academic benefits of mixed-sex education are unproven. It is widely acknowledged, however, that girls do better in girls-only secondary schools, and some of the best secondary education to be obtained for girls in Britain today is provided, in both private and state sectors, by single-sex schools. Why, then, force girls to attend mixed-sex university classes if they genuinely do not want to do so?

The sad fact is that Britain has Jewish and Muslim communities denied access to higher education because a spurious and intolerant political correctness will not accommodate their religious beliefs. This is not so in the US. In New York, strictly orthodox Jewish students, for example, can attend Touro College, or Yeshiva University, and get (with state and federal financial support) first-rate qualifications in a supportive, single-sex environment (if that is what they choose) that respects their religious views.

In their search for true equal opportunities British universities and colleges need to engage much more intensively in religious as well as ethnic awareness. I would advise them to look across the Atlantic at radical ways in which members of even the strictest religious communities are able to achieve their academic potential.

fields.bodyText: It is commonplace in intellectual circles to speak of multicultural Britain, and to celebrate its ethnic diversity. These concepts have found their way into university management strategies and mission statements. But what about religious diversity? In a previous article, Abul Taher painted pictures of unhappy Muslim girls, torn between loyalty to family and the wish to take advantage of educational opportunities Britain offered them. It was not so much the education itself that worried the parents as the social side of university life, the participation in and absorption of an alien culture, and social interaction with non-Muslim men. Are institutions of higher education really attuned to the implications of Britain's religious diversity and are they actively addressing the needs of its religiously diverse set of communities? More basically, in spite of all the hype about "increasing access" and "equal opportunities", what are places of higher education doing to make the education they provide accessible by members of "strictly observant" religious groups? Optimists might argue that a great deal has been done. After all, religious tests for entry into Oxbridge were abolished more than a century ago. At the Oxford I attended in the 1960s orthodox Jewish students had to pay for non-kosher dinners they would never eat. Lectures and tutorial classes were held on Saturday mornings (the Jewish sabbath). It was only after the second world war that Oxford adopted special regulations to deal with orthodox Jews who were unable to sit public examinations on a Saturday. fields.headline: In the fast lane
fields.standfirst: For 30,000 Muslims in Britain the end of this term is a testing time. Exams and studies must be worked around Ramadan.  Abul Taher  reports
fields.trailText: For 30,000 Muslims in Britain the end of this term is a testing time. Exams and studies must be worked around Ramadan. Abul Taher reports.
fields.body:
Now Christmas is closing in fast, most students at Britain's universities will be busy wrapping up their work so they can concentrate on the endless parties that greet the end of term.

But for an estimated 30,000 Muslim students, there will be no such celebrations, as most of them are busy observing Ramadan, which this year falls in December. This period, which covers the most sacred 30 days in the Islamic calendar, is marked by Muslims across the world with fasting (complete abstinence from food and drink) from sunrise to sunset and by spending extra hours in devotion and spiritual contemplation.

Islamic societies across Britain's campuses have been active holding special religious sermons and lectures to inform and educate their members on the significance of a month when partying and clubbing are especially frowned upon.

At Leicester University, which has perhaps the most prominent student Islamic society in the UK, students strive to fulfil both their stringent religious duties and their academic responsibilities, some of them having done their exams in the middle of their fast.

"I knew Ramadan was going to fall during my exams, and I prepared for it," says Rasheed Akhtar, 20, a medical student.

Despite his numerous exams and course-work, Rasheed has not yet broken a fast, nor does he intend to, not with just three more days before the end of term. On the contrary, he says, Ramadan helps him to become more disciplined. "It helps you to develop self-control. You have to eat at the right time and pray at the right time. It definitely disciplines your lifestyle," he says.

However, the third-year medic admits that Ramadan does make studying that much more demanding, as he has to get up earlier - usually around 5am - to have a pre-dawn meal (sehri), which is a religious requirement for all those intending to fast during the day.

Also, much of his evening time, which he would normally devote to revision and completing course work, is taken up by lengthy Ramadan prayers which are also obligatory.

But the devout Muslim does not have any complaints, even though he is necessarily having to work much harder than his non-Muslims peers. His only regret, he says, is that his whole university work is actually disrupting his Ramadan devotions. "During Ramadan, you want to worship more, read the Koran more. I feel my study disrupts Ramadan, which is about remembrance of God."

For those Muslim students not as disciplined as Rasheed, Ramadan is a testing time. "Ramadan has increased the stress on me," admits Mohammed Shafiq, who is reading economics. "At the moment I'm finding it OK, but my deadlines are due. The fasting and the getting up early in the morning makes me tired throughout the day."

Shafiq, 20, who says he is a "middle-of-the-road Muslim", has all the stress of being a final-year student in a difficult discipline. He admits his time-management is somewhat lacking, which doesn't help when both religion and academia are demanding so much simultaneously.

Not only is the workload great but there is also the stress of filling up lengthy job application forms, all of which must be sent in before the end of the month.

For him Ramadan has come at a bad time. He says it is a "double dose of exams" for him this year. "First of all, Ramadan is a sort of an exam. It's a test of one's faith. And then straight after that, I've got all my real exams in January."

So far he has missed a few lectures because he couldn't get up on time due to the erratic sleeping habits Ramadan has brought on. Fortunately, his lecturers and tutors have been understanding and respect his religious devotions.

Despite all these difficulties, Mohammed admits Ramadan has been easier this year for all Muslims in Britain, as the holy month has conveniently fallen in December, when the days are the shortest.

Historically, in the month of Ramadan, the first Koranic verses were revealed to the Prophet Mohammed in the year AD 610. So Muslims mark this month by striving for spiritual and moral edification through sacrifice, abstinence and self-study. But since the Islamic calendar is lunar, the Muslim year always goes back 11 days against the Gregorian calendar, so Ramadan is never fixed.

Some students recall times a few years back when Ramadan fell during summer and the days were longer and hotter. "Then it was an act of faith," says one student.

But fasting in a university campus in the west has other difficulties and peculiarities. Rumana Kabir, 20, a third-year psychology and sociology student, says Muslims become more visible during Ramadan because they are fasting. They are constantly quizzed by other "astounded" students. "They think you are affected by it more than you really are."

Her friend, Layla Fitzwilliam-Hall, who was born to parents who converted to Islam, says she often finds the non-Muslim reaction to fasting "quite frustrating" - especially when they see her observing it. "A lot of people find it strange when they see a white person practising Ramadan or Islam," says the 21-year old.

Even the president of the Islamic Society, Tushar Bhuiya, 20, has not been exempt from the "frustrations" that Layla has experienced from fellow students not familiar with Islam. Living in a hall of residence, he recalls one night when he was reciting the Koran in his room. Everyone else on his corridor thought he had started singing in a strange way.

Tushar, who is reading law, says another difficulty of observing Ramadan is that there is always "temptation around you" in campus.

"In my corridor alone, there is drinking going on all the time," he says. And he adds that since sex and alcohol are present everywhere all the time, people can unwittingly break their fast through human weaknesses like sexual arousal, which one must also abstain from.

"There's a lot of temptation around you to morally break the fast," he says.

Yet for Muslim students at British campuses, Ramadan has numerous benefits as well, one of which is the sense of community it produces.

Tushar, who organises communal on-campus evening meals to end the fast (iftar), says such Islamic Society events become the focal point for all Muslims, as does the prayer room.

"During Ramadan, you see people attend prayers and iftar, who you never knew were Muslims before," says Tushar.

And since Muslims at universities are from different ethnic and national backgrounds, they tend to stay in their groups throughout the year. But Tushar says that during Ramadan they break these national barriers and mingle with each other on the same dinner table.

"There are Nigerians, Malaysians, Chinese as well as home students, who gather together during Ramadan. It truly becomes international."

To Layla, who finds it difficult to belong to a "national Muslim group," being white Anglo-Saxon, Ramadan is a time to see the diversity of Islam and the unity its faith produces. And while she is part of both the western and Islamic ways of life, she says she still prefers Islam.

"Muslims are more friendly and community-based. They are not so individualistic" - characteristics that are most visible during Ramadan.

fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.trailText: • Exit pursued by a bursar. Howls of thespian outrage greeted the closure of the Playroom theatre in Cambridge last week by Corpus Christi College, which owns it. There was dark talk that the college was preparing to sell this prime piece of real estate which had nurtured the likes of Sam Mendes and Emma Thompson.
fields.body:
 Exit pursued by a bursar. Howls of thespian outrage greeted the closure of the Playroom theatre in Cambridge last week by Corpus Christi College, which owns it. There was dark talk that the college was preparing to sell this prime piece of real estate which had nurtured the likes of Sam Mendes and Emma Thompson.

Not true, says bursar Sally James - she closed it because the student Fletcher Players who use it would not stick to the proper safety regulations (blocking fire doors etc). "I gave people lots of second chances but we do take health and safety very seriously." The students will be allowed back in next term if they behave themselves.

 Nottingham's decision to pocket £3.8m tobacco money for the country's "first international centre for corporate social responsibility" outraged at least one smoker. Vin Hammersley, director of communications at Warwick Business School, choked on his cigarette when we reported this claim. Warwick's Corporate Citizenship Unit was established four years ago with help from BP (though not a sponsored chair).

"As an addict I never expect tobacco firms to let the truth get in the way of the story - but I expect better from the Guardian." Glad two of the country's centres of business ethics are slagging each other off on the hallowed principle of getting your retaliation in first.

 Universities are over-administered and under-managed, says the Treasury. Enter Michael Shattock (who managed a rather successful one near Coventry) and the Institute of Education, London, to shake things up with a groundbreaking MA in Higher Education Management. One administrator felt the initials "Mayhem" spelt more of a shake-up than intended.

News

A 17-stone sociologist skilled in ethnography and kick boxing revealed how he donned a bullet-proof vest, quit the safety of the academic ivory tower and became a bouncer, writes David Ward. Dr David Calvey, of the Centre for Employment Research at Manchester Metropolitan University, spent six months under cover on the doors of clubs in central Manchester with his heart in his mouth and a tape recorder up his bomber jacket.

He found first-hand evidence of the influence of criminals and drug dealers in a city famed for its clubbing reputation. In a chapter for a new book about dangerous research, Calvey describes an incident in which a bouncer was hurled into a canal and one in which a club manager locked himself and his staff in a cellar when two men suspected of carrying guns began hammering on the front door: "I prioritised my own survival over sociology."

Research News

Winning ideas
University College London has won nine of 28 new awards totalling £125m for research buildings and equipment in the latest round of the government-Wellcome Trust Joint Infrastructure Fund. It the first time a single university has won such a high proportion of grants in the competition. Cambridge, Oxford and Edinburgh all won two awards, worth £125m in total.

Form fooling
A rule intended to dampen the academic transfer market of star professors is turning into a bureaucratic nightmare for university officials preparing for the next Research Assessment Exercise.

Universe

Lettori seek justice again
Unions representing Italy's 1,500 foreign language lecturers, or lettori, are going to the European Court of Justice for a fourth time over pay and conditions, writes Domenico Pacitti. They claim they were downgraded to technicians and had their salaries cut by up to 50% in 1995.

A poor state of affairs
The chances of getting a university education in the US depend very much on which state people are from, concludes a recent report by the National Center for Public Policy and Higher Education, an independent think tank. In California 38% of 18-24s enrol in universities, and just 20% in Nevada.

fields.headline: Play's the thing
fields.standfirst: Many schools now ban traditional playtime games, it emerged last week.  Jerome Monahan reports
fields.trailText: Many schools now ban traditional playtime games, it emerged last week. Jerome Monahan reports.
fields.body:
"Play in any form has been stopped in schools because there has been such a great emphasis on literacy and numeracy. This has taken over our lives and play has lost its place in school." So said one headteacher in a study published last week which revealed that traditional playground games are disappearing from Britain's schools.

Fears of litigation - a recent poll showed that 57% of parents would seek compensation if their child were injured at school - and of Ofsted snootiness over safety and "non-educational" pursuits have prompted many schools to ban perennial favourites such as conkers (an offensive weapon) and British Bulldog (too dangerous), according to the study by Sarah Thomson of Keele University.

There's another side to the story, though - a playground in North Wales where children have learned to play in harmony thanks to traditional games such as Sticky Policemen and The Bomb.

At Llanddulas primary, the pupils have become expert players of catching and skipping games, helped by a collection of ropes, balls, marbles and stones. That "the box", as it is known, and its modest contents have proved so popular is an object lesson in the benefits that flow from taking playtime seriously.

"Until the spring of 1999 our small play area, no bigger than a netball court, was home to 110 children for two outdoor sessions a day," says deputy head Colin Lavelle. "The children passed the time trying to wrestle, imitate violent cartoons or run around the small playground at top speed - and collisions were inevitable."

At that time, year 6 were busy surfing the net in their IT lessons. One of their searches took them to an Irish school site where they found the rules for traditional children's games. "We decided to test them out for ourselves," explains Lavelle. "Those the class liked received a full review, including ratings for difficulty and enjoyment. I decided to print off and laminate the reviews into game cards. And as some of them required balls and ropes, the box was born.

"A few simple rules followed. No one could be excluded if they wanted to take part in an activity and balls were to be thrown and not kicked. The class also appointed two of their number to be the box monitors. And that was it - they were off."

A year on and playground behaviour has changed radically. Nothing has been done to alter the environment. It remains a standard flat area of tarmac and yet the atmosphere is pleasantly different. None is more appreciative of this than the children themselves.

"I just used to stay with the girls," says Kim Jasper, 10. "The boys were rough and it was boring just sitting around - we never played anything. Now it's fun." Her classmate Yasmin Morgan-Griffiths is also impressed by the transformation. "It was a surprise when the box came - I love the skipping and it's good to learn new games." Luke McKenna, nine, has recently arrived at Llanddulas. Playtime at his Solihull primary did not compare well. "My old playground was giant - apart from 'Tig' there was not much going on."

An all too common problem, according to Thomson's survey of 1,000 children in Staffordshire, Shropshire and Lancashire. "All the schools I visited saw playtime as a time that could not be left entirely to the children's wishes," she explains. "It seemed that many of the children's attempts to play were extinguished by the same supervising adults who complained that children 'did not play'."

According to consultant Marc Armitage, it is all too easy for teachers to miss the elaborate games that are going on. "Before anything is changed in a playground it is essential to carry out a thorough audit of what is really happening. Not to do so is to risk displacing existing activities."

Tim Gill, director of the Children's Play Council, agrees. "Far too often schools cope with playground problems by clamping down. School playgrounds may look like chaotic places, but playtime is one of the few oases in children's lives when they can just be themselves."

Education consultant Wendy Titman points out that playtime constitutes a kind of "informal curriculum" and needs as much sensitive nurturing as the subjects taught formally indoors. "Sadly, it receives less and less emphasis," she says.

"The government is very muddled here," adds Ken Davies of charity Learning Through Landscapes. "It wants the next generation to be healthy and happy but all the emphasis on the classroom means it's loading things in the opposite direction."

Meanwhile at Llanddulas, the stimulation continues. "We have entered an interesting stage," says Lavelle. "For the most part, the pupils that selected the box activities have left the school and now the games are being adapted - the names and rules are altering."

For Luke McKenna, the spirit of independence is even more advanced. "To be honest," he says, "I never play the games the teachers teach us - I invent my own."

Useful link
Llandulas' playground games directory

The games people play

The Bomb
Players: 5+
Equipment: tennis ball.
Rules: Everyone stands in a circle. One person throws the ball to someone else (at chest height so it is easy to catch). As soon as the ball leaves the first person's hands, the group starts a countdown - ten, nine, etc. The idea is to get rid of the ball as quickly as possible by throwing it to another person. When the countdown reaches one, the next shout is "bomb" - and the person left holding the ball is out. If "bomb" is shouted when the ball is in mid-air, the last person to touch the ball is out. The winner is the last person in.

Fish
Players: Three teams and an extra person, ie 7, 10, 13, 16 or 19 people.
Equipment: A large square space (3m by 3m or more), with corners marked with posts or jumpers.
Rules: Children arrange themselves into three teams and each team stands in one of the corners, leaving one corner empty. One person stands in the middle of the square. He or she is "It".

Each of the teams is named after a fish. The person who is "It" calls one of the fish names and the people from that team must rush to the empty corner without being touched by whoever is "It". They must not run outside the box. If someone is tagged they are "out" for the rest of the game. The winner is the last person surviving. They win the game for their team.

Black Magic
Players: 4+
Equipment: None
Rules: Someone is "on". The others sit in a line facing in one direction and stretch their hands out in front of them. The person who is "on" runs down the line, touching each hand and saying with each touch "black, black, black".

Whenever they want to, they say "magic". As soon as they say it, they must run as fast as possible away from the line, and the person whose hand was touched last must leap up and say "stop". The "on" person must freeze. The person who shouted "stop" then adds up the number of letters in their first name and surname. That is the number of "pigeon" steps (toe-to-heel) they can make (Ann Smith = eight steps).

If the number of steps takes them within touching distance of the person who is "on", they swap places. The game can go on until the crack of doom or the bell for lessons, whichever comes sooner.

At Llanddulas primary, the pupils have become expert players of catching and skipping games, helped by a collection of ropes, balls, marbles and stones. That "the box", as it is known, and its modest contents have proved so popular is an object lesson in the benefits that flow from taking playtime seriously. "Until the spring of 1999 our small play area, no bigger than a netball court, was home to 110 children for two outdoor sessions a day," says deputy head Colin Lavelle. "The children passed the time trying to wrestle, imitate violent cartoons or run around the small playground at top speed - and collisions were inevitable." At that time, year 6 were busy surfing the net in their IT lessons. One of their searches took them to an Irish school site where they found the rules for traditional children's games. "We decided to test them out for ourselves," explains Lavelle. "Those the class liked received a full review, including ratings for difficulty and enjoyment. I decided to print off and laminate the reviews into game cards. And as some of them required balls and ropes, the box was born. "A few simple rules followed. No one could be excluded if they wanted to take part in an activity and balls were to be thrown and not kicked. The class also appointed two of their number to be the box monitors. And that was it - they were off." A year on and playground behaviour has changed radically. Nothing has been done to alter the environment. It remains a standard flat area of tarmac and yet the atmosphere is pleasantly different. None is more appreciative of this than the children themselves. "I just used to stay with the girls," says Kim Jasper, 10. "The boys were rough and it was boring just sitting around - we never played anything. Now it's fun." Her classmate Yasmin Morgan-Griffiths is also impressed by the transformation. "It was a surprise when the box came - I love the skipping and it's good to learn new games." Luke McKenna, nine, has recently arrived at Llanddulas. Playtime at his Solihull primary did not compare well. "My old playground was giant - apart from 'Tig' there was not much going on." An all too common problem, according to Thomson's survey of 1,000 children in Staffordshire, Shropshire and Lancashire. "All the schools I visited saw playtime as a time that could not be left entirely to the children's wishes," she explains. "It seemed that many of the children's attempts to play were extinguished by the same supervising adults who complained that children 'did not play'." According to consultant Marc Armitage, it is all too easy for teachers to miss the elaborate games that are going on. "Before anything is changed in a playground it is essential to carry out a thorough audit of what is really happening. Not to do so is to risk displacing existing activities." Tim Gill, director of the Children's Play Council, agrees. "Far too often schools cope with playground problems by clamping down. School playgrounds may look like chaotic places, but playtime is one of the few oases in children's lives when they can just be themselves." Education consultant Wendy Titman points out that playtime constitutes a kind of "informal curriculum" and needs as much sensitive nurturing as the subjects taught formally indoors. "Sadly, it receives less and less emphasis," she says. "The government is very muddled here," adds Ken Davies of charity Learning Through Landscapes. "It wants the next generation to be healthy and happy but all the emphasis on the classroom means it's loading things in the opposite direction." Meanwhile at Llanddulas, the stimulation continues. "We have entered an interesting stage," says Lavelle. "For the most part, the pupils that selected the box activities have left the school and now the games are being adapted - the names and rules are altering." For Luke McKenna, the spirit of independence is even more advanced. "To be honest," he says, "I never play the games the teachers teach us - I invent my own." Useful link Llandulas' playground games directory The games people play The Bomb Players: 5+ Equipment: tennis ball. Rules: Everyone stands in a circle. One person throws the ball to someone else (at chest height so it is easy to catch). As soon as the ball leaves the first person's hands, the group starts a countdown - ten, nine, etc. The idea is to get rid of the ball as quickly as possible by throwing it to another person. When the countdown reaches one, the next shout is "bomb" - and the person left holding the ball is out. If "bomb" is shouted when the ball is in mid-air, the last person to touch the ball is out. The winner is the last person in. Fish Players: Three teams and an extra person, ie 7, 10, 13, 16 or 19 people. Equipment: A large square space (3m by 3m or more), with corners marked with posts or jumpers. Rules: Children arrange themselves into three teams and each team stands in one of the corners, leaving one corner empty. One person stands in the middle of the square. He or she is "It". Each of the teams is named after a fish. The person who is "It" calls one of the fish names and the people from that team must rush to the empty corner without being touched by whoever is "It". They must not run outside the box. If someone is tagged they are "out" for the rest of the game. The winner is the last person surviving. They win the game for their team. Black Magic Players: 4+ Equipment: None Rules: Someone is "on". The others sit in a line facing in one direction and stretch their hands out in front of them. The person who is "on" runs down the line, touching each hand and saying with each touch "black, black, black". Whenever they want to, they say "magic". As soon as they say it, they must run as fast as possible away from the line, and the person whose hand was touched last must leap up and say "stop". The "on" person must freeze. The person who shouted "stop" then adds up the number of letters in their first name and surname. That is the number of "pigeon" steps (toe-to-heel) they can make (Ann Smith = eight steps). If the number of steps takes them within touching distance of the person who is "on", they swap places. The game can go on until the crack of doom or the bell for lessons, whichever comes sooner.

webTitle: Education: The diary of a parent governor

fields.headline: On the board
fields.standfirst: The diary of a parent governor
fields.trailText: The diary of a parent governor
fields.body:
A couple of weeks have passed since our performance management training evening, and nothing more has been said on the subject. In the meantime I find myself drawn ineluctably through the school gates again for a meeting of one of the committees I volunteered for - curriculum development.

Since this is not an open meeting, or even a full meeting of governors, it takes place in the informal surroundings of the staff room. The atmosphere is subtly but perceptibly different from other governors' meetings. The group is smaller and more intimate but, more important, all but one other governor are members of staff. There is a brief pause for greetings when I come in, but then the assembled company returns to informal gossip. I feel like a trespasser.

Present are: the head, Mr Richardson; his jolly deputy Mrs Mills; an experienced year 4 teacher named Miss Roberts (this is not a school where the concept of "Ms" exists): a staff assistant, Mrs Madigan; the staff governor who is a dinner lady, always known simply as Marcia (this is not a school where ancillary staff have surnames); and a partnership governor, Terry, who works in some lay capacity for a nearby City Mission.

The presence of the latter I note with sinking heart - not because he is unpleasant (quite the opposite, he is, in that distinctively Christian way, too nice). The problem is that Susie (the friend who put me up to this governor business) has been haranguing me about how "the God Squad" are taking over the school, turning assembly into "happy-clappy hour" and so on.

Most of the parents seem entirely uninterested, but then that goes for virtually everything. If anything, they seem to see the school's vaguely religious tone as another sign of its affiliation with traditional educational values and to approve of it - even though the version of Christianity on offer is evangelical rather than good old CofE.

By contrast, Susie - a card-carrying burn-the-churches anarchist - is the most vocal tribune of the minority tendency with which I identify myself: the middle-class, liberal-lefty secularists. As luck would have it, the school's religious education policy is up for discussion today. I grit my teeth and attempt to summon up some atheist rigour.

Even when called to order, however, the meeting's coffee morning atmosphere is disarming. The reason the RE policy has been rewritten is a largely formal one, that it needed to be updated - or to be seen to have been updated. As Miss Roberts points out, Ofsted inspections are moving from four-yearly to three-yearly intervals; a school moreover is likely now to receive only six weeks' notice of an inspection, instead of three months. Hence curriculum development means mainly this "rolling programme", as she calls it, of ploughing through all the teaching policies and ensuring they haven't passed their sell-by date. I take a deep breath.

"Er, since we're discussing RE, a number of, ah, parents have raised concerns with me about whether assemblies are sufficiently multidenominational. I mean, are we giving sufficient weight to other religions and indeed, um, non-religious themes. In assembly, I mean?"

Mrs Mills beams at me: "Oh yes. Absolutely. We follow the national curriculum on this. It sets out the proportion of Christian, Muslim, Hindu and other religions we have to include: you know, the five main religions. Plus a certain number of assemblies are devoted to issues of behaviour - telling them how to be nice to other people, basically.

"Oh yes, we go by the book as far as that's concerned. I don't think you need to worry."

"Ah, right. No, I suppose not."

I feel utterly nonplussed and pathetic. What do I tell Susie? Oh, God.

fields.headline: Holy grail
fields.standfirst: As last week's league tables confirm, church schools have what it takes. And whatever it is, David Blunkett is looking for it. By  Joanna Moorhead
fields.trailText: As last week's league tables confirm, church schools have what it takes. And whatever it is, David Blunkett is looking for it. By Joanna Moorhead.
fields.body:
Pre-kids, being Catholic was deeply uncool. I'd tell people and they'd look at me with that glazed look: wasn't it all about sexual hang-ups and guilt?

But now I'm a parent and most of my friends are, too, being a Catholic has a completely different currency. "Really?" they say, eyes bright. "You're so lucky. That means your children are in a church school, right?"

Right. And church schools, as the newly released primary school Sats league tables once again confirm, deliver. Of the top 20 highest scoring schools in England, 13 were church schools; of the 50 schools at the bottom of the league tables, only eight were. And they're getting better: of England's 100 most improved schools, 35 were church schools.

Chances are, wherever you live, the "best" school locally will be Saint This or Our Lady of Something-or-Other. It's not uniform, of course: there are excellent county schools, too, and average church schools. But the pattern of achievement is consistent and - though we all know Sats are only one indicator of success - they tell a story.

It's a funny kind of story, because religion isn't exactly flying high when it comes to bums on pews. But what churches lack in attracting worshippers they make up for when it comes to attracting parents: the vast majority of church primaries are heavily oversubscribed, and those that don't get filled up with the children of churchgoers have no shortage of takers from non-believing families.

Ask about the secret of their success, and one word keeps on cropping up. Ethos. Schools standards minister Jacqui Smith recently told Catholic educationalists in Wigan: "When I think of a Catholic school, I think of a strong ethos." Her boss David Blunkett is on record as saying that if he could, he'd like to bottle whatever it is that makes church schools so successful.

Without even trying, a church school undoubtedly is part of the community. My children are at mass on a Sunday with the same people we see at school on a Monday: in the congregation, too, are teachers and governors. The parish priest (who chairs the governors) and his assistant are in and out of the school.

There's a real sense in which the community owns the school, too. The parishioners are making a financial contribution, and the governors are not only connected with the church, but are also the actual employers of the teaching staff. "It's about unity of purpose," says Eileen Fitzpatrick, director of the Leeds Catholic Diocesan Education Service. "In accepting a job in a church school a teacher is buying into the system, and agreeing to support the same aims and ambitions."

When it comes to aims and ambitions, the interesting thing is that church schools do not put academic achievement above all else. "We're definitely not a school that's driven by Sats results," says Monica Speers, head of Our Lady of Fatima School in Harborne, Birmingham, which scored top marks in the Sats tables. "We aim to do well academically, of course, but at the end of the day we're trying to educate well-rounded human beings. We're trying to make them good citizens, and we're trying to encourage them to be good Christians as well."

RE, as you'd expect, is taken seriously. "Catholic schools are very keen to ensure that 10% of the curriculum is RE," says Fitzpatrick. "In the past, people used to say of our schools, 'look, they get good test results in spite of all that time spent on RE'. Now they're coming from it the other way and saying 'perhaps it's because they take RE seriously that they're doing so well'."

These days, RE is a lot more about how God loves us, how each one of us is cherished. "It gives them a sense of self-worth and purpose," says Fitzpatrick. "And we also see the pursuit of excellence as part of our spiritual quest - in our search for God, we have to do our very best."

And parental involvement, which schools now fall over one another to prove they've got, has long been a feature of church schools. "Home-school contracts?" says Fitzpatrick. "We practically invented them, about a hundred years ago and without a piece of paper. Church schools have always been able to work in close partnership with parents."

John Coe of the National Association for Primary Education agrees. "The general level of parental support is high in church schools, as is family stability. There's a powerful family ethos at work - I'm not making a qualitative judgement, but the stability and structure and reassurance do add a great sense of well-being to young children."

The fact that church primaries tend to be small - many are one-form entry - is another plus. "There's a definite correlation between the smallness of the school and academic success," says Coe. Marian Driver, head of another top-scorer in the Sats tests, St Mary's Church of England Primary in Bitteswell, Leicestershire, says small is also beautiful when it comes to bureaucracy, or lack of it. "We've got just 115 pupils on our roll, and it does make everything much simpler. In a large school there are always more people involved in any meeting or discussion, and communication is more of a problem."

St Mary's, surrounded by countryside, is blessed with a distinct lack of youngsters who are in any way disadvantaged - but, says Canon John Hall, general secretary of the Church of England Board of Education, it's too simplistic to say church schools do well because they often have a high proportion of advantaged pupils. "We do have rural schools, but we also have many schools in inner cities, and though Anglican congregations may include middle-class families, they often include people from disadvan taged backgrounds, too.

"What's more, Anglican schools don't always take children just from among the worshipping community - some are open to those who live closest to the school, and see their role as serving the general population." This isn't, however, true of Catholic schools, which always provide first and foremost for their own.

And there's the rub, because however good church schools are, they're not desirable, designed or available for every child. Yet the evidence that they've got something significantly right is growing - and while the education department may have its ear cocked to hear what it is, it may be something recent education policy hasn't done much to encourage. After all, at the end of the day "ethos" isn't what Ofsted inspectors are most interested in. And maybe it's the thing that should interest them most of all.
