webTitle: Education: Deptford Green school's citizenship day

fields.headline: Citizen gain
fields.standfirst: Deptford Green school is setting the pace in nurturing the citizens of tomorrow, explains  Esther Addley
fields.trailText: Deptford Green school is setting the pace in nurturing the citizens of tomorrow, explains Esther Addley.
fields.body:
Keith Ajegbo is missing a weatherman. It is nearly ten past nine at Deptford Green school in New Cross, south London, the morning beeps have gone and the senior students are already waiting in the sports hall for today's special assembly, but the star speaker is nowhere to be seen.

Ajegbo, the headteacher, has the half-excited, half-harassed air of a man who has been planning this day for months. "Everything would be fine if I only had Ian McCaskill," he calls over his shoulder, breaking into a trot along the corridor.

Today is an important day at Deptford Green. It's the inaugural "citizenship day", intended to flag the school's commitment to teaching pupils to become responsible and engaged members of public life. Since David Blunkett last year established citizenship as a core curriculum requirement from 2002, the education department has been eager to locate schools developing best practice in teaching a subject that critics still regard as amorphous and abstract, neatly conceived on paper, but almost impossible to develop into meaningful, practical lessons. In Deptford Green, at least, the department has found a willing innovator.

Forty minutes later, the missing McCaskill has been located and put to task exhorting 600 students to look after the environment. Local MP Joan Ruddock attempts to impress on them the importance of their vote, and a number of other dignitaries stress the importance of getting involved. The students are then packed off to their different locations for the day's citizenship-promoting activities.

Workshops range from rubbish recycling to preparing a broadcast at a local radio station; from staging a mock parliamentary debate to compiling a photoarchive of the area. A lucky few have managed to make it onto the trips to Tate Modern and the Houses of Parliament; in one room a group of 20 pupils are learning to juggle.

If Deptford Green is not quite unique in its emphasis on civic engagement, the way it is funding today's citizenship activities is unprecedented. Last year the school approached the government with a proposal that it be accepted as a specialist college. Instead of specialising in one of the four core areas of arts, technology, languages and sport, however, Deptford Green would be a centre of excellence in citizenship.

Perhaps surprisingly, they were not immediately shown the door. The first curriculum materials for teaching citizenship will be launched tomorrow, but many are still unclear as to how the subject will work in practice. "We need clearer examples of what citizenship actually means to teachers on the ground," says David Kerr, a citizenship consultant to the education department who is one of a number of observers prowling the corridors.

"They are probably going to develop good practice here. That's a very powerful model for the way it might well work for other schools." Deptford Green has not been given specialist status, but the department did award £150,000 over two years to develop practical curriculum models, which the school matched with £50,000 from the investment bank UBS Warburg.

The money will be spent on a peripatetic citizenship worker and on a community space, stocked with computers, that will be open to parents as well as students. The responsibilities of the student-staffed school council will be extended to include consultation on curriculum and school governance, and an element of civic engagement will run through the humanities curriculum.

The school is also developing a short course in citizenship, which it hopes to have recognised by an exam board, and eventually plans to offer some form of academic accreditation to students volunteering in the local community.

But if winning over the government was one thing, Ajegbo must now convince his students of the project's value. In a classroom upstairs, a distinguished visitor is outlining the procedures in a magistrate's court. "The first thing that happens is that the clerk reads out the charge ..." The students slump over their desks.

Another group are watching a video about how parliament works. "The government are taking our money at 16 and they are spending it on other people's dole," says one girl from year 11 indignantly. "They aren't spending it on us, because we can't vote them out until we're 18." True, concedes the teacher, although she could write to Tony Blair directly. "As if he would pick up that letter and just decide to change the way the whole government works," scoffs her friend.

At the back of the circus skills session, sixth-formers are making a video of the day's activities. "The teachers say we are learning to work as a group, but I think it's just a fun day off school," says Zarina, 17. "There are people in this room learning how to balance a scarf on their heads - what has that got to do with citizenship?"

Her friend Bode is irritated by Joan Ruddock's claim in assembly that she represents the area. "She said she was the leader of Deptford and she doesn't know anything about Deptford, she's not even from here. I think she needs to take a trip to the Pepys estate, because it's dangerous out there." The things they need to be learning about are "safety and where you live, and those kind of things," he says.

Rohan, who is 17, is indignant about the man in a suit he tried to interview for the video who told him to "chill". "Some of the people here are just doing it to get promoted," he says into a video camera balanced on his friend's shoulder. The citizenship day is a good idea, he says, but it's been a bit boring. But haven't they just given up their lunch hour to make the video? He stops, then gives a wicked grin and bounds off to interview the passing drama teacher, accidentally enthused by the task in hand.

A lucky few have managed to make it onto the trips to Tate Modern and the Houses of Parliament; in one room a group of 20 pupils are learning to juggle. If Deptford Green is not quite unique in its emphasis on civic engagement, the way it is funding today's citizenship activities is unprecedented. Last year the school approached the government with a proposal that it be accepted as a specialist college. Instead of specialising in one of the four core areas of arts, technology, languages and sport, however, Deptford Green would be a centre of excellence in citizenship. Perhaps surprisingly, they were not immediately shown the door. The first curriculum materials for teaching citizenship will be launched tomorrow, but many are still unclear as to how the subject will work in practice. "We need clearer examples of what citizenship actually means to teachers on the ground," says David Kerr, a citizenship consultant to the education department who is one of a number of observers prowling the corridors. "They are probably going to develop good practice here. That's a very powerful model for the way it might well work for other schools." Deptford Green has not been given specialist status, but the department did award £150,000 over two years to develop practical curriculum models, which the school matched with £50,000 from the investment bank UBS Warburg. The money will be spent on a peripatetic citizenship worker and on a community space, stocked with computers, that will be open to parents as well as students. The responsibilities of the student-staffed school council will be extended to include consultation on curriculum and school governance, and an element of civic engagement will run through the humanities curriculum. The school is also developing a short course in citizenship, which it hopes to have recognised by an exam board, and eventually plans to offer some form of academic accreditation to students volunteering in the local community. But if winning over the government was one thing, Ajegbo must now convince his students of the project's value. In a classroom upstairs, a distinguished visitor is outlining the procedures in a magistrate's court. "The first thing that happens is that the clerk reads out the charge ..." The students slump over their desks. Another group are watching a video about how parliament works. "The government are taking our money at 16 and they are spending it on other people's dole," says one girl from year 11 indignantly. "They aren't spending it on us, because we can't vote them out until we're 18." True, concedes the teacher, although she could write to Tony Blair directly. "As if he would pick up that letter and just decide to change the way the whole government works," scoffs her friend. At the back of the circus skills session, sixth-formers are making a video of the day's activities. "The teachers say we are learning to work as a group, but I think it's just a fun day off school," says Zarina, 17. "There are people in this room learning how to balance a scarf on their heads - what has that got to do with citizenship?" Her friend Bode is irritated by Joan Ruddock's claim in assembly that she represents the area. "She said she was the leader of Deptford and she doesn't know anything about Deptford, she's not even from here. I think she needs to take a trip to the Pepys estate, because it's dangerous out there." The things they need to be learning about are "safety and where you live, and those kind of things," he says. Rohan, who is 17, is indignant about the man in a suit he tried to interview for the video who told him to "chill". "Some of the people here are just doing it to get promoted," he says into a video camera balanced on his friend's shoulder. The citizenship day is a good idea, he says, but it's been a bit boring. But haven't they just given up their lunch hour to make the video? He stops, then gives a wicked grin and bounds off to interview the passing drama teacher, accidentally enthused by the task in hand.

fields.headline: Class notes
fields.trailText: • The Plain English Campaign has announced its annual awards for talking nonsense. This year, Luton education authority was singled out for a booby prize for calling children's go-karting lessons "a multi-agency project catering for holistic diversionary provision to young people for positive action". Beat that if you can. Worryingly, the campaign's "Golden Bull" awards for nonsense in official publications went to a record 11 organisations this year.
fields.body:
 The Plain English Campaign has announced its annual awards for talking nonsense. This year, Luton education authority was singled out for a booby prize for calling children's go-karting lessons "a multi-agency project catering for holistic diversionary provision to young people for positive action". Beat that if you can. Worryingly, the campaign's "Golden Bull" awards for nonsense in official publications went to a record 11 organisations this year.

 Speaking of bad English, the news release sent out by Conservative Central Office commenting on the primary school league tables said numeracy and literacy standards would have been even higher had Labour not "medalled in our education system". A correction followed within the hour - accusing the government of having "meddled".

 To lose one key figure in education is unfortunate, to lose two might seem like carelessness. Barely had Chris Woodhead vacated the hot seat at Ofsted before Mike Tomlinson took over. But who will replace our friend Nigel de Gruchy, who in terms of sheer cheekiness (never mind the soundbites) has become arguably the most high-profile teacher union leader?

By the time he steps down as general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters/Union of Women Teachers in Easter 2002 to become president of the TUC for a year, he will have done the job for a staggering 12 years. The front runners are assistant secretary Chris Keates, treasurer Mick Carney and deputy general secretary Eamonn O'Kane.

 The Guardian's disclosure earlier this month of the decision to close Telegraph Hill school in south-east London came as the Royal Society of Arts went to press with a discussion document on the school within the broader context of failing schools.

The study followed the development of the school throughout a critical year, after it was reopened in September 1999 under the government's controversial fresh start scheme. Its author, educational consultant John Bastiani, was given regular access and his fly-on-the wall account is a fascinating read. Copies are available for £6 each (including p&p) from Lesley James, head of education, Royal Society of Arts, 8 John Adam Street, London WC2N 6EZ.

webTitle: Education: Language degrees are less popular

fields.headline: Babel rebuilt?
fields.standfirst: Numbers taking language degrees have been falling steeply but  Keith Marshall's  research has revealed the stirrings of a sixth-form revival - thanks to AS-levels
fields.trailText: Numbers taking language degrees have been falling steeply but Keith Marshall's research has revealed the stirrings of a sixth-form revival - thanks to AS-levels.
fields.body:
The end of the 20th century has left the specialist study of modern languages in the UK in crisis. Universities are cutting single honours degrees, whole departments are closing and the study of some languages may cease altogether. This is because the supply of A-level students from schools and colleges has gone into sharp decline.

In the late 1980s and early 90s, there had been an upswing in language learning at school and university. A language was made a compulsory core subject in the national curriculum.

Around 1992 that began to change. In French and German, in languages overall, A-level numbers have declined relentlessly. The only exception is Spanish, but not enough to compensate for the overall decline.

The fault line in language learning is not the passage from school to university, it is the passage from year 11 to 12 from GCSE to the first year of A-level, from secondary school to sixth form/further education college.

After GCSE, the point in the education system where pupils can choose whether to do a language, more and more have opted not to. Why is this?

There are many reasons, some based on misinformation and misunderstanding. The rise of English as an international language, the growing hostility in the UK to the European Union have something to do with it. There are also perceptions among school pupils that languages are more difficult than most other subjects, or that they will improve their career prospects if they do "vocational" subjects, more of which are now available at A-level.

While brighter pupils have been doing eight to 12 GCSEs, they have only been doing two to four A-levels. There has been a suspicion that pupils were having to drop subjects they were ready and able to do.

In October 1998, to test if frustrated would-be linguists existed in sixth forms, Bangor University's modern languages department carried out a survey in 110 schools and colleges across the country. It addressed 2,200 year 12 pupils who had got A*, A or B in a GCSE language but were not doing that language at A-level.

It found that a substantial proportion, given the chance to do another A-level, would have chosen a language: this would have been enough to raise by as much as 50% the number of A-level language students in their institutions.

In the academic session 2000-2001 there is a chance to make this happen. Curriculum 2000, designed to broaden the range of subjects and skills pursued in the sixth form, divides the old-style, two-year A-level into two separate awards: AS-level taken in the lower sixth, and A2-level taken at the end of the upper sixth. Pupils are being encouraged to do an extra subject at AS-level. The question is how many have made that extra AS-level subject a language they have done at GCSE? And how many will continue it to A2-level?

The final AS-level entry numbers will not be available until spring 2001, but knowing how things are shaping up could help teachers and pupils to up their efforts this winter.

So Bangor has done a provisional survey of UK schools and colleges. With 112 returns analysed to date, and caveats about the size of that sample, the results are encouraging:

 Numbers for the new style AS-level this year (2000-2001) look like being dramatically up on those for the old- style A-level + AS last year (1999-2000) - 74% of schools report an increase;

 French is up 35%, Spanish 31%, German 15%;

 All languages together are up 30%;

 Minor languages such as Italian and Russian have increased, though from low base lines;

 Numbers doing two languages are up by 44%;

 Teachers' predictions for the new A2 over the old A-level are optimistic: Spanish to go up 28%, German 17%, French 13%.

Curriculum 2000 holds enormous potential for modern languages. For the short term, it is important that this message of good cheer goes out to sixth form language teachers, so as to demonstrate the high stakes we are playing for this year.

Making a success of AS-level in terms of numbers and results in its first year is vital. It will create a platform on which to build a bridge to A2-level next year and from there on to university. In the longer term, universities can play their part in realising the potential of these new exams.

If the schools in the Bangor survey are typical, then the new AS-levels are on the brink of turning round dramatically the fortunes of specialist language learning in sixth forms and universities. By pulling together, language teachers at secondary, further education and higher education levels can improve the odds on the dawn of the 21st century being a new dawn for languages in the UK.

 Meanwhile, the position in universities has deteriorated with a further drop in students starting single honours language degrees this autumn (figures are being compiled by the funding councils), writes Donald MacLeod.

Specialists fear a new round of cutbacks will leave universities unable to cope if and when the number of applicants increases. Hilary Footitt, chair of the University Council of Modern Languages (UCML), urged vice-chancellors to take a longer-term view of the prospects of their languages departments because numbers were likely to rise.

"If they don't, we may have to run down or close languages departments and then find there is a real national need for specialist linguists, and an increasing number of students wanting to take languages in higher education on the strength of the new curriculum."

Hull University's ruling council on Friday discussed a radical review of all subjects, including a switch from single honours language degrees to joint degrees like chemistry and German. Minority languages are under particular pressure and staff fear Dutch could be cut at one of only four centres in England (the others are at Cambridge, Sheffield and University College London). A university spokesman said single honours languages had been in decline because fewer students were doing them at A-level but joint degrees were popular.

Footitt said the UK needed a strategic approach; otherwise decisions by individual universities would decimate language provision. "With all the talk of the Nice summit, it's about time that we looked at what our EU partners are doing, and tried to see ways in which UK cooperation with specific EU countries could help us to preserve and develop our language base."

 Keith Marshall is from the School of Modern Languages, University of Wales, Bangor. Information on UCML can be obtained here.

What can universities do?

To maximise numbers doing not only AS-level but A2-level, university and college language departments can reach out to pupils in the lower sixth and earlier years, helping teachers make the case for modern languages.

Admissions officers, across all academic disciplines, can encourage pupils in schools to do languages to AS-level by accepting unreservedly the UCAS points applicants gain from them. Language departments can provide first-year courses catering for students arriving with the new AS-level language skills (between GCSE and full A-level/A2-level).

More degrees can be constructed with other subjects, which allow for the study of languages to a level below full honours standard.

Fall and rise of language learning

Change in exam entries for A-level or A-level equivalents in modern languages 1993-2002* (*predicted)

Old-style A-level and AS-level

Subject | 1993 | 1999 | Change 1993-1999

French 33,037 22,902 -10,135 (- 31%)

German 12,072 10,317 -1,755 (-15%)

Spanish 5,329 6,399 +1,070 (+20%)

New-style A-level (1) and AS-level

Subject | AS Change 1999-2000 | A2 (2) change 1999-2002

French +35% +13%

German +15% +17%

Spanish +31% +28%

Notes
1 Percentage changes (actual) in take-up for new-style AS in schools surveyed 1999/2000-2000/2001, 2 Percentage changes (predicted) in take-up for new-style A2 in schools surveyed 1999/2000-2001/2002
Source: Marshall

fields.headline: Maradona's return eclipses ceremony
fields.standfirst: Fifa's gong night in pictures
fields.trailText: Diego Maradona's chlidish spat with Pele over the Argentinian's status as the century's best player overshadowed the player of the year gala last night, won by Zinedine Zidane.
fields.body:
Diego Maradona made a dramatic return to Italy last night to collect his player of the century award as his feud with his arch-rival Pele overshadowed Fifa's annual player of the year gala in Rome, won by the France midfielder Zinedine Zidane for the second time in three years.

The 40-year-old Maradona, who played for Napoli for seven years until 1991, flew into Rome accompanied by his wife Claudia, his two daughters, mother, father, brother and manager and was met at the airport by a fleet of Mercedes after answering an emergency personal plea from Fifa's president Sepp Blatter to come to the Italian capital and patch up his differences with Pele.

The pair have been at loggerheads ever since becoming embroiled in a war of words over which of the two was more deserving to win the player of the century accolade.

In a bizarre diplomatic move designed not to spoil their big pre-Christmas extravaganza, Fifa announced on Sunday that a second, separate award was being given to Pele after its original internet poll open to the general public had been surprisingly won by Maradona, who took 53.60% of the internet vote ahead of Pele's 18.53%.

Both were besieged by the media as they arrived at last night's gala within seconds of each other. While Maradona made no comment, Pele said: "It's true we are not good friends. He was a good player and I have respect for him but if he thinks he was a better player than me, that's his problem."

Amid the childish spat, Zidane was the model of diplomacy. Asked to decide between Pele and Maradona, the Frenchman replied: "They are both great players who played at different times and in different epochs."

Any hopes of Zidane joining his numerous compatriots in the Premiership were firmly dashed by the World Cup and European Championship-winning midfielder. "The English league is excellent with many high-quality players but it is not one of my priorities," he said. "I have a contract with Juventus until 2005."

Zidane picked up 370 votes, ahead of second-placed Luis Figo who gained 329. Third was last year's winner, Rivaldo, with 265. The top British player was David Beckham, who came sixth.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Not tonight darling, I've got a big game on tomorrow

fields.headline: Not tonight darling, I've got a big game on tomorrow
fields.trailText: Down the years sportsmen have produced enough ludicrous libidinal analogies to keep the Fast Show's Swiss Tony going for several decades.
fields.body:
The former QPR striker Stan Bowles once said that faced with a choice between a night with Raquel Welch and a day in a betting shop, he'd take the betting shop every time. Bowles is clearly the sort of player who'd be welcomed by the Wimbledon boss Terry Burton.

Last week the Dons' waggish manager blamed his side's poor form at Selhurst Park - they have won there only twice this season - on the fact that some of his players were having sex the night before the game. He is now proposing that the team spend the eve of home matches in a hotel. Though, given the price of accommodation in London, Bowles's preferred venue might be cheaper.

Some may feel that Burton's comments belong to a bygone era. Or indeed the 1970s when the International Olympic Committee president Avery Brundage felt moved to observe: "The ancient Greeks kept women out of their games. They wouldn't even allow them on the sidelines. I'm not sure but that they were right." (The more you learn about Brundage the more you come to realise that his name was the least ridiculous thing about him.)

However, in an era when practically every other aspect of a footballer's personal wellbeing, be it his body fat ratio or bruised ego, is under the care of highly trained professionals it is refreshing to know that at least one area of the game is still entrusted to people with a degree in saloon-bar philosophy from the university of life (formerly vital force college of further education).

The notion that sex uses up the same energies as sport and is therefore bad for athletes predates even Avery Brundage. Many warrior societies have held fast to the belief that women distract a man from his true purpose in life, which is of course to jab pointy sticks into total strangers. Since many coaches believe that each match is a battle of Thermopylae (albeit with more hooved beasts on the field, if the opposition are managed by John Beck) why wouldn't they take inspiration from those wife-shy Spartans?

The participants themselves, who seem as keen to compare sport with coition as managers are to link it with warfare, have further strengthened the theory. Down the years sportsmen have produced enough ludicrous libidinal analogies to keep the Fast Show's Swiss Tony going for several decades. Jackie Stewart, for example, told us that "Cornering a car is like bringing a woman to climax", Eddie Irvine that winning a grand prix "is like making love to the 10 most beautiful women in the world", and Jim Baxter observed that "I've always believed in treating the ball like a woman" (what, sitting on her in the middle of the pitch at Wembley in front of 100,000 people?)

Some sportsmen would clearly have to ransack their memory banks to match Fabrizio Ravanelli's comment, "scoring is like a form of orgasm. You feel exhausted but happy". In his excellent biography of the cyclist Sean Kelly, David Walsh recalled a seminar in Dublin at which the Irishman answered questions from the audience. Kelly was notoriously laconic but when asked about sexual abstinence he spoke eloquently enough, replying that he did not have sex for a week before a one-day classic and for six weeks before a major tour. Later, after some hurried calculations, another pro remarked: "By my reckoning Linda [Kelly's wife] is still a virgin."

Another great believer in chastity was the undefeated heavyweight champion Rocky Marciano. The Rock excused himself from the marital bed for months before a fight because he believed that sex weakened the legs. If this is true then we can only wonder what might have happened if George Best had managed to stay away from beauty contestants for a few months. He'd likely have become the first man to leap the Channel.

Though Kelly and Marciano were both great sportsmen, to my mind the final word on this matter belongs to Angelo Dundee, veteran trainer of the far from chaste Muhammad Ali. In a conversation with the wily old cornerman, the sports writer George Clinton mentioned that during Primo Carnera's days as heavyweight champ the gigantic Italian became so concerned about the debilitating effects of desire that he took to wrapping a rubber band around his member when he went to bed. "Carnera?" Dundee replied scornfully. "He could have cut it right off and he still wouldn't have been a fighter."

Or indeed the 1970s when the International Olympic Committee president Avery Brundage felt moved to observe: "The ancient Greeks kept women out of their games. They wouldn't even allow them on the sidelines. I'm not sure but that they were right." (The more you learn about Brundage the more you come to realise that his name was the least ridiculous thing about him.) However, in an era when practically every other aspect of a footballer's personal wellbeing, be it his body fat ratio or bruised ego, is under the care of highly trained professionals it is refreshing to know that at least one area of the game is still entrusted to people with a degree in saloon-bar philosophy from the university of life (formerly vital force college of further education). The notion that sex uses up the same energies as sport and is therefore bad for athletes predates even Avery Brundage. Many warrior societies have held fast to the belief that women distract a man from his true purpose in life, which is of course to jab pointy sticks into total strangers. Since many coaches believe that each match is a battle of Thermopylae (albeit with more hooved beasts on the field, if the opposition are managed by John Beck) why wouldn't they take inspiration from those wife-shy Spartans? The participants themselves, who seem as keen to compare sport with coition as managers are to link it with warfare, have further strengthened the theory. Down the years sportsmen have produced enough ludicrous libidinal analogies to keep the Fast Show's Swiss Tony going for several decades. Jackie Stewart, for example, told us that "Cornering a car is like bringing a woman to climax", Eddie Irvine that winning a grand prix "is like making love to the 10 most beautiful women in the world", and Jim Baxter observed that "I've always believed in treating the ball like a woman" (what, sitting on her in the middle of the pitch at Wembley in front of 100,000 people?) Some sportsmen would clearly have to ransack their memory banks to match Fabrizio Ravanelli's comment, "scoring is like a form of orgasm. You feel exhausted but happy". In his excellent biography of the cyclist Sean Kelly, David Walsh recalled a seminar in Dublin at which the Irishman answered questions from the audience. Kelly was notoriously laconic but when asked about sexual abstinence he spoke eloquently enough, replying that he did not have sex for a week before a one-day classic and for six weeks before a major tour. Later, after some hurried calculations, another pro remarked: "By my reckoning Linda [Kelly's wife] is still a virgin." Another great believer in chastity was the undefeated heavyweight champion Rocky Marciano. The Rock excused himself from the marital bed for months before a fight because he believed that sex weakened the legs. If this is true then we can only wonder what might have happened if George Best had managed to stay away from beauty contestants for a few months. He'd likely have become the first man to leap the Channel. Though Kelly and Marciano were both great sportsmen, to my mind the final word on this matter belongs to Angelo Dundee, veteran trainer of the far from chaste Muhammad Ali. In a conversation with the wily old cornerman, the sports writer George Clinton mentioned that during Primo Carnera's days as heavyweight champ the gigantic Italian became so concerned about the debilitating effects of desire that he took to wrapping a rubber band around his member when he went to bed. "Carnera?" Dundee replied scornfully. "He could have cut it right off and he still wouldn't have been a fighter."

webTitle: Lloyds cuts would hurt every bank customer

fields.headline: Lloyds cuts would hurt every bank customer
fields.standfirst: Notebook Bid for Abbey must be resisted
fields.trailText: Notebook Bid for Abbey must be resisted
fields.body:
It is crunch time. Lloyds TSB is expected to table a fresh offer, worth a little over £13 a share, for Abbey National this morning. Unless it is accepted by lunchtime, Lloyds will probably go hostile, promising job cuts, branchclosures, and massive savings.

The City, where lean and mean promises better shareholder returns, will applaud. It has seen Lloyds do it before - with Cheltenham & Gloucester, Trustee Savings Bank and, more recently, Scottish Widows. Chief executive Peter Ellwood will pledge annual savings of £500m and his oppo at Abbey, Ian Harley, will be fobbed off with a promise that his 750-strong branch network will be left alone for two years, restricting job losses to 8,000.

Thereafter the dirty work will begin. Lloyds has 2,200 branches and already, in more than 400 cases, two are within half a mile of each other - a legacy of TSB, where primary legislation was required before true integration could happen.

Great prospective news for shareholders, perhaps. But what about customers? This is a deal which will affect all of us who bank - whether with Lloyds or Abbey or anyone else.

By attempting to buy Abbey, Lloyds is effectively looking to take out one of its prime competitors. More importantly, it is acting now to prevent the creation of a "fifth force" in retail banking by spoiling the planned merger between Abbey and Bank of Scotland.

While the stats-bending department at Lloyds may be able to cite market shares that fail to match levels at which Royal Bank of Scotland was allowed to snap up NatWest, the circumstances are markedly different.

What should be foremost in the mind of the competition authorities which will decide this battle (forget about the City institutions here - the casting vote is closer to Whitehall) is that Abbey and BoS combined is a real danger to Lloyds. Even on its own, Abbey has been making all the noise about boosting its share of current accounts (less than 5%, against Lloyds' 25%) and its share of business accounts (almost non-existent at present).

This is competition in the clearest sense of the word. It is an unavoidable fact that, by allowing Abbey to join the Black Horse stable, it will reduce competition. This bid, if it happens, will destroy consumer value.

Shire audacity

From his base in a sleepy Andover farmhouse, Shire's chief executive, Rolf Stahel, has masterminded another international coup.

This time, Shire has swooped on a Canadian drugs firm that is making profits of $110m a year at an operating margin of nearly 60%.

BioChem Pharma is able to generate such earnings because it has struck gold with two key products: Epivir for HIV and Zeffix for hepatitis B. The company is one of the rare profitable graduates from the biotechnology industry, which Mr Stahel has dismissed as a game of "molecular roulette".

Critics yesterday queried whether Shire ought to be issuing $4bn of shares to buy a company with little of obvious value in the way of imminent product launches. Mr Stahel's answer is that steady cash from Epivir and Zeffix will reduce Shire's dependence on its psychiatric portfolio. He also believes BioChem's vaccine portfolio might contain a hidden "jewel", yielding results in the long term.

Mr Stahel's record of turning plodding donkeys into stallions is impressive - last year's merger with Roberts proved successful, despite attracting a similar reaction to yesterday's raspberry from the stock market.

Yesterday's deal might look chunky but it is difficult to attach a fair value to BioChem, because it outsources all of its marketing and distribution.

Shire has been the success story of the year for Britain's pharmaceuticals industry. The government should take note of the firm's warning that, unless drugs get friendlier treatment, it will follow Glaxo SmithKline by moving its nerve centre to North America.

No failing grace

At the age of 58, David Jones, chief executive of National Grid, has ousted himself. Roger Unwin, head of UK and Europe, takes over next March - a year before Mr Jones' scheduled retirement.

This man floated the business five years ago at £3.4bn and has watched its value grow to £9bn. A series of US acquisitions has taken Grid into the American top 10 of power firms; it was never going to be just another low-growth utility whose returns were set by the British regulator. Along the way, the extraordinary Energis telephone venture was spun off, leaving Grid with a 35% stake in a business worth £8.5bn.

So what does Mr Jones walk away with? Er, his pension - and that is it. No song and dance, no big kiss-off cheque.

He didn't fail, you see. He just did an exceptionally good job.

webTitle: New survey finds banks offer better savings rates

fields.headline: New survey finds banks offer better savings rates
fields.trailText: If you're looking for a savings account, banks - not building societies - offer the best rates, a new survey has revealed.
fields.body:
If you're looking for a savings account, banks - not building societies - offer the best rates, a new survey has revealed.

The Research Department (TRD), an independent financial services research organisation, found banks offering, on average, half a percent more than building societies on instant access savings accounts.

The research looked at the average savings rates offered by banks and building societies for a £1,000 investment on different types of account - branch, internet, postal and telephone. All savings plans, whether paying interest annually or monthly were included.

According to TRD, significant differences were found in the average rates for types of account. It found internet accounts paid the most with an average of 5.42%, followed by telephone accounts paying 4.59%, postal accounts paying 3.91% and branch accounts paying 2.66%.

"On the whole, bank accounts offered higher average rates for postal and telephone accounts while mutuals were better for branch and internet accounts. However, because mutuals have so few of either telephone or internet accounts the comparison is not really viable," TRD said.

In their traditional stronghold of branch based accounts, building societies offered an average of 2.77% against 2.48% paid by the banks. But for postal accounts, building societies paid only 3.71% on average compared with 4.03% paid by the banks.

The research also found that 83.5% of building society savers prefer branch accounts compared to just 45.6% in the banking sector, suggesting that building society customers are aware that branch based accounts offer the best value.

The moral of this story is: be aware that rates differ significantly between types of account and whether they reside in banks or building societies, and choose your account accordingly.

fields.headline: Smash Hits Poll Winners Party
fields.standfirst:
London Arena
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: London Arena Rating: ***
fields.body:
At the annual pop love-in that is the Smash Hits Poll Winners Party, two earth-shattering discoveries are made. First, if you're a pop star you have to wear black leather trousers - it's the law. More importantly, you need to have been born in the Emerald Isle. Because if you're not Irish, you ain't gonna win.

The Smash Hits party is ostensibly a chance for the readers of the magazine to catch a glimpse of their idols. Girls, uniformly wearing little vests, spend the last few frantic minutes before showtime alternating between smoothing their hair and blowing their whistles. As the countdown begins, the screaming gets louder.

Hosted by Richard Blackwood, Katy Hill and Louise, the show is slick, with bucket-loads of glitter streaming from the ceiling and fireworks going off every five minutes. And fortunately the tape machine's in full working order. This being the world of pop, most of the acts mime, or at best sing over their own backing tracks.

That makes sense when you've got one act running off the oddly designed set - supposedly an interpretation of a lost world - as another takes up position. But for Samantha Mumba, about to burst into Gotta Tell You (and almost out of her top) it means having to wait for someone to turn off Sonique.

Kylie Minogue camps it up nicely, lifted on to a podium by some bare-chested young men, posing and preening as she asks "Do you like what you see?", while Billie does Britney, even down to the hair extensions. Only All Saints let the side down, going through the motions as the girls around me point at Nicole Appleton and giggle.

But today is really all about the boys. At least on stage. Katy Hill makes the mistake of asking: "Have we got any boys in the house?" She is met by a rare silence. Because the men are here to be worshipped, adored and completely objectified. Whether it's Ronan or H from Steps, they're fantasy figures come to life.

Five are the best of the frankly dismal-looking bunch, a great performance of We Will Rock You starting out as a carol before the guitar screeches and pop's bad boys whip off their all-white costumes to reveal, yep, black leather trousers, which fan fave Richie battles to keep on, their bagginess almost beating him.

Westlife, on the other hand, win practically everything - from Best Album to Best Haircut - and do little, sitting on stools and singing the aberration that is My Love.

Only Bryan MacFadden tries to lift the dirge by donning a white T-shirt with Five emblazoned on it in jewels. Just like their music, it's been done better before, but the teens keep screaming.

webTitle: Irish trilogy full of life and soul

fields.headline: Irish trilogy full of life and soul
fields.standfirst:
The Wexford Trilogy
Tricycle
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText: The Wexford Trilogy Tricycle London Rating: ****
fields.body:
Billy Roche's play A Handful of Stars dropped unsolicited through the letterbox of the Bush Theatre in 1987 and was produced the following year. It heralded the arrival of a major writer, the first trickle of what was to become a torrent of Irish writers who looked towards Britain to have their work produced, and the first play in what was to develop - with Poor Beast in the Rain and Belfry - into a trilogy about small-town Irish life.

Now, for only the second time in Britain, there is a chance to see all three plays, either in a single day or over several nights. You should seize the opportunity. These are not showy plays; individually, you might even say, they are slight. But their heart beats so loudly and with such compassion that the cumulative effect is of gazing down from a great height upon swarming, sweaty humanity.

These are plays about little people in an insignificant Irish town whose ordinary lives are transformed into extraordinary drama. Roche turns gossip into theatre and the everyday into mythology. It doesn't matter what order you see them in: whether you engage first with tearaway Jimmy taking futile pot-shots at the town and hiding his wounded heart with a swagger in A Handful of Stars, or his theatrical descendant, Danger Doyle, returning to Wexford after an absence of 10 years in Poor Beast in the Rain. You can begin or end with Belfry, about the sacristan Artie O'Leary who hasn't really lived until Angela, who arranges the flowers, shows him how. Whatever the order, it is the sound of the church bell, tolling mournfully for these small, unfulfilled but rich lives, that you will take away with you.

Plenty of Irish plays have covered similar territory since. In modern Irish drama every small community is a frontier town with mythic anti-heroes. But Roche succeeds in a way that somehow seems true, not contrived, pointing to the way we mythologise our lives to make them seem significant.

The writing is beautiful yet unpretentious, and every character is vividly drawn. It allows for wonderful acting: there are no weak links in this cast but I particularly liked Rebecca Egan, bitter and broken as the girl Danger Doyle left behind in Poor Beast, and seductively gawky as Angela in Belfry; Gary Lyndon, who is the know-it-all Conway in Stars and the know-nothing Artie in Belfry; and Peter McDonald, who metamorphoses from the James Dean-like Jimmy in Stars to the anxious, inadequate Father Pat in Belfry.

Until February 4. Box office: 020-7328 1000.

fields.headline: Duran Duran's endurance test
fields.standfirst:
Duran Duran
Clyde Auditorium
Glasgow
Rating: **
fields.trailText: Duran Duran Clyde Auditorium Glasgow Rating: **
fields.body:
When we speak, in awe, or in horror, of 1980s pop and fashion, we really mean a very brief interlude fizzling out somewhere in mid-decade. Duran Duran remind us of that time more than any other band - they were seriously glam at their peak (models, yachts and big hair were de rigueur even for a quiet night in) but always straining for credibility and never quite finding it. Almost 20 years after that heyday - although with only two members of the original line-up and a marked absence of boats, beauties and bouffants - they are still with us.

The evening's first full-flung bit of nostalgia is the recollection, as Simon Le Bon shouts his way through New Moon on Monday, of the weakness of his singing voice. Packed into a tight-fitting sleeveless white top that screams 1982 but not in a nice way, he sings flatly, breathlessly, unable to hold the key notes.

None of this is helped by a clumsy-oaf stage persona. Trying to do a rock'n'roll leap from a very low-level amp, he trips and goes flying. In another rock-star gesture - mike-stand twirling - he knocks the whole thing over. In between he cavorts, dances badly, punches the air, stoops to pick up some red roses and a pair of black undies, thrown by an adoring crowd. Lots of women take photographs of him, presumably to put on their biscuit tins for those moments of temptation.

In the corner, twiddling with synthy knobs, is Nick Rhodes, still sporting David Sylvian's old haircut and lashings of scary Goth make-up. They make an odd couple, especially during Hallucinating Elvis, one of the more painful parts of the evening. With a backdrop of virtual-reality projections in which the King comes among us, Le Bon adds a silver shirt and Brains glasses to his ensemble, presumably wanting to look like an Elvis impersonator. He doesn't; he looks like Les Gray, erstwhile lead singer with Mud, while Rhodes has something of Andy Warhol about him in certain lights. It is like being stuck in a really giddy episode of Stars in their Eyes.

Except that this tour clearly has a much smaller budget. It's the cheapness of the proceedings that really pulls you up, marks the time that has passed between the days of that video for Rio and now. The screen on which they show arty videos and the cyber-Elvis is a big crinkled sheet; they have no backing singers, only perky female voices on tape. As a big finale they kick a few balloons into the audience in a forlorn, underwhelming gesture. They get kicked back.

All that saves the night from being convincing evidence on which to ban nostalgia (this thought does present itself as Le Bon high-kicks during their cover of White Lines) is that when they stick to their most simple pop creations - Girls on Film, Ordinary World, Save a Prayer and Rio - they can still endear. But when they get rocky and pretentious (Playing with Uranium) or the vocals get beyond Le Bon (Hungry Like a Wolf), it all becomes a very convincing case for living in the here and now, instead of looking back.

Duran Duran play the Apollo, Manchester (0161-242 2560) tonight, the NEC Birmingham (0121-780 4133) on Thursday, then tour.

fields.headline: Takeovers explained
fields.standfirst: As Lloyds TSB prepares to launch a hostile takeover bid for Abbey National, Jessica McCallin explains what the process entails
fields.trailText: As Lloyds TSB prepares to launch a hostile takeover bid for Abbey National, Jessica McCallin explains what the process entails.
fields.body:
What is a takeover?

A takeover involves the acquisition of one business or company by another. The acquiring company wants to get enough shares to take a controlling stake in the company it wants to takeover.

If the company which is being taken over is listed on the stock exchange, a strict protocol of rules and regulations exist to protect the interests of shareholders. A time limit is set for acceptance of the offer. If the company making the offer gets control of 90% or more of the shares, it has a legal right to acquire the remaining 10% of the shares at the offer price.

Some companies have two classes of shares, one class with voting rights and the other without. The susceptibility of a company to takeover depends on who controls the majority of shares in issue and which shares have the voting rights. Control of the company can rest with shareholders who don't have a majority of shares but do have a majority of votes.

Private companies can defend themselves relatively easy because their shares are closely held. Public companies are more vulnerable because the acquiring company can enter the stock market and buy up shares.

Where does the hostile bit come in?

A takeover bid may be friendly, where it is recommended by the board of the company being taken over, or it may be hostile, where it is rejected by the board and the company making the offer goes direct to shareholders.

Lloyd's TSB has been trying for a friendly takeover of Abbey National without much luck and may soon announce a hostile takeover. Any hostile offer is likely to include 1.5 Lloyds TSB shares and £3 in cash for each Abbey National share. This would value each Abbey National share at £13.05, higher than the £11.44 they closed at yesterday, and may act as a sweetener to undecided Abbey shareholders.

Some analysts say hostile takeovers are bad news because the new owners will have provoked the animosity of its new purchase.

Why do companies take each other over?

For a lot of reasons, but they all revolve around competition. A company will take over a rival so it can poach its customers and gain more market share. Or it could take over a rival with a view to closing it down, to make its target market less crowded and increase the chances of it winning new customers. Similarly, a company looking to expand into a new market sector might decide to take over a company already in this sector instead of growing a new business from scratch.

webTitle: Vengerov's one-man show at the Barbican

fields.headline: Vengerov's one-man show at the Barbican
fields.standfirst:
ECO/ Vengerov
Barbican Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
ECO/ Vengerov Barbican Hall London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Much of the best - and a little of the worst - of Maxim Vengerov was in evidence on this occasion. Despite the presence of the English Chamber Orchestra and the Israeli conductor Vag Papian, this was very much a one-man show, and although Vengerov exuded bags of charisma and his usual self-effacing charm, one couldn't quite help wondering if an ego had landed.

The concert certainly formed an effective showcase for his formidable talents. He played the Beethoven Violin Concerto with Papian conducting,and after the interval took the baton himself in a performance of Mozart's Jupiter Symphony. For all his enthusiasm and exuberance - he twirls around on the podium with balletic grace and tangible glee - that was perhaps an unwise move. He's a plausible conductor, though not a great one, and the symphony took an awfully long time to get going. Much of the time, he aspires to the kind of spaciousness one primarily associates with Klemperer's Mozart, though with little of the latter's emotional depth and resonance. The first movement was sluggish and the Andante dawdled. When we got to the Minuet, however, Vengerov suddenly struck form, shading it towards a waltz and infusing it with an infectious, unashamed Viennese lilt. The finale had a certain magisterial elan, without quite scaling the heights of elation that the greatest interpreters bring to the work.

He's better off as a violinist, in short, and his performance of the Beethoven was, in its way, stunning. Rarely, I suspect, has this most noble of concertos been played with such perfection of technique and such lacerating sweetness of tone, its long, rapt phrases seeming alternately to hover and swoop seraphically in the air. Interpretatively he plays safe, refusing, on occasion, to sacrifice beauty of sound for emotional danger. There's no self-conscious showing off, even though the cadenzas - his own - are filthily difficult. The first, a massive triple-stopped variant on the opening movement's second subject, veers closer to Brahms than Beethoven and breaks the mood a bit. The second is an exhilarating cascade of tone. Papian's conducts with violent, emphatic gestures, not always securing a comparable emotional response from the ECO, whose playing was muted on occasion.

When it was over, Vengerov returned to the platform clutching a Baroque violin rather than his Strad, and gave us the Adagio from Bach's G Minor Sonata as an encore, probing it rhapsodically rather than opting for a stiff formality of approach. The audience held its breath in wonder, then went wild.

fields.headline: Isserlis/Jarvi/LPO
fields.trailText: Royal Festival Hall London Rating: ****
fields.body:
As one of the most famous romantic warhorses, Dvorak's B Minor Cello Concerto seems to embody all the virtuosity and bravura of the 19th-century concerto form. Yet in Steven Isserlis's and Paavo Jarvi's performance with the London Philharmonic - part of the orchestra's Sleeping Beauties festival, curated by Isserlis himself - the trajectory of the whole piece was transformed from showy display to inner communion.

Even as early as the radiant, slower theme in the orchestral introduction - magnificently phrased by Nicholas Busch, the LPO's principal horn - it was clear that this interior, nostalgic realm was the true goal of this interpretation. This first movement was all about a conflict between public and private kinds of music: the formal histrionics of the allegro proper opposed to the intimacy of the ravishing, slower melody.

Isserlis's extraordinary warmth of tone and lustrous range of colour perfectly matched this glowing interpretation of the movement, culminating in the music's rapturous, major-key coda. But it was the second, slow, movement that signalled a decisive turn inwards, creating a private dialogue between Isserlis and the orchestra. Dvorak himself inverts the priorities of the romantic solo concerto in this slow movement. In the work's only cadenza, he uses the cello not as an instrument of lyrical intensity but as the embodiment of an archetypal, pastoral vision. The cello plays open fifths and simple intervals, and Isserlis turned this apparent simplicity into a heart-stopping, visionary moment.

It's a prophetic passage, too, for in the last movement there is a similar epiphany, as the music slows down just as one expects a final peroration. But in Isserlis's performance, this languid music was emphatically conclusive. He projected Dvorak's synthesis of themes from the first and last movements with serene conviction - the only logical ending to this revelatory, thoughtful performance.

Brahms's First Serenade was the relative rarity - or "sleeping beauty" - of the programme. Although Brahms does not attempt to integrate the grand statements of the opening and closing movements with the simpler charms of the inner dances, the Serenade is a fascinating, transitional work. Jarvi and the LPO relished the pre-echoes of later, mature Brahms - especially the Second Symphony and Second Piano Concerto - and were enthusiastic advocates of the subtleties of the Serenade's menuets and scherzos.

webTitle: One last try then it's war, Lloyds TSB to tell Abbey

fields.headline: One last try then it's war, Lloyds TSB to tell Abbey
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB is today expected to make a last ditch attempt to woo Abbey National into a friendly takeover before launching a public attack on its prey.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB is today expected to make a last ditch attempt to woo Abbey National into a friendly takeover before launching a public attack on its prey.

The new offer for Abbey, which would terminate any hope of a tie-up between Abbey and Bank of Scotland, is likely to value each Abbey share at around £13.05 in Lloyds TSB shares and cash.

The decision to make a fresh approach to Ian Harley, the Abbey National chief executive, is thought to have been made at a lengthy Lloyds TSB board meeting yesterday.

Along with investment banking advisers JP Morgan and Merrill Lynch, Peter Ellwood, the Lloyds TSB chief executive, is believed to have decided to make another attempt to cement a friendly deal with Abbey National. The City believes that if Mr Harley and his chairman, Lord Tugendhat, turn down the offer down again, after spurning Lloyds TSB last week, Lloyds TSB will heap more pressure on Abbey by making details of the deal known.

The offer Mr Ellwood is expected to present to his counterpart is said to include a combination of cash and shares. It is thought to comprise 1.5 Lloyds TSB shares and £3 in cash for each Abbey share, a premium to the £11.44 at which Abbey's shares closed yesterday.

Such a move by Lloyds would shatter any hopes harboured by Bank of Scotland and Abbey National of completing their tortuous merger talks.

Senior City sources said they expected the coming 48 hours to be key to ending the stand- off between Bank of Scotland, Abbey and Lloyds TSB. While BoS and Abbey's merger talks got off to a difficult start after being leaked to the market, negotiations are said to have warmed.

While both sides appear to believe they are now capable of reaching an agreement, BoS is thought to be reluctant to inform the City about the details of the talks while Lloyds TSB waits in the wings.

The risk for BoS is that it is left defending another failed merger attempt after its hostile attack on NatWest a year ago resulted in Royal Bank of Scotland claiming the prize.

Lloyds is expected to try to play down job cuts, keeping them in the region of 6,000 and pledging not to close any of Abbey's 750 branches for two years.

Lloyds TSB refused to comment.
